Source (H): In what appears to be her first novella, author Sophia Sharp lays out a fantastic new paranormal saga for the teen and young adult audience.Nora Colburn is the perfect high school junior, trudging through her junior year.  Enter Hunter Gerald, troubled new kid in school - and his mysterious paranormal powers.In believable detail, the world in "Forsaken" brings the story to life:  high school drama, supernatural powers, good versus evil, budding young love.  It's all there, and more!A very entertaining storyline. You'll find no teasers here!  I highly recommend reading it yourself - you WILL NOT be disappointed!

Okay so I started reading this and it sounded so familiar to me to the point where I knew that I read the books before and so that was when I decided to go into my kindle library and get Sophia's first novels I read of hers which were called the dream realm trilogy. The covers are basically the same on the books as well so I thought that maybe it was just her trademark thing or something but boy o boy was I wrong. Every page in that book was identical to the pages in this book and the only difference was the author changed the names from Laura to Nora and from Logan to Hunter and some she even kept the same. Her books are amazing so don't get me wrong but I think this is a really cheap thing to do. I already paid for all of these books and if I wouldn't have realized it I would have paid double which isn't fair. I guess one thing that makes it okay to her is the fact that her dream realm trilogy Is no longer in the kindle store because I couldn't find it anymore..at least I still have my copies though. People shouldn't do this to make extra money and play us for stupid basically. I don't know if that was her intentions but it really upset me when I noticed that this was what happened. Just because you changed the name of the book and the names of the characters doesn't mean it's a whole new book.With all of this being said... if you don't own the dream realm trilogy and you never read it then I would recommend the books cause they really were amazing but I thought people should know that it is a copy of her first novels and she only changed the names of the characters and the title of the book.  This is why I am giving it a one star because I already have the original copy I have it a five star when I read it and I don't agree with authors that plagiarize their own work to make more money of their readers, is not fair to us. If your not happy with the price of your books than change it but don't change the book title and names of its characters so u can pass it off for a new book and make more money!!! Sophia you were a great author so please make new book to read and don't copy your books again, it really upset me and I an sure it would upset about if it happened to them. If you ask want proof let me know bc I can loan you the title dream realm trilogy to see for yourself that both stories are identical besides names of characters and title of book and series. I hope this helps you ask our if you have her dream realm trilogy please don't get this series it will be a waste money because you would already have the series like I do. Have wonderful day everyone and remember if you haven't read dream realm trilogy then by all means get this series bc dream realm trilogy Is no longer available in kindle store.

Source (H): This book is a great read! Love the fantasy plot with some suspense/thriller thrown in to keep things even more interesting. Nora is a young lady most of us can relate to, but finds herself in circumstances most of us can only imagine! Highly recommend this story!

This is a great place to start with James Joyce, because it is readable and engaging. What at first seems like a slow start is actually a slow burn that bursts into flame at the end. If you've ever doubted whether your life is full, or your love is true, or worried about death or the claims the past makes upon the present, you'll be intrigued by Joyce's treatment of these themes.You will probably want to ignore the annotations on a first read, though. One is actually a partial spoiler for the ending, which I think is a terrible practice. If you are a tourist in Dublin, you will enjoy knowing just where everything takes place--and with these annotations, you will--but for anyone else, it is frustrating to follow a footnote only to find out on what corner of Dublin an aforementioned statue sits. Similarly, for antique furniture enthusiasts, it may be interesting to find out, in two separate footnotes, that peirglasses and cheval glasses are both different kinds of mirrors, but is it worth interrupting the narrative? Of the hundred or so footnotes, only a handful provide useful information for a non-specialist, and even these can be inferred from context. The only one that might be hard to guess is that "delicate," in a certain context, means stricken with consumption, which we call tuberculosis--so now that I've given you that one, you can ignore the rest until your second, more scholarly reading.
Source (K): Wonderful and accessible Joyce, pedantic annotations

Source (H): Fine conservative blog but way too many cryptic video links for reading enjoyably on Kindle.  Save your money

It is nice to see the flagship of the conservative magazines come to Kindle - I have been a subscriber to National Review since 1994 or 1995, and was excited enough to get my Kindle, and even more now that I can have it on there, which makes it even better. Thanks NR! :)

When I moved to Mexico, I knew that I would have trouble with magazine delivery.  And I did.  My magazines would arrive three or four weeks after publication.  What were once news articles were now history essays.But I was pleased yesterday when I stumbled onto my favorite magazine -- National Review -- on Kindle.  Now I have NR faster than I did with mail delivery in The States.  What could be better than falling asleep with Florence King?

Having The National Review available on the Kindle is wonderful. I love waking up every other Saturday morning to find a new issue on my device. The format for the magazine is great. When you open an issue, you view the cover and then move into the table of contents. On the left side of the page you view each section heading and on the right the articles for that section are listed. The organization makes navigation to your favorite section or skipping to an interesting article very easy. If you are interested in great conservative writing, do not hesitate to subscribe to this Kindle version of The National Review.

I had National Review in my "wish list" based on reviews and because I was looking for a solid conservative magazine.  But then I learned the editors are not as forthright as I expected them to be.Our nation can no longer afford the truth to be buried just because it is sometmes unpleasant to admit to it.  When a news and opinion magazine begins to condemn the truth, it is time to look elsewhere.  I will not spend even a few dollars on media that stifles truth, and I am afraid that National Review has engaged in such censorship.

I have been a subscriber to National Review for years and always enjoy each issue. They have one of the best and most ideologically diverse teams of conservative contributors around today, and each issue is always packed with thought provoking analysis and opinion. Ranging from politics to culture, each article is very well written. I hope 'the suits' invite their tech team to the next NR cruise, because this digital version of their magazine is great.I am new to using a Kindle Fire, and at first was disappointed with the way the magazine seemed to be formatted. It looked like it was just PDFs of the paper magazine, which makes for terrible viewing on the 7" Kindle. Then I noticed at the top of the Kindle interface a nifty little button to change from 'Page View' to 'Text View'. And just like that the magazine is converted to an easily read format. There is a table-of-contents that allows you to jump right to the article or section you want to read (I always flip right to Athwart by James Lileks). And articles that you have already read become grayed out.The periodical covers many issues that are affected by national and world events, so the digital version is great because you actually get the latest issue while it is still topical.

This magazine was mostly advertisements.  There were very few actual articles and the articles that there were didn't deal with practical "arts and/or crafts".  The magazine is poorly named.  If you're looking for high end, expensive accessories for a home you are redecorating then this magazine might suit your needs.  If you're looking for articles on practical, crafty ideas and methods for practical home decorating then this magazine is a waste of time and money.  Very disappointing.

This was a Christmas gift for my daughter and she LOVED it! It turned out pretty well! The only thing was that it took a while to get a picture the right size and make sure it was clear and fit the whole cover. That process was slightly difficult. But overall, would totally do it again!
Doesn't fit my Kindle Fire HD "7 despite it saying it does. Not a huge deal, but I have to remove it from the chase to decrease volume, power on, or charge.

The picture is awesome, and the design printed out especially great for having such dark colors.  The only problem I have is that it scratches really easily and after a week there are already little marks everywhere on one of the sides.
The printing was very good quality also. My only complaint is I have to leave the case open to charge the kindle because of the way it's made.

I write blog reviewws forThe Kindle Blog Reportand this one, The Happiness Project, is one of the best I've found. It is inspirational. That's the only word for it, inspirational. Too many people go through life just existing, not even knowing that they're unhappy. This blog will open your eyes to what your life should be like, and can be like.In today's world, with tenseness and nervousness about the economy abounding, everyone's under more stress than ever. Try putting a little happiness in your life - find out how to do it at The Happiness Project.
Source (K): I cannot recommend this blog highlyenough

Source (H): Each issue has numerous well written articles about the current issues in America and the world.

I am a registered Kindle user and an existing subscriber with The New Republic print and digital editions. I receive the magazine in print in the mail and can read The New Republic online, as well as on the New Republic iPad app as part of my subscription with no additional charge.  But I cannot read it on my Kindle without first buying ANOTHER subscription specifically for the Kindle from Amazon.  Definitely not worth it to me at all!  For those who do not have an existing subscription directly from The New Republic, then paying for the Kindle edition may make sense as it contains excellent journalism.
Source (K): Existing New Republic subscribers have to buy another subscription to read on Kindle.

Source (H): I have been a print subscriber for many years and reluctantly did not renew this year at $79.  Too rich for my blood (and low salary.)  Then I noticed it was available on the Kindle (which I use daily.)  I will ignore the ignorant reviews about the magazine's "alleged slant."  Most readers want to know how this periodical looks on the Kindle.  In a word...excellent.  TNR is very print-oriented (and the feature articles and reviews tend to be long) and this is formatted excellently on the Kindle.  This is a magazine that does not have to be read immediately and in the past I would have a stack of them (much like New Yorker.)  It is so efficient to have them on the space friendly Kindle.  Navigation is even easier than the print edition...very intuitive.  The Kindle edition arrives even sooner than the print edition.  For the devoted TNR reader looking at Kindle, this is a "no brainer."  All the content (except letters to the editor) are present in their entirety.  Enthusiastically and highly recommended!

Politics aside, I was pretty disappointed in the Kindle edition of TNR. There was very little content and what was present was essentially a few web articles converted into Kindle format. Not worth the subscription fee.

I was astounded to see that one of the most venerated American publications has received a measly three star average. Almost as soon as I saw this, I guessed that it must be due to readers who disagree with the viewpoints it presents. Sure enough, all negative reviews are by people who identify themselves as "right-wingers". Doubtless, we have Fox News and its imitators to thank for this new phenomenon. Or perhaps they're Internet trolls. (Really? NWO tin foil hatters? Really?) Whatever the case, to those reviewers: you judge writing upon its merits, not the opinions it expresses. This is already long for a Kindle review, so I will just add that The New Republic is one of the last bastions of real journalism left, and it is substantive reporting like this which is the only known antidote to sensational, mindless cable TV news. But by all means, if you're so intransigent that you shut out all views that don't mirror your own, don't waste your time.

I just got my Kindle last night and was delighted to find The New Republic available for the device at a significant discount. Whether you agree with the politics or not is up to you -- I generally do, but if you do not know already the magazine definitely leans left on the political spectrum but if you are considering purchasing this you should know that already. As for the actual layout (which really should form the review -- after all if you don't care for the politics what are the chances you have actually purchased a copy or tried a sample?), the Kindle really works well for The New Republic since it is largely image free in print. There are photos included in some articles though. The content itself is largely intact aside from one or two missing items, notably letters to the editor, and well laid out through the menu system, similar to how newspapers on the Kindle are laid out. All in all the subscription option for TNR on the Kindle is a strong one.
I don't believe that "The New Republic" is not available in Brazil (South America).The selection of magazines for kindle owners in Brazil is crappy!
Just knowing it is read on Air Force One is all you need to know.

I have subscribed to The New Republic on my Kindle since October 2012, but with the recent re-launch of the magazine I have decided to unsubscribe. The last two issues have been, for lack of a more elegant phrase, unreadable. Since the magazine re-launched under Mr. Chris Hughes, articles have been spliced together, text is jumbled, paragraphs run into each other, and everything from dollar signs to asterisks appear where letters should be, making reading more of a guessing game than an intellectual or relaxing experience. This has not just happened once, but with two consecutive issues of the magazine. And the mistakes are more than annoying: they will surely interrupt your reading flow, and make you regret the fact that you paid for such a lousy product.I typically do not write reviews online, though I thought I should warn potential customers in this case. I have really enjoyed The New Republic's writing and journalism for the past month - the book reviews were fantastic, the long-form, in-depth articles outstanding, and the commitment to "wonkish" topics suited my personal taste perfectly. Unfortunately, the magazine has made a distinct choice of putting out a sub-par product, one that will give you more headaches than joys.Even more disturbing was when I called The New Republic to complain. When I explained the mistakes and asked the operator how the magazine expects me to pay $2.25 for a virtually unreadable product, she said that the magazine "apologizes for the mistakes" and "acknowledges that there are still kinks to work out" with the re-launch. Make no mistake, this magazine is willing to sell you unreadable text for pure profit. Please, follow my lead and subscribe to The Nation, The New Yorker, and other magazines that genuinely care about their subscribers and how the formats appear on Kindle devices.Unless The New Republic cleans up the formatting issues, please avoid this magazine at all costs. It will save you a lot of trouble and money.

Although two reviewers find this to be a "liberal rag," I find that although I do not always agree with their articles, I appreciate the well researched and documented articles.  They are thought provoking and often opinion changing - if you are open to learning and change.  If you are a diehard right-winger and not open to the other side's opinions, then I agree, do not waste your time.  You will only be missing a balanced picture of the issues.
Why dont they just call it the NEW WORLD ORDER magazine.  I cant believe anything in this mag.  Makes me sick.

This magazine has writing on par with The Economist yet breaks down to about $1.12 per issue. Oh, and more importantly, I've had no delivery or formatting issues with this magazine on my Kindle.
Liberal rag. The left can do no wrong and the right are a bunch of money hoarding, back dealing, good ole boys.There I just gave you the whole thing. Save your 2.25 and your time.

Source (H): Being Irish I read the Irish Times quite regularly - but usually only a snatched couple of articles on the website every day. I was hoping that using it on the Kindle would give me more opportunities to catch up on the news, with less distractions. This it did, and every day of my free trial the current edition came down without a problem. I missed the images a little - but only for some stories where a photo helps with context.However I cancelled at the end of the trial as the $22 a month is a big expense, considering I didn't get time to read the paper every day. I'll go back to skimming the stories online for free, thank you. I'd be prepared to subscribe for closer to 5 a month but at the current price it just isn't worth it.Oh - one more thing, the recent Kindle software upgrade (3.1?) vastly improved the layout for newspapers and really helped with navigating the sections of this paper quickly, and skimming headlines.

1.  Amazon claims the newspaper is delivered at 5:00 local Dublin time (midnight previous for East Coast time), so you should be getting it at midnight as that day begins.  I purchase the "current copy" from time to time, but that day's issue is not ready until much later.  I wanted the paper today, New Year's Day, 2010.  It's 10 a.m here in PA, and yesterday's paper is still being sold.  10 hours late so far. Not good enough.2.  Amazon claims that the classifieds are in the issues, but they're not.  I've looked from one end of the paper to the other, it's just not there.  This is definitely serious.  If a claim is made, it should be honored.  I could really use the classifieds, as it happens, and this is also NOT GOOD ENOUGH.I love the paper, have no problem with the formatting, and accept that photos can't be there.  However, if a claim is made, it really should be honored.  Therefore my rating has to do with Amazon's service and honesty, not with the paper itself.

As a student in University, I was able to access the complete Irish Times website and read the paper online. I found it very useful and informative. I moved to the UK a few years ago and subscrbed myself online, reading most days. I did find it frustrating to only be able to read at my computer and was awaiting patiently for mass market mobile devices that allowed reading.Now the Kindle is available internationally, this has solved my problem of not being able to bring the paper on public transport going to and from work. The quality of the writing is great as expected, but I really miss the ability to do the crossword. It was one of the reasons I was willing to sign up when I lived in the UK. Now I live in Australia, I can receive the paper every day and read it when and where I want, which is ideal. Seeing that the Irish Times was available on the Kindle was on of the reasons I bought it.I think it would be great if your kindle subscription also entitled you to the full website subscription so I could do the crossword. Perhaps they could put a special website address for access at the end of the paper in the Kindle edition or just provide a username and password when the subscription is purchased. It is, after all the same news, just presented in a different way. It is for this reason I am giving 4 stars not 5.I have not docked marks for lack of pictures as this is made clear for international readers, but it can be frustrating when an article refers to pictures. It would be great if the Kindle generally could sync pictures for international users when connected to the computer, similar to iTunes.
Source (K): Great for Irish abroad, but not quite as good as real paper

Source (H): OK, I confess, I'm one of those Americans who has a secret wish to move to Ireland. Needless to say, an infant/young child wasn't an ideal traveling companion (neither is the younger sister who was born three years later) so I'm still waiting to viist.But in the meantime, I've subscribed to the Irish Times, and it's just so interesting to read about the daily activities there, get the perspective on the U.S. news, that sort of thing. I tired a couple of the big city American papers, and I just enjoy this one a lot more.

After enjoying reading the NY Times so much on my Kindle, I decided to add a second newspaper subscription. I tried sample issues of three other U.S. papers. They didn't add much to what I got reading my local papers (the old fashioned way) and the NY Times on the Kindle. My high school French and German aren't good enough to try those three papers, so I gave the Irish Times a try. It's an excellent value for the low price and a good European compliment to the U.S. papers I read. Lots of stories, many  you'll never see in a U.S. paper. Coverage of U.S. and world news is very good and the local Irish stories are interesting. I'm more than half way through the trial subscription and will be continuing it. One issue had a few small articles in Gaelic at the end that I couldn't read. I don't know how often they do that. I'm in Ohio. I turn my Kindle wireless on a  little before 6 a.m. every morning. New issues for both papers have been there, at that time, every day so far. Total download time for both is under a minute.

Like others who have reviewed the Irish Times, I got the paper because I wanted to see the world out of the US in non US terms. In English.I find myself fascinated by life in Ireland and the European stories that never make it into print here. Did you know that Switzerland thinks it's being overrun with German immigrants? Neither did I.The only thing I miss is having some pictures. They were talking about a house that sold for over a million euros, and without a picture, I couldn't put it into an American context, so I don't know if it was a lot or a little. (they thought it was a lot, but I live in California where even with this mortgage meltdown, a small house goes for easily half a mill.)I wish the presidential candidates would all read the stories about their health care. It seems really bad.So, if you want a foreign paper in Englis, I think you'll like this.

Although the cost of this "prequel" to Mongoliad is not expensive, I still felt short-changed.  It's really an unfinished short -- and I do mean short -- story, apparently intended as draft input to a future expansion of the story begun in Mongoliad (the Foreworld Saga).  About a 15 minute read, if you don't first drop it out of boredom.  Comic book literature without the graphic art.  If you enjoy that sort of reading, wait for the continuation of Mongoliad and spend the 15 minutes it takes to read "Sinner" on something more satisfying...anything else is likely to be.

Very easy to read, especially like the text view. I've read this magazine for years, it's great. And I can keep them all on my kindle and carry them all with me.

This one I have really enjoyed. It is an older story, written in the 1920's, so there are some archaic ideas on behavior. I thoroughly enjoyed this book. Ms King sure used many big words throughout the book which was refreshing as this is not the norm for other paranormal romance books that I've read to date (and I read quite alot of them). Her vivid imagination was captured in her book quite well. And because the book was set in Australia, I just loved it! As an Aussie, I am familiar with the geography of this book (for once) and now I really want to visit Cape Schanck (I only went out to Mornington Peninsula, not Cape Schanck).Anyway, getting back to the book, I really liked Bree and Sebastian. There were twists and turns throughout the book and I liked how her 'power' developed throughout the book. And Sebastian is so sweet. The book flowed smoothly and everything made sense. The book was also fast-paced which was great.I just started the 2nd book and I'm quite addicted to the series already. Well done Ms King.

Engaging and intriging are the first words that spring to mind when considering this book.  The story moves at a good pace and the reader is eager to reach the next chapter.  The characters are strong and by the end of the book you feel as though you really know them.  If time had allowed, once I got hooked by the story I could have read it in one sitting because you just had to know what the outcome was to be.  I will certainly purchase book two and look forward to where the story will lead me. Read this book, you will not be disappointed.

Changed my rating to a 4 star. I have lightly used the product and it's met my expectations so far. Very responsive, looks and feels great. The texture is a light rubbery feel and the joysticks are accurate in how competitive product's joysticks feel. I need to check the other settings of the controller, but the app controls worked very well. I've used the product on both my HTC One (M7) and Amazon Fire TV with great success!As per those commenting on my 'inappropriate' use of the rating system for shipping concerns. Would it not effect your user experience if you were told it would arrive in 2-days with your Amazon Fire TV as an Amazon Prime member? I pay money yearly to get the products within the window I select. Nyko, and all indirect sellers, opt to place the shipping methods on their product as well. A review is supposed to be helpful to those wanting to buy the product. I tried to warn those that they may be waiting far longer then what they put in their shipping options. I don't like getting told 2 days then having to wait more than 2 weeks later than when the product I purchased this for arrived. Do you?---Original---TL;DR I'm still waiting on my Amazon Prime 2-day shipped pair of PlayPad Pros. that I ordered on April 12th (we're at 12 days out at the time of this review). I've had no warning from the manufacturer, Amazon, or the product page (as seen on Amazon's game pad page at launch: delayed 2 weeks etc.).I was skeptical about the product as it is off brand but I hadn't heard great things about Amazon's branded game pad for the Fire TV. I'll return here to put a proper review of this product as soon as it actually arrives.

Source (H): I just took the free trial of all three Atheist blogs that Amazon offers for the Kindle, and this is the only one I'm subscribing to. It has 3 to 6 articles every day with news and things of interest to Atheists. The blogger Hemant Mehta comments on each article, often using humor and cynicism about religion. Each article has several links in the text so you can get more information. There are links to Facebook, Twitter and more at the end of each article so you can share with friends. Some of the articles tell of public events relating to Atheism happening all over the U.S. that you can attend.This blog is made for the Internet, so some things don't translate well to the Kindle- words in pictures and cartoons are blurry even when magnified, and of course you can't watch videos. Source (H): I'm not going to bother discussing the content. Anyone looking at these reviews probably knows what The Economist is and believes the content to be great. The issue, here, is the Kindle offering, most notably, the price.Yes, it's expensive, and yes, I wish they'd reduce it a bit. But I'm not as outraged as some other reviewers.In comparing Kindle vs. web and paper, it is reasonable to consider, among all the factors discussed by others, the nature of Kindle itself. I notice that with the Kindle subscription, I find myself comfortably reading pretty much the whole issue. With print, I read just a small fraction.One factor, undoubtedly, is font adjustment. I'm getting to the age where reading hard-copy newspapers and magazines is becoming a bit of an exertion, so this is a huge factor. Of course web browsers allow for font adjustment, but I spend enough time working in front of a computer. I do cherish opportunities to do some things in different settings, such as an easy chair, or out on the lawn.I also wonder if the more stripped-down emphasis on text is a factor as well. There's not as much to look at with the Kindle edition (they do try to put in some pictures and charts, but visuals are not what Kindle does best). With the magazine, there's so much to look at, I spend too much time going back and forth. Ditto the web site, where there are so many things to click on. With Kindle, there are lots of little easily-digestible text nuggets and I just go from one to the next.I'm not sure if my explanations of why I read more on the Kindle version is accurate (I'll leave the details for amazon's usability experts to study), but I do notice the same phenomenon with my Kindle version of The New Yorker, where I abandoned the print version altogether.Speaking for myself, I'm getting a lot more bang for the buck with the Kindle subscription. Hence my willingness to tolerate the pricing.

Finally!  At last!  It is great to be able to read one of the best magazines on my Kindle.  Being able to quickly browse the E by sections, look up words in the dictionary, etc., make it at least worth the same price as the paper.  The quality of the illustrations is great.  This was not expected.  My understanding is that Amazon eats a good portion of the fees. If you do not see the value in the Kindle version, stick with your paper.  For me, the Kindle version is so much more versatile due to all of the device related benefits.  I will not have a problem swapping versions for no change in total cost.  If you think the Kindle format should somehow be a discounted version, think again.  If this is too expensive for the exact same content with more Kindle-related features, how is the paper version not too expensive?  The Economist probably makes much less on this format less their ad revenue, but I am glad they have chosen to give us the option.  The only thing I may miss is losing full access to The Economist website and audio versions.

(Her subscription is my highly valued gift to her.)

Source (H): Amazon,As a loyal customer, I'm BEGGING you to wake up and smell the coffee. Americans like me are simply NOT going to pay the same price for a product that WE KNOW has less overhead costs.For the digital edition, the Publisher doesn't have to pay for paper, ink, salaries for printshop employees, or shipping costs....AND WE KNOW THAT. So why do you think we're going to be willing to pay $10.49 a month when we can subscribe to a real, hold-it-in-your-hands, throw-it-in-your-backpack, recyclable paper edition for $2.49 a week? Look at the math: 12 months x $10.49 = $125.88/year for Kindle edition. 51 issues delivered by mail at $2.49 = $126.99/year. You really expect us to believe that the Publisher can only pass along $1.11 of his ENORMOUS overhead savings to us? PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE get Publishers on board with this thing.....Kindle COULD revolutionize the publishing industry in a TRULY environmentally-friendly way.....but you're well on your way to pricing yourself into the same fringe market that solar power did back in the 80's when we really should have embraced it.Respectfully,Phil

The Economist was once a great source of ideas and information, but now reads more like a  press release from the Obama fan club. Even its economic commentary is now of dubious value & can be  recognized as re-tread rhetoric rather than the product of objective reasoning. No longer worth it.

I can't truly express the excitement I felt upon learning that The Economist was finally available in Kindle format, but I would say it was equally negated by the feeling I had when I learned that Amazon was trying to charge the same amount as the print edition.  I don't even get to kill a few trees with this version!  Thankfully The Economist website still displays the print edition for free.

I read this magazine on Kindle 2.0 and it has all the pictures and graphs with NO advertisements. Plus, I get this magazine faster than any other medium when I download it into my Kindle.  You can save many trees reading the Kindle version. But you will also save money by reading the printed version (Hint: make it cheaper Amazon!)The Economist is arguably the most prestigious mass publication on economics, political, social, and global matters. The articles can be intensely enriching, educational, and thoughtful. If you are looking for a light read on everyday pop culture and celebrities, stay away from this world class magazine that is written by and caters to the intellectuals. This is the magazine many high schools recommend to their students who want to improve their reading to a college level.  Its articles may confound those whose most challenging read has been the Mad Magazine and the National Enquirer.The Economist differs from most periodicals in the subject matter expertise and the quality of analysis. Apparently, the Economist attracts and hires only those who are already intimately familiar with the subject matter. Many writers have a Master's degrees or higher on the subject they are writing about. My guess is that the Economist magazine, which is over 150 years old, is not short on funds and can afford to pay the best and the brightest, even those who have had no previous interest in journalism, to come and write for the magazine.The political leaning of this magazine is best described as libertarian. The magazine definitely leans to the right and advocates government fiscal conservatism and anti-regulation. It is notable, however, that the Economist was very strongly anti-Bush (George W). The Economist called the George W Bush's administration incompetent, arrogant, misinformed, fiscally irresponsible, and full of cronyism.I give the Economist great deal of credit for making audacious, yet justified, criticisms of many dictatorships and other oppressive forces. The Economist has been banned in China for its undaunted criticism of China's human rights abuses. If you want to pay and read a magazine that writes about things which few magazines are willing to tackle because of fear of negative consequences to their bottom line, then the Economist fits your bill.This periodical is higher in cost. The Economist website offers the printed version for $59/year. The Kindle version is double that. MAKE IT CHEAPER AMAZON. Haven't you heard of the new BN Plastic Logic "Kindle Killer"?

As a longtime subscriber of The Economist, I was quite enthusiastic at the opportunity to subscribe via Kindle: on time delivery, no more bypassing the magazine at airports and shops because I knew mine would be waiting at home, no more wrinkled torn copies from the Post Office, the ease and convenience of Kindle downloads. So, I tried the 14 day trial in spite of the reviews here.After trying the Kindle version and experiencing its shortcomings, I think it's unconscionable and arrogant to ask the same price for the Kindle subscription, sans some of the satire / cartoons, etc. and particularly without the ability to use The Economist's website as allowed by the paper subscription. (Further, to add insult to injury, when I inquired if I could switch my subscription, as I still have months left on my paper sub, The Economist customer service replied there was no way to accomplish this.)Kindle is brilliant, but Amazon needs to watch the offerings' quality, feature set and pricing, or they will in the end lose traction to other, alternative readers. The digital age is certainly here, but we will see rapid innovation and change, lots of competition and hopefully price competition as well. Source (H): I like The Economist as much as any of the other weekly news analysis/business magazine out there.  Of course that may be because I am more familiar with it - I had a subscription for several years up until early 2009.  At that time I was getting my news from several Internet sites as well as from 2 Kindle newspapers and couldn't see paying the price they were asking for "old" news.  When the Economist first came out on the Kindle I decided not to subscribe.  Now that I am using the Kindle DX, which is much more periodical friendly than the original Kindle, I have decided to start reading it again.So why do you read "old" news?  So it isn't up-to-the-second-as-it-happens, but most of what is in the magazine is still relevant.  There are always a few in-depth articles that help my understanding of the situation or bring up new ideas.For the most part the value of this type of magazine is the analysis and view point.  I happened to really like the type of analysis the give in this magazine and appreciate the different point of view.  I sometimes disagree with the conclusions the writers come to, but they always make me think.  Too often the conclusions of news analysis is based more on politics and emotion instead of the facts, but not here.The Kindle version of the Economist follows the print version very closely.  Many of the pictures are missing, but the important charts and graphics (and cartoon) are all present.  Blowing some charts and graphs up on my Kindle DX I have found the resolution to be excellent.  I could see a little frustration with the original Kindle, but the implementation/layout for Kindle 2/DX is great.Besides a few missing pictures the Kindle version is also missing all of the ads.  Although they were sometimes fun to read, particularly the job offerings, I don't miss them.  This does, however, bring up what seems to be the most import point to many here - price.Most periodicals rely very heavily on advertisement revenue to stay in business.  I don't know the exact numbers, but my guess is advertising more than pays the price for printing and postage.  In that case, e-versions of a magazine with no advertising sold at the same price as a paper subscription might even lose money, particularly if you remember that Amazon has to slice some off of the top to pay for your "free" 3G service.So, you get the same content but searchable, without the ads, guaranteed to be delivered where ever you happen to be at the time (never lost in the post, reaches you when on travel) at about the same price as the environmentally-unfriendly paper version.  Is it worth it?I think so.-Oh yes, I forgot online content.  Strangely enough I was never disconnected when I unsubscribed so I can still get in.  I also get daily e-mails.  I can count the times I've used the online content on the fingers of my right hand.  If you need it paying extra can be a drag and lowers the value of your Kindle subscription.  It might be worth calling or e-mailing The Economist about.  My guess - since you can discontinue at any time buying from your Kindle is, from their viewpoint, more like picking it up at the newsstand every week.- I can understand getting the paper version if more than one family member reads it - The New Yorker costs the same printer or kindle (don't see as many complaints) and I moved to print version when I discovered my wife was reading it on her Kindle.- One Last Word - It costs about as much as a large cup of coffee per issue but lasts longer....
Source (K): Is it too Much to Pay for Great Content?

Source (H): I am a subscriber to The Economist, so I have both paper and web access to the magazine. The Economist has FREE downloadable apps for multiple devices, so that subscribers can read the magazine on their phones or devices, but there is no app for the Kindle Fire.This appears to be Amazon's way of inserting itself into the cash flow river for magazine content. I am all in favor of profit, but this approach won't succeed. With few exceptions, serious readers of The Economist are going to get the full magazine content directly from the magazine publisher. They are not going to pay twice as much again for a watered-down version of this magazine just so they can read it on their Kindle or other tablet device. The same is likely true for most magazine and newspaper content.People who buy tablets like the Kindle Fire want a device that is going to make content access easier, not more difficut. They not going to allow themselves to get imprisoned in the manufacturer's corral. That is the "America Online" approach to access, which we know ends in economic stagnation and dwindling market share.I am sure that the secondary app market will address this problem soon enough and that I will be able to buy an app for $1.99 that will allow me to read The Economist on my Kindle Fire. It would be nice if Amazon recognized that it is on the wrong track and released its own app.

Overall, I am very pleased with the Kindle version of The Economist.  This was required reading material for me in college, and years later, I am still hooked -- without having to do assignments and recite in class, thank goodness.  The caliber of this magazine never fails to impress me.Content-wise, The Economist covers a wide variety of current events.  The magazine, published weekly, always starts off with a recap of what has happened in the world over the last week.  Contrary to its name, it sums up all of the major headlines from international politics and relations to natural disasters to legal news.  Of course, it also includes business and economic happenings as well.From there, The Economist delves into its cover story and several other introductory articles which are usually unrelated to each other.  Following this, there is a briefing on a particular subject, letters to the editor commenting on past stories, and a section focusing on digital highlights that can be found on the website.The Economist primarily breaks down its content by region.  There are sections dedicated to the week's events in the United States, the Americas, Asia, China, Middle East and Africa, Europe, Britain, and International.  There are also other sections that are not broken down geographically: Business, Finance and Economics, Science and Technology, Books and Arts, and Economics and Financial Indicators.  There is also a lengthy obituary for one person in each issue.  Occasionally, there will be a special report included pertaining to a topic that is particularly relevant at that present time.  There are also periodic publications within the magazine, such as the Technology Quarterly, that cover certain topics in further depth.  Some job postings are also included.There is a mixture of objective articles, subjective analyses, and opinion pieces in each section.  Given this variety of writing, I wouldn't suggest The Economist for anyone who is looking for newspaper-style reporting.  The authors are far less guarded in trying to mask their personal views.  Personally, I greatly appreciate this type of reporting; however, I can't honestly represent it as everyone's cup of tea.Another reason why I love The Economist is the variety of the content that it provides.  They publish a good number of interesting stories that most people probably would have never seen or heard elsewhere.  So you can read these and bring up them up at a dinner party so you can look extra smart in front of your friends. ;)Onto the Kindle format since this is what has so many people up in arms... the Kindle version does omit a lot of the ads and some of the cartoons that you would normally find in the print version.  Personally, I am pleased with the fewer ads, but I understand that some people do enjoy them since they are generally different that what you would find in other publications.  I do miss some of the cartoons, though.Because of the size of the Kindle screen, it is difficult to read from the page view without using the zoom function.  However, zooming in is easy enough to do, so I really don't mind this.  Also, you can switch from the page view to text view where the article appears like an actual book would on your device.For the Kindle Fire, you can bring up a scroll function at the bottom of your screen by tapping it.  From here, you can scroll from side to side to find a particular page (it shows a small picture of each page as well as a page number).  Tap on that icon to go directly to the page you want, tap again to make the scrolling table of contents disappear.  The only problem with this is that since the scrolling pictures are so small, it's hard to tell which page is which and which page you actually want to pull up.What I have found a little frustrating is that sometimes my Kindle won't bookmark or sync my current page.  When I try to resume reading, it pulls up the cover, and I have to go searching for my previous location.  Now I always make a mental note of my current page number when I stop reading.I do agree with others -- I am a little miffed that we don't get access to The Economist's online content through this subscription.  I'm sure that there is some fine print in the relationship between Amazon and the magazine itself, but I would really like to see them iron out this wrinkle.  For $9.99 a month, that content should be included.  The price for the other digital subscription available through their website (one year) is less than $70, and it includes online-only content.  The Kindle version costs almost as much as the print subscription (which also includes online-only content) yet still lacks this feature.  It is rather frustrating.

I love this magazine, but shame on the Economist for trying to rob subscribers. Distribution costs are GONE and they still try to nail us. If they weren't trying to sell this magazine to...well...economists, they could probably get away with it. Give us a break on the price and stop trying to insult us. I've canceled my hard copy subscription, since I know they are crooks now.

I read all of the reviews before I decided to try it out. I was a subscriber to the print edition for several years, and I found myself taking the time to read it less and less. I think the Kindle version is very well laid out and easy to read, and I have my Kindle with me almost everywhere and can sneak in an article when I have a bit of down time. I will read more of each issue on the Kindle.I find the website to be distracting, and do not miss not having access to it. I bought this subscription for the articles. Do I wish the price was less, sure. However, I think that the price is not bad considering that you get all of the content and none of the ads or distractions.We all have to decide how we spend our money, if this isn't how you want to do it then don't. Source (H): I subscribed to the printed paper version of The Economist for a while and found that it's not what the hype would have you believe.  It's allegedly authoritative insights and opinions are virtually the same pabulum you get from most other media sources these days. The only real difference is that the writing style is more pompous. Yes, the much vaunted Economist is not only a liberal rag, but an overpriced one to boot. So, the ridiculous price of the Kindle version is no big surprise to me. I'll refrain from buying any Kindle newspaper or magazine until Amazon offers a reasonably priced, quality publication for conservatives. The Limbaugh Letter would be an excellent place to start.

The authors of the many many reviews which say this product is overpriced are forgetting a few key things.  First, there's no advertising in the Kindle edition.  That alone is a big hit for the Economist in profit, so it makes sense that either other features would be left out or the price raised.  Second, the free wireless delivery.  Amazon does not get free use of the 3g network.  They have to front that cost somewhere in order to give us the free 3g, and it's not in the cost of the device, especially with the newest generation 3g model only costing $189.  The ability to receive the magazine wherever you are, instantly, and then carry at least the last 7 issues with you at almost no extra cost of space or weight is great!  The last point I would make is that Amazon has not become as big as it has by operating at a loss.  Obviously the current price is profitable based on cost of production vs demand.So basically it's just up to you!  There are perks to either side, and I think both are reasonably priced for what they provide.  It just depends on what aspects are most important to you!In case you were wondering, I went with the Kindle subscription.

Source (H): There is lots of high dollar advertising in the Economist.  It seeems folks have gotten spoiled by advertising subsidizing print publications (just like they got spoiled by commericals bringing them "free" tv and low cost newspapers.) If you currently subscribe to The Economist, which costs approx. $119 per year for print and digital content, the Amazon Kindle is the ONLY device that will not allow you to view the content without purchasing an additional subscription directly through Amazon.  To be clear, The Economist subscribers are able to access the magazine, and audio, on any other Android device including smart phones and tablets, and both the iPhone and iPad allow this as well.  Upon calling Amazon customer service about this, they explained that if you want the magazine on the Kindle you have to purchase a 2nd subscription - there are no plans to bring the currently available Android The Economist App into the Amazon app store.  Additionally, even if you have not subscribed yet, by purchasing through the Amazon store (on this site) you pay the same price but do not receive any of the audio or additional content.  At that price tag, I would say that is the most ridiculous scam I have heard of, and would have never thought Amazon would go to those lows.  Let's hope they don't take a similar stance on other publications, which would break down the whole point of the tablet / electronic media movement which is mobility, sharing across devices, and a reduction of print materials.

There is a lot of confusion about the subscription benefits between the Kindle vs Digital vs Print offerings that need some serious clarification. The Economist is a fantastic publication so I'm writing this to make sure people aren't giving the magazine undeserved flak, and that people here understand what's going on behind the scenes...Here is the issue: The Economist, like most other major publications, provides lots of value-added features to subscribers but make limited access to their website free for SEO and ad revenue generating purposes. These subscriber features include: full audio podcasts, full access to apps and commentary, and of course full digital access to the printed content. The digital subscriptions and authentication to access this content happens directly on the Economist's servers, so features served from the Economist's servers are easily matched and delivered to subscribers. AMAZON'S KINDLE DELIVERY INFRASTRUCTURE has a separate user database, separate servers, and a separate transfer protocol that is 100% independent of the Economist.This wouldn't be a problem, except that AMAZON DOES NOT ALLOW PUBLICATIONS TO AUTHENTICATE AGAINST AMAZON USERS SUBSCRIBING TO THE PUBLICATIONS' OWN PRODUCT! This is technically easy to do by implementing an API for publishers. But without it The Economist has no way of knowing who is subscribing through Amazon, so they cannot offer the digital features to kindle subscribers.This is how it SHOULD work (listen up Amazon):1) You pay for the Kindle subscription2) You then sign up with a free account at Economist.com that doesn't have any subscription rights to it (yet)3) You add your amazon info to your Economist user account4) The Economist's server pings the Amazon server, and the Amazon server says "Yup, this guy is definitely a paying subscriber, and he is paid up through XX/XX/XXXX"5)You get the Kindle subscription every week, plus the ability to log in to the Economist.com with a newly subscriber-enhanced user account.This doesn't work because Amazon does not allow step 4 in the above example. The Economist would LOVE to give Kindle subscribers digital access, but there's no practical way to do this because Amazon refuses to implement APIs to make Step 4 possible. The lack of digital subscriber features here is 100% AMAZON'S FAULT!Why the same price? When you sign up as a digital subscriber directly at Economist.com, they get 100% of the $120, but from a Kindle subscription they only receive $84 out of $120 retail price on Amazon (bummer). If they charged less, they'd get only $70 or $60... and last I checked the newspaper industry isn't profitable enough to take deeper and deeper cuts into it's retail price. However, they are economists over there (just a hunch) and as a result I think they chose the CORRECT pricing strategy of $120 for the Kindle edition. Here's why: The Economist takes a 30% haircut and delivers a sub-par product via Amazon (because it doesn't include extra features), so they're subtly encouraging a reasonable person to just subscribe directly with Economist.com to receive the superior product. They make a subscription on kindle available simply to appease those few subscribers who must have a whispersynced copy formatted like the print edition on their Kindle and wouldn't subscribe under any other arrangement. In effect, kindlers are paying the "Amazon's Infrastructure Sucks For Publishers" tax by paying the same but getting less.Unfortunately, most people's negative reviews blame the publisher for not getting the extra digital features, and interested parties are looking at these comments and writing off The Economist completely, instead of taking exception specifically to the service Amazon pigeon-holes publishers into. Of course The Economist can't really say this on Amazon, but I have no problem laying it down for them. So for my fellow Amazoners, don't just choose between subscribing or passing on the Economist, consider the kindle or (direct) digital option as well, and vote this comment up so others can see it.
Source (K): Subscriptions: Kindle vs Digital vs Print

Source (H): I have been a regular reader of the Economist for at least forty years, and normally I read it more or less cover to cover.  Contrary to some reviewers I do not think the Kindle edition is expensive.  For me, now living in Ireland, its weekly price is less than the daily cost of a good Irish newspaper.  Over the past four decades its editorial standards have varied--there have been times when I felt that its extremely bright editors were sometimes being just too clever for their own good.  But in recent years it has been very good indeed. Its global and business news coverage is unsurpassed and presented in an accessible and very readable way.But to be useful one needs to read it regularly soon after publication.  When I was working, I travelled a lot, often for weeks at a time, and I alternated between a regular print subscription, supplemented by single copy purchases when I was away, or simply purchased it at local newstands wherever I was.  When I retired and moved to Ireland the problem has been that there is no postal delivery on a Saturday. Sometimes Monday is a public holiday, so one gets it on Tuesday, and occasionally there are glitches and it arrives only on Wednesday.  Since it goes to the printer at c.o.b. on Thursday, this makes it six days late.When I was in the US this summer I experimented with the Kindle edition and liked it.  So when I returned to Ireland, I cancelled my print subscription and took out a Kindle one, downloadable to my computer each Friday.  In some respects it is an improvement on the print edition--its table of contents is a marvel of organisation, go instantly to articles of particular interest, and Kindle also knows exactly where you stopped reading.  Its main drawback, and the reason I give it only three stars, is that the Economist is wonderful for its presentation of data , and that very many of its articles include statistical tables and charts.  In print and on the website these are in colour.  These are obviously available on the Kindle only in black and white--which is a drawback--but much worse is the fact that they are too small to be readable--at least by me by me but I would guess also by most people.  There are too many to make it convenient to resort to the website or a magnifying glass.  Increasing print size does not change the size of a chart or table.  Since the print edition has been so well adapted to Kindle in other respects, perhaps a way to adjust table size could be found.  Then I would give it five stars.

It's quite true that the cost of electronic transmission is lower than the cost of print delivery.  Certainly the marginal cost per electronic subscriber is infinitesimal or zero.But the editorial (content-creation) cost is the same for print and electronic editions.  And that cost is generally covered by advertising, which the Kindle doesn't have (thank God).So we should be willing to pay -- and perhaps pay well -- for electronic, advertising-free editions of distinctive publications (like the New York Times, or The Economist) to keep them going.  The loss of these publications would be a great loss for the world; blogs just won't fill the gap left by the demise of professional publications.I am a rabid Kindle enthusiast and evangelist.  But the problem here -- as noted by Joe K. -- is the disproportionate share of the subscription price going to Amazon (70% Amazon/30% publisher).  If Amazon persists in grabbing a disproportionate share of subscription revenue, readers and high-quality content creators will find other ways to connect and support each other.  Once competitors to Kindle get into circulation, the middleman's cut should be pushed down.A subscription price in the 3 to 4 dollar range would be more palatable.
Source (K): Real publishing operations need real money

Source (H): Considering the content of the Economist, I assumed some degree of above average intelligence from its readership, however, upon reading so many scathing reviews I am sorely disappointed.  While it is true that the Kindle edition of the Economist is priced similar, perhaps even slightly higher than the comparable print edition, you must realize that the price paid for a print subscription is heavily subsidized via advertising.  True the cost of delivery and materials are significantly less, however, you must keep in mind the Economist is not receiving any money from advertisers.  Furthermore, it is unclear how much of the cost is going to Amazon.  Taking all this into consideration, I doubt the Economist is making any greater margin on the Kindle edition than on their print edition.  In fact, I would guess they are probably making less.  The only legitimate argument I have heard, and the reason for 4 stars rather than 5 is that the Kindle subscription should most certainly come with the same web access afforded to print subscribers.  That being said, I am sure there is some technical hurdles preventing easy verification of a legitimate Kindle subscription.  Kindle subscribers are not identified by the Economist's existing subscriber ID's, but by what I am sure is an Amazon specific identification system.  It is therefore difficult to legitimize and keep track of Kindle subscribers without a close integration between the Economist's and Amazon's internal (and most likely proprietary) subscriber identification systems.
It's a shame that the Economist, and probably to a lesser degree Amazon, are trying to gouge their customers after they've spent so much time and energy building goodwill.

The quality of the product needs no discussion.  It is one of the few magazines you must read to be informed.  I'm delighted to see it (finally) available on the Kindle.The Kindle edition is of good quality; certainly no worse than any other similar Kindle magazine.  I'm very happy to see that this edition preserves some of the charts and illustrations of the print version.  However, I hoped that it would have preserved more of a magazine-like layout, particularly on the DX.  These Kindle magazines are certainly readable, but can be a bit monotonous.Regarding the price, I really don't understand all the outrage.First, this is The Economist: it has always been more expensive.  The Economist is a high-quality, thriving news magazine in a time when many of its peers have folded or have adopted dumbed-down content to attract a larger audience.  Its pricing policy is certainly one reason the magazine continues to do well.Second, though the Kindle edition reduces publishing costs for the magazine, it also does away with advertisements.  This is not a book; it is a periodical.  Magazines (and newspapers) generate the bulk of their revenue through advertisements.  Even net of physical distribution costs, subscription prices don't cover production costs.  I'm perfectly happy to pay a regular subscription rate to avoid being sold the latest brand of toothpaste with every turn of the page.I can't fathom how someone spends $400 or $500 on a Kindle, only to complain that $.30 per day is too expensive for The Economist.  I suspect that many of the complainers either 1) don't actually own a Kindle or 2) wouldn't read The Economist in any form.  Or both.

What working out with weights will do for your body, The Economist will do for your weekly knowledge of the world in which we live. And like your weight-driven work-outs, you will reap immediate and long-term benefits, including a greater understanding of world events and how they shape the world today.This is a tremendous publication and I am extremely thankful that it exists. The amount of information it conveys about our world each week is unparalleled.I began reading this magazine in paper format about five years ago.
