(I understand that you do not gain access to the web-based articles with the Kindle subscription, but I find the convenience of the Kindle format well worth the additional cost and lack of web access. I also find it ludicrous that people give one-star ratings based upon the lack of web access alone, rather than speaking for the content of the publication itself. So it goes.)The writing is smart and never condescending. It is also not too "pop", like a lot of news magazines can be. I honestly don't care what Lady Gaga is doing (and with whom), and thankfully neither does The Economist.The Economist often has a view (which they will openly state) in the articles it presents, but I see this more as a "common sense" worldly perspective, not a heavily-biased slant which many periodicals have - without admitting as much. The Economist should not "rankle" those from the Left or Right politically, it often takes the sides of either, depending on the issue in question. I consider myself an Independent politically, and find this view refreshing.The benefits of this magazine are two-fold - at least.  Firstly, the amount of knowledge that you will gain about the world in which we live is phenomenal. The coverage is extensive, including articles about the upcoming French election, as well as Boeing's attempt to keep up with demands of numerous airlines.  Secondly, I just feel better about myself when reading The Economist. There's no better way to describe it, but I simply enjoy the feeling that reading this magazine gives me. Every issue I read, I keep thinking... "Oh yeah! I should discuss this with my wife/friend/co-worker..." or "Oh man...  I really should start a blog and present some additional thoughts I have on this issue, and see what feedback I get!"  It just gets you thinking...  a lot.The Economist also gives you a fresh perspective of the world and our place in it. I think this is important now more than ever, as we are bombarded daily with many black/white, yes/no, for/against issues, regarding everything from Apple vs. Windows, Democrats vs Republicans, etc.  The Economist presents insightful nuances of the issues it presents, giving the reader pause for thought rather than leading to knee-jerk, sound-bite conclusions.There is also a Business section each week, containing articles which are easily on par with those in Business Week or any other business-focused periodical.You can obviously garner a lot of world news information online for free from various web sites. But if you want a single source of intelligent and comprehensive information about the world we live in, you need look no further. The articles are very well-presented, containing not only the information, but a thoughtful interpretation about the events within the article as well.Be prepared to learn a lot. I truly wish this were recommended reading for everyone. I feel that I have benefited immensely from reading The Economist. And so will you.
Source (K): Consider it your Weekly World Work-Out - with immediate gains!

Source (H): Most of the negative reviews have complained about price; mine is similar. I get the dead-tree edition for about $70 a year, at the student price. So not only would the Kindle edition not be cheaper, it would actually be significantly more expensive than the dead-tree version! Guess what my decision is.

I've read positive and poor reviews of The Economist, with the positive seemingly outweighing the poor. I decided to give it a shot, and I regret it. I was expecting The Economist to give me an unbiased, unique perspective of current and past global issues and their economic intricacies, but instead what I got was a very pro-liberal magazine. I'm an American conservative and I don't mind a good debate. I want to read a newspaper, magazine or watch a news broadcast that pays attention to both sides of the isle; I think it's healthy. Oftentimes my opinion varies on certain issues in the political continuum. But The Economist doesn't even offer other views a chance. With regard to European politics, it bashes viewpoints other than liberal. It blames Angela Merkel for the result of the Eurozone crises and for not instantly, freely opening up the vault of Germany to other European nations, without consequence, for bailout upon the first hint of trouble. It bashes David Cameron's policies as failed, laughable, and abhorrent for Britian. As for American politics, it refers to the conservative base as a 'dwindling constituency of old white men.'Give me a break. This is kind of stuff is the same jumbled malarkey which MSNBC released every day and calls it news. I don't mind a good, healthy debate from both sides, but with The Economist's reputation, I was expecting more. To be fair, the only slightly positive remark I have towards The Economist is that it offers international financial news and information regarding smaller and (less consequential) contries, which can sometimes be worthwhile. But that is not a saving grace. I won't be resubscribing. Truth be told, I sometimes toss it aside in disgust.I want readers to know what they're getting. This forum is for reviews. In short, The Economist is a liberal magazine, and unless you regularly attend Democratic rallies or are particularly, keenly interested in the economic indicators of the housing industry in southeastern Nigeria, the majority of the script in this magazine will be uninteresting, recycled rhetoric.
Source (K): Not exactly what I was expecting

Source (H): I assumed at over $10 a month that more care would have gone into developing the kindle edition.  Many of the charts and graphs are so small the legend is unreadable which in turn renders the displays meaningless.I canceled my kindle subscription after the first issue and will renew the physical magazine.

Come on people, STOP YOUR WHINGING!  This is America, the land of free markets.  Sure, you can buy an iPad and read the content on there for less money, but you will get interruptions from emails dinging.  Sure, you can get it in the best form, print, but you will be cussing the letter carrier when your magazine doesn't arrive on Saturday.  Yes, this seems pricey, but it is a monthly expense that can be stopped anytime.With the cost of the Kindle going down to a decent range, maybe Amazon will realize that it will only truly compete with the tablets if it has the same content in presentable form for a competitive price.  But in reality, it will probably be at this rate until inflation justifies a bump.
Source (K): Well written and thoughtful material for less than a cup of coffee a day

Source (H): I've never subscribed to any type of periodicals in print (save for a brief period in school when we were required to read Time/Newsweek). Since obtaining a Kindle (and later on a Kindle DX) I have discovered periodicals and the in-depth reporting service they provide. It is a bit of a shame to see the newspaper, magazine industry struggle as I have seen that they provide a very valuable place in society (at least the high quality publications do). Items like the New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and now the Economist provide VERY high quality content and it has been so refreshing to read in depth coverage rather than having to rely on superficial TV coverage along with a focus on non-news items.On the one hand, I do feel that the price set for the Kindle edition of the Economist is a bit high. On the other hand I have been reading a few Economist print issues before (and have now activated the 14 day trial for my Kindle DX). This is a very high quality publication. What price should a well researched, highly informative, and quality version of a publication receive? If we are only willing to pay rock bottom prices for content, we will invariably get rock bottom quality material.No doubt this is one of those high quality content publications. The Kindle edition only adds convenience and portability to an excellent publication. If the convenience and portability do not justify the price for you, then I would suggest you stick with the print edition. Please also realized that the Kindle edition contains absolutely no adds to offset/subsidize the cost. Also, if the current implementation/limitations of the Kindle periodicals (i.e. DRM issues, color, etc) are not to your liking, I would also suggest the print version. For me the Kindle version is the best and most convenient way to read The Economist.After reading my first Kindle edition, I have been very pleased with the content and the fact that The Economist staff has provided a nicely formatted Kindle version. I stopped my LA Times subscription due to the awful formatting issues as well as the lack of pictures/charts. The Economist Kindle edition does not have formatting issues and the charts/images look really good on my Kindle DX. The articles are divided into sections that are very easy to navigate with using the Kindle. I can easily pick the articles I want to read as well as the articles that I want to skip.I'm very impressed with the quality of the content (which is not a surprise really), and the superb formatting work put in to make sure that The Economist looks good on the Kindle (DX).If I were looking at both products (The Kindle version and the print version) and both were roughly the same price, I would definitely pick the Kindle version for convenience.  Although it still remains to be seen whether I will keep this after the trial period since I do still feel that it is a little bit overpriced.4.5 Stars from me. Scale back the price a little and it will be a perfect 5.
Source (K): High Quality Content, Looks Great on Kindle DX, A bit overpriced.

Source (H): I've always loved the Economist, and have subscribed on and off for years. Having just got my Kindle Fire, i thought I'd see if the Economist was ported to it (previous reviews had criticized it, but I think they referred to pre-Fire versions). Rather than subscribe for a full year without knowing how it looked on the Fire, I thought I'd dip my toe in by purchasing a single issue first. And I'm glad I did. The Kindle edition is in no way worth it.  What you get is simply a copy of the printed magazine that you can read online. But isn't that what you want? you may well reason. Um, no, not really. What I expect is a VERSION of the printed magazine that works on and - more importantly - takes advantage of the capabilities of my device. Unfortunately The Economist has made very little effort to use any of the features of the Kindle. What you do get is two options: an exact copy of the printed version (which is the default) or a 'text' version, which is an extremely rudimentary page-flipper with about as much visual interest as a screen of block type. Which is what it is.The copy of the printed version contains every page from the printed version (including the adverts - annoyingly, you sometimes have to scroll through three full pages of adverts just to get to the next article), exactly as-is - same page-based (not screen-based) layout, and still only flippable by page. Even if an article continues on the next page, all you get is the same printed arrow indicating this - no text flow, no hyperlinked "More..." or anything. It's like they just scanned in the printed edition and uploaded that. Even more annoying than this complete lack of online navigational features is the actual content itself. In this view, the article text is a pure IMAGE - not text display. So it comes out slightly blurry (or at least less than sharp) at maximum zoom (which is still not really that big - too bad if you have poor eyesight). On a 7" tablet the un-zoomed text is a strain to read. The only way to zoom in is to pinch-and-zoom (although this is limited to about a 2x zoom which still only comes out at about 7pt text...), but then you find yourself scrolling around the screen trying to read a whole article. So the 'print view' is pretty much useless on the Kindle Fire.The 'text view' is thankfully at least legible, and does offer the basic built-in Kindle features to change the font size, but it is an appallingly cut-price 'conversion' (and I use the term conversion very loosely). Each article is presented effectively as 'flat text' sometimes with a lead-in image, but most often not, and all you can do is flip between pages as you would a novel. There is no 'click' to expand for images, no nice scrolling of articles, and absolutely no effort made to cater for (not even take advantage of) the capabilities of the device.To be fair, the 'print view' does include a scrollable set of thumbnails, but clicking on either just sends you to the relevant page (and if it contains multiple articles you're left to your own devices to rove around the page looking for what you want). Both the 'print view' and the 'text view' include a workable table of contents, but it's pretty visually uninteresting.  I know The Economist markets itself on its words, and ultimately I guess that's what you're paying for, but really, I'd expect at least some effort to take advantage of a medium, rather than just shoehorning a 'built for paper' version into it.Do I expect too much? No, I don't think so. I also subscribe to Time (actually it was a gift). The print subscription comes with a free Kindle (or iPad or anything else) version - there's even a specific app for it. This app is GREAT! All articles are reformatted specifically for the Kindle Fire screen, fit on it perfectly without the need for zooming, use an incredibly intuitive and easy-to-use touch-based interface, has a decent table of contents with jumps to articles, etc., etc.. It has overlaid pull-outs, pop-outs, embedded video, and is just a sheer pleasure to use. It really shows what can be done if you are willing to put a bit of time and effort into it.I MUCH prefer the Economist as a serious magazine but the Time Kindle Edition really puts the Economist's efforts to shame. I look forward to reading Time on my Kindle Fire (even more so than the print version), but The Economist is just so uninviting. It's like going back to Bulletin Boards in the early days of the Internet, after having spent years on a feature-rich multimedia browser - something you'd only consider as an emergency backup. Certainly I would never choose to read the Kindle version of the Economist if I had the paper version.I really hope that someone at The Economist reads these reviews, because they must try harder if they expect people to pay for this woefully sub-par offering. They need to look at what Time has done, and then match that.Me, I'm glad I only wasted $4.95 on a single copy, instead of $110 on the annual subscription. And I'm thinking of asking for my money back on that.
Source (K): On the Kindle Fire: Just a scanned copy of the printed version

Source (H): Magazine - 5 starsKindle price - 1 starAside from the controversy between the Kindle price and regular paper subscription price, anyone can do a Google search and find the code that will pull the latest issue off of the website, reasonably format it (though not exactly like the Amazon edition) and then all you have to do is "translate" it with Mobipocket and dump it on your Kindle...all for FREE.  And yes, I get all of the articles and pictures.  And I can get the latest issue AS SOON as it hits the website.  I just did the 14 day trial and they sent me...last week's issue (?!?)...when I can clearly see the new issue on the website.  So all I'm asking is, meet us somewhere in the middle of Free and the $10 you are charging.(I do subscribe to the print edition, but as far as I can tell, I am not logged in to the Economist website, so anyone can get this mag on their Kindle for free, with the proper tools)

Do yourself a favor and download the "Calibre" software for ebook readers.  If you subscribe to the print edition, it will automatically login, download all the content, create an ebook and either email it to you or transfer over the sync cable to your Kindle (or Nook or whatever).  Total cost is usually < $100 if you shop online for the print and online (web-based) edition.  I'd love to buy this even if it cost a bit more, but why reward their awful product?
Source (K): Do it yourself for much less

Source (H): The complaints here against the Economist are specious, the fact remains if you want in-depth global political and economic analysis, nothing compares. Yes there could be better formatting of the cartoon or images, but the e-version delivers all the substance of the paper rag, without ads, and a click away.Note that without ads, Economist does not generate traditional revenue that the paper version does, so logically they would have to charge a premium amount.  Yes the price reflects this...but every time I consider cancelling my subscription I compare it to TIME (which i continue to get in paper form) and it is like the comparing the adult version of a book to the children's version.To satiate the casual readers, a monthly digest containing perhaps 2-4 sections would be wise (have it contain International and then allow the reader to select 1-3 additional sections such Asia and Europe) and offer it at month's end for $5.
Source (K): Complain all you want, but it is the premier news magazine

Unfortunately issues are delivered to the device late in the day instead early morning(like Polityka each week). This is a decent publication to keep you up to date on the markets.  The timeliness of the issue and availability of instant data is the reason I only give it 3 stars.  I believe it is becoming less relevant each year, unless you are so out of touch that you don't have access to a computer...and some people are, which is fine.  Others, like myself, don't care about the numbers and read it for the articles.  By and large, however, it isn't so riveting that I feel bad when I don't get to it by week's end.The price concerns me since I subscribed to the print version last year for $50/year.  I will not purchase the Kindle edition.

Like no other publication on Amazon, the new Barron's shows up the idiocy and greed of Amazon's international Kindle distribution model. Amazon charges international users of the Kindle about USD 2 for every item delivered, allegedly to cover 3G charges. But nowhere in the world does the download of 181 KB (latest Barron's edition) cost USD 2. Where I live, the cost is USD 0.03. I'd happily pay that to Amazon.To make things worse, and ridiculously so, Amazon removes pictures and graphs from publications to save on wireless delivery cost. In Barron's, that means a segment called "CHARTING THE MARKET" ... with NO charts! Accompanying text is there, with direct references to the charts, but the charts are not delivered. No other publication makes Amazon's greedy wireless model look more obviously idiotic.As for the publication itself: it contains fewer articles than the print edition and no graphics. It has the same shortcomings as the print publication: USA-centric shortsightedness, frequent factual errors especially about non-USA issues, illiberal slant to policy discussions, lack of grounded research. But it is no worse then the tree-killing cousin.
Source (K): Barrons shows up Amazon Kindle distribution errors

Source (H): Just downloaded the "9/20" edition and got the cover, but a complete deja vu copy of the 9/13 issue instead of this week's.  Delivery here is not ready for prime time.

When it works, the Kindle edition is a perfectly pleasant way to read the magazine, especially if it's the commentary and not the tables you're after. Trouble is, it often doesn't work. I've subscribed for about four months and I've either received very late delivery (meaning several hours after I complained) or incomplete delivery (a partial edition with just a few articles and no functional index) on at least half a dozen occasions. That's a pretty high failure rate. Buyer beware.
It is after 10am and the Barron's still has not appeared in my kindle. I know it is at the news stand now. Why does it take so long to get the digital version. One would think it would be faster.

I tried the two week free trial and really enjoyed the magazine. I would like the convenience of reading it on the Kindle, but 10.99 per month is too expensive. I'm thinking about subscribing directly to the online version at $79 per year.1/30/10 update: I just subscribed to an offer in the mail for $52 for the online and print editions for a year. I suspect that I got this offer because I signed up for the free trial and then cancelled.6/29/12 update: I cancelled the subscription about a year ago. The company has been making annoying daily phone calls to my house to get me to resubscribe. We have repeatedly said that we weren't interested. We finally gave up and blocked the phone number.
Source (K): They will not leave you alone

Source (H): I've experienced multiple bugs when reading Barron's issues on my Kindle. Sometimes advancing to a "page of death" in the issue is enough to cause the issue to become unopenable until the issue is downloaded again -- inconvenient when on the subway to say the least. I routinely notice HTML encoding bugs (e.g., "S& amp;& amp;& amp; & amp; & amp; P 500").  The formatting is often poor, with missing line breaks or section headings making interviews difficult to parse.  The graphics, charts and figures are usually illegible; they're not sized properly to view on the Kindle. Unlike a paper subscription, a Barron's Kindle subscription does not entitle you to use the Barron's website.  As of a few months ago, customer service informed me such an option (Kindle + Web) was not available.As for the content, let me briefly comment that when Barron's writes on sectors that I know pretty well (technology / Internet), I am sometimes struck by the shoddiness of the reporting --- competitors they forgot to mention, bad understanding of the business at hand, failure to ask key questions.  I often worry that sectors I know less about (let's just say everything else) are getting the same treatment.
Source (K): Buggy, Bad Formatting and No Barrons.com Web Access

Source (H): I was EXCITED to find out that Think Simple Now is now available for Kindle.No mistake, I read A LOT of content daily: I currently have 110 sites in my RSS reader.  But there's no site that I look forward to as much as Think Simple Now.Why? It's---#1 Relevant:  There are writers out there who publish interesting work, but it doesn't really apply to my life.  Tina consistently puts out articles that make me think "That's just what I needed to read today."#2 Practical: Sometimes you'll read content that reads well, but is short on practical application.  Tina always gives doable steps to go with her insights.  I often end up passing copies of her articles on to friends and coworkers.#3 Personal: Over the months I've gotten more than just great insights and applications; I've gotten to know Tina Su the person.  Somehow knowing that her articles really do come from her own life experiences makes a real difference; it helps me reflect on my own life and see how I can change and grow myself.#4 Consistent: Last but not least, Tina's content is consistently top-notch.  I have some writers I keep up with for that one gem of an article out of a dozen that they write.  There are few writers that just keep turning out gems time after time after time.  I don't have to wonder if Tina's latest article will be worth my time or not: they're all gold.Bottom Line: You won't find better updated content on self-improvement and personal growth.  Highly recommended.

"Decisions" could have been a contender. It has a rough-and-tumble hero in Donovan Grant, the bum pilot working for the wealthy owner of a resort on a 50-acre Fiji island, and he has a handicap: He can't make decisions except when death is on the line; he must be Sicilian. One would expect a book set there to make me feel the balmy breezes, the roar of the ocean, and the feeling of entering a unique culture.But the details aren't there. The views are postcard pretty and about as deep. Donovan engages in saucy talk with a buxom young brunette and her blonde sister, but the eroticism is undercut by the overblown descriptions of their assets. Surely a line like "When her eyes made contact with Grant's, the sway of her buttocks multiplied several orders of magnitude" is worth some kind of prize. His reliance on witty banter about names stretches over two chapters, and wears as well as a man who loves to tell knock-knock jokes. In short, this pilot doesn't take off as a character you'd want to fly with.

With witty dialogue and snappy pacing, Mr. Wicker's teaser has made me want to read the rest of the story.  The main character's wit and self deprecating humor remind me pleasantly of Harlan Coben.  As with all good thriller books, my mind is already racing ahead with possible mysteries and plot twists.  I can't wait to read the rest to see what happens next!

You know, if the synopsis is true, this is a Mystery, not a general fiction item. It certainly has that "hard-boiled" style, and that's really the key differentiator: While certain mysteries (Walter Mosley, e.g.) bring you into intimate human contact with the narrator and other characters, this is more in the action/adventure mode where the narrator is impossibly cool and tough, where all the females are babes, and where guys can take a punch to the jaw. It's okay, but it seems to me misleading to have registered this in a genre where it doesn't belong.
Source (K): This shouldn't be in General Fiction

Source (H): A middle aged fool drinks and oggles young women.  He has a problem with making decisions.  He rakes the women with his eyes.  He drinks some more.  This goes on endlessly.  Nothing else happens except toward the end the ground tilts.It is supposed to be funny. I never cracked a smile.  If I am very bad, I suspect that in the afterlife I will be condemned to read nothing but novels like this one, endlessly.  I better be good.I don't understand the five star reviews.  I could say maybe it's me, but I don't really think so.The writing is smooth and professional.  Two stars for that.

Maybe I am a peaky reader, but the main thing that I expect from a book is to have some sense. A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man by James Joyce is a big disappointment for me, because it's very very BORING.I know that I should not say that I dislike a book before I have finished it. But this novel is pretty disorganized; I couldn't resist reading more than some pages. I felt that I had wasted my time with this book, where almost nothing happens. I also had the impression that Stephen is an outsider - who remembers the entire conversation at the Christmas meal (for example) - not the main character. Probably I cannot understand the stream of consciousness technique, because I couldn't read Mrs. Dalloway either.There are too many characters that do not seem to be clearly defined and that discussion about religion - on the First Day of Christmas - was too long for my taste.If all Joyce's novels are as this one, then he lost me.
Source (K): Hm... it's worse them the worst book that I have ever read

Source (H): Like many, I read A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man in my youth.  Now, much later (50 years), I am struck by the evolution within this autobiographical novel of its language, paralleling the growth of the "young man" himself.  And I am reminded that Joyce had, and still has, the largest vocabulary of any author--it is said that Ulysses has 30,000 different words, including tenses (by comparison, Shakespeare had a vocabulary of over 10,000 words, an incredible ten times the average person of his era).  In addition, the power of Joyce's description of Hell is unparalleled, except perhaps, but only perhaps, by Dante. Read during my first extended visit to Ireland, this book fulfills its reputation as one of the five best English books of the 20th Century.

The book was incoherent and poorly written.  Obviously Joyce was under the influence of something when he wrote it.  It would probably help if the reader would also partake of a similar inebriant before attempting the book.I started the book 3 times previously over the last 45 years and was determined to finish it this time.  I was trying to understand why it is rated so highly on the list of all time fiction.  I am still baffled.  Actually, I don’t know why it is classified as fiction since it is basically an autobiography.The book starts off with some amusing anecdotes from the author’s early life.  Then it quickly descends into psychological drivel which continues throughout the middle half of the book.  Apparently, people who rate books have decided to read more into the words than what is actually there.Eventually, Joyce returns to real life and inexplicably slips into journal mode.  I think that while writing the book, which was originally serialized, he forgot what he was writing about and just kind of babbled forward.The book is a real struggle with little reward for the reader.  I wouldn’t recommend it and certainly would not rate Joyce as a great writer.

I subscribed to this last week. The past two days the "trivia" started out with an entire page thanking subscribers for their help in raising a total of $175 for a charity. Hmm. While the spirit of giving or collecting is amongst us, and I applaud Mr. Gallagher's efforts to rasie money, this doesn't sound like trivia to me, and therefore should take up the first page. How about delivering on the "product" of "trivia" first then providing your fundraising requests and/or updates?Today's trivia was entitled "How does a Laundromat tell whose shirt is whose?". Here's a sample of the "trivia": "While some laundromat's wash the shirts water in net bags, this is done primarily to protect your garment rather than to separate it from others."  Reread that:  "While some laundromat's wash the shirts water in net bags..."  HUH?  I didn't know that shirts had water. Hey Mr. Gallagher: Please run spell check and grammar check and re-read your post BEFORE you post it. After all, we're paying for this." So unimpressed that I just cancelled my subscription. I'd rather spend $0.99 cents a month on an entire Readers Digest than this crap.
Source (K): Mr. Gallagher should run "Spell and Grammar Check"

Source (H): I did not like this because this does not have any of the music I like and I've never even heard of any of it. What happened to Metallica, the band perry, katy perry, bruno mars, bvb, or even Justin Beiber for god's sakes!!!!!!!!

Wow, where do I begin?  This book is worth exactly what I paid for it $0.00.  The main character, Claire, is a whiny, poor me, spoiled brat.  She is needy and stupid.  The writing is terrible.  The scenes are not described well.  You keep thinking that it has to get better but it just doesn't.  I have no idea why everyone gave this a 4 or 5 star.  I couldn't even finish it.  Other than supposedly being gorgeous, Ethan has absolutely no personality whatsoever.  You THINK he likes Claire but other than one dream Claire has, you don't get the impression he likes her at all.  Claire is obsessed with him.  She barely knows the guy yet all of a sudden she is begging him to tell her what to do.  She is needy and clingy and it's embarrassing to read.The one pseudo positive element of this book is the potential for a good world to build with.  The premise of where the vampires came from is somewhat unique.  However, the writing was so awful and contrived, you felt cheated.Not a book I would recommend to anyone.
Source (K): Could have been done much better!

Source (H): This is a very happy book that both children and adults will enjoy!While reading it, I felt like a kid, listening to all kinds of wonderful story-like descriptions about birds.  The information is factual, yet  presented in a way that children can understand and enjoy.  Ms Blanchan's  descriptions make the birds come alive!

As the novel has no description  above, here is the synopsis for those who wonder what the book is about:The novel begins in the 1790s in the coastal town of Monkshaven. Sylvia Robson lives with her parents on a farm, and is loved by her rather dull Quaker cousin Philip. She, however, meets and falls in love with Charlie Kinraid, a sailor on a whaling vessel, and they become engaged, although few people know of the engagement. When Kinraid goes back to his ship, he is press-ganged--forcibly enlisted in the Royal Navy, a scene witnessed by Philip. Philip does not tell Sylvia of the incident and, believing her lover is dead, Sylvia eventually marries her cousin and they have a daughter. Inevitably, Kinraid returns to claim Sylvia and she discovers that Philip knew he was still alive. Philip leaves her in despair at her rage and rejection, but she refuses to leave with Kinraid.Philip joins the army, and ends up fighting in the Napoleonic wars where he saves Kinraid's life. Kinraid goes back to Britain, and his wife, who knows nothing of their history together, goes to Sylvia to tell her that her husband is a hero. Sylvia then realizes she is actually in love with Philip, and Kinraid's marriage suggests to her that he was not as faithful to her as she had believed. Philip meanwhile was horribly disfigured by a shipboard explosion, and returns to the small Northumbrian village to try to see his child. He ends up staying with Sylvia's parents' servant's sister and rescues his child when she nearly drowns. In saving his daughter he is fatally injured, but is reconciled with his wife as he dies.
My only disappointment is the inability to print a pattern .  When I knit I always. print a copy of my patterns and make notes on them.  There was something I wanted to make but probably won't.

Uncaged: Top Activists Share Their Wisdom on Effective Farm Animal Advocacy is a must read for everyone, animal lover or not. I was especially taken by the section written by Dr. Charlotte Laws, PhD.  Laws brilliantly points out that there can never be true consideration for nonhuman animals under a democracy that is only run for people, which excludes all living beings, namely animals. In an Omniocracy, a term she coined, nonhuman animals are constituents therein their interests are considered. As an animal lover who's been involved in animal rescue for the past twenty-eight years, I am thrilled to read what this author has to say in favor of setting up a government that shines a light on animal abuse and advocates to stop it. She gives examples how each of us can make a difference, in practical doable ways. I highly recommend this book to read what she and others who have written here have to say for the betterment of living in harmony and the ending of suffering to our animal brethren.
Source (K): Very important read on Animal Rights

Source (H): I ordered this last week because my 16 month-old black 2nd generation Kindle cover looked like the elastic band was going to break.  This cover is distinctive and very well-made.  Note to Amazon:  just because a product (i.e my Kindle) has a newer model it doesn't mean I'm going to junk it and buy the latest version...please keep SOME accessories in stock for those of us who are perfectly happy with the product we now own.
Source (K): Buy it now before it's discontinued!

Source (H): I'm still in my free trial period, and I've been getting the AJC for a few days now. As long as delivery is consistent throughout the trial period I think I'll keep the subscription.I don't read the print AJC very often unless someone leaves one laying around. I can tell that the Kindle edition probably has a few less features, but for the price I can't really complain. It has the main national and state news stories that I care about reading. It has at least the main story image for most of the stories that have images. The sections are well organized and easy to navigate.Pros:- Easy to navigate through individual articles, from article to article, and by section. There can even browse by full text and summary which is awesome- Includes images (it seems many Kindle papers do not)- Titles, image quotes, and story text are all clearly differentiated- Includes opinions, special sections, obituaries and pretty much all the content of the print edition as far as I can tell.Cons:- Seems to be missing weather, tv listings, etc. Probably due to formatting issues.Overall:- Other newspapers should take a cue from the AJC. They seem to have made some pretty big overhauls in the past few months based on info in previous reviews. The formatting, content, and most importantly price I feel are all perfect for a Kindle version of a paper. If you live in the Southeast US I would give this one a try.Overall I'm pretty happy with it. The only thing that could change my opinion would be if the deliver is inconsistent. I will update my review after my trial about my experiences.

Talk about disappointed! I have subscribed to the Kindle edition for five months. The AJC, in their infinite wisdom, stopped delivering the hard copy edition to my area in January. The Kindle edition was a godsend! For a while!Lately, the Kindle edition has either been late or not provided at all --like this past Sunday and Monday. I refuse to allow the AJC and Kindle to continue to abuse me. I have canceled my subscription. For the first time in about 37 years, I will not be receiving the AJC. Their loss, not mine. I'll read the NYT on-line!
Source (K): They need a paperboy! Someone to deliver on-time!

Source (H): Let me begin by expanding on Amazon's description of what you do and don't get compared to the dead tree version.  You don't get anything in map or table form, such as weather, comics, TV listings, puzzles, or sports standings.  You also don't get some syndicated features, such as Dear Abby and other advice columns.You do get all the special local sections.  The AJC publishes a daily Gwinnett News for newspapers distributed in that county (a holdover from when there was a competing newspaper there).  You also get all the weekly local sections for other parts of the metro area.  Contrary to what another reviewer wrote, you do get the Sunday paper, but it's missing some material that doesn't originate with the AJC, such as Parade magazine.As for the quality of the AJC itself, it is not a world class newspaper and doesn't try to be.  It relies almost entirely on wire services for national and international events, and coverage of state and local issues is sometimes brilliant, sometimes nonexistent.  It's coverage of local business and real estate is certainly good, though, and sports coverage is outstanding.  There are a couple of excellent sports columnists, and coverage of SEC and ACC college football is extensive and year round.The newsstand price of the AJC is now $6.50 a week, so the Kindle version is certainly a good value.  Overall, a very good way to read a decent newspaper.

This collection of ten short stories was assembled nearly 100 years ago as a teaching aid.  It "attempt[s] to present selections from a list of the greatest short-stories that have proved, in actual use, most beneficial to high school students." The introduction presents a brief history of the short story from Cervantes' "The Liberal Lover" in the seventeenth century to its widespread popularity in the early twentieth century. It also defines the essence of the short story, not by its length, but that it "...deals with a single character, a single event, a single emotion, or the series of emotions called forth by a single situation." Each element in the short story should build to the stories point, even when it comes as a surprise to the reader.  The introduction ends with a list of short story collections for suggested reading.Of the ten stories in this volume, two stand out:Bjoernstjerne Bjoernson's "The Father" traces several events in the life of a father who looks out for his son.  It builds to a unifying emotional end.Guy de Maupassant's "The Piece of String" is a morality tale about truth and reputation--and which matters more.Each story in the collection is followed by a brief biography of its author, a critical analysis of the author's work, and a list of recommended additional readings.  Although obviously dated in it's discussion of the short story, the book is an enjoyable and recommended read.

Just so everyone knows, the stories listed in the table of contents are:"The Father" by Bjoernstjerne Bjoernson"The Griffin and the Minor Canon" by Frank R. Stockton"The Piece of String" by Guy de Maupassant"The Man Who Was" by Rudyard Kipling"The Fall of the House of Usher" by Edgar Allan Poe"The Gold-Bug", by Edgar Allan Poe"The Birthmark" by Nathaniel Hawthorne"Ethan Brand," by Nathaniel Hawthorne"The Sire de Maletroit's Door" by Robert Louis Stevenson"Markheim" by Robert Louis StevensonNo navigable table of contents, and the formatting is a little wonky in places, but a very nice book for a freebie.
Source (K): List of short stories contained in this free Kindle book

I'm sure this magazine is fine for a lot of people. I even recommend that you try it, since they have a free trial subscription. That being said, this magazine was not for me. Global warming, climate change, political views, and opinions are just fine. But the name of the magazine is "Discover" not "Climate Change Monthly". I want to be entertained and maybe learn something in the process, not be lectured to about and prodded into a belief that I may or may not subscribe to. Pardon the pun. By the way, if the major thesis of this publication was microbiology or any other singular topic, I still wouldn't care for it. So, if you're into global warming/climate change, then power to you and enjoy. As for the technical aspects of the magazine; layout, design and formatting, there were no problems that I could see. The pictures and articles were in all the right places on the screen, and the experience of reading it was comparable to or better than having a physical magazine in my hands. The price was pretty good as well. A little broader science coverage, and a little less focus on a controversial topic, and I'll probably give it another shot. Until then I'll just stick to science blogs and books.

The Kindle subscription to Discover is a good value. The magazine layout has been translated well for the Kindle Fire. I cannot comment on whether this version is better or worse than what is available on the ipad, because I do not own one. The content of Discover magazine covers a variety of topics and is written to hold the reader's short attention span (i.e. interesting and easy to read). These attributes suit my amateur interest in science well. My only complaint is that I wish I could interact with the text more: highlight, comment, etc.
Source (K): Good value for casual science enthusiasts

Source (H): Sad, we only bought our Kindle a few months ago and publications like this have elected to be available only on Kindle Fire. Maybe Nook was a better deal after all.

The reviewer above who stated Discover is only available on the Kindle Fire is wrong. She misunderstood the statement "Only available on Kindle Fire". This statement applies only to the various Kindle platforms. If you have a Kindle App on your PC, Mac, IPAD, Android tablet, phone or other device, then this magazine and other magazines available through the Kindle store will not work at this time. They only work on the Kindle Fire. This magazine CAN be found in other non-Amazon digital stores and works on other devices than Kindle Fire.
Source (K): Discover not limited to Kindle Fire

Source (H): I have been a loyal Discover subscriber for over 20 years.  A year ago, I made the switch to paperless.  As you might guess from my opening sentence, I'm no youngster.  Why is that relevant?  Because I often need to zoom in to see or read details, to accommodate my ever more inflexible eyes.  Generally, this is a perfectly sufficient strategy, and it's a pleasure to read electronic material such that I can change to a comfortable font.  However, the font in this magazine seems scanned, rather than being based on vector, postscript or other re-sizable technology.  For standard pages, this is still sufficient, but the scanned nature of the magazine yields low-quality results when one tries to zoom in on a photograph, or (and this is the worst part), detailed and often-annotated graphics in the magazine.So... the content is great, the presentation in the current Kindle-friendly format is mediocre.  Because this significantly limits my enjoyment of the magazine, I'm giving it two stars.  I'm even considering going back to the print version.
I thought this magazine was about science?  Rename it "Global Warming Monthly".  Honestly, they find a way to squeeze it into the magazine every month.  RUBBISH.

Too cool for words.Subscribe NOW. At a penny shy of a buck-fifty per story you can't afford NOT to! You won't be sorry. In fact, you'll wonder how you ever lived without it. =)
Source (K): One Story never fails to delight and intrigue!

Source (H): I've been getting One Story since August 2009. It is the Kindle magazine I most anxiously await. Sure, the charging/delivery schedule is a little off, but it doesn't affect the content. At $1.49 per month, who cares?Each month I get to experience a new writer with a new story. I wasn't sure about this at first, but it's clear now that this is a terrific publication. It has yet to disappoint.Some surprisingly talented writers are featured in One Story. I'm sure most are up-and-comers who will someday be widely recognized.

I subscribed to One Story out of curiosity a couple months ago.  I've read three stories so far.  The stories are all very well written.  Each issue includes an About the Author and some Q&A; with the author.I docked a star because I am still not exactly clear about the pricing and publishing schedule.  It costs $1.49/month, but I thought I saw they are delivered every 3 weeks.  The dates I listed below are the "publish" dates, not the dates they arrived on my Kindle, and they don't seem to be the same time apart.  I see there's an Oct 6 issue on line, but it has not arrived on my Kindle yet (as of Oct 15)...At any rate, to give an idea of what the stories are like, here are brief descriptions of the stories I've read so far.Aug 10:  "Frost Mountain Picnic Massacre," by Seth Fried, 4610 wordsA surreal story about a town that turns out every year for an annual picnic outside of town.  Each year some horrible, bizarre disaster happens, yet every year they go again.  It's written somewhat in the style of "The Lottery", a short story we studied in school decades ago.  The descriptions are bright and cheerful, but there many hints at these dark sinister forces at work that no one seems able to confront.  I don't want to give away a lot of the story.  This was a really unique story, and if they were all, or mostly, as original as this one, I'd say One Story is a bargain at twice the price.Aug 30:  "Desiderata," by Jennifer Haigh, 6174 wordsA story about an aging widow and her relationship with her deceased husband and (platonicaly) with the retired janitor from the school at which her husband was the principal.  Through the span of the story she discovers some things about her husband, and about herself, that she'd not known before.  While this one was very well written, and I really enjoyed the ending, I've read too many other stories about aging widows looking back on their lives, such that I kept waiting to see what is unique about this one.Sept 10: "Stag," by Rob McCarthy, 6553 wordsAnother quite unique story, centered on a recovered alcoholic young father who has recently separated from his alcoholic wife, for the sake of their five year old daughter.  He moves into an abandoned house outside of town, hoping that the surrounding quiet and nature will be good for his daughter and their relationship.  The title refers to a stag that appears in the middle of the story and takes a center role through the rest of the story.  Again, I don't want to spoil anything.  I didn't "enjoy" this story as much as the picnic one above, but not because it isn't a great story.  It is very intense, and a bit emotionally wrenching, leaving me in a bad mood!  This story incorporates some nice symbolism, and really beautifully ties the symbolism into the story line at the ending.I especially enjoyed the Q&A; with the authors at the ends of these stories.  It is surprising to see what motivated them and where the elements come from.I imagine you could google the authors or titles and learn more details about the stories on line.I sense from the three I've read so far that the stories will cover all different genres and writing styles.  If you enjoy taking a small gamble and reading different things, without knowing what they will be about in advance, definitely give One Story a try!

A prowling mountain lion may or may not be responsible for the carnage and disappearances that are occurring with surrealistic regularity in a corporate office park. Lust, jealousy, anger and a serve-by-serve replay of the famous Federer-Sampras 2001 Wimbleton matchup -from a ball boy's point of view. One family, two couples together in a house but separated by a generation. Then Hurricane Andrew intrudes.Those are stories in recent issues of "One Story," the monthly magazine devoted to short fiction. All three are most likely by authors you don't know now, but are probably going to be hearing more from soon.One story and no more each month. Plus an author interview. An author is published in "One Story" only once. That's a rule that ensures new voices, fresh takes and a big variety of literary tastes.On the Kindle, "One Story" pops up every three weeks. I am charged $1.49. It's more or less my story-of-the month club. It is like subscribing to "The New Yorker."  I feel compelled (motivated) to read. Put it off and another issue will be in the mail box next week and I don't want them to begin piling up. I know that another "One Story" will show up on my home page sooner than I expect and when it does it is going to overwrite the current story."One Story" editors have earned my trust. They have proven to be very good at choosing; expert at sifting and winnowing. I'm confident that their judgment and the shape they give to one story each month will result in a read I find compelling. Some stories, of course, are better than others. Each in its own way, however, has proven provocative and in some shape or fashion appealing. Put aside something less worthwhile. Put something off for a half hour. Everyone can find time for one story a month; everyone should.
Source (K): Find the time, one story a month, c'mon it's worth it

Source (H): Issue #129 was outstanding. The next issue was a total 'bomb' however. The author in the interview was pretentious and assuming in addition to being an uninteresting writer. One out of two is not bad, but I'll look for a higher ratio of good/bad writing for my $2.

Was trying to post the full title toFifteen Thousand Useful Phraseshere, but was informed of the following by Amazon: 'Oops! There are a few limits when you are putting product links in your review - you can't have more than 256 characters in a product title.' That being corrected, with the improbably long title of "Fifteen Thousand Useful Phrases: A Practical Handbook Of Pertinent Expressions, Striking Similes, Literary, Commercial, Conversational, And Oratorical Terms, For The Embellishment Of Speech And Literature, And The Improvement Of The Vocabulary Of Those Persons Who Read, Write, And Speak English," this literary compendium by the late Greenville Kleiser is memorable, and not just for its long title.Greenville Kleiser (1868-1935) was the writer behind of a long list of motivating books and guides to oratorical success and personal development, some of which are still available.  He also worked as an instructor in Public Speaking at Yale University.  Originally published in 1917 by the Funk & Wagnalls Company of encyclopedia fame, this work is surprising in its depth, not just for its forty-word and 295-character title, including spaces.It should be noted that on the downside, there is no Table of Contents, at least in this particular free Kindle version. This Kindle edition,Fifteen Thousand Useful Phrases, is said to have a table of contents so that you don't have to constantly press on the Kindle's 'Next Page' button on my Kindle to navigate to the section you want. It will cost you a buck, maybe more, but that's why we have choices between free or paid.After getting past a rather random preface of sorts, we find what's called a PLAN OF CLASSIFICATION, followed by a listing of the eleven sections.  There's an interesting introduction by Frank H. Vizetelly, a lexicographer, etymologist and editor who was employed by publishers Funk & Wagnalls to act as an editor for the firm's dictionaries and encyclopedia. He was also the author ofA Desk Book Of Idioms And Idiomatic Phrases In English Speech And Literature.Author Kleiser follows with a preface entitled How To Use This Book, followed by a Plan Of Study which outlines the eleven sections that we will see below, with some examples of some of the more interesting phrases encountered among the 15,000 offered in this work.  I can only list a few of the more interesting, out of the ordinary or witty ones encountered, and have done this by the sections in which they were found in this book.  Some of these may appear as being misspelled, but they were transcribed here as the author himself wrote them, including his explanatory notes which have been left in their original brackets.SECTION I: Useful PhrasesA: "abandoned hope", "amatory effusions [amatory = expressive of sexual love]"C: "conjugal felicity"D: "damask cheek [damask = rich patterned fabric; wavy pattern on Damascus steel]"E: "effulgent daybeams [effulgent = radiating light]"S: "sesquipedalian words [sesquipedalian = long]"SECTION II: Significant PhrasesA: "abashed and ashamed", "abstinence and self-denial"B: "babel and confusion", "bigots and blockheads"G: "galling and humiliating", "glib and loquacious [loquacious = very talkative]"SECTION III: Felicitous PhrasesA: "abstruse, metaphysical, and idealistic"E: "effluent, radiating, and fructifying [fructifying = Make fruitful or productive]", "egotistic, disdainful, and proud"J: "jealousy, exclusiveness, and taciturnity [taciturnity = habitually untalkative]"O: "obstinacy, stupidity, and willfulness", "officious, fidgety, and talkative"W: "waddling, perspiring, and breathless"SECTION IV: Impressive PhrasesA: "able, skilful, thorough, and genuine"C: "captious, petulant, peevish, and splenetic [captious = point out trivial faults]"F: "fanatic, enthusiast, visionary, and zealot", "fancy, humor, vagary, and caprice [vagary = extravagant or erratic notion or action]", "fop, coxcomb, puppy, and jackanapes [jackanapes = conceited person]"O: "obdurate, unfeeling, callous, and obstinate"Q: "quack, imposture, charlatan, and mountebank [mountebank = flamboyant charlatan]"S: "scandalize, vilify, traduce, and offend [traduce = humiliate with false statements]"SECTION V: Prepositional PhrasesPreposition "of"...B: "babel of tongues"H: "harbor of refuge", "harvest of regrets"J: "jangle of sounds", "jargon of philosophy"S: "savoring of quackery", "sting of satire"Preposition "by"...B: "ballasted by brains"Preposition "in"...B: "barren in intellect"W: "wallow in idolatry"Preposition "into"...B: "bullied into silence"K: "kindle into action"L: "lapse into pedantry [pedantries = attention to detail or rules]"Preposition "to"...F: "fly to platitudes", "foredoomed to failure"R: "reduced to impotence", "repeat to satiety", "run to seed"Preposition "with"...C: "cling with tenacity", "clothe with authority", "covered with ignominy"K: "kindle with enthusiasm"S: "seething with sedition [sedition = conduct or language inciting rebellion]"SECTION VI: Business PhrasesF: "Frankly, we believe it is extremely worth while for you"I: "I am confident that you will be thoroughly satisfied", "I am giving the matter my personal attention"Y: "You are certainly justified in complaining"V: "vehicle of intercourse", "vicissitudes of life [vicissitudes = sudden or unexpected changes]"SECTION VII: Literary ExpressionsA: "A broad, complacent, admiring imbecility breathed from his nose and lips"B: "Beaming with pleasurable anticipation"C: "Cold gaze of curiosity"F: "Familiar and endearing intimacy", "Felicitousness in the choice and exquisiteness in the collocation of words"H: "Half choked by a rising paroxysm of rage"J: "Jealousies and animosities which pricked their sluggish blood to tingling"R: "Ransack the vocabulary"S: "Sacrificed to a futile sort of treadmill", "She felt herself carried off her feet by the rush of incoherent impressions"SECTION VIII: Striking SimilesA: "A blind rage like a fire swept over him", "A book that rends and tears like a broken saw", "A breath of melancholy made itself felt like a chill and sudden gust from some unknown sea"B: "Beauty maddens the soul like wine", "Beheld great Babel, wrathful, beautiful, burn like a blood-red cloud upon the plain"Q: "Quaking and quivering like a short-haired puppy after a ducking"SECTION IX: Conversational PhrasesA: "A most extraordinary idea!", "A thousand hopes for your success", "All that is conjecture", "An unfortunate comparison, don't you think?"E: "Either way is perplexing", "Eminently proper, I think", "Excuse my bluntness"H: "Happily there are exceptions to every rule", "Have I incurred your displeasure?" "Have you any rooted objection to it?"M: "Many thanks--how kind and good you are!", "May I ask to whom you allude?", "May I venture to ask what inference you would draw from that?"R: "Rather loquacious, I think [loquacious = very talkative]"V: "Very well, I will consent", "Vivacity is her greatest charm"SECTION X: Public Speaking PhrasesA: "A fact of vast moment", "A few words will suffice to answer", "And now I have completed my review"I: "I adduce these facts [adduce = cite as an example]", "I view that prospect with the greatest misgiving", "It is an egregious mistake [egregious = conspicuously and outrageously reprehensible]"L: "Language is inadequate to voice my appreciation"SECTION XI: Miscellaneous PhrasesA: "A bewildering labyrinth of facts", "A piece of grotesque stupidity", "A pleasant flow of appropriate language"B: "Bandied to and fro", "Based on a fundamental error", "Beguile the tedium of the journey", "Bemoaning and bewailing his sad fortune", "Beset with external dangers", "Betrayed into deplorable error"K: "Keen power of calculation and unhesitating audacity", "Kindle the flames of genuine oratory"P: "Pregnant with a lesson of the deepest import"T: "The hurly-burly of events"Z: "Zealous in the cause he affected to serve"Greenville Kleiser authored many other titles, such asSuccessful Methods of Public Speaking,The Training of a Public Speaker,Model Speeches for Practiseand more.  I've only listed the freebies here, but if you do a search on the author's name, many others will appear.According to a recent article in Wikipedia, the "average persons' active vocabulary consists of 10,000 words, regardless of native tongue."  This is interesting because it represents a meager fraction of the lexis of that language in that according to theNew Oxford American Dictionary, there are more than 350,000 words, phrases, and senses, though other sources place this as closer to roughly 600,000 words.  These discrepancies are partly due to relative simplicity of spoken language to written language.  Additionally, one may understand more words than one uses, meaning that one's working vocabulary may not be representative of one's total knowledge of a language.A 1987 research on native English speaking university graduates found an average vocabulary size of 17,200 base words.  With the numbing down of television, one might wonder if that's still true.For those who are adventurous, the text-to-speech feature in this book is enabled.  Check your documentation for your particular model, but if you have a Kindle 2 you can start text to speech in the Text menu while you are reading. Hold down the 'Shift' key and press the 'SYM' key to stop or play.  Some of the results are quite comical, as you may find.I'll call this a 5-star read if just for its vast content of phrases, but only a 2-star book because of the lack of an active Table of Contents.  Still, in recognition of the late author's fascinating work here, I'll raise it to a 4-star offering, and if Greenville Kleiser were alive today, it would be a 5-star read due to his meticulous nature in editing.To quote the author: "And now I have completed my review"... hope that it was helpful.2/2/2012

Source (H): Back in the bad old days, if you wanted to read hot BDSM fantasies you were stuck with the bodice-rippers in which the anti-hero used rationale like "your mouth is saying no, but your body is saying yes...and if it isn't yet, I'll spank you until it does," to justify raping the spineless heroine. Savannah Tennyson was raised by her father to show no emotion and give no quarter in business.  Her faade is unshakeable and unemotional.  The only person who can get through to Savannah Cyborg, as she is called behind her back, is Matt Kensington.  He makes her furious more often that not, but Savannah has to admit that Matt has never lied to her and she trusts that he never will.  Invited to a late night meeting to discuss a business opportunity, Savannah has no idea that the opportunity is her body and the business is what happens when Matt and his four trusted advisors make her body sing.  With touches of fire Savannah is brought to the brink of ecstasy and then some, but what happens when her ropes are untied?Matt loved Savannah and because of this love, he knows he has to do something drastic to get her attention.  I like his personality very much - dominate without being overbearing and just enough tenderness that Savannah knows without a doubt that he wants her.  Savannah was tough to get to a handle on.  Her upbringing alone is enough to make even the nicest woman hesitant and while Savannah uses sarcasm often with Matt, it isn't enough for Matt not to know what she is covering up - her emotions.Board Resolution by Joey W. Hill is a BDSM novel that will push your buttons, but make you think.  Add in an uber sexy hero and his band of four fiery hot brothers and the results are wicked.  Originally released in the Ellora's Cave anthology, Behind the Mask, I am glad that Matt and Savannah now have their own cover.  And he definitely covers her.TaliaReviewed for Joyfully Reviewed

While the idea and concept for this 'series' could be amazing, once again, this falls short with not enough information.  How did the last war come about?  How was the Network created initially?  What kind of civilization condones such cage matches?  What is the state of affairs now?  What in the world is 'the Change' and where is the biological description of it?I have many more unanswered questions that I hoped the 2nd book would answer, but alas, it didn't. She promised him that she would find him. She's keeping her promise! There are many rules to the game and it's not just the contestants lives in danger their families lives are also. Ok, I'll be blunt.  I started this book with preconceived notions, and not positive ones.  The ideal of woman being all that strong with only weak men around really didn't thrill me.  I'm a strong woman, but I want my man to be a man, not some weakling.  Luckily this book didn't disappoint.  Once I got past my preconceived conceptions of the book, I got into it and I'm happy to say I was not disappointed.  I didn't want to put it down.  The final decision is that I enjoyed the book and am anxious to read book two of the series.Don't be put off by the so called bloody scenes some described.  Yes, there's some death, but the author didn't dwell on it.  In fact, nothing was dwelled on, which I really appreciate. It was fast moving, but you could keep track of what was happening.  I didn't once start skipping over sentences or paragraphs as I have with other author's books.  You'll want to read every word.Romantic, sexy, steamy scenes?  Yes, there's that too in this book.  I do love a good romance novel with an actual plot and some good action.As far as some other comments about the lack of background...I just shake my head.  I don't need a whole book on why something is, this is fiction.  Get over it.  Enjoy the book and the story it contains.  The story wasn't about what happened 500 years ago from the beginning of this book, it's a story about Candice, Angel, Daniel, Baker and the Network.  The characters are, as usual with this author, fantastic.  The story line is entertaining and fast paced.  It certainly doesn't drag.If this book was accidently erased from my kindle, would I re-buy and read it again?  Why yes I would, but not until I get a hold of the next book in the series.Looking for a good, interesting book to read this weekend?  Buy this one.  I'm pretty sure you'll be discussing it at the office come Monday morning!  Start early though ~ once your into it, you won't want to put it down, which can cause sleep deprivation.

Eight Months Before The Clue HuntI love the original 39 Clues books, and have on my short list to read the second series The Cahills vs. Vespers, but this short series released between December 25th and December 31st 2011 really caught my attention. 7 Days 7 Short Stories each give us part of a clue and more background information on some of the characters from the books. If the other 6 are as good as this one, they will be more than worth the price of $0.99 each.This short story starts on Christmas Eve, the year before the hunt for the 39 Clues begins. We find out that Grace knew she was dying and that she was aware of the Vespers' history. We also meet Dan and Amy and get some more insight into their character. The short story has a fast pace and before you know it you are done. And even though it fills in more pieces of the overall story arc, it leaves you wanting to know more. I am glad I picked up the eBook and if you like the other books, I guarantee that you will be also.
Source (K): Great series of short stories in the 39 Clues Universe.

Source (H): Got my black MarBlue Atlas Kindle case. It has an excellent leather appearance. Not understanding of those that need to snipe about non-leather things especially if it looks good. (Those that have money to burn apparently) The double stitched border looks professional and high quality. When reading the review on this product to decide on blowing $40 or $25 I concentrated on the middle of the road reviews on the magnetic Amazon model. I want to know the absolute worst thing I should be aware of and its repetition is the only thing that I can depend on for any possible truth from my consumer perspective. The majority of the 5 star people I had to assume would be predisposed to give it a great review to justify their expenditure. In the mediocre reviews I always look for consistency of the mediocre complaint. If there is no consistency, there is a good chance that simply kavetching of picky perfectionists are more the order of the day and the item is actually a top notch purchase.The Amazon Cover model consisted of three main complaints. Very consistent! One, it was pretty expensive for the simply acceptable but definitely adequate quality. Two, the magnetic closure was many times not 100%. It didn't close completely all the time, or it did not turn off the unit as designed. Third, it seemed heavy. There were consistent variations of these themes.The MarBlue on the other hand has awesome reviews, even the mediocre reviews did not have the repetitive problem that makes my red flags go up. The hand hold was a universal plus. Now that I have it, I agree, the hand hold strap is fantastic and brings an entirely new dimension of reading with this unit for in bed nightime use. The Amazon unit also had its weight highlighted several times while MarBlue did not. I can now vouch for the most acceptable weight of the MarBlue. My Kindle White is held most securely by four corner elastic straps. The hand hold strap is solid and sturdy looking and appears capable of lasting for the life of the product.If you do not have a leather fetish, the appearance of this cover is more than appealing. One complaint mentioned is its sensitivity to indentation or whatever. I do not experience that sensitivity. The faux leather is definitely not jelly bean consistency. It's solid and beautiful as long as you don't abuse it. The protection of the integrity of the Kindle is excellent. I feel as if I dropped it from even waist or table height, no damage would result. I recommend this item especially for the price. Based on the Amazon cover reviews since I physically don't have one to handle, I don't discern any step down in quality as long as you don't value the auto off/on feature.

This Kindle case may be acceptable for some users, but it's not for every one. It has a nice feel and holds the Kindle securely with the elastic corner bands. It's usefulness is limited to the three small Kindle types, not the Kindle with the keyboard or the Kindle HD. Double check your Kindle type before ordering this cover.The more bothersome issue relates to feature that makes it different from others: the ability to slide your four fingers into a band on the inside cover and keep a firm grasp on the book. I have small hands even for a woman. In order to get my hand iin the proper position I needed to stretch the band and the pressure was too great for me to keep the Kindle in that position for more than a few minutes. Since I sometimes read for an hour at a time, this would become uncomfortable quickly. Not particularly useful for me.

When I bought the original Paperwhite in the fall of 2012, I also bought the Amazon leather cover, and I've been very pleased with it, so much so that I'm using the same cover for the new 2013 Paperwhite. It looks good, it holds the Paperwhite very securely, and it has a little magnet that serves double duty - keeping the cover securely closed and activating the AutoWake feature of the Paperwhite.The Marblue Atlas cover appears to be well made and durable enough to last for years of service. The faux leather looks good, and the stitching is uniform and tight. It doesn't have a magnetic lock like the Amazon cover has, but the elastic bungee will keep the cover securely closed when you're not reading. And the wide hand strap is a nice touch for hand-holding the Kindle.But I have two concerns about this case:1. The Kindle is secured in the case with four elastic straps. That's okay, but straps can break, although these seem tough enough. However, I much prefer a more secure plastic snap-in shell like the Amazon case has.2. A bigger concern is the lack of a magnet to activate the newer Kindles' AutoWake feature. AutoWake is a great feature that lets you avoid fumbling for the on/off switch every time you use the Kindle.Overall, the Marblue Atlas is a nice case. It doesn't have all the features of the Amazon case, but it's less expensive. If the lower cost is worth the tradeoff in features - notably AutoWake - the Marblue Atlas is definitely worth a look.
Source (K): No AutoWake, but otherwise, it's a very nice case

Source (H): I am pleased with this case for my Kindle. The reader fits securely in its retaining straps and the case is held shut by an elastic band. I do wonder, though, how long the elastic will hold up under constant use; I will update this review when and if the strap gives out. The case also has an interesting elasticized sleeve that allows you to fold the cover of the case back and slide your hand into the sleeve for secure handling. The sleeve is somewhat awkward for me to use, but it has been only a few days that I have been using it and it provides piece of mind if you are reading on the train or subway and are prone to doze while reading. I have also noticed that the sleeve and fabric cover of the case imparts an unpleasant odor to the hand when it is inserted into the sleeve for any period of time. I hope that it will pass in time, as it is quite noticeable. I had been using a sleeve/pouch to transport my Kindle while commuting or traveling, and I find this case to be more convenient to use in that you do not have to find a place to stow your pouch while reading. That being noted, I think that the padding on my present pouch would provide more protection to the Kindle if dropped while stored. I would rate this case a 7 out of 10.Update: January 12, 2014 - some time has now passed and I am more happy with this Kindle case! The scent about which I complained has largely gone and I am more comfortable using (or not using) the strap for my hand. I am still somewhat skeptical about the long-term survivability of the elastic strap on the outside of the case.Update: June 11, 2014 - This product has really grown on me. The closing strap is still intact, and the case has protected my Kindle against the usual bumps of commuting quite well. The internal hand strap is still a bit too snug for my larger hands and I seldom use it. I have upgraded my rating to four stars - I like this product a lot.

Source (K): Quality Cover For The Kindle Paperwhite

Source (H): It was the wrong size.  I have a Kindle Fire and this one was for the Paperwhite. Returned it for credit.

This is a review of both the black and blue MarBlue Atlas Kindle Cases. These are decent cases and have some good things going for them. I wouldn't say they're great cases but they do the job with, what I consider, only a few flaws.The system for attaching your Kindle to the cover are four very strong and quite tight rubber reinforced elastic cords. I've had several Kindles and numerous cases over the years and as far as four corner case mounts this is the most secure of that style I've ever seen. I had my PaperWhite mounted in this case and shook it violently, over a pillow and ready to catch it should anything happen, and not only did it stay in place it didn't move a fraction of an inch. I was very impressed with that function of the case.The case exterior is a synthetic leather that truly looks and feels like leather. It is well made, and fairly handsome. Unlike many synthetic products this had no harsh chemical smell. The blue cover looks a little less like leather than the black but it is a very nice shade of blue.The interior is an attractive, and soft, dark grey microfiber that's quite pleasing to the touch.The case is held closed or open with a half inch wide cloth elastic that is well attached to the case. This holds the case closed quite well. The hinge area of the case is a bit too large/tall/wide making the case when folded back a little ungainly and if not strapped down it wanted to flop closed.Inside the case is a nearly three inch wide strap made of the same soft, grey microfiber attached with elastics at both the top and bottom. This comes into use when the case is open you can put your hand or fingers under this strap to read one handed. With my PaperWhite I found this to be slightly uncomfortable making me arch my hand in an odd manner to get my thumb onto the screen. I'm not a fan of the strap, the sections at the top and bottom where it's stitched to the elastic create two lumps that sit directly on the Kindle's screen. They're soft but it's two unnecessary pressure points.This case does not have the magnet that the Amazon brand case does that turns the kindle on and off when you open it. The power button on my PaperWhite was a little hard to reach with the shape of the case and the location of the mounting strap. It wasn't too difficult to use but it's nowhere near as easy as opening the case and having your Kindle come on.In conclusion...The case is decent. It's a little... gappy, the front cover bends when you have your hand in the strap and this creates a gap that will let debris into the case and onto your Kindle. I'm not crazy about the strap but that's more personal preference than anything else. This is a well made decently protective Kindle case.

I ordered this personalized with a photo I provided, and that's why I won't be sending it back. The description says it will fit a standard Kindle, but it's about 1" too short!  The elastic bands secure the kindle in the case, however, they are stretched very tight and I'm wondering how long they'll last.  It seems to be a quality item, the case itself is nice, and my husband really likes the hand elastic feature, but we're both disappointed that it doesn't actually fit a standard Kindle.
Source (K): Check the size! A standard Kindle does NOT fit.

Source (H): I am going to compare this to the Amazon Kindle Paperwhite Leather Cover.The MarBlue Atlas cover feels cheaper with a smooth almost vinyl feel to the cover. The Amazon cover has a magnet which secures the case closed while the MarBlue cover has an elastic strap to keep the book closed. The Amazon cover automatically turns the kindle on and off when the cover is opened or closed while the Marblue cover does not.The cover is sturdy enough and folds open for one handed reading. There is a handy strap which keeps the flap secure when reading one handed which is better than the amazon leather cover. Also, there is a hand strap which makes one handed reading easier than the Amazon cover.The MarBlue cover weighs less than the amazon leather cover which is nicer when reading one handed.Overall, I would say that the MarBlue cover for the Paperwhite is better for reading one handed but the Amazon leather cover is higher quality fit and finish.If you find this review helpful please give it a thumbs up below. Thanks!
Source (K): MarBlue Atlas Kindle case vs. the Amazon Kindle Paperwhite Leather Cover

Source (H): I've been a print subscriber for years, and Esquire rates as my favorite magazine of all my subscriptions.The problem is that I'd need to pay twice for the same content if I want to read it on my Kindle Fire, since unlike FORTUNE or Wired, you don't get access to the content unless you're willing to pay for it yet again. From making the perfect ice cubes, to the meaning behind AM/PM, getting the most for a charitable donation, free 411, the origin of Boxing Day (something I've always wondered about but never investigated) and even the benefits of various colors of sunglasses -- there's a bit of everything.MARIA CAMP, Author ofRelevantly Random
