I'm trying to replace my kindle with my new iPad and this isn't available with it. Sure seems like they are missing out on a huge potential audience, myself included.

I've decided to quit Kindle. Period. Then, no reading of New York Times on it.In the past month, the Kindles of my family (5 of them) freeze too often. Mine died yesterday afternoon again. This happened a couple weeks ago while I was traveling. It happened many times during the past several months.I've always thought Kindle is flawed, but I bought many because I think e-ink is the right technology for reading whereas a lighting-up screen like iPad and KindleFire is wrong for reading.To the end, Amazon really disappointed me. Amazon has not improved the e-ink technology at all. Instead, it has gradually made it unstable, slow, and interruptive to reading. Many updates of the Kindle focus on commercial goals rather than improvement of reading experience.I've decided to stop all my Kindle subscriptions now and throw away all the kindle books I have purchased. This decision is after about 5 years of efforts to love Kindle.Good-buy.=========My old review=========I subscribed the Kindle version for a short period. I think the pricing is ridiculous because it is locked into one Kindle, unlike books that can be placed on 6 Kindles. I want to carry a small Kindle on the way but prefer reading on a large Kindle at home. If I subscribe a paper version, my whole family can read different sections at the same time in the morning. If I subscribe a web or iPad version, my whole family can read any section the same time on everyone's iPad. With the Kindle version, only one person can read the journal. Because of this, I stopped buying any more Kindles, regardless how good it is. As you can see, the over-pricing not only kills the NYTimes's Kindle version but also kills Kindles.

Source (H): i have read the new york times for many years, mostly on sunday. the paper is becoming more liberal in my opinion. i do not enjoy reading it as much as in the past. the well street journal is taking its place in some of my reading.

It was a good independent newspaper for years. Is now a radical powerfull media serving to liberals, radicals, leftist and extremits. Is going down specially because it reputation go very bad every single day. Let me see if I have got this right.The journalists and editors write these stories on computers and same them to files. Those files then go to the print shop to be converted from digital to printed media at an incredible cost in paper electricity ink and equipment.Next they go to the Digital Publishing department (emailed to Amazon) or at no real cost upload it to amazon who then distributes the content for them from servers that amazon pays for.First they devalue it by only providing a portion of the printed copy, then they jack the price up to $20. I've subscribed to the NYT for 25 years in the paper version.  Having purchased a Kindle primarily for reading the Times, I love the accessibility--plus, even though I recycle, there is less paper in the landfill.  And, though others have been concerned regarding the content, I have found that for the most part, the Kindle edition is very similar to the paper one.However, as others have already stated, a 40% increase is ridiculous.  Certainly it is cheaper than home delivery, but I just spent $250.00 six months ago for the Kindle and don't want to return to a paper newspaper.  So, like many others, I will be canceling my subscription when the price increases. Hopefully there is another quality newspaper that I can find.To the Times: consider a Monday-Friday edition, along with a stand along Sunday paper.
Source (K): Loss of a long standing NYT reader

Source (H): I have a challenge for you: take the 14-day free subscription of the Times and read it "cover" to "cover" every one of those 14 days.  Of course it is almost impossible unless you are a speed reader or have too much time on your hands, but I feel it is very enlightening to at least try.  After those 14 days can you name me a half a dozen news sources that have the breadth and depth of coverage as the Times?  How about 3?  Any?In my opinion the NY Times is one of the world's great news sources.  The breadth and depth of reporting is simply amazing.  Sure, some weeklies or monthlies have a feature article or two that are as deep as articles in Times, but the Times does it day after day.Unfortunately all of this news does not come cheap.  In fact, for new subscriptions and in a few months for all subscriptions, it costs about $20 a month.  With so many cheap or free news sources out there, including some from the NY Times itself, why pay so much?I like reading the Times on my Kindle, particularly my new DX (most pictures blow up very nicely on DX).  I can take it anywhere without worrying about an Internet connection, just like the paper version.  Unlike the paper version I also have it delivered to me no matter where I am.  There are no worries about the environmental damage from making, delivering and disposing of a huge hunk of paper and ink.  Still, is it really worth an average of just over 65 cents an issue?What do you get for that 66 cents anyway?  You can save back issues for reference and pick up missed editions.  I don't have a word count, but I would guess a single copy of the Times is about the size of many best sellers - that is, a book worth of high quality news daily.  There is definitely more information every day than any of the weekly, bi-weekly or even monthly magazines I have read.  Without advertising.I think one thing people miss when they compare the price of Kindle periodicals to the price of the paper version is advertising - a huge amount of their revenue comes from advertising.  Even the on-line version of the Times is packed with advertising.The Kindle version has no advertising, so no income beyond the price of the "paper" itself.  That's a major hit on revenue even when you take into consideration the savings in printing and distribution.As a slight aside - I was just looking at the NY Times web site and see they offer an electronic version for $2.62 a week, pretty much the same price as the Kindle version (2.62 /7 = .66 while 239.88/365 = .657).  The paper version costs more (they were advertising the weekender edition for $3.80 a week).  It seems that most Kindle periodicals are now almost the same price as the paper versions, though the paper edition is rarely as expensive as the Times (a single Sunday paper is about $10!).So, is it worth it?  I personally feel that $0.66, which is far less than the price of a cup of coffee, less than one subway trip, less than an impulse buy of the skimpy local paper, etc., is not too much to pay for what I consider the greatest news source on earth.

I bought the Kindle because I got tired of lugging around a book bag full of books everywhere I went. I wanted the ability to have my textbooks on the Kindle and to leave the bookbag home. SO far that's been a good deal. I never even considered a subscription. When the Kindle came I noticed there was a 14 day free trial and so I thought I'd give it a try. When I lived in New York, I loved the NY Times and it has remained my favorite newspaper of the last 40 years. But it was impossible to get a copy where live. If I wanted to read it, I had to travel into town to get a copy, or settle for mail delivery many days after the fact. Since it was free on Kindle for 14 days, I thought, "Why not?"Now my subscription to the Times has become my reason to love the Kindle. Sure I've downloaded lots of books onto the Kindle. But every morning I get up, turn on my Kindle, brew some coffee, and by the time I get back to the Kindle that day's edition has been downloaded. I love it. I can quickly skim through that days articles and decide which ones I want to read with coffee and which I want to savor later in the day.What a joy it is to have it automaticaly there for me every morning. Leaving my book bag at home, now, I have all my books with me and if I only have a few minutes later in the day, I now have the chance to pull out the Kindle and read the articles I'd saved for later reading!
Source (K): It's not just for books anymore!

Source (H): The electronic format NYT has several disadvantages.  First, the font seems to use less pixels then other newspapers so the text is a bit more difficult to discern and read at all font sizes.  Second, as another reviewer mentioned, the left justified format with ragged edges is cumbersome when compared to a fully justified electronic newspaper.  Third, there is a full blank line inserted between each paragraph which sacrifices space without improving readability.  Finally, the Washington Post provides a word count for each article which is a nice way of letting you know how large of an article you are diving into, sort of like you would gather from looking at the size of an article on a printed page.I am a diehard NYT reader but the Kindle electronic format leaves me cold when compared to other electronic newspapers.

I just received the Kindle Fire as a gift and am disappointed to learn that if I want toread the NY Times on it I have to cancel my PC subscription and resubscribe on Kindle whichis five dollars a month more expensive than the PC subscription.  Shame on the NYTimes!

For a recent trip to Turkey (March 30 to April 16) I tried to order the New York Times on Kindle. We receive the print edition daily, and I wanted to keep up with the news in places where I knew we would not have access to English-language newspapers. I thought I'd ordered a one month subscription, but when we were in Turkey I never was unable to receive the NYT on my Kindle. When we arrived home I found (by accident) copies stored on the Kindle. I deleted them, and tried to find on my computer a way to stop receiving the paper on the Kindle. Today I see that I STILL am receiving the NYT on my Kindle. (Normally I click on my Kindle to the book I'm reading.) I'm deleting all of June. HOW DO I STOP THIS? I DON'T WANT THE NYT ON MY KINDLE! I READ THE PRINT EDITION!!!
I'm not willing to spend over $200 for a newspaper.  The NYT needs to drop their price closer to $60/yr.

I think thi newspaper is great it tells you everything that is happening here in new york.
Why pay for a newspaper that is missing key sections? I will subscribe when the entire paper is on the Kindle.  No science section and the absence of David Pogue's articles is a deal stopper.

The missing content is very disappointing. I subscribed to the Kindle version when NYT began requiring a subscription to their full web version. I prefer reading the Kindle over a PC.I am very pleased with what I can read and I am reading more of the paper. But, the missing articles, content, and truncated pieces leads me to consider dropping the subscription.I do not understand why all of the text cannot be delivered. If this were corrected, this would be an outstanding product.

I love my Kindle 2 for books, blogs, and magazines. However, newspapers are a challenge. Obviously, it would be nice to have quick access to news of the day as well as detailed articles, as you can get from a computer's internet access. I have tried the New York Times for this service. However, I canceled my subscription after two months. It is incredibly expensive ($13.99 a month) especially for something you can get free online. In addition, you can't scan sections easily, such as you would do with a real paper (view front page section stories).Most importantly, I just can't stand the liberal bias. I expect it on the editorial pages but when it permeates every political article, it is nauseating. It reminds me of a moveon.org mouthpiece. Every political article must be read with your own filter of the motivation of the NYT. I just can't support paying for such bias. And they wonder why they are going bankrupt...Regarding options, I do subscribe to the WSJ which does have a way to scan the important non-business stories of the day, just like their front page right hand column. However, it is just once a day with no update on breaking news. The Kindle blogs on news are all lacking as well, though the Reuters and AP options are the best I have found (though they are left leaning as well).Nevertheless, there is still a void in Kindle news coverage compared to what is available online. How about adding a way to easily read online news from other news outlets such as Fox, ABC, NBC, CBS, CNN, Drudge, etc? While I am ranting, why not add Barrons too...I do love my Kindle, really.

Source (H): First of all, I'm happy there's a trial subscription so that knowing what I now know prevents me from spending any money on an actual subscription.  I was really looking forward to solely reading the New York Times via the Kindle.  But, having realized that not all of the articles are available I'm very disappointed.  Luckily I thought to compare what's available in the electronic version with what was delivered to my home.  Otherwise, I wouldn't have known what's missing!  Less money for the electronic version shouldn't mean that I get less of the news/articles.  I'll be canceling the the New York Times Kindle version.

I have never been an avid newspaper reader.  I prefer to find a specific section or article.  The Kindle serves this purpose well.  It is really easy to search by section.  Plus no more dirty print covered fingers.

As far as I'm concerned, keep the business and sports sections, give me the science and health sections.  Please, Powers that Be at the Times, take this plaint seriously, and include health and science in the Kindle edition

Source (H): Why would any thinking person bother with a rag (virtual or no) that has descended to such sloppy ill-researched reporting? I prefer my editorials published as such, not gracing page 1 as news. With the paper edition I can at least line the bottom of Tweety II's cage as well as housetrain Spidey, our 8 weeks old mastiff.

No illustrations charts or diagrams and only a few token photographs to demonstrate that they are possible. Missing or truncated articles. I find myself going to the NY times online edition to make sense of the omissions on the Kindle edition. What's the point of paying $14 a month when you get more online for free? I don't know who is responsible; Amazon, NY Times, or Sprint. In any case this is a bizarre and useless product.

The NYT Kindle edition is a good alternative for subscribers outside the NYC metro area (e.g. National Edition subscribers). Not only is it much cheaper than a print subscription, but it also includes the Metro section.  Another benefit of the electronic edition is that it is advertising free (for the present anyway).In my view, the only significant drawback of the Kindle edition is the omission of the much beloved NYT crossword puzzle.

Source (H): There's no way I'd get through the whole New York Times every day (I barely get through the much slimmer Washington Post as it is), so subscribing just doesn't make sense for me. That's my problem though, not the fault of the Times or Amazon.What I like is that you don't have to subscribe, you can simply pick up single issues when you want to read them, just as you can with other Kindle magazines and newspapers. Amazon currently charges 75 cents for a single issue of the Kindle NYT, which is a great deal on the Sunday edition. This fat delivery includes the usual book reviews, magazine, extended op/eds, and travel (among other regular sections).As with other Kindle newspapers, it's well-formatted and easy to navigate. Dithered black and white pictures are occasionally included; for my six bits I could take or leave them. Editorial content is identical to that of the paper newspaper with minor omissions like TV guides, crossword puzzles, and advertising. The best part? Nothing to recycle when you're finished reading.
Source (K): Great deal on single issues (I'm a Sunday reader)

Source (H): I love to read the NY Times because it gives you a wealth of information, but I just could not afford to spend the 2$/day and 5$ for the Sunday Paper.  However, I realize that reading the Times is an investment on human capital, and to me, that is invaluable.  At first, I was ambivalent about the Times on the Kindle because of the 3-star rating it got (I don't like to buy anything below 4-stars, as I believe Amazon reviewers tend to be representative of the population), but the more I read the reviews, they became more polarized and extreme.  So I thought: "Why not try it for myself? There's a 14-day free trial, at which you can cancel anytime, and the subscription is 20$ per month, which is a far better alternative from the roughly 70$ paper subscription.I get the NY Times downloaded onto my computer, and what do I see? In the Table of Contents (Where all the sections are listed), I see all the sections lined up on the left column, and next to each listing is the number of articles that they provide you, in parenthesis.  As you scroll down the list, there will be the Titles for each of the articles on the right-hand column.  I cannot tell you how convenient this feels.Many people will gripe and moan because the kindle subscription does not offer all the articles.  They probably like to peruse the whole paper, and I admire their diligence and willingness to read as much as possible.  However, some sacrifices have to be made (problems mainly due to licensing).  However, the Times will offer you the majority of what you would normally read (Maybe 90 percent? Sans graphs and charts).  Another added bonus is, you don't have you get your hands dirty anymore and make those wide movements especially on a crowded 7 train in the morning when traffic is heavy.  Simply put, on one single page, you get to see everything you want to see, and then you make a simple-click and get to that spot without the hassle a normal paper would give you.I am 17 years old and I know that many others in my generation will defer the Times for the Post or the Daily News, because it is cheaper and more convenient.  However, with the purchase of my recent kindle, and the NY Times, I am reading A LOT more now (30mins on the paper -> 1 hour kindle).  It is just that much more of a pleasure to read now.  So parents, please invest not only in an Amazon Kindle (or another e-ink reader), but also the NY Times.  It is an absolute blessing.

Missing the classifieds, ads, travel section etc. makes the NY Times for kindle a bit worthless.  I still have to buy the Sunday edition to get the "relaxing" parts of the paper that make it special.I don't know why they can't include it all.

The problem with this subscription is that the value is a huge rip-off. I love the NY Times, but for that price, you would hope for pretty much the full version. First off, the Kindle does support JPEG and other images so there is no reason why tables and pictures are being left out. Secondly, there is no Crossword which merely exposes limitations of the Kindle: no print support or ability to read the proprietary Kindle files from your computer. I think a cost of $4.99 a month is a more justified price for this.

I have subscribed to the Kindle edition of the New York Times since the very first day it was available and always found it to be a great value.  I have grown used to reading it on my first, second and now third generation Kindle.  At 13.99 a month it was a luxury, but worth the extra cost.  I was dismayed to learn a few months ago that on October 2 the original subscribers would be paying 19.99 a month to read the NYT on the Kindle.  Like so many others who have posted here, it is quite simply not worth it at that price point.  Sadly, today was my last day for reading the NYT on the Kindle.  The publisher's greed should not be rewarded...I hope they lose money as a result of this mean spirited decision.

I have been getting notification on my computer of NYT headlines for some years (and then I can view the entire article and others), so I thought I would try the Kindle edition.Pluses: downloads to Kindle automatically; it's there each morning; it's easy to read successive articles, and easy to skip ahead or back to the next article.Minuses: virtually no photos and no graphs/maps; missing the tech and other regular sections; missing the crossword (okay, maybe not important); expensive at $20 per month.While nothing is as good as the physical newspaper, I think the NYT Company could have done a better job with this Kindle edition.
Clearly this paper has stopped doing investigative reporting and are getting their stories right from Obama and Pelosi.  What a shame.

UPDATE: So apparently it is now possible to link Amazon and NYTimes accounts to get the right access. Has Amazon let us know about this? Nope. But someone else did reach out to me after I mentioned this on Google+. Thanks to them!Generally, I'm very impressed with the NYT. I actually have two subscriptions (Kindle, and Audible), both with Amazon since they bought Audible. Well, I really wanted to love the NY Times on my kindle.  Overall, my reaction was to like it, but not love it and here is why:-  it came every morning before I got up and has all the NY Times articles for the day.  They are very readable like everything on the kindle- no updates during the day, if you have a computer you can get the current updates as well as the daily paper_ poorly organizaed on the kindle, hard to move between sections

One of the reasons that I got a Kindle was as a convenient reading device when carrying a laptop isn't practical.  I have a weekend print subscription to the NY Times, and I thought that would extend to cover the Kindle version. However, unlike what I thought I read on the NY Times "Digital Subscription" web page, it turns out I have to pay for a second subscription if I want the "e-reader" version in addition to the print version.I thought about switching entirely from my print subscription to the "e-reader" subscription, but that would be a significant downgrade since the "e-reader" edition (a) is missing a LOT of articles that I enjoy (e.g. Science, Technology, David Pogue ....), and (b) is only updated daily.  I've decided that I'm better served by keeping the print subscription, reading the NY Times website when I can, and canceling the Times subscription for my Kindle.In summary, the Kindle version of the NY Times is a complete failure for me.

What educated woman or man would turn down the opportunity to browse over the previous day's events that are going to shape our world?What man or woman would turn down the opportunity to educate themselves by reading some of the greatest journalism in the world day to day on any topic that stimulated them?Today's world is not the world of 50 years ago when mother and father would sit at the breakfast table reading the newspaper and educate their children about what's going on in the world.  In today's world we grab our breakfast on the go.Our children grab their schoolbooks on their way out the door saying " I'll grab something later." The time has come that it should no longer be acceptable to bury our heads in the sand and say " I don't read the news, it's too depressing.  I don't read the news because I don't have time."We owe it to our children to know what's going on in the world, and when our children see that we find it unacceptable not to know they will become curious themselves.  With the invention of devices like the Kindle we're no longer burdened with the unfolding and spreading out of a bulky newspaper.  We're no longer shackled to a computer desk, or a heavy laptop to find out what's going on.  The visually impaired, or the physically disabled no longer need to be frustrated because smaller handheld devices slip out of our hands, or are just unable to be read by us because of their small print.A new day has come.  Large news organizations with 24 hour a day coverage should no longer be the only place we have time to figure out what's going on.  Those organizations give us a taste, but it is up to the individual to go to the newspapers for the full story.I read this wonderful paper that I am reviewing, and I can testify to its value.  In a debate with a very close friend just a few days ago we were discussing a topic.  I spoke with passion about an article I read in the New York Times.  My friends argument started out with " Well this journalist on TV said."I stopped him at that point.  I pointed out I was not discussing the subject with a journalist from TV.  I wanted my friends opinion.  My friend smiled and said " Touche".  Then he gave me his opinion, but when I countered with a more detailed argument he was lost.  The TV journalist only gave a basic overview of the issue where on the other hand the newspaper gave specific details.Newspapers on the Kindle make reading the daily paper painless.  There is no ink to get on your hands, it is incredibly compact so it can be read anywhere.  Perhaps a school bus or a crowded coffee shop.With the five way joystick one push to the right takes you to the next article making it incredibly easy to skip over every article you find boring, annoying, or just not grabbing your imagination at that very moment.Bookmark an article you don't have time to read and go right back to it when you have more time.  At the end of the night instead of throwing away the paper, or letting them stack up simply delete it, turn your wireless on before turning off the Kindle, and when you wake up in the morning turn your Kindle on and enjoy the paper all over again.$13.99 a month which means even in the shortest month of the year it's only 50 a day for your newspaper.  They hooked me with the two week free trial.  Another great thing about two weeks free is that if this is not your newspaper you can try other newspapers from all over the world.Knowing what's going on is really the most important thing, because informed people make informed decisions which usually translates to better decisions.Thank you Amazon
Source (K): A daily education is priceless and so very needed

Source (H): You lost me at $20.00 a month, come on NYT thats just greed!!!You could at least offer a weekend sub. for the Kindle

Thanks Amazon for allowing these reviews. It has made my decision to buy a Kindle or any ereader for that matter) now very easy. I WON'T!!!!!! The primary reason was getting newspapers like NYT. But if I can't get EVERYTHING from the print edition on the electronic edition, I'm not interested! You just saved me a LOT of MONEY!

We are currently working through the technical requirements to verify Kindle...subscriber accounts and offer access. More information will be available soon."See #28 here:  [...]I telephoned Customer Service at NYT earlier this morning (SAT 16-Apr-2011). OK, before we start, I'm a conservative.  I hear the conservatives gasping that I would read the NY Times and the liberals saying I'm too evil or too stupid to understand the NY Time's point of view.  To both: lighten up, this is a review, not a Manifesto.Good Things:  (1) NY Times on the Kindle is very well formatted.  I see others have commented that you can get the same info for a lot cheaper by going to the Times' website.  I will gladly pay for the convenience and the quality of the formatting. (2) Great to be able to read the paper when I want; also if I miss a day I can go back to an earlier issue or an article I clipped to get the info I want.  (3) I've not had any issue with delivery.  If I leave my Kindle Wireless on I've found I can get the latest paper by 5:30AM without fail.  If I don't want to leave wireless on to save my battery it only takes less than 1 minute to download any issue. (4) The free trial period sold me.  I was unsure at first but after noticing the good things above I decided to continue my subscription.  I don't know how easy it would have been to cancel but I trust it would be easy with Amazon.  (5) I really enjoy the book reviews but usually check out other websites to make sure the reviewers weren't too biased over the subject matter. (6) It is amazing to read the NY Times and then without fail see the same subject covered the next day on TV--the Time's does seem to establish what is "the news" and the others seem to follow like sheep.Bad Things: (1) OK, it is the NY Times-- I won't be able to read much about my Phillies & Eagles until it is Playoff time (take that Mets fans!)but I can at least see the major happenings.  (2) OK, it is the NY Times--I usually just skip over the NY happenings articles & real estate sale sections since it doesn't mean much to me in Indiana.  (3) OK, it is the NY Times-- I have to put up with the politics of the Newspaper on the editorial pages (expected) but why does this bias show up in Science articles & Obituaries? I've learned to shake my head or hit the "next" button.Generally, I think this is a great "application" for the Kindle which I recommend to others.
Source (K): NY Times on Kindle: Conservative View

Source (H): I'm flabbergasted.  Why on earth would the New York Times publish an electronic version that omits entire sections and many articles that appear in its print version?  The tide is rapidly turning against print journalism generally; free news content abounds on the Internet.  So why on earth would the Times stiff subscribers by providing less content?We can bemoan the advent of e-publishing to no end, but the handwriting is on the wall:  the days of pulp and ink are drawing to a close, especially for newspapers and periodicals.  If and when the Times leadership begins publishing the full print edition for e-readers, then I will consider subscribing again.  But until then, consider my subscription cancelled.

I wrote the review below in April 2011.  Most of the issues are now resolved.  I can see my favorite features - only lingering downside is less photos. But that is a minor complaint.  I am now very pleased with the NYTimes/Kindle service.r-----$20.00 a month seems like a reasonable price to me, as I had been a Sunday-only subscriber for years and the cost of that ran (even while haggling a steep discount every few months)almost $20.00 per month.Positives for the Kindle Edition -Easy - Downloads are a cinch.Portability - Reading The Times on my kindle makes for an easier commute on a crowded Train.I like how the "paper" is sectioned, with headlines.Archives - last 7 days archived. Love that.I really like that the "paper" is delivered without a driver, or newsprint or ink.Negatives -Can't seem to find "The Haggler" which is a Sunday feature I enjoy.I am constantly nagged by the question of what story is not included in the Kindle edition.The un-resolved issue of NYTIMES.com access for Kindle users needs to be cleared up.If you don't download that day's edition, you cannot download it later. (I keep my wi-fi mostly off, to save battery life)Fewer photos and poor resolution of the photos that are delivered.No Wedding pages (I'll live, but do enjoy looking at these announcements)No ads (NY theater, cabaret, etc)All in all, I am pleased with, but not ecstatic about, The NY Times Kindle edition.Randy

I'll stick around until March.  Then it's bye-bye if they try hiking the price back up again.  But we've already seen that they don't always do what they say.

First, Amazon does not archive Newspaper and Magazine issues in your account for more that a few issues unlike when you purchase books.It is up to you to back up NPs and Magazines onto your computer to archive, for example The Wall Street Journal.Here is the rub. Should you loose, receive a replacement Kindle (warranty or otherwise) or purchase a Kindle 2 ALL past issues of Newspapers or Magazines that were downloaded to the original Kindle will be UNREADABLE on any subsequent Kindle even though it is registered to your account.Think about this for a moment. You buy these periodicals and obtain the rights for your use, but if you purchase or replace your Kindle you have no further rights to read past issues YOU bought and paid for.One better hope that their Kindle never breaks because Amazon does not repair YOUR Kindle they replace it with another. Therefore no more use of your periodicals.Sound absurd? Well it is true. So much for a reference library.On one hand you can purchase a hard copy of a magazine or newspaper and let 1000 people read it, but now it turns out you can't even read a copy of the very one YOU purchased.For all the good that has come out of Kindle it amazes me the obvious necessities that have not been addressed.

The NYT is way over-rated. Just a few examples. On their first page, they talked about saving the nation's energy by painting roofs white. Any white paint? No, special white paint from government labs! It turns out any old white paint will do, that a government program is not necesaary, but the NYT did not say so. Irresponsible. In the area of health reporting, Pope wrote a silly article about a Dr. Kesler's book about food. She did not mention that, as head of the FDA, he was engaged in running battles with vitamin and food manufacturers for years. Many of these battles he lost in the courts, which is now why we can use aspirin for heart treatment, which is just as good as the expensive biotech drugs the FDA was touting. Uncritical and irresponsible reporting. A dereliction of the journalist's duty.And what about the economists like Krugman who don't have a clue about how to save the nation's economy. Yet they pontificate in those pages.If you are a times reader, i encourage you to find better sources.Later...To continue this rant, I posted a comment on the NYT website in response to an article. My tone was reserved and systematic. The subject was the blocking of medical innovation by the medical bureaucracy and government. (FDA) GUESS WHAT? tHE COMMENT WAS ERASED. They evidently censor comments they don't agree with, or that may offend their advertisers. Is this the kind of society you want? You may not agree with me, but do you want to shut up those you  disagree with? Hint: You could be next.So my objections to the NYT are ethical and moral. Unfortunately, they have become government hacks rather than responsible journalists.

I live in Japan, and the monthly Kindle subscription price to The New York Times is $27.99, and this includes 3G international delivery via Whispernet. However, if I subscribe to the same publication with a U.S. address, the price drops to $19.99, but if I wanted it delivered via Whispernet internationally in over 100 countries (3G & WiFi), I would have to pay $4.99 per week. Do the math, and it makes sense to subscribe with a Japan address. However, if you subscribe to multiple newspapers (which I do), it starts to make sense to subscribe with a U.S. address, and pay the $4.99 weekly fee which covers multiple publications. All this came to light when I couldn't get Reader's Digest with a Japan address ("not available in your area") and I used my U.S. address, which prompted a message on my Kindle about the international unlimited Whispernet service for periodicals at $4.99 per week. On the other hand, why can't Amazon deliver the NYT via WiFi and not charge the $4.99 which is probably prompted by fees charged by overseas 3G network carriers? Also, the system is set up to try to download on 3G networks first, and WiFi if a 3G connection can't be established, and turning off Whispernet isn't going to help since that would stop WiFi delivery too! I suppose getting a non-3G Kindle (WiFi only) might do the trick, but I'm not springing for another Kindle at this time. Or maybe the NYT should take the example from Newsday (that great Long Island newspaper which I also subscribe to), which has only one price - $14.99 for US or international delivery. The spread on the LA Times is even worse than the NYT - $9.99 domestic delivery, versus $19.99 international. So, if you subscribe to  both the LAT and NYT, use a U.S. address, and pay the $4.99 weekly charge, and you save some money.
They are charging $19.99, which is more than it costs for the print edition and it isn't even the entire paper. This is over priced.

The NYT digital subscription is like the old roach motel - you can get in but you can't get out.First problem they hit your credit card every 28 days instead of once a month.  Sneaky.  After a while you have no idea when is the end of the billing cycle (which is when you want to cancel).Second, to cancel you have to call, on a telephone.  WHY IS THAT???  Believe me, the wait is long, looong. When (if) they finally answer, the struggle begins.Third, the reps are such liars.  Mine said, "Sir, you are cutting out, I am going to have to hang up..."  and she did.  I was calling on a land line!  It was infuriating.  What am I to think of that company's reporting truth if they have such little regard for it while talking to a person?The 99 record clubs of my teenage years had more integrity than the NYT!

It's an absolute embarrassment to see The New York Times increase the subscription price from $13.99 to $19.99. Whatever genius came up with the idea of a 40% increase will be shocked to see how many NYT subscribers they will lose when our six months grace period ends, if not sooner.

Source (H): I have been subscribed to the Times on the Kindle for six months now and wanted to comment on the lay out.  They altered it last week and it is, far and away, the best lay out of all the papers.  They list the who wrote the story for every section, not just the op-ed as before.  They give more summary of the story.  And, best of all, after reading an article, the next article is right there waiting so you can see if you want to read it instead of having to hit an additional button.  It might not sound like much, but it safes a lot of time.  With the other newspapers--Post, Journal, etc.--it is difficult to find certain articles even when you know where it should be in the paper.  For example, the Post has its daily book review in the Style section.  However, it is often hard to even find the book review.  Or, if you want to read, say, Tony Kornheiser's column before he left the Post, you have to go through all of the headlines before finding it.So, I want to applaud the Times for the changes and urge the other papers, and magazines (who have the same problems), to the layout of the Times and make the changes.  We all know that the Kindle is the future, especially every day where we read about more lay offs at all the papers.  It is a cheaper alternative for the papers and eventually every magazine and newspaper is going to go to it.  I just hope they all continue to improve the lay off.And, does any one know if there is a website with information on when other newspaper or magazines are going to come to the Kindle.  Where is The New Yorker, NY Review of Books, and all the other great magazines and papers that haven't made it to the Kindle yet?  I think once a day I'm checking back, like I used to do when all the new podcasts were coming to Itunes.

There are much better sources of news.  I'll give one:  The Week.I really don't have the stomach for slanted "news" stories anymore.NYT - I've moved you to another category, much like you did for books so you could manipulate the results to match your ideology.

It's almost worth it because the NY Times is worth reading in almost any format.  But the articles are cut back, the content only updates once a day and there apparently is no Sunday paper. I am a big fan of the NY Times and see it as one of the top newspapers in the U.S.  One: $19.99 for the Kindle download covers every edition for the month.  Okay, say you miss looking at it for a day or two, that is still an excellent price.  You don't have time to read it all, no problem.  The fact is this is an everyday download.  Well worth the price.  Two, and listen up, you also get access to the NY Times on their homepage giving you the articles and the opportunity of email letters sent to your box which outline the major stories of the day, just in case your life has been particularly busy.  Like I said, downloading the NY Times through Amazon is a Double Plus.  Pass this on.

Source (H): I love the New York Times -- but I tried a trial subscription and was unable to cancel it. Am still trying, but tried my Amazon account and the New York Times subscriptions services.  I'm still trying -- but be forwarned.
I think it is bizarrely ironic that the Technology section of the NYT is not included in the Kindle edition. What the what??

I have been tremendously impressed with Kindle, and Amazon's support, until a few minutes ago when I learned that they simply expect me to lose MONTHS of my New York Times, Washington Post, and London Financial Times daily editions upon replacing my original Kindle with a new one after my original's screen developed defects. They only store 8 days of past history for these subscriptions and everything prior to that time is LOST.This is a SERIOUS deficiency in Amazon's support. I understand the need to protect the publishers copyright, however, Amazon could provide a means for users to upload their subscription library back to an Amazon utility, then have Amazon decrypt and re-encrypt their library keyed to their new hardware. Such would be the logical, and responsible, policy. As it stands I am going to have to spend the time to replace my defective display screen, from the replacement unit sent, and send back the replacement device with my original and defective screen. However, if my loss of pixels (the reason for my warranty replacement) turns out to be caused by a defect in a circuit board on the unit, rather than the display itself, I would be hosed... Or, moreover, if the unit had been utterly destroyed, even if I had backed up the data, it would be useless, encrypted, noise...Be aware, before you shell out money for subscriptions to these newspapers, that the marvelously rich research library that you are accumulating over time, is exceedingly fragile and ephemeral....
Source (K): Loss of your Newspaper Subscription Library should Kindle fail -- DRM and Encryption

Source (H): I don't know what other reviewers have been smoking to think that $13.99 per month for The New York Times is expensive.Every Sunday before my Kindle came I would pause at newsstands and look longingly at the Sunday New York Times, mentally calculating if it was worth paying four dollars for a huge, heavy, difficult to carry mass of paper that I would have to cart around on a subway and a train until I finally got it home.  The Sunday edition alone costs 52 weeks times $4 = $208 -- by comparison the Kindle version costs me $13.99 times 12 = $167 for all 365 issues.Furthermore, my Kindle edition of the New York Times is always ready and waiting for me no matter how early I wake up in the morning.  This is always nice, but particularly so on holidays when the the New York Times often sells out at the newsstands early.I find myself reading a lot more of the New York Times using my Kindle than I used to read in the pre-Kindle era.  I particularly find myself reading more of the Arts section.  Another good thing about the Kindle edition is that I find myself reading an article from start to finish, whereas there was always a great tendency to skim articles in the pre-Kindle days.The Kindle New York Times does a good job of including pictures.  They are a little fuzzy but good enough to give the general idea.It's true there are no classified ads, but it's rare I need them, so on those occasions I don't mind buying the paper edition.I also particularly like the ability on the Kindle to quickly look up the meaning of a word in the New York Times I don't understand.I can't think of any better way to quickly and methodically gain an in depth understanding of the world around us, than to subscribe  to the Kindle edition of the New York Times.  It's a truly great newspaper.
Source (K): Great price for a great newspaper

Source (H): I didn't purchase the Kindle 1 because of its poor reviews for reading newspapers. I expected this would be fixed in version 2, and I'm delighted to say it was.  Therefore, although I've subscribed to daily delivery of the NYT for more than 40 years, I canceled my paper subscription and subscribed on my Kindle. I have been paying $13.40 per week or $696.80 a year.  With the Kindle, I am now paying $167.88 a year. Therefore, even in Year 1, after spending over $400 with the cover and extended warranty for the Kindle, I will be saving more than $100 and over $500 each subsequent year.Pros:* You get to finish the front page and all other stories that are continued elsewhere without having to turn to page X and then back to the front page. ( I've generally read the FP articles I was interested in and then turned through the rest of the first section, picking up the articles as I went through the section). How many times have you not finished an article because you didn't have time to go through the paper?*Articles for each section are easily sorted so you can pick the ones you are interested in and then return to the list* YOU CAN ADJUST THE FONT. For me and other older, visually challenged readers, that's a huge plus.* Just as a blackberry enables me to keep all of my contact and schedule data in one place, the kindle does the same for the majority of what I will be reading.* It is like reading a book, not at all like reading a computer screen with back lighting that tires your eyes* Easier reading experience= more reading* With the ability to turn a page with the touch of a finger, easier to eat while reading. Furthermore, if you like to read the paper in bed while your spouse is sleeping, there is no noise from page turning.Cons:*I find the "black flash" when you turn a page somewhat annoying. I've gotten in the habit of looking away for a second when I hit the next page button to avoid this. Ideally the new page should appear without any flash* It's slightly heavier than I would prefer but the size is perfect.* The web access feature is experimental and did not work when I tried a simple search using google.* You can't email an article directly from the kindle. You have to download clipping to your computer with usb cable.It's not perfect, but it's a better reading experience than the paper version and, if you're a NYT subscriber a money saver as well.
The best of the Kindle newspapers with a great format. I could not stay with it because of its editorial stance.

With the new policy initiated by The New York Times, Kindle subscribers to that newspaper will not be able to access the Times online more than twenty times a month while iPad users and many cellphone users will have unlimited online digital access.  Having a Kindle subscription to The New York Times is, therefore, of greatly diminished value.  For that reason, unless full digital access is included in The New York Times Kindle subscription, I will cancel my subscription.  I am very disappointed that Amazon Kindle dropped the ball here.  Their service in providingThe New York Timesis now greatly inferior to that of the iPad.
Source (K): N ew York Times Kindle Subscription limits online access

Source (H): The download is very inconsistent. Many times the paper does not come for a few days. Because of this I am cancelling my subscription.

I currently pay $35 a month for a six-day subscription to the print edition. The Kindle edition only costs $14 a month. So, if the Kindle edition of the NYT can replace my print subscription, the Kindle pays for itself in just over a year and a half and I get the Sunday NYT 'for free'. Beyond that, the Kindle edition doesn't involve killing trees or using noxious chemicals to turn them into paper, and beaming my paper to me every morning takes a lot less fossil fuel than trucking trees to a mill, trucking paper to a press, then delivering the printed paper to my driveway. Plus, I never have to go out in the cold or the rain to find my paper in the bushes or under my car; I should never have to deal with a missed paper, which happens once or twice a month with my delivery service; I never have to suspend delivery when I go on a trip; and my newspaper will actually go with me.So, I have a lot of incentive to like the NYT on the Kindle.After three days, I'm still not sure if I do.On the plus side, my biggest worry before my Kindle arrived turns out to be a non-starter. I wondered how I'd take to reading the news on a screen only a few paragraphs big. As promised, this is not an issue. After a very short time, you don't really notice the paging any more than you notice turning the page of a book, or moving your eyes to the next column. I've read a whole novel without any annoyance, and actually find the comfortably sized Kindle less of a hassle than a broadsheet newspaper. (My SO is looking forward to no more piles of old newspapers on the kitchen table, even if that means our 13 yo won't be reading the paper any more.)Also, I find I really don't miss the experience of flipping through the paper, looking for those interesting stories that didn't make the front page. You can browse section by section, and paging through a section a story at a time is really not bad.You can store a lot of days worth of news in a stock Kindle, and can search them all quickly; you can store even more if you add a cheap SD card. In the unlikely event that the Times uses a word you don't know, you can quickly look it up with the Kindle's great search feature.On the minus side, comparing my print edition to the Kindle edition, I can see that the print edition includes stories that the Kindle edition does not. I'm really not sure quite what to make of this: so far, at least, I'm actually reading more of the paper than I used to, because I can carry my Kindle to work and read articles in dead time. It's hard to know how to balance not even seeing some stories vs reading a lot more of them. (I do know that I really miss the Market Gauges pages even if, realistically, I only look at them a few times a month.)A less ambiguous minus is the pictures, which (to use a technical term) really suck. They're hard to make out, and there's a max of one per story, no matter how many there are in the print version. Even worse, many of the pictures and - so far as I can see - ALL the charts and graphs are omitted. This hurts business coverage; I haven't seen a Science Section yet, but I imagine this will be really painful.So. Convenience, greenness, and economics vs the loss of maybe 15% of the content. This is a hard call, for me, and I sure wish the NYT would make it easier by including the missing content.
Source (K): Very good, but could be better

Source (H): I subscribed to NYTimes on my Kindle, and stopped my paper subscription - savings approach $200/year.I am not concerned about proprietary format, since I always dispose of newspapers daily. My re-cycle is dramatically reduced, which is great, and I don't have to go out into the driveway in my nightgown to get the paper. Source (H): I have been a Kindle NY time reader for over a year, but when I tried to gift a subscription to my mother for her Kindle for Christmas, I ended up being out $240 because gift cards can't be used for subscriptions, nor will they give me my money back, nor do anything whatsoever to try to make it right. I am cancelling my own NY times Kindle subscription, moving over to iPad, and never looking back. I predict Kindles will go the way of blackberries and Palm pilots, and that no one will be reading book or periodical content from Amazon two year from now.Below is the transcript of my chat with Amazon customer service reps.You are now connected to Anthony from Amazon.com.Me: I want to use my gift card (balance of $194 or so) is the payment method for my new york times subscription.Them: Hello Rachel. My name is [name removed]. I'll be happy to help you. Let me see what I can do here.Me: Ok. this is Jason, on behalf of Rachel. Rachel is my mother, and I gave her the gift card to buy the new york times with, but we can't figure out how to make it apply.I gave her the gift card for $240 for a 1-year subscription. Since then, three other purchases have dropped the balance down to $194, but I can make up the difference with another credit card.Them:I have looked into this matter and found that a gift card cannot be used on a Kindle subscription because it is a recurring bill. A gift card can only be used on a single charge purchase, but not on any purchase that will have a recurring bill.Me:then we'd' like to use it for a one-year, single purchase, subscription, rather than for a recurring one.Them:The Kindle New York Times subscription is charged on a monthly basis. A full year subscription cannot be purchased at this time, but I can get some feedback submitted to see if that is something we can get added in the near future.Me:This is not acceptable.Them:I am very sorry for the inconvenience. Let me get you to a Kindle Specialist who may have more options available.A Customer Service Associate will be with you in a moment.You are now connected to Dev from Amazon.com.Them :Hello, my name is [name removed]. I'll be happy to help you today.Me:Thank you. Have you seen the chat history with [previous guy]?Them:Would you mind if I put you on hold for a minute or two while I check your previous conversation?Me:i don't mindThem:Thanks for waiting, Jason.May I know whether the subscription was charged before adding the Gift card balance in your Amazon.com account?Me:The order was: 1) I gifted her the $240 gift. 2) She subscribed to NY times. 3) after the 14 days, she was automatically billed to her amazon visa, because we couldn't figure out how to buy it out right and charge it to the gift card. The purpose of the gift card was because I couldn't figure out how to gift her a one-year subscription outright. So I gifted her the amount of the subscription.Them:Any gift card balance available on your account will be applied to purchases from the Kindle Store, except for content with recurring subscription charges.Me:So, how do we apply this gift card balance to this gift, then?Them:May I place you on hold for 1 to 2 minutes while I check this for you?Me:yes pleaseThem:Thanks for waiting, R....Are you referring to the subscription as gift or the Gift card balance as gift, Jason?Me:The gift was intended to be a 1-year subscription to the NY Times, which I would renew next christmas if she wants it, or else not. However....I couldn't figure out how to gift her this from my own amazon account, where i saw, then (I think) that the yearly subscription rate was $240. This was in December. So....instead, I gifted her a $240 amazon gift card, electronically, delivered to her e-mail address.Then, we tried to redeem the gift card for the NY times subscription, but it looked like we had to do the 1st 14 days free bit, so we couldn't provide the gift card as form of payment then. I told her to let me know once the 14 days was up and we'd figure out then how to apply the gift card to the intended gift--the NY Times subscription.So, she has let me know that it is time to do so, however, I see that it is billing her amazon visa instead. Meanwhile, other purchases she has made (3 shirts) which she intended to use the amazon visa for, instead drew down the balance of the gift card.Them:I'm sorry, Jason. At this time only Kindle books can be given as gifts. The Kindle gifting feature does not support periodicals, active content, free books, or Kindle books on preorder.Gift card balance cannot be applied on the subscriptions.Me:That being the case, I would like my $240 dollars back, please, and I'll buy her an e-subscription to NY times that she can read on her ipad.Can you help me with this?Them:I'm sorry, Jason. Since the purchase was made using the available Gift card balance in your Amazon.com account, our system won't allow us to refund the Gift card balance.Me:I don't understand....what purchase?Them:Three purchases was made from this Amazon.com account and the amount was deducted from the Gift card balance. Hence our systems won't allow us to refund the gift card balance.Me:What can you do for me then?Can we apply the gift card balance to her amazon.com visa account?Them:Please be on hold. Let me check what possible I can do for you.Me:HoldingThem: Thanks for waiting.Me:OKThem: I'm sorry, Jason. Since the Gift card balance was already used, it is not possible to issue refund or transfer the gift card to another account.Me:What will be possible, then?Them: Using the gift card balance in the same account is the only option. If you'd prefer, I can either turn off the auto renew for subscription or cancelling it completely.Me:Dev, do you care about the satisfaction of Amazon customers?Them:I can understand your concern, Jason. However, our systems won't allow us to change the Amazon policies. This is the reason I'm unable to do anything. I tried to check and do the possible for you. But our systems won't allow us to do that. I'm really sorry for any inconvenience.Me:My question was whether you are interested in the satisfaction of your customers. Are you?Them:Yes, ofcourse.But in this case, I'm unable to do anything from my end, Jason.Me:Ok, I am having an extremely unsatisfying experience, so I know that must be as upsetting to you, as it is to me. Correct?If you were me, would you be satisfied with this outcome?You can just imagine how helpless my elderly, mostly homebound mother must feel.You mention that the "systems" won't let you create a solution that will be satisfactory. Correct?Them:Our systems work as per our Amazon policy and won't make us any change to the Amazon.com Policy. This is the reason I'm unable to do anything from my end. I can understand your concern and even I would have felt the same. However, out system won't allow us to make any changes to make it work breaking the Amazon policy.I'll forward your concern to our Kindle development team and we'll consider your feedback as we plan further improvements. We're regularly working on improvements to your Kindle experience. Your valuable feedback will help us to improve the selection and service we provide.Me:Systems may be programmed to enforce policies, but policies are created by people. Are there people there who are authorized to make exceptions to, or override policies, when those policies don't make sense? Or, are their policies for, or decision makers who are authorized to, make things right for unsatisfied customers?If so, I would very much appreciate, ..., if you could put me in touch with one of those people. As it is, you are the only person I "know" at Amazon.Besides...., of course, who was good enough to put me in touch with you when he realizedhe was not in a position to help me.Them:If you'd prefer, I can connect you for a call and let they transfer the call to the appropriate department and let they check what possible they can do. But I'm unable to do anything from my end, Jason.Could you provide me your phone number so that I can connect you for a call now?Me:Certainly..... Will you be able to provide them this transcript, or must I start from the beginning.Them:You can ask them to check the chat conversation. All our chat conversation are stored in our systems.I'll connect you for a call now. Please be on hold.Me:Thank you.Them:You're welcome, Jason.Connecting your call.Your call is now connected. Could you please confirm it, Jason?Are we still connected?Our chat has now been idle for 1 minute. If there isn't anything else I can help you with, then the chat will be disconnected automatically. The phone representative will be able to see the conversation once our chat is over. Thank you, Dev.Thank you for contacting Kindle support.Them from Amazon.com has left the conversation.Them from Amazon.com has left the conversation.I was connected to [name removed] via phone who told me there was nothing she could do to help me.

Source (H): I was very surprised and disappointed to learn recently that my Kindle edition of The New York Times was missing editorial opinion pieces.  The most recent example is an op ed article by Roger Cohen which appeared in the print edition on April 20, 2009 but was not included in my Kindle edition.  The only reason I know this is because a friend sent me an email with comments on the article, which of course I hadn't read.I have known for the 16 months that I have been subscribing to the Times on the Kindle that I have not been getting things like the weather tables, sports scores and standings, and the crossword puzzle, and although I don't understand why you don't provide that information, since you do provide pictures and other images, at least you warned me about it when I subscribed.But random missing content is very disquieting, particularly since I don't know what else I am missing.  Kindle should either tell its subscribers specifically what content is not included, or, preferably, Kindle should fix the problem.I have been complaining about this issue for awhile, and until now your representatives have told me that the Times is responsible for content, not Kindle. (Therea in your leadership group at least understood my problem today.)  But I am contracting for the Times with Kindle, and you have a responsibility to me and your other subscribers to provide the product advertised.  You are not doing that now

Source (H): The Kindle edition of the New York Times solves a big problem for me...I no longer have to decide between either lugging a laptop around or sitting at my computer to read the New York Times and purchasing an enormous amount of paper to recycle.  As all of us Kindle lovers know, reading a Kindle is as pleasurable as reading a book curled up on the couch and now I can get the latest Times edition w/o the aforementioned problems.  I do agree that the $13.99 price is a bit steep and would much rather see $9.99 but in all honesty, I don't mind spending the additional $3.99 because in the long run it will encourage the industry to support the Kindle which is (I think) the most marvelous invention since the proverbial sliced bread.This is the future...and I am embracing it!

I love the convenience and pricing, and I do find myself reading more of the paper because the Kindle is so easy to carry with me at all times.  But the description of this subscription implies that all the content in the print edition is included except for crosswords, tables, graphs, etc.  This is not true, however.  This morning, for example, two of my favorite op-ed columnists, Maureen Dowd and Thomas Friedman, have columns in the on line edition, but neither appears on my Kindle edition.  I have also noticed that a hockey blog I like to read, Slap Shot, is not always included.  So I can't say I am totally satisfied.  I'd love to know how to contact the NYT directly regarding this issue.

While not perfect, this app is VERY good on the Kindle- especially the Fire. Great color photos with some articles, easy to use interface and an enormous amount of content EVERY day. Not everything in the paper, but the vast majority of it. The best news journalism that exists.But I just dropped it from my Kindle as a protest against the cost. I am a weekend (F,S,S) print subscriber which costs me about $40 month. Everyone in the house can read their favorite sections at their leisure and we can all share it at the same time. As much as E-Readers are great, it is also nice to have a real paper, the glossy magazine, and smell of newsprint.As a weekend subscriber, I get free access to the full, unlimited NYT web version on my PCs, which is VERY good- even better than the print version when it comes to photos and graphics and way better than the Kindle version as it contains many more photos, videos, articles, archives, and as superior navigation. You can get an 8-week subscription currently for 99 cents to all of their digital editions, including iPad (but NOT E-readers like the Kindle for some reason)which includes access to the web version.So, to continue on the Kindle, I would have to pay $20/month for the Kindle version on top of the $40/month I am already paying for home delivery on weekends. For less than that combined cost, I could get 7-day/week home delivery and get more content with more flexibility and the ability to share it with the entire household.The bottom line for me is that while the Kindle version of the NYT is very good, it is NOT as good as the web or print versions, and it is overpriced- especially if you get any form of home delivery of the print version.
Source (K): One of the best things on Kindle- and why I dropped it

Source (H): Purchased a Kindle2 and subscribed to the NY Times. One goal was to avoid the 1/4 mile walk to the mailbox to get the paper, another was to get rid of the piles of old newspapers which also have to be hauled 1/4 mile to be recycled. Key to this was getting a REAL NY Times electronically.Close, but not quite yet. The reading experience has been fairly good onthe Kindle2...and the paper is on my device when I wake up in the morning.However, very valuable sections are missing. For example, on Friday's paper the Broadway theatre listing was missing, while the classical and dance sections were there. These weekend activities are an important part of the Times value to subscribers (at least in the NY area) and need to be included.  A few more photos would be nice too : the real estate and weddings sections have none. Both of these are cases where a photo adds value to the story.With just a little more work, it would be a great substiture for the hardcopy paper.Amazon,  PLEASE PLEASE work with the NY Times to get it better. Both products would be better as a result.

While I am generally pleased with the Kindle edition of the paper and find the daily delivery extremely convenient, the Sunday Magazine STINKS on the Kindle, and I'd really appreciate an explanation as to why.  Articles from the magazine are mysteriously missing in the Kindle edition from time to time, and the remaining articles often appear out of order (though the order has improved - mostly - over the past 6 months).This weekend however I got riled up all over again: The 12/26/2010 Sunday Magazine was OMITTED from the Kindle edition completely!!  This is the "Lives They Lived" issue which is a special one that admittedly includes many pictures, but the essays themselves are also important and exactly what I wanted to read.  Can it really be so hard to upload that text??What's even more galling is that there was NO EXPLANATION -- no "Kindle Edition Note" or email to subscribers explaining that a major section of the paper wasn't included. The Sunday Magazine is one of the main reasons that I subscribe to the Times versus another paper, and knowing what is and isn't included would allow me to make an informed decision about my subscription. Yet there is no communication. Harumph.

Generally pleased with my subscription but VERY annoyed that, in contrast to the description that it will include NYT articles sans graphs, charts and crossword--what you're not told and I tried very hard to find out before ordering--is that several articles are omitted from each edition and sometimes the articles that are included abruptly end, chopping off the final few sentences or paragraph. Yesterday's Sunday edition (Aug 24) only had 3 articles from the Book Review--a fraction of that section. This flaw needs work fixing or NYT need to state the subscription contents clearly.

I'm all for digital content and long ago gave up on reading the print edition of the NY Times. When I heard I could have the Times delivered to my Kindle I was thrilled since reading on the Kindle is far nicer than reading on a laptop. Then I actually tried the Kindle version and was VERY disappointed.The problem is the content - or to be more accurate the LACK of content. Simply put, your subscription fee on Kindle gives you only a very tiny slice of the NY Times. For example, the December 25ht, 2009 edition contains a paltry 6 articles for the Front Page section. Furthermore, several sections are completely missing. In a rather ironic twist, two of the missing sections are the Technology and Books sections - go figure! Also missing are Science, Health, Education, Automobiles, and several other sections. The **free** NY Times site contains over 2 dozen sections while the **paid** Kindle version contains only 9 sections. Seems odd that a paid subscription should result in less content. I get that there are costs associated with delivering digital content but I find it hard to believe that the costs are that much higher than delivering the NY Times content. Some of this is no doubt due to the lack of advertisements on the Kindle version but given a choice between more content with ads or less content without ads I'll put up with the ads anytime.While the promise of a Kindle edition is great the actual execution comes up very short. For now I'll stick to the free on-line edition. When the decide to give me a more complete edition of the Times on Kindle I'll happily pay for it.
Source (K): VERY limited version of the NY Times - stick to the free site.

Source (H): Love the Kindle.  Really liked the idea of being able to read the NYT during commutes and the quiet early morning hours.  It just doesn't measure up, cost/ content wise tho. If you don't have a color Kindle - charts, photos, etc are problematic.  Thatextra content (photos etc) are limited in number compared to NYT.com or the print version.  And why doesn't the Kindle subscription give me access full access to NYT.com beyond the free 20 (soon to be 10) articles everyone can get?Far cheaper and better is to get a home delivery (which includes full access to NYT.com on your PC)  or a digital sucscription to read from your PC.Oddly enough, that home delivery or digital subscription includes access from your phone or ipad, but *NOT* your Kindle, you have to have a separate subscription for that. Makes no sense.  Can't reccommend it until one subscription covers **everything**
The Times used to be a respected newspaper but no more. If you care about fair and balanced reporting then stay away from the New York Times.
