Source (H): Very simplistic writing.  Lack of contractions, sentence structure errors and a few other things made for an awkward read.

The NEW BREED is an unsual story for me but one that I found exciting and very entertaining.  It is about a college girl who gets dumped before she does the dumping and proceeds to get drunk.  On her way home her adventure starts or does it?  Did she imagine the flames coming out of a guys mouth at a dark shadowy substance or was it real?This story is action packed and leaves you wanting more.  I highly recommend it for anyone who likes books about dragons, demons, ordinary people, beings of pure evil, knights and who knows what else.  It was a joy to read and has definitely earned the 5 star rating I gave it.

Though there are some errors in this book that are distracting it was a very quick and enjoyable read.  It's clear the writer is a novice, but one that has great potential. For a free book I can't complain! I've read some HORRIBLE books by young indie authors but this is by far one of the best I've come across. Unfortunately, so many poorly written books are available now because self publishing and independent writing is much easier thanks to technology. That's why detailed and helpful reviews are important. Despite the spelling and grammar errors this book kept my attention. One other reviewer complained about the use of "Anyways". That, I didn't have a problem with - this is a young adult novel, and young adults use very poor grammar and commonly use "anyways" as an accepted word. That I felt was just the author identifying with the audience and being age appropriate with how her main characters talk. It's more so the sentence fluency, structure and spelling errors that tend to bother me - which wasn't THAT big of a problem here. Though the Colton relationship was annoying, as others have said, it's very typical for teenagers and young adults to act like they were and be that immature. The fact that the relationship annoyed me means that it was well developed - at least it made me FEEL something. I even shed a few tears for the main character at one point. I connected with many of the characters in the book and was rooting for them at the end.Despite the lack of writing experience this author may have, she was able to tell a great story in a way that kept me coming back for more. Grammar skills are easy to learn - great story telling is not. Her character and story development was well done and she has me anxiously waiting for the next book in the series. That, for a young self published author, is a huge accomplishment. With a good editor this author could produce five star novels.
Source (K): Clearly a novice writer, but one with great potential

Source (H): Do not subscribe to this. I have a Kindle Fire and was looking forward to getting magazines that are hard to find in my area. I signed up for Yoga Journal at the end of November and received the issue listed as November 1st. Since then I have been charged twice and have yet to ever see another issue. My understanding is that this is a Bi-Monthly magazine, I thought that meant 2 issues a month.  At this rate I would have been lucky to see 2 issues in one year! To buy the current issue it costs $2.99. I signed up for a free 14 day trial period, and then pay $1.67 a month to have it automatically downloaded to my Fire. After 2 1/2 months I have paid $3.34 and have only received one issue. Who knows, maybe it will get better later on. I just don't want to see how much money they will take from me before it gets there.

I love getting Yoga Journal on my Kindle, but the Kindle subscription is slower than traditional print. For example, the current Yoga Journal issue has been out in print for a couple weeks (it's everywhere I go), but the Kindle version is still stuck on last month's magazine. Very disappointing.

I love receiving the Yoga Journal magazine through my Kindle. I haven't had to wait at all for my copy. You do have to sync your Kindle to receive your current issue, but that's not a problem. I plan on getting all my subscription thru Amazon to my Kindle once the paper version expires. I'm not fond of the digital download thru my email on the print version. Amazon & Kindle are great, no waiting for me at all.

Plus, you have to scroll past countless ads just to get to any content. Maxim on the Fire is useless if you want to comfortably read the magazine. But if all you want are the pictures, then it's great. I gave it two stars instead of one because the photos look great. If I was rating it on legibility, then I'd have to go with one star. I was really enjoying this magazine until I noticed a few errors. I tried to ignore them, but I just couldn't anymore after I found this last one in "The Meaning of 'Meaning'". Excerpt: "...it might be the best reason to suspect that I had no located no real meaning at all." Did you spot it? It hit me like a freight train. Maybe I'm just being picky, but I expect better from something I'm paying to read. I haven't yet decided if I will keep my subscription. Source (H): I have subscribed to this magazine for approximately two years.  I have also visited the magazine's discussion group forum on its subscriber site.  So, I am familiar with the magazine and how its editorial staff conducts itself in internet discussions.  My personal background is as a trial attorney, and my undergraduate background was in physics.  I have spent years studying philosophy, science, history, etc., and am not a novice to philosophy and its methods by any means.  I just wanted people to know my background and experience with this magazine, so one would know the basis for my remarks.  First of all, the magazine is always late, so don't count on getting the current monthly issue for at least an additional month.  The quality of the articles is poor, and it is not clear to me if anyone who writes for the magazine actually has a background in philosophy, science, history, or any of the subject areas that they comment on.  As an example of the overly simplistic thinking this magazine endorses, there is a running column from one author who flops around from making the claim that morality exists, and then claims morality does not exist.  His solution to the abortion issue is to just let the people involved work it out.  The author is seemingly unaware of the likelihood that the "people involved," may not be able to reach an agreement, and the major issue with abortion is whether the unborn child has any standing at all.  Does the unborn child count or not?  Apparently, overlooking such moral issues is considered to be a sign of brilliance on the part of the author and the editorial staff.  If one has a serious interest in philosophy, then one would be better off looking elsewhere.  Do not even get me started on the magazine's discussion group.  There, Rick Lewis himself publicly stated that the claim by one user, that the "Jews control the entire US economy and the banks," was NOT anti-semitic.  The editors of this magazine seem to have a great deal of sympathy for anti-semitism, American-bashing, socialism, racism, sexism, etc., as evidenced by the membersship they promote in its forum discussion group.  Anyone wanting to support this magazine, should be aware that the editorial staff has the "intellectual" level of what one may find on numerous hate sites throughout the net.  A silly magazine; written by silly people.

Let's face it the real point of kindles is to read free books. However, not every free book is worth it but Albert Robbins III changes all that. This father of six reviews many books for us and lays down what he thinks of them straightforwardly. He is not cruel with his opinion but his very honest. An amazing reviewer and one worth reading.

The author of the blog is very supportive of indie authors and not only offers reviews but interviews as well.  The reviews tend to be short but to the point, which I appreciate.  It's more like talking to a friend about a book they have read than having someone try to analyze it for you and the interviews tend to not be the standard Q&A fare.

The book was published early last century, but the ebook format is clean (not scanned and transcribed) and contains hyperlinks to notes and a linked table of contents.  If you're just looking to read through the events of Jesus' life put in order, it is an excellent free resource, and I'm grateful for it!  If you're a more serious student (grad school or semenary, say) you might look for something more recent.I was hoping for a very readable harmony of the gospels (for free).  This is a little too crowded with notes for that purpose, so you'll have to skip past them on your way through the reading of Jesus' life.  That's not to say that the notes are all that bad.  The notes I find most helpful or enjoyable are the notes about times and dates and places, of which this version has as much as any harmony I've found.I would give it 5 stars for the gospel content, the Word is the greatest gift to mankind, who is Jesus Himself as the gospel writer John points out.  But I give it 4 since I've enjoyed easier reading features in other versions, such as bolded main narratives where there exists parallel narratives, and less obtuse footnotes.
Source (K): A fine free version, though it's notes can get in the way

Source (H): A wonderful story set in Dublin, Ireland, that starts with the main character Fionn (a name taken from legend), as a young boy, his imagination is really well captured as he tries to make sense of the tangled lives of his grown up relatives, as well as endure a terrible ordeal. Thirty years later, after returning from exile, Fionn has to start all over again, with women, life and his own character. The arrival of J.F. Kennedy and his wayward family is the tipping point for Finn to make changes.  This book is so well written, it skips along like a dance. Thoroughly enjoyed it, now going to look at this author's other book.

At first, I didn't really know what to expect but the description and sample seemed interesting enough so I decided to give it a chance. I am very glad that I did as the book went way above and beyond my initial expectations and has left me with a new author to keep an eye on.What I admire most about this book is the well-refined, clean writing style that articulates the entire story in a way that even the most critical readers could appreciate. The story is creative and imaginative, playing out in a way much different than the trend that most others follow. I don't want to give away too many spoilers but I would like to add that the ending is something that I haven't seen before in a book and I had no idea that is was going to play out like that, if you've read the book already then you will know exactly what I mean.Usually, if an author tries something original it doesn't always go to plan but I think President Fionn is a prime example of those rare hits or 'hidden gems' that most of us are always on the hunt for. I will definitely be keeping an eye out for more releases by Christine Mary Flemming.

Having lived in Ireland, I can fully relate to how the author has created suchwonderful story.The characters are lager than life, the likes you would often come across in real life, if you ever visited Dublin.With a style of writing that has a way of transforming you back to a time of an innocent Ireland that was only beginning to wake to the changes of a new era.In all this is a magical story full of adventures and one that should be high on yourlist of reads
Source (K): Should be high on your reading list

Source (H): "President Fionn" is a layered character novel sharing with us the life of a young boy named Fionn, who is a gentle daydreamer who loves to read. He lives in Dublin with his mother and sister, abandoned by his father, and he is surrounded by a colorful family. His mother pushes his sister to marry a man she doesn't love for a secure future, and Fionn idolizes his grandfather despite some indications that he's not as perfect as Fionn wants him to be. However, his grandfather does have one excellent trait--he believes in Fionn and insists the young man will grow up to be president of America.When Fionn is shocked by his childhood innocence by a chain of violence, he remains a dreamer, but one who is detached and removed from most life situations. As an adult, he returns to the scene of his childhood, dealing with unsavory and ungrateful family members; he also fixates on President Kennedy--the charisma and message of hope the man brings, something that Fionn desperately need--and follows the leader around Ireland, waiting to be noticed.The strength and great interest of "President Fionn" is in its characters; while the plot is interesting and keeps the pages turning, it is Fionn himself who provides the heart of the book and engages the reader's empathy and sympathy. He is a complex, likeable character who invokes pity at times and hope at others, especially in his adult years. Fionn's mother, sister, and other family members are also multifaceted and almost come alive off the page, while Father Mahey is a cold and chilling villain in the way he preys on others. I would recommend this novel to those who enjoy character studies, coming of age novels, and novels set during the Kennedy era.
Source (K): Compelling Characters that Live Off of the Page

Source (H): Complex and rewarding work from a true storyteller. A real gem of a novel, this book celebrates the human spirit's ability to triumph through belief and creativity. Fionn is a charismatic character that I related to a lot. The author captures the daydreamy quality of childhood very well.  He lives in Dublin with his mother and sister and was abandoned by his father. The complex way we see his grandfather --through Fionn's loving eyes is only part of the story, but an important one, because the way his grandfather believes in Fionne is life-defining and a real reminder that we can positively impact others by having faith in them.Fionn's life in Ireland is harrowing in many ways, and the visceral impact of that is well told. Having President Kennedy enter the story was a brilliant and captivating premise. As the personification of the better aspects of the American Dream coming back to visit his ancestral homeland, by focusing on President Kennedy Fionn is able to do the same in a sense...tap into and reclaim inspiration and the best aspects of his family as he find his way to his own internal homecoming by chasing after Kennedy. It's a coming of age story plus a lot more.Fantastic plot, themes and characters mark this novel, and I'd highly recommend it as a good read that will leave you feeling like you understand yourself, your childhood and how to connect with others a little better.

Christine Flemming draws you in with Fionn's sure voice and sense of place and time-- Ireland in the 1930s through the 60s--I honestly feel like I've spent the last 36 hours in Ireland. A place I never knew I wanted to go but one that I longed to go back to five minutes after I finished the book. I can't remember the last time a book has so completely transported me to a different time and place. The world that Ms. Flemming has created will stick with me for a long while and I couldn't be happier about it. I find the best books contain characters we can connect with and relate to. The speed with which Ms. Flemming is able to establish a connection between the reader and Fionn is seriously impressive. This book is emotional, so be prepared to put your whole heart into it. This is not a lollipop and merry-go-round tinted revisiting of one's youth, but rather a very honest examination of a young boy being introduced to the world in a very harsh way. Watching Fionn as he comes to understand that he will always have to navigate through the good and bad in life, and then the subsequent realization that he has the strength to do so, is heart-warming and inspiring. Fionn is a good kid that will grow into a good man, but not without a lot of pain, hardship, loss, and hard work. Those he trusts most betray him and basically abandon him when he needs them the most. Those who would help don't know how. And it's up to Fionn to find a way to grow into the man his grandfather always believed he would be. He's a guy you can't help but root for.

President Fionn has renewed my interest in reading the classics. I read with great excitement and anticipation of the many adventures found in this story of many twists and turns. Reading this novel also revived my childlike fascination with a great story. I had it downloaded onto my Kindle and was very pleased with the quality and ease of reading from a screen rather than on paper. I now am pursuing other classics of literature that meet my interest.Clearly this book remains one of the best books out there regarding adventure. Anyone who is a fan of the adventure genre will see where all of our expectations for a great adventure story came from. The language may be a bit of a challenge to younger readers, but in spite of this,I highly recommend this book for readers 14 and up.

Mixing Irish angst and American politics up in in the cup of a young boy's life is a marvelous idea and is done very well in this novel. It plays along and moves very well from innocence to betrayal to resolution and revolution of character and plot. I would recommend it as a raining day, Saturday afternoon,  read by the fire book,  but not as bed time story, because you won't want to put it down, and will never get to sleep.

This book is amazing. The main character is someone you get to know and feel for. The story line is about  a young Irish Boy named Fionn and the trails he goes through with his family. When Fionn returns to Ireland, so does the bad memories. in a way he is kind of starting his life over with the adventure and romance. Things pick up for him when President Kennedy comes to town. Fionn hops on his motorcycle and follows the President on his tour of the country. The story is well-written and developed creating a smooth read and a realistic story.I highly recommend this book to anyone that enjoys a good read.

When Fionn, now in mid-life, returns to his childhood home in Ireland he finds some unexpected things.  While there President Kennedy happens to be visiting the country, and Fionn falls in to follow him and his entourage.  Reflections on his childhood, his father and grandfather, lead him to places he never anticipated.  A clean writing style with good character development, flow of story, setting, and authentic conversations between characters.  Definitely recommended!

I wasn't quite sure what to expect when I first started this book but the beautifully written story had me zipping right through as fast as I could just to learn how Fionn's adventures would end.The main character, Fionn, is quite an extraordinary fellow and you genuinely empathize with him throughout his journey.  He is such a gentle soul that you just cringe when he is put in undesirable situations and you imagine what it is like for him.I liked the time jump from the 1930s to the 1960s and from an child Fionn to an adult Fionn.  It really added an extra dimension to the story that give it so much more depth and feeling.I also loved how Kennedy and his visit to Ireland was woven into the story.  It makes the entire thing feel somehow more real and poignant, especially with this year being the fiftieth anniversary of his assassination.The ending was certainly an intriguing twist that I did not expect.  It was truly a mark of the author's brilliance that it was such a genuine revelation.I was quite pleased with this book and I highly recommend it.  I'm certainly looking forward to future releases by the author.

Rating: 9.0/10.0Review: Having always wanted to visit Ireland and see it's sites, this book was immediately interesting to me. The way the author describes the characters, the scenery, and the story kept me intrigued for the duration. She does a really good job at keeping you reading, and I don't have any doubts that other historical fiction fans would enjoy this book. I also enjoyed the points in the story where US politics and Irish upbringings merged. It was definitely intriguing.Reviewed by IABookReviews.com

This is a fascinating story that spans over thirty years, from 1930s Dublin, Ireland to the swinging sixties in 1963. At the beginning Fionn is on his way back to Dublin after spending the best part of his life in the country. He has the right to be uncomfortable about returning, as he has some bad memories to face there. Times have changed and Fionn is a fish out of water, but when President Kennedy arrives in Dublin, in the June of that year, things start to happen for him in an almost mythical fashion. It is as if Fionn is starting life over, romance, adventure, new ways of thinking all combine to shake him up. I had no inkling of where it would lead and loved the crisp, light, moving way this author writes. Very funny at times and deeply moving.

Interesting subject and great characterizations. “President Fionn” is filled with lively, colorful characters who illuminate a fascinating time in Irish history (and world history!). Spanning 30 years, from Dublin during the depression to the swinging 60s.Fionn is an Irish boy (dubbed ‘president’ by his doting grandfather) surrounded by the turmoil and upheavals of the mid-twentieth century.  Though a dreamer by nature,  Fionn can’t help but become caught up in the times and is especially fascinated with President John F Kennedy, who he follows hoping to be noticed by the great man.What a wonderful tale of Irish life, the love and pain that comes with close families, and the dreamer that we all want to love.  Christine Mary Flemming has written a tale of hope for the future and entanglement with the past that will resonate with readers. I look forward to reading more of her books!
Source (K): Swinging 60s, JFK and an Ending You Won't See Coming!

Source (H): I wasn’t familiar with this author until I read this story, but I definitely plan to check out some of Ms. Flemming’s other books! I loved the plot, the pacing, and the characters. This quote is what I think is a great example of the author’s ability to paint a very clear picture of the main character, Fionn, and his family:“Fionn’s mother liked to tell everyone that his father had gone off to America to find work and had dropped his family like a bad smell, but he knew that was a lie. His father had really gone to Africa on an adventure, and had been killed by a raging lion who had toothache from all the sweets he’d found in the pocket of another fella he’d eaten.”Unexpected twists in the plot, and unanticipated ending. Colorful, relate-able characters. Interesting undertones of historical and cultural commentary, especially for an American (such as myself) who has studied this era but only from the perspective of American history.I’m so glad I read this book and I recommend it without reservation!

The author of this book acted very interesting story about eight year old boy called Fionn, who has i big dream... I will not say anything more, leaving readers to experience the book. Many thanks to author Christine :D

This book has amazingly been both heartbreaking and heartwarming. It takes you on a road down tragedy and the struggle of a soul to survive that tragedy, with unexpected and at first unwelcome help from the family he tried so hard to forget. The path Fionn takes leads him not only to discover the flaws and illusions he has created about himself, but about the people around him. Set in 1930s and 1960s Ireland was a historical breath of fresh air, both fascinating and enlightening. The characters will enthrall you, as you see how their lives unfold and how Fionn overcomes his past to realize his childhood dream. I would highly recommend this book to anyone, and hope to see more from Christine Mary Flemming in the future.

This book is about an amazing eight-year-old little boy. His name is Fionn. He wants to make the trip to America from Ireland. Fionn will end up on amazing adventures that you won't want to miss.His grandpa believes that he could end up President one day. It is great to hear someone believe in their grandson as much as he does. It is a great story about a little boy that will leave you wanting to read more. This book is a fictional book, but the author did a great job of adding in some historical facts that make it educational as well.You will be loving this book from the second you start it. I had trouble putting it down and can't wait to find more books by this author. It was one of those stories that I will be recommending to other people to read. I think my daughter will be the next one reading it.

I had high expectations for “President Fionn” by Author Christine Mary Flemming. After devouring the book whole I must say the story went above and beyond with its creative subject and heck of a twist for an ending! How refreshing it was to read an Irish tale – Dublin accent included in conversation which I loved! I don’t want to label this book as a historical fiction but it has historical facts and fictitious characters – that being said, the story is so much more. I sympathized with Fionn and his plight, but would have never imagined such a thought-provoking ending! Christine Mary Flemming has created a truly one of a kind story with real life situations, elegant descriptions and often amusing dialog. Any reader who has an interest in Kennedy, Ireland and social issues will enjoy this book – but don’t take my word for it! I guarantee you’ll be hooked after the first chapter (if not before). Well deserving of 5 stars. I can’t wait to read more from this author.

This is a fascinating book, written by a true master writer. The storyline itself is rich and will keep you turning the page wanting to find out more. The author is excellent at building up suspense and tension, making the hours fly by faster than you can notice. On top of the amazing thriller and psychological drama, there is a powerful cultural aspect to this book. Both in terms of the fascinating events surrounding JFK and the entire cultural epoch of the '60s, but this book also serves as a window into the Irish culture. Such a rich tapestry is difficult to find among the quickly-written books of today, and as such, it is a very precious book. I highly recommend it to everyone.
Source (K): An inspiring story full of strength

Source (H): There is little doubt after reading this book that the author can defiantly spin a tale, telling the story of Fionn a young boy from Dublin whose character is so well written you could well believe he based on a real life person.The storyline itself is beautiful woven with plenty of intrigue and events that include President Kennedy's visit to Ireland during the sixties.Overall coming of age stories that are based on and Irish culture, don't come every often, this one is full of magic and should be top of your list

President Fionn is one of the greatest combination of adventure and inspiration books that I've read lately. The characters are clearly illustrated through the author's word usage. The plot is well thought out and everything flows perfectly. The book grabbed my attention throughout the whole novel. I especially like the ending. I would definitely recommend this book to anyone!It's been countless years since I've read a book this good. I had forgotten what a good story Mrs. Flemming has given us. I really enjoyed rereading it - with plenty of colourful characters and never a dull moment, this is truly a book for all ages. I'd highly recommend it. Thanks for reading

"President Fionn" by Christine Mary Flemming follows the life of an idealistic young Irish man named Fionn. His passion and imagination combine with his troubled reality and spiritual connection to the young American president to create a remarkable journey of growth of change.I was pretty amazed at the ability of the author to build such a deep character in Fionn. She manages to create a whole history, psychology, and life for this man to the extent that you do not doubt that he is or was a real person.  I am curious as to where she got the inspiration for the character. The juxtaposition of fantasy and reality, of where Fionn wants to be and where his life is at, sets up an interesting dynamic as the protagonist follows JFK across Ireland. The book presents an unyielding sense of optimism set against a darker more objective reality.The characters, texture, and pacing of the novel work together to create a rich medley of a story which is both easy to read, and enjoyable. Flemming is a natural writer, and her prose is lyrical and clear. I really enjoyed reading this story which no doubt comes from a very talented author. Well done.
Source (K): Beautifully written portrait of a young man

Source (H): President Fionn by Christine Mary Flemming is truly a delightful read. You start the book off with a character who is returning to his childhood home after many long years. There’s a hint that something terrible happened to his family, and you’re given a glimpse of an older Fionn.That introductory chapter sucked me in, and I was delighted to turn the page and find myself faced with a much younger Fionn with a vastly differently outlook on life. Thus begins a story that spans more than three decades of time when all is fully told, but I do not dare share more than that and spoil what is to come for those who have not yet read this book.This read was a breath of fresh air for me, and the writing style and pacing of the story is spot on. Flemming’s prose is lyrical and her characters really came to life as I moved from page to page in the story. The book is also well researched from the viewpoint of historical fiction, and the editing of the text is excellent. I heartily recommend President Fionn to anyone looking for a fun, creative, and unique book.

I was pulled into Ethan's world from the first page. The writing and the voice were excellent and I found myself reading until I was finished. I could not put it down. What I found so intriguing was that this young adult book was from a teen boy's POV - usually we see a female main character - and Ethan is immediately likable. This isn't a story just for those looking for teen/family relationships - I really believe Ethan's story could fit all of us at some point in time and that the themes in this novel are universal. I highly recommend this book for the voice, plot, originality, writing style, and the overall message. It's a must read!

I find it very disconcerting Family Circle does NOT offer full digital subscriptions to readers who have subscribed to their magazine for years, like me.  I DO NOT have problems continuing to read the hardcopy version, but I do have a Kindle and would love if I could access it from there, rather than having to pay for a new subscription.Needless to say, I will not be renewing my subscription when my current one is done.Family Circle continues to be a great family-oriented magazine, filled with great recipes, craft ideas and household hints.  You are not alone in this problem, but seems if you wanted to get in good with all your longterm readers, you would offer the digital versions FREE to already-paid subscribers.

I think it is a bad policy on FC's part to force customers to pay twice for the hard copy magazine and then to have it on the kindle too.  Other magazines do not do that to their customers.  Will anyone at FC address this issue?  I see other folks have the same comment.

I used to pick up Men's Fitness frequently 4 or 5 years ago. When I saw it available for preview on the Kindle I thought I'd found a better way to get the tips and inspiration I needed. Sadly the magazine has turned into a muscle building yellow pages rather than a fitness guide for regular guys.The Kindle milti-mode presentation was good. Content... not so much.
Source (K): Get a workout looking for the articles between the advertisments

Source (H): This is a great fitness Mag. I'm a personal trainer so I'm picky with these sort of things. I wont bother with a subscription with my kindle because I already get this to my home. Unless they are giving current subscribers some sort of deal for already receiving the hard copies.
Very handy to have with at the gym on my kindle fire. Plenty of issues to read when sub'd. Con's - cant make page markers to go back to. Other than that I would recommend this

I signed up for the free trial of the magazine on a whim, but I will definitely be keeping this subscription!  There are 2 fiction stories in each issue.  The two in the current issue (June 2011) are amazing.  Both of them were incredibly well written and transported me to different worlds.There is also a non-fiction article and an author interview in the issue.

Clarkesworld is the 3rd Sci=fi magazine available for Kindle subscription service, right behind Asimov's and Analog, and it looks great.The subscription issue(s)has a well laid out format, with an easy to navigate menu along with a progress bar to show where you are within the story/article that you are reading. The cover art is still viewable on the kindle but, since the kindle isn't in color, it does loose some of its vibrancy. With the kindle app on my Droid X, however, the cover art looks amazing.I wished there were more stories in each issue, but since Clarkesworld is offered free on their website I can see why that is so. Content costs money. The editor, Neil Clarke, says in the current issue's editorial that if the magazine can reach 500 subscribers by October 2011 then they will add a third story. That is good news!

I just subscribed to Clarkesworld, read one issue, and canceled my subscription, just that quickly. I have been reading science fiction since the early 1960's. At the same time, I dislike both flowery writing, and horror.  IMHO, a story about a woman who is made from pastry and who is repeatedly eaten alive is horror.  And the writing...it was flowery, almost poetry..in other words, the writing got in the way of the story. There was one story that was almost passable, about a post apocalyptic world where mining ants had destroyed civilization...but when you thought about it, it didn't make sense.The ants were bred to seek metal, to somehow bite pieces of it off and to gather it around their nest. You could recover the metal by destroying the nest. Ants were specific to a particular metal, and they were fast - in one case a helicopter was destroyed in a few minutes, just by moving a half dozen or so ant nests into it.First off, there is no reason that mining ants would be eating raw metal, as depicted, they would eat ore, and somehow extract or excrete the metal. There is no evolutionary advantage to them eating the metal, so there is no reason they would breed true.  Thirdly, considering all they made of poison destroying the ecology and all that, I can't imagine that they could not protect themselves...I can think of several things that would reliably kill all of the ants in an area, or which could provide a barrier that ants couldn't cross.  Gamma ray radiation of the sort that is used to sterilize medical supplies, liquid nitrogen.  There are poisons that will kill everything in an area, and which will then dissipate.  Radioactive iron, for example, has a short half life - so seeing an area with some could kill all of the iron eating ants in that area, and after a couple days, people can come back. Or there could be a screw worm solution of some sort. This was a plague that was going to end "civilization as we know it" and it would have attracted a huge amount of effort - but all people did was to use more and more powerful poisons - such that they affected everything including things that should be more adaptive, such as intestinal bacteria, but not the ants.But that is OK. Science Fiction stories have had bad science in them for a very long time.  The problem was, almost exactly, the one in Mark Twain'sFenimore Cooper's Literary Offences, his criticism of the writing of James Fenimore cooper'sThe Last of the Mohicans. He talks about letting the writing get in the way of the story, of being too flowery, and of not using plain language...and that is what I see here...just too much (and too flowery) writing for the amount of story there.I still read the writers I loved as a child...Robert A. Heinlein, and Ben Bova, H. Beam Piper.  They used simple language to tell a story that was interesting - the ideas in the story were in the forefront.This is science fiction, and the ideas should be as important as the characters. In "Between Planets", Heinlein makes Venus one of the characters...too bad he got it all wrong, I would have loved to wash dishes on that Venus.Now in Clarkesworld, the editor has picked three stories, and they might have been written by the same person, and the writing was the main character.  I kept on having to think, "How clever that turn of phrase was."By the end of the third story, I felt like I was swimming through a thick morass of clever turns of phrase.  I then thought, "Well, that was a chore," and cancelled my subscription.I wish Clarke all of the success in his world.  But please note that if your pleasure is Heinlein, or Robert Forward, or such, and if you feel that Phillip Jose Farmer's work was a step backwards, you probably won't like this magazine.If your pleasure is literature, if you thought Cooper was a better writer than Twain (and I have met people of that mind) you will certainly like this magazine.

Mitt Romney's jobs plan is a bold, sweeping, detailed proposal that will reverse the Obama decline. This is not just a jobs plan. It's a fundamental turnaround of the American economy. Mitt Romney has 59 specific proposals -- including 10 concrete actions that he will take on the very first day."Day One, Job One:  On his first day in office, Romney will submit a jobs package to Congress consisting of at least five major proposals and will demand that Congress act on the package within 30 days, using every power at his disposal to ensure its passage. He will also take immediate and specific steps within his sole authority as president by issuing a series of executive orders that gets the U.S. government out of the economy's way. The goal: restore America to the path of robust economic growth necessary to create jobs."
Source (K): Mitt Romney's Plan To Turn Around The Obama Economy

Source (H): So we have this huge deficit and Mitt wants to give the wealthy a generous tax cut. Maybe that would work if we lived on the bizarro world of  DC comics. Mitt, can't we have the wealthy give just a little more to reduce the debt? Let's just call it a Bush war tax since those wars were executed on IOUs. Oh, so it might reduce job creation? Well, I'm no economic genius but how about a job creation credit offset? Not a good idea? You really just want the wealthy to get a tax reduction. Thanks for the honesty Mitt.
Source (K): Tax cut for the wealthy...one finger salute for everyone else.

Source (H): Mitt Romney released this book free on the Kindle just before the first debate between the Republican candidates for president.  The timing and benefits to Governor Romney are obvious.  This channel allows him to communicate his message quickly, outside of the adversarial, sound-bite constraints of debate, and free from the charge of, well... charging for it.  Nicely done.  There are advantages for prospective voters, too--including those certain they will not support Romney's candidacy.  He lays out a very specific plan.  Agree with him or not, readers must admit that this is more than a vague cry for some kind of unknown change.  It is clear where Romney stands and what he proposes to do.In an introductory letter, Romney outlines his approach.  "I have formulated a comprehensive and integrated plan that focuses on seven areas where reform is urgently needed:  taxes, regulation, trade, energy, labor, human capital, and fiscal policy."  He then tackles each area in turn, describing its impact on the economy, the negative effects of President Obama's policies, and the objectives of a Romney administration.  The book closes with an appendix containing fifty-nine policy proposals.  If Romney is elected, we can use this list of proposals as a scorecard to track his promises and his progress.A sample of briefly-stated policies from the appendix:- Repeal Obamacare.- Pursue new trade agreements with nations committed to free enterprise and open markets.- Open America's energy reserves for development.- Prohibit the use for political purposes of funds automatically deducted from worker paychecks.- Cap federal spending at 20 percent of GDP.The book also includes endorsements of Romney's plan.  The first is an overview of economic policy by R. Glenn Hubbard, Dean of the Columbia Business School.  There are more specifically-themed endorsements from conservative business and political figures.  They include Scott McNealy of Sun Microsystems on Tax Policy, Nebraska Governor Dave Heineman on Trade Policy, former Missouri Senator Jim Talent on Energy Policy, and eBay's Meg Whitman on Human Capital Policy.  The statements by these high-profile supporters appear at the end of chapters, set off clearly from Romney's own analysis and proposals.This book is highly recommended to readers who want to evaluate Mitt Romney's approach to jobs and the economy.  Readers also interested in Romney's views on foreign policy would benefit from his previous book,No Apology: The Case for American Greatness.

Mitt Romney outlines his strategies for leading America as President.  As Mitt has spent the last five years training and preparing for the Presidency, he has conducted extensive analysis and planning.  President Obama skillfully leveraged Web 2.0 to propel his 2008 campaign, and Mitt has embraced the Digital Age by sharing his plans and policies via Kindle.  Beyond the simple talking points depth of other campaigns, Mitt offers extensive details including his 5 bills and 5 orders for day one.  While other candidates offer gimmicky approaches or radical proposals that have no chance of passing in Washington, Mitt's extensive economic plans to revive the American economy offer Americans a clear strategy to debate and implement.  As Americans decide who to vote for in the GOP Primaries and the General Election in Nov 2012, this is a must read to help you decide if Mitt's plans resonate with you.  Given Kindle readers are more educated and more likely to engage the political process, this free book is worth the read.
Source (K): A Solid Plan for America in the 21st Century

Source (H): 5 stars!! This is a novel approach to reaching voters (especially the Kindle version), and I wish all candidates would do the same.  Let's get rid of the pretty rhetoric and get down to business with specific and detailed plans to restore our economy. This book does just that. As Kevin pointed out many of these reviews might make people think that they are hearing from campaign workers building up good reviews on this book but, like him, I am a completely independent reviewer.  I heard about this book from an email from the campaign and downloaded to read it.  One thing i really love about having this on my Kindle is that it keeps this information close at hand and I can refer to it when having a knowledgeable discussion of the issues.  I also appreciate having a main source for mitt' plan instead of having to glean it from parts of many different speeches and documents and set forth in a very organized way which really helps when trying to find his plan on certain issues.  The fact that a candidate is willing to set it all down in one source and you not having to quote from one speech or another or having to put his plan together from many sources.Mitt's plan is not only concise and well thought out but is written in a way that makes it very easy to understand and not wrapped up in political rhetoric so you don't have to pull plan parts out from the politics of the day to discern exactly what he is saying.  And his plan makes sense and makes it easy to see how it can work without miracles instead of hard work.  He makes it very clear how something will take longer then others but what we can expect the results to be.  We aren't being handed a bunch of chants to repeat without being given a clue as to what they mean or how it will be brought about.This is a must read, especially if you have ever had a moment when you felt like shrugging and wondering if there is a way to get this country fixed and back on its feet here is your answer.  I could go into detail about the plan but its better that you read the details for yourself and not just take my review for it.  Even if you are currently willing to let the incumbent resume office in 2013 you need to take the time with this book and compare what you have heard for the past 3 years and what you have seen with what Mitt has to say about his plan for the future.  Not only do I agree that fence sitters will take a great deal away from this book but you won't be willing to just let the status quo continue and just re-elect the currant President.What this country needs and how to get there, how to return us to the strength this country had in past administrations is laid out for you page after page.  I actually found that the more I read the more I wanted to read and the more I learned.  It gives me a very clear view of how we got into the mess we are in now, one that many worry there is no solution to.  Mitt has a great grasp of how and what caused the predicament we are in now and one has to be clear about what wrong turns happened and how to go forward from here on the right track and what that will take.  Mitt is promising a logical step by step plan that will change things around with a sound timeline that with hard work makes sense for where this country can go.  Yes, we can do it and here is how.  And the how is the most important.  I don't think we can take another 4 years of any candidate becoming President with a great outlook that they want to achieve and promise they will but without a solid plan for the next step to take.This is a detailed plan and a very responsible one.  You may not agree with what bits and pieces you have heard up until now, from one speech or meeting here and there but this puts it altogether in one place for you.  It also gives you a good guide, once read, to evaluate and question what other candidates think about an issue and how they plan to handle it.  I found that every issue that mattered to me, and some I came to adopt as ones that should matter and I had neglected to think about, was laid out by Mitt, researched and discussed in a logical and informative way and followed by his plans to deal with the issues.
Source (K): I am an independent reviewer too

Source (H): Poorly written and, as his campaign, nothing of how he would do what he wants to do.  Vague and very short on how he would create the jobs everyone wants.  The book "The Peoples Money" is a far better book on how!!

I read this book because I have been watching the Republican Primaries and the beginning of the Primary Election very closely, and I had yet to hear Romney come out with any SPECIFICS on how is plans on improving the economy.  After 25 straight months of private sector job growth under President Obama, Romney has to have a clear plan for me to vote for him.  As an "Independent", I wanted to see if I could find out what that plan was.  The only way I can describe what I read was, "George Bush Version 2.0".The book's summary says that, "Mitt Romney seeks to reduce taxes, spending, regulation, and government programs." This is very true ... Under the Republican's "Paul Ryan Budget Plan", which Romney endorced and the American Counsel of Bishops has denounced, stating it, "fails to meet moral standards" Mitt Romney would reduce taxes ... but only on those making $500,000 or more.  In fact people making $1 million a year would get a $260,000.00 reduction in taxes!  But there is NO tax cut for middle class Americans ... in fact, under Ryan's plan, (which Romney said he'd approve if President) people making $30,000 or LESS would see an INCREASE in taxes!!!Ok, so onto, "Mitt Romney seeks to reduce spending".  Yes, this is true, too.  Unfortunately, the reduction in spending includes the Education Department, (he told donors at a fundraiser event that he'd either, "Consolidate the Education Dept with another Dept or make it a heck of a lot smaller."  There would be HUGE cuts to federal Pell Grants for college students, and Paul Ryan's Budget also calls for a permanent increase to Federal Student Loans interest rates.  Personally, our Education Department is NOT something I would like to see fall under the "reduce spending" category.Ok, so we've dealt with taxing and spending ... now let's talk about "less regulation".  In definition Regulation = Rules.  Republicans don't like them, (well, to be fair, Corporations and Wall Street don't like them, and Republicans tend to represent those guys.)  This one should be obvious ... do you guys remember what happened last time Wall Street had no rules???  Regulations aren't automatically bad ... John McCain ran in favor of Cap and Trade when he ran for President in 2008!  Having no regulations is like having sports with no rules ... do you really think corporations are going to do, "the right thing" on their own??  We have government regulations to thank for companies no longer be permitted to dump toxic waste into our lakes and rivers, regulations to thank for child labor laws and government regulations to thank for minimum wage laws.  Businesses hate regulations because it is more expensive for them to dispose of toxic waste properly than it is to dump them into the nearest lake ... and it would be much better for their bottom line if they could offer desperate workers just $5 an hour rather than have to pay minimum wage.  Romney's business, Bane Capital, was all about increasing businesses bottom line ... so just be careful before you fall into the trap of deciding that "all" regulation is bad.Ok, so now we've addressed, "less taxes, spending, and gov't regulation." Let's move on to "less government programs".  The worst example on Romney plans to reduce gov't programs is Medicare.  His plan is laid out in the Romney/Ryan Budget, and it would CHANGE MEDICARE AS WE KNOW IT!!  It would no longer be a government guarenteed healthcare plan, but a "voucher" system ... where Romney would basically give seniors a "coupon" with a dollar amount that they can use on the "free market" to buy their own private insurance, (and if that "coupon" amount isn't enough, oh well, Grandma's just gonna have to pay the rest out of her own pocket.)  Romney and the Republicans want to "privatize" Medicare because it easier and cheaper for them ... even though it's clearly NOT in the best interest of our seniors.  In both the arguement of reducing gov't regulation, and in a reduction in gov't programs, I believe we need to demand that our lawmakes be EXTREMELY specific about what gov't regulations & programs they want to end, and who it will affect.Romney's book summary goes on to state that Romney would, "Relinquishes power to the states instead of claiming to have the solution to every problem."  If elected, and if the above actions did occur, things would go back to the states, but not for the altruistic reasons Romney seems to want us to believe.  Consider this:  If Romney cuts Federal Funding for Education, who do you think would have to make up for that budget gap?  The state and local gov't through tax increases, right?  So again Romney tries to sell us by saying he'll, "Give states more power" but fails to mention that this comes with the promise, "I'll give states a greater financial burden" as well.  Since only the rich will benefit from Romney's tax decreases, the middle class will still be paying the same amount of federal taxes they do now PLUS the additional taxes at the state and local levels to make up for all these, "savings in spending" Romneys doing in Washington.Romney's book summary ends with, "Any American living through this economic crisis will immediately recognize the severity of the break that Mitt Romney proposes from our current course."  I couldn't agree more!  We have a choice between Mitt Romney, who would TRIPLE the tax breaks for millionares and billionares than the Bush tax cut did, and go back to the "deregulation" days when corporations and Wall Street could do whatever they wanted, and hope they don't put us into a full depression next time they make their own rules and drive the economy off the cliff. Or we can stay with President Obama, who chose to save GM when Romney said to, "Let it go bankrupt" and who helped Americans struggling with foreclosers, when Romney said that we, "shouldn't do anything" to stop the housing market from hitting bottom.  Romney doesn't think like a simple, "business man" ... business men, (and women) care about their customers.  Romney thinks like a Venture Capitalist ... it's all about numbers, not people.  Let GM go bankrupt and the housing market crash - forget about all of the lives destroyed by those decisions.I was hoping to find some specifics in this book that would make me see Romney in a different light ... but the book struck me to be as phony as Romney's campaign has been so far.  Romney is like jello, you just can't nail the guy down ... you only have to listen to him for a few speeches to watch him flip flop on his positions, all the while being incredibly vague about what he would actually do - policy wise - that would make him so different than President Obama.  I leave this book feeling no better about Romney than when I began.

First off let me state by saying that this book was written by a politician, not an economist. Being an economist myself, I can spot a load of BULL when I read one and this document is 90% bull.I'll just take one area and point out where this guy is so very wrong. Energy Policy.Sticking to legacy energy resources will not help make America prosperous. All Romney can talk about is coal, oil, and natural gas...the three money makers of legacy energy production that very much want to remain the money men they are. Coal is a disaster no matter how you look at it and some good advice for coal workers would be to take federal job training money when its offered to you and get out of the industry because you are about to be put out of a job due to disruptive technologies producing energy so cheaply it will become uneconomical to mine coal for energy purposes.Let me explain to you why.The energy resources of tomorrow are thorium, fusion, solar, wave, wind, and geothermal. Fusion is probably a decade away while wave, solar, wind, and geothermal are building geometrically and will produce a great deal of America's energy within another decade at a cost ranging from 1/5 to 1/3 of to produce the same amount of energy by coal or nuclear. It is becoming increasingly apparent that nuclear is to dangerous for most areas of the world so it is a really good thing that we have thorium to move forward with as it is many times safer and produces 100 times the energy per kilogram compared to uranium. Our first thorium reactor should go online either in 2012 or 2013 and at the latest 2015. With thorium you have 0% chance of a meltdown and the half-life of the waste material is 250 years compared to the thousands of years with uranium.In a couple decades we can expect fusion reactors to replace virtually all legacy energy product. Fusion is not a pipe dream, we have a test reactor in California right now that has already completed a couple tests and the results were amazing to say the least. It is estimated that the entire country could be powered by 5-10 fusion plants running at full capacity so the era of low cost energy is nearly here.As for the rest of the book....well you research it yourself. This one was deleted by me right after reading it.

First of all, I would expect nothing less than such a review board to be laced with many "reviewers" who simply do not feel the need to actually read what they review. Aside from the enraged ideologues, we will also have Romney's political rivals who must somehow catch or derail this train that just left the station.As an ultra-conservative tea party RTKB type, I was more impressed with this book (that actually reads like a book) than I expected to be. It is full of ideas and tactics that you never hear discussed in typical bbq politico discourse. Anyone with a truly earned high school diploma can understand what is being explained in here. There is no reason to be intimidated by it. That being said, it has meat and potatoes for the thinkers, as well.I heard bells going off at certain ideas that I saw were attempting to get to the root of the problems and not merely treat the symptoms. This book serves oh so many purposes for the Romney campaign. I think it treats the people like adults, it offers something more than just campaign rhetoric and criticism (which are also plentiful), it gives you an idea of just how much Mitt had familiarized himself with the American economy and it's problems, and I think it shows that he actually cares about America and Americans (not just conservatives). It also shows that he is not an ideologue who is here to merely scream and shout for his team, but rather someone who fully understands and believes what he is saying, yet also recognizes the need to develop political will in the people. There is a lot of volatility in our society right now and a prettty disgruntled gov dependant class (IMHO). The last thing we really need is for a quarter or maybe half of our country to believe that a form of oppression is being implemented upon them by a greedy, evil (R). There may actually be a way out of this! This is about what will do the most for the most amount of people and what can actually be accomplished without needing to have the conversation about who deserves or does not deserve what. Many slam him for not "coming out strong enough" for so and so, or "being a Rino" for not condemning so and so. C'mon, playing that game only preaches to the choir. If he were running for the president of the RNC or Tea Party that would be fine, but he realizes he is running for the POTUS and, whether we like it or not, he will also represent the other half of the country who are not conservative. Being an ideologue makes good hay in the Primaries, but people stop hearing you when you say certain things (just like in religion). This is where Perry could learn a lesson. I actually agree with Perry, but he could get a lot more done by making a thoughtful case for why our ideas will work instead of saying key words to only rally the base. How many people are turned off when a professing Christian approaches you and asks you if you have a personal relationship with Christ(too)? As a Christian myself, I know it is not the best way to relate to a non-believer. To present any "doctrine" as a given without explanation or consideration for all of the people you are speaking to (Paul), all while divining the motives of whomever disagree (Obama) will make you less friends in politics or religion. If you have something important and controversial to say, don't just proclaim it settled (Gore), make your case, and if need be, agree to disagree! I suspect that when all the political dust settles, most conservatives, moderates, and maybe even liberals may find that they at least don't have as much reason to hate Romney as many do Obama and Bush. That sounds like a good way for a new President to actually get the ball rolling with political capital and avoid a civil war while he is at it...Here are a few noteworthy conservative ideas Romney lays out AND makes a good case for-Secret ballots and free choice for or against unions in all states.Income earned and taxed abroad is not taxed again here.Green card attached to every advanced technical degree given to foreign students.Getting CO2 (what we exhale) removed from the Clean Air Act.Make regulatory bodies have to maintain budget, any new policy created by a regulatory body that effects the economy by mor ethan $100 mil must be approved by Congress.Cut federal jobs by 10% through attrition, not firing, by reallocating 1 new hire to a more useful job for every two that leave or retire from the areas needing to be cut.I am anxious to get things fixed, too, but I also realize that it took a while to get so far off course, and this ship won't turn on a dime. I do believe most of the ideas in this book would go a long way toward getting us back on course to being the beacon of freedom and prosperity we once were. Americas enemies are chomping at the bit to hit us when we are down. Let's not give them the chance. The best defense is a good offense, no???For the "real conservatives" who constantly look for a few "sound bites" to further write him off as a RINO, you may well choke while trying to digest all the meat here. It also might be harder to talk with your mouth full, but I suspect that is by design. Also, [...] ought to clear up quite a few misconceptions. It is not my site, nor do I have one, but I found it the other day and was dually impressed.Now for a little fun-Fantasy ticket as of today:POTUS - RomneyVP - Rubio, West, maybe CainChief of Staff - GingrichPress Secretary- Gingrich or Ann Coulter (LOL)Sec Treasury - Ron PaulSec Def - WestSec State- not HillarySec Homeland Sec- Joe Arpaio (LOL)Sec Interior- BachmanHey! We can agree to disagree...;)

Source (H): I just read Romney's book NO APOLOGIES. From that I concluded that Romney is more of a tactician than a grand strategist. Romney doesn't seem to have any grand vision for ending the Great Recession. Of course nobody else does either! What Romney does bring to the table is an ability to improve things at the tactical level --- to make so many individual improvements to government processes that the cumulative effect in improving our economy becomes major.While Governor of Massachusetts, Romney seems to have improved enough aspects of state government to become very popular, despite his being much more conservative than most of the Massachusetts electorate.This book is a campaign manual for what Mitt would like to accomplish as President. There's nothing at all radical in Mitt's agenda. It's more of a tweaking of the methods of government than revolutionizing them. Mitt wants to tweak the tax code so as to reduce the corporate tax rate. He wants to rationalize the patchwork of government regulations that impose an unreasonable compliance burden on business, but he supports reasonable, clear, and understandable regulations. He's for more free trade with Latin America and less with China. He wants to repeal Obamacare, the national version of what he did for healthcare reform in Massachusetts, and let the states do their own thing individually. He wants to reform, but not eliminate Dodd-Frank regulations on banks. He wants to reform the legal system to prevent excess damage awards. And of course he wants to develop all economical forms of energy in the USA.IMO these are hundreds of small-potato ideas that probably don't excite many people when taken one-by-one. Nevertheless, small potatoes can be tasty. Put enough of them together and they become weighty. I prefer this kind of incremental plan to the grandiose trillion-dollar stimulus spending programs that don't seem to have accomplished much in the way of improving our economy.Anybody seriously seeking an in-depth understanding of Mitt Romney should read his autobiography NO APOLOGIES. Because that is written in Mitt's own words it gives a clear impression of who he is as a person and what he would like do as president. However, this book is a decently written campaign manual of Mitt's agendas.
Source (K): A decently written campaign manual for Mitt Romney

Source (H): I'm not a big Mitt Romney fan, but this is a very nice piece of literature for a campaign to put out.  I can't think of any other campaign who has ever put out a plan this detailed this early in the process and made it available to this many people.  Certainly Obama hasn't put out anything this detailed.Because of that, I'm going to rate this 5 stars.  I really hope more candidates follow his example and we get a primary based on ideas instead of personal attacks.Now for the content:*Taxes*Mitt is definitely focused in the right direction on taxes, but I wish he'd go further and I think he easily could.  He supports cutting the corporate tax rate (currently the highest in the world) by 10%.  Good start, but that still leaves us with a fairly high rate compared to other OECD nations.  He supports ending the death tax, ending taxes on savings and investment for low and middle income individuals (thank you!), and switching to a territorial tax model instead of our worldwide tax system.  He says we need a lower, flatter, income tax structure, and that's great.  Unfortunately he doesn't really offer too many details on that.*Spending*Here I think Mitt needs to go a lot further than he has.  He offers a 5% across the board cut for non-defense discretionary spending, which is good but is really just a small percent of a tiny fraction of total spending.  He wants to raise the Social Security retirement age or modify the escalator to keep that system solvent.  He would cap and block grant Medicaid to the states.  Unfortunately he does not really address Medicare, which is by far the biggest driver of our debt going forward.  He also doesn't address any reforms in military spending.*Immigration*He's got a fairly immigrant-friendly immigration policy, which I like, but it only focuses on immigrants with skills or who graduate college.  Not bad, but immigrants in the US generally come in two flavors:  Very highly skilled, and very low skilled.  Both are complimentary to the existing US workforce (if they weren't, they wouldn't be here) but he only addresses half of them.In my opinion the rest is barely an improvement over Obama.  He's basically making the case that he'd do a better job than Obama, not saying he'd do a 180.  He'd spend government money on better energy sources, beat China around better, use government money to fund different or better education programs.  It's a lot of government solutions to problems that should be in the realm of the private sector.  He's probably right that he'd be a better manager than Obama, but I'd rather have someone that lets Americans manage their own lives instead of trying to do that from Washington DC.  That's what Republicans should stand for, and that's the kind of Republican I'm going to be voting for in the primary.Thanks again, Mitt and company, for putting this out there.  I hope to see a lot more stuff like this out of your campaign as well as all the others.
Mitt Romney will be the next president of the United States!  This is his plan!  And it's a pretty comprehensive plan!

Even as president, Obama is still voting "present" and not showing any leadership.  Is there any doubt that the economic times call for a man of the ability, experience and international leadership experience as Mitt Romney?

Mitt Romney has referred to this book as the definitive expression of his economic plan in the Republican candidate debates, so I decided to do some due diligence by reading it.There are 59 recommendations in all, most of which would involve reversing policies of the current Administration.  The basic thrust is to slow the big government express and cut the private sector a little slack.  Some highlights follow:TAXES (cut corporate tax rate from 35% to 25%, preserve Bush tax cuts, overhaul tax system longer term); REGULATORY (repeal Obamacare and Dodd-Frank, force regulators to consider costs of complying with new regulations, require Congressional approval of major regulations); TRADE (negotiate more trade agreements, get tough with China); ENERGY (expedite development of untapped US oil and gas reserves, ban EPA regulation of carbon emissions); LABOR (reverse NLRB effort to favor union organization vs. impartially arbitrating labor/management disputes); HUMAN CAPITAL (rationalize federal training programs and block grant them to the states, encourage immigration of well educated people with valuable skills); FISCAL (cut spending and cap it at 20% of GDP, support a balanced budget amendment).Most of these ideas seem sensible to me, but the difficulties involved are understated in many cases and there is little discussion of how to overcome predictable objections.  For example:#Repealing Obama would take more than an executive order that support should be given to states that wanted to opt out, including offering an alternative program (none is satisfactorily described in the book) that would work better.#It is said the first step towards "getting the federal debt under control" will be "admitting we have a problem and refusing to allow any more irresponsible borrowing."  In, other words, "just say no."  Fine, but how would President Romney propose to get the members of Congress on board?No president could hope to implement more than a fraction of such an agenda, so it might have been better to focus on what Romney regards as the four or five top issues and go into more detail.The absence of an identified author results in off putting statements like "Mitt Romney says" this and "Mitt Romney proposes" that, which detract from the book's impact.,,An account attributed to Romney would have worked better, even if most readers suspected it was ghost written.In sum, "Believe in America" marks Romney as a competent manager versus an inspirational leader. Probably that is who he is, but it is not necessarily a recipe for electoral success.

This might have been a reasonably good book if the universe had popped into existence in January, 2009.  But since the universe is actually more than 32 months old, this book is a partisan joke.For instance, Romney promises to "review and eliminate Obama-era regulations", but not Bush-era regulations, or Clinton-era, or Reagan-era, or Nixon-era, or Roosevelt-era.  It's all about Obama.  Obama, Obama, Obama.  (Barack Obama is mentioned 175 times in the book, George W. Bush 10 times, and Bill Clinton once.)So don't expect President Romney to try to repeal the Patriot Act, or No Child Left Behind, or even the ban on bringing liquids into airports.  Those regulations came into existence before Obama, before the beginning of time.

Believe in America is the more rhetorical, the less personal, the less biographical, and less balanced pendant to Mitt Romney's bookNo Apology: Believe in America. It also makes it, despite some more up-to-date information, the less interesting of the two. That it is less personal and biographical shouldn't come as a surprise, as it is, first of all, not written by Romney himself, and second, it is a pamphlet, a campaign manual, complemented by messages from Romney-supporters in business, industry, and government. For anyone interested in getting to know a little more about Romney the man, No Apology is the better choice.I praise the initiative of writing a pamphlet in which ideas are relevantly summarized. The way it is distributed for free, either as a PDF, or as an eBook for Kindle should be lauded. I'm not a great fan of the book's structure, however. It should work fine in theory (a chapter on tax policy, one on regulations, one on trade, etc., and chapters subdivided in Obama/Romney dichotomies), but in practice you keep reading about the same policies over and over.The pamphlet's main thrust, unsurprisingly, is that President Obama did about as much wrong as he could have and that a Mitt Romney as President would be about as antithetical to that as it can get. Whether that's really true I leave in the middle. For anyone hoping that this text would have anything to say on social issues, you will be left in the dark here--the title might have already given that away. Of course, the economy will, pace Santorum, be the most important subject of the 2012-elections.With an unprecedented downgrade by S&P;  "almost 46 million Americans...living on food stamps;" crippling unemployment ratings, and an average duration of unemployment that "has risen from 24.1 weeks to 40.4," Romney is more or less rightfully positioned against a president who had garnered a mythical reputation. Romney, on the other hand, is constructed as someone who will be able to fix the economy. He contributed in upgrading the credit rating of his Massachusetts--although raising taxes in 2002, before Romney was elected, may have actually been one of the key reasons [...]. And the pamphlet reminds us that when Romney was elected Governor, "the state economy was in distress and the budget was out of control." What it doesn't tell us that three Republicans (1991-2003) were Romney's predecessors.Many of the ideas in the pamphlet disappointingly lack in content and scope. Romney likes to talk about "streamlining" and may think people credulously believe in that concept as to accept it. Yet, much remains unclear when he wants "rules affecting coal power plants [to] be streamlined to achieve the necessary environmental protection while avoiding job-killing plant closures." He wants to overhaul the Clean Air Act, the Clean Water Act and others, which begs the question: how does he combine that with adhering to the idea of  "preserv[ing] environmental gains." In essence, how, and what, and when? When Romney discusses financial regulation reform he merely points at what's wrong with Dodd-Frank, then demands deregulation, while stating that the good concepts of Dodd-Frank "must be translated into law in a way that creates a simple, predictable, and efficient regulatory system appropriate for our dynamic economy." Again, how, and what, and when? Flexible regulation practices of some sorts are needed. However, when the pamphlet claims "because foreign regulators are not likely to implement restrictions of their own, U.S. banks will be left at a competitive disadvantage" it is flat wrong. Europe has stricter financial regulation laws that are supported by clear majorities.Now, what surprises me a little in a treatise about fixing the economy in such hard times is the amount of third rails, such as the military (or militarism as Paul would say), loopholes, and tax-increases. Why not have a sane discussion on rational cuts in defense spending. Why not have a sane discussion on the many loopholes corporations consistently find to pay hardly any taxes? Romney himself did a pretty good job on cleaning out some of these excessive loopholes during his time as Governor, now we don't hear anything of that in the Republican camp. (Actually, Gingrich in the September 12, 2011, debate when asked about these loopholes, flatly stated "I'm cheerfully opposed to raising taxes" as to `reassure' people he won't do anything about them). Has it come down to this? I agree with Romney that the tax code should be simplified, I agree that the death-tax is inane. What I do not agree on is that Republicans make people believe that an incredibly small tax raise on the very rich will be bad for the economy. They seem to have forgotten that the rate was at a one time high of over 90% from the mid 40s until the mid 60s. Even during most of Reagan's time, the rate was 50%. And yes, the poor are still waiting for the trickle-down effects from that era.The total lack of criticism of any of President Bush's policies is daunting as well. Not a word on him, yet instead the pamphlet cites an overly incorrect statistic on debt: "It took 43 presidents 220 years [from 1789 through 2008] to accumulate $6.3 trillion of national debt." I do not wish to understate in any sense the enormous deficit and debt increases during the Obama-era, yet before he took office, the debt was already almost $11 trillion.I'm also getting a little tired of that, by now, well-known and unproven narrative that someone from the private sector is instantly--as by magic--able to govern a country. Thus, the statement "Mitt Romney spent most of his career working in private enterprise" is a nice one, but it doesn't tell us anything. As if malpractice is non-existent in private enterprise; as if fraud is non-existent in private enterprise. If there's one thing we've learned from the crisis, it is that "corporations are people" indeed, but not in the beneficent sense Romney has it. Lest we forget, President Bush had ample experience in the private sector. And the pamphlet's statement, "with little private-sector experience, President Obama turned to the only thing he really knew: government," is about as silly as claiming that Romney as President, would use his Urim and Thummim to designate what's best for the US.

"W drodze" jest trzecim polskim pismem w Kindle Store i pierwszym miesiecznikiem. Check how many ratings this magazine has. At the time of this writing, this makes the 40th. A quick breakdown shows a single 5-star, a single 3-star, and 37 one-star reviews. These 37 reviews are based off of a type of "boycott" of the magazine, based off of Ex-editor Jerry Tsai, who stated publicly that a particular firearm (HK MP71A) should not be available to civilians.Clearly, this is a violation of our second amendment right.The good news, is that as of Sept. 9, 2012, Jerry Tsai has resigned. The means that those 37 reviews stating that RECOIL magazine is "anti-gun" can be ignored. A stain on the canvas, maybe - but definitely not worth ruining the reputation of the entire magazine on one of the most popular websites in existence.Now to the serious review part:RECOIL magazine is not just a magazine for firearms. It also spotlights modern technology for hunting, sports, and survival. They've got fairly in-depth reviews of almost every featured product, including the negative parts of the product - glad to see a magazine isn't biased because of their sponsors, for once. They have a fairly decent mix of articles, with the primary focus obviously being firearms. They try to include knives, vehicles, flashlights, hatchets, and anything else you could need for any kind of survival situation. Physical copies include a mid-size paper target, and the cover of the actual magazine is a rough light-grain sandpaper-esque texture, which is kind of cool and interesting at first, until you pick it up the wrong way and grind your nails on it.Overall: Read it, and be sure to clip your nails.
