You'll spend that much in gas driving to and from your local bookstore to "save" the fifty cents on the cover price.

As a mystery/thriller fan, it was a great treat to see Ellery Queen Mystery Magazine offered on the Kindle.  My Kindle edition of the initial issue offered included 9 short stories, including a great Lawrence Block "Keller" story and a new English translation of a wonderful Japanese mystery set in the world of the Japanese police. There was also a short review column on mystery blogs and a meaty, interesting book review column.  The issue was rounded out by a nice reproduction of the print edition's cover, two cute poems (crime-oriented, of course), and announcement of the magazine's 2007 Reader Awards.At the end of each story, one is given the option to jump back to the table of contents to select another story, but I chose to just sail right through and read the whole edition "cover to cover".  That's something I never did with the print edition for some reason.  I guess just seeing one nicely presented page at a time on the Kindle versus seeing one big intimidating digest all at once makes all the difference for us readers who battle an occasional lazy streak.I'll likely check out one or two other Dell magazines offered on the Kindle.  It was a nice diversion from the regular reading of my Kindle novel and news blogs to enjoy a piece of short fiction every day or so (I made this first issue last about two weeks).  But, whatever other Dell titles I end up trying out, Ellery Queen Mystery Magazine is likely to be the one ongoing, regular visitor to my Kindle each month.Note: Amazon frequently updates the presentation the functionality of Kindle blogs and periodicals, so as this review gets older, it may no longer accurately describe the current version of this product.
Source (K): Yet another reason I'm glad I bought a Kindle

Source (H): I was very excited to find out that Ellery Queen's Mystery Magazine is now available for the Kindle.  I love the magazine, but often I find that I get behind on reading it.  My dogs ate my last one.  Literally.  I've been looking for more content for the Kindle, because it is so handy to carry with me in the car.
Source (K): I Love Ellery Queen's Mystery Magazine!

Source (H): My psycho ex-girlfriend broke into my account and made many purchases including this one. THERE IS NO REFUND OPTION HERE AND I DEMAND A REFUND IMMEDIATELY. I have changed all my passwords (for the second time). I demand a refund on this title from my account immediately.

The writers in this magazine base their articles on the Bible. They frequently quote or cite Scripture as they discuss an issue. It is conservative in its approach to the Bible and religious matters. An excellent resource for anyone wanting a better understanding of God's word.

Oh Magnus! Why do you have to be so awesome?What Really Happened in Peru is a collection of a few short stories of Magnus's adventures in Peru over the years. It really gives you some insight on Magnus and how he thinks. Throughout the story I couldn't stop laughing my head off. My face was probably red. I had trouble breathing at times.To say I liked it is a tremendous understatement. It is a wonderful edition to the Shadowhunter Chronicles. I can't wait until the next book comes out!

I have never liked co-authored books. In fact, often I'll read a book that's a great concept, but it will end up being unsatisfying in a way I can't quite put my finger on, then I find out it's co-authored and everything makes sense. (I'm looking at you I Am Number Four.)Co-authored books have a problem that can only be described as "voice". Two authors cannot write in exactly the same voice, it's what makes and author unique, their own distinctive nuances and wordchoice, their literary fingerprint. When authors get together to write what ends up happening is they write in sections and the story seems disjointed, or they write together and lose any remnant of voice entirely. Whatever Happened in Peru falls squarely into the latter category.Cassandra Clare quickly became my favourite author back around then time City of Glass was released. I love her world, but more importantly I also love her writing. I loved it precisely because she creates beautiful prose that will disappear as I get absorbed in the story, but somehow still manages to make an impression. What Really Happened in Peru is not beautiful prose. It's utilitarian. The story is fine, the dialogue, the characters, the plot, it is the writing that falls flat on its face, the execution. There's no flourish. But I can show you what I mean quicker than I can tell you. Here's the first paragraph:"Magnus awoke in his roadside inn just outside Lima, and once he had arrayed himself in an embroidered waistcoat, breeches, and shining buckled shoes, he went in search of breakfast. Instead he found his hostess, a plump woman whose long hair was covered with a black mantilla, in a deep, troubled conference with one of the serving girls about a recent arrival to the inn."Utilitarian, like I said. A sequence of facts in this case that all set the scene (Magnus is staying at an Inn outside Lima, he's dressed in his usual flashy style, he went for breakfast. The hostess is a plump woman with long hair and a mantilla. She's talking to one of the girls about someone who just arrived.) There are no thoughts or insights here, no pretty writing, just repetition of the facts of the story. And it's the same problem with the whole book. The story is okay but the writing is dead.To contrast, here are the first two sentences of City of Lost Souls:"'How much longer will the verdict take, do you think?' Carly asked. She had no idea how long they'd been waiting, but it felt like ten hours."That, my friends, makes me want to read more.

I expected the usual beautiful and haunting Clare style and got just plain silly instead. Cassandra Clare can and does do humor in her books, but she does not do shallow and unsatisfying, and that's what this is. I am disappointed, because I really looked forward to these stories and won't buy another. The central question posed by the title isn't even answered, but is fobbed off in a supposedly cute "the world will never know" fashion. Didn't work, not in the least bit. The whole thing felt like a cheat, from beginning to end. There is one decent part, where other warlocks describe what it was to grow up with a human mother's love, but Magnus's reaction to it is so incomprehensible, it's more off putting than illuminating. If Clare is going to "co" author with anyone, it needs to be with a writer who can do real justice to the material--respecting it rather than making a joke of it.

Neal Boortz is a conservative radio talk show host based out of Atlanta's WSB.  His nonbiased opinion on any topic is aproached without the element of political correctness, taking pride in calling himself an "equil opertunity offender". It holds true.
Great magazine but what gives with the pricing.  2 year print subscription that has to be mailed out monthly for $15 or 2.49 month ($60.00 for two years) for the Kindle edition.  Give me a break.
Source (K): What is the deal with the price....?

Source (H): Protagonist Franklin Bryant inexplicably finds himself in Trance, a sort of purgatory where the power-hungry demon Charon holds court. Charon offers Franklin a less-than-tempting choice: turn against his girl friend and her friends, or die. But when Franklin realizes that the people in his life had already turned on him, the decision becomes easier.MUTINY is a novella that's apparently midway through author Artist Arthur's Mystyx paranormal series. I was surprised to realize it is from Harliquin's Kimani Tru line (as opposed to being self-published) because it has several structural problems: it could have used better copyediting, the "voice" is uneven, and the story changes from first to third person not only between characters, but within the main character, for no apparent reason.In the first part of the story, the main character has an enjoyably sarcastic voice, but it feels at odds with the setting he finds himself in. Then, he goes from being an apparently easy-going, laid-back guy to a power-hungry evil guy over a few emotionally unconvincing scenes. He also goes from seeming to be primarily physically interested in his girlfriend to being obsessed with her.Despite these problems, MUTINY is an interesting, fast-paced story... which leads to a few more issues: First, this reader had to struggle to figure out what was going on, only to be left hanging at the end, because the novella is not complete, but more like a teaser (apparently) for the next book.If you're already hooked on the series, then you might as well read MUTINY. If you're desperate for free paranormal YA, you might as well read MUTINY. But if you are looking for something satisfying, something you can connect with, you might want to pass this up.

I greatly enjoyed reading the first issue of Opinionated.  Imagine the Sunday political roundtable TV shows but instead of smart people trading soundbites, you get smart people explaining themselves coherently.  Mind you, they are still out to persuade and Opinionated drops any pretenses on that score; each essay is labeled "Liberal", "Conservative", "Independent" or "World View" - Opinionated readers will not need the labels though it does lend an air of sporting competition to the proceedings.  Individual essays are brief, provocative, and tightly written.  In just five minutes you are exposed to a point of view, perhaps opposite to your own, that must be taken seriously.  And the authors take you seriously, too, as the writing has an intellectual edge; not to worry there is plenty of schoolyard finger-pointing to keep you entertained.If you are looking for new perspectives and good fodder for conversation at cocktails, without wanting to labor through a long article, Opinionated will fit the bill nicely.  And if this concentrated bulletin of thought helps us boil down the complex issues and decide what we really should be doing to improve the country right now, then Opinionated will have served a truly useful purpose.
Source (K): Raises the level of discourse in America

Source (H): I'm a liberal-leaning independent so I start with the conservative opinions first, knowing they're most likely to p**s me off. Some do but others surprise me and hold some truths worth acknowledging. Then I read the independent and world views, finishing in my comfort zone of liberalism. When I put my Kindle aside after having read a few opinions I invariable say to myself that this e-magazine is probably the best reason to have a Kindle, though I wouldn't want to give up all the books I'm enjoying. Open your mind and allow different points of view to enter. Be critical of all, whether they reflect your views or those of the other side. You'll be better for it.
Source (K): There's usually some truth to be found

Source (H): I'm not sure I'm going to continue with this mag after the initial trial. The selection of content is good. The "World View" columns tend to be liberal in view, giving the magazine a bit of a liberal bent. But that's not why I rated this magazine 2 stars.I rate it two stars because of its lazy organization. Reading the mag in article order results in a tiresome repetition of viewpoints. First, there's the Liberal opinions. Then the Conservative opinions. Then the International opinions. In each group of opinions there are usually two or three themes common to each philosophy. For instance, Education, The War on Terror, World Financial Institutions, Obama, Bush all had opposing viewpoints represented - but spread out throughout the magazine.Rather than feeling I'm first reading in one echo chamber and then moving to the next echo chamber, it would be far more interesting to read these articles by the theme of their content. I'd much rather read a collection of articles organized topically, forcing arguments against each other and truly engaging the reader.Frankly, the editorial layout of this mag is just plain lazy and completely uninteresting.The opinions are fine. The writers are good. And I like the opportunity to read opinions that normally wouldn't make the feed of my RSS Reader. But seriously, is there any lazier way to lay out this type of magazine?

This is a wonderful addition to the Kindlefamily...the serious commentary of peopleon the left-center-right on the issues facingthis country today...a non-partisan platformlike the C-SPAN cable channel but in a printedform that we can read while we go about ourbusy daily lives.

Both the liberal and conservative writers faithfully echo their party lines.  I would prefer the inclusion of some thoughtful, moderates.  Most Americans consider themselves middle-of-the road.  They would be hard-pressed to find pleasant reading here.

While I have mostly enjoyed reading the opinion pieces, after 6 months I decided to cancel my subscription. It takes too much time out of my reading budget. I have learned a lot about opinions on the left and right, but over time the authors have become too predictable and I found myself skipping more and more of the text.I may pick up again at a later time, but for now I am taking a break. I still wish the magazine success.

I didn't like it because I was looking for information instead of partisan opinion. But, the title of the publication is 'Opinionated' so I should not have been surprised. I'm simply not interested in political spin on a topic. Our society is too poisoned with this type of stuff. I prefer facts on which I can make an informed judgment. You've heard the statement: 'Opinions are like a..holes, everyone has one'.

I enjoyed reading Opinionated for a little over a year.  I would read all positions from both political viewpoints.  Although I did notice that liberal viewpoints always outnumbered conservative ones, I was fine with it.  Then towards the end of the 2008 election campaign period, I noticed all of the "liberal" writers using very similar wording and phrasing to attack John McCain.  It seemed as though they were getting together and trying to paint the exact same picture for everyone, as if enough of them said it, then all would naturally start to feel the same way.  It bothered me, but I didn't think that collaboration would be possible.  Then the praise for the Obama election became the same duplicative praise. I had had enough and cancelled my subscription.  I never reviewed Opinionated.  Now that I have heard of the "Journolist" fiasco, it all makes sense and I felt compelled to send a review.  I'm glad I cancelled.

I'm enjoying Opinionated much more than I thought I would. I am so turned off by the "pundits" on Sunday morning talk shows; and the extremely smart columnists whose rather nasty comments turn me off; but Opinionated is balanced and the essays are thoughtful and I can read them whenever.  In fact, I won't ever have to look at television again and am quite looking forward to that.

I have recieved four issues of Opinionated so far, and must say that I have enjoyed reading each issue.  The columns are well written, and some will even add a smile or chuckle to your day.  I have read just about every column included in each issue.  Each column is typically a five minute investment in time, so you can digest them throughout the week between responsibilities if you are a busy person like me.The one thing I will mention is that the publication is slanted to the left (or at least all the issues have been so far) in the amount of content provided.  There are always more liberal views expressed than either conserative or independent, and liberal submissions are always presented first.  I don't mention this because I'm some kind of ultra-conserative, far from it, but I thought it was a valid observation.
Absolutely the best newspaper covering New Europe. Excellent writing. Reporters and editors obviously care about and take pride in their work.

I am an American, but I have been living in Prague for the last seven years. In this time, I will honestly say that the quality of this newspaper has definitely gone up. It used to be extremely condescending, and sounded like a bunch of American twenty-somethings writing about the "inferior" Czechs.The newspaper now does a much better job of providing objective journalism. If you are an English speaker in Prague, then this is one of the only news sources covering local happenings.  For this reason, I am giving a generous three stars. The "bigger" stories provide a local view, but are otherwise better covered in larger publications.If you have an interest in news in the Czech Republic and specifically Prague, or if you are living there, then I guess this could be interesting. I read this occasionally (like when it is given for free on airplanes), but don't really miss it when I don't.

I was a loyal LGF reader until recently.  Not too long ago, Charles covered a wide range of issues, worked hard to be fair and accurate and actually wrote things that were enlightening and entertaining.Recently though, LGF has just fallen to garbage.  Almost everything that was great about LGF has disappeared. Now it's little more than a venue for Charles to settle his list of personal vendettas.  Take a look at LGF now and you'll see something like An Open Thread, something about Intelligent design, Another post attacking Pamela Geller or Robert Spencer.  In short, LGF has become one big beaten dead horse.Then there's his comments section.  If you dare disagree with Charles, you'll get about 3 chances to back down and apologize or you'll get banned. There's absolutely no room for contrary opinions, no matter how polite or diplomatic you may be.It's really sad - LGF used to be a great blog and a great community. Now it's little more than rehashing of the same stupid issues over and over and over and over - and a bunch of angry sycophants with no tolerance for any deviations from Charles' dictates

A once interesting blog, LGF has descended into the maelstrom of leftist apologetics and navel-gazing, bolstered by a full bevy of logical fallacies from the argumentum ad hominem to the straw man.  In the process, or concurrently, it has also degenerated into a cultish fan club for its proprietor, rigidly enforcing codes of conduct and punishing all diversity of opinion with a brutal efficiency that any tinpot dictator would envy.

Though I was following this blog for some time, they have let their arrogance and a couple of fixations lead them to near unreadable status.Get over your spat with Spencer et al and get past the evolution vs. creationism.  It's tired and most of your writing on it is petty and childish.  You are losing your voice.
Source (K): Had merit but gone off the deep end

Source (H): If you enjoy middle-school blogwars and endless self-congratulation, can't live without moral preening and serial backbiting, and adore clueless cut-and-paste political commentary, this site delivers!

Little Green Footballs is one of the most addictive sites on the net for newshounds and political junkies of all stripes. There are many great features that keep you on top of news and the latest controversies minute by minute as well as great analysis in the comments that contrasts what the rest of the blogosphere is saying. LGF has four great things going for it which make it a favorite site of journalists and bloggers everywhere.The first is the owner, Charles "Icarus" Johnson, who is a great journalist in his own right having broken many stories, scandals, and controversies over the past few years. He is unyielding in his hunt for facts and when the facts go against conventional wisdom he fearlessly bursts the bubble. No ox, left or right, is too sacred for him to gore. A few of his coups are the downfall of Dan Rather over the faked memo, the missile shots  "fauxtoshopped" recently by Iran, the many examples of leftist, Hamas, Hezbollah, and Palestinian media manipulation, his exposure of Discovery Institute's fraudulent political campaign to get intelligent design taught in science classes, and his thorough outing of the European Fascist right as well as their many connections to the Paleoconservative and Bircher wing of the right in the US.He is expert in analyzing politics and the middle east, and is particularly good at enumerating the extremists in all camps. His affinity for truth makes him one of the most trustworthy sources on the net, which is quickly losing credibility through incessant spamming of conspiracy theories, knee-jerk reactions, outrage of the day posts, and "follow-their-favorite-pundit" blogger clones.The second great thing is the community aka "The Lizards" who add comments to every post by the hundreds - they analyze, dig for further leads, and often turn over rocks you won't find in the mainstream press. Over the years the community has grown tremendously, but the people who stay long term tend to be good debaters, factual; and like the website proprietor, they are honest to a fault.They don't care about bruising tender net egos in their debates because the key thing that differentiates the lizards from other web communities is their allegiance to factual evidence. (some of the bad reviews here are from those crushed in the melee of factual debate who then moved on to start LGF stalker blogs - a phenomenon that speaks to the strengths of the lizard community.)Many experts in terrorism, journalism, science, philosophy, technology, and business are members, and when news breaks they are right on top of it. You will find that the Lizard's google-fu is exceptional; they will root out the pertinent sites and factual data within minutes of any major event. They also put forth good speculation and analysis from their own expertise, and get to the facts before many news agencies. There's a clear reason why most major news outlets tail the comments at Little Green Footballs during any major breaking event.As an example when the highway bridge fell over the Mississippi the lizards located several local sources liveblogging the event and linked them, and the community analyzed the photos, compared them to past photos, and predicted accurately the point where the bridge had failed and the order the spanfalls occurred in accurately within minutes of the failure. The only thing they missed was the gusset plate that later investigations found too thin.The third great thing is the spinoff link feature: in it you will find categorized breaking news, analysis, opinion, trends, and stories from all over the net and the world with many contrasting views. Since the links are also monitored, you will not find conspiracy sites, or agit-propaganda except the occasional filings under the moonbat and humor categories. The links are multiply categorized because the lizards have many different interests, from netfads, to multimedia, to news, to music, from art to culture to politics - you will find it all there. The best new articles of the net and the newsworld also float to the top from Lizards plussing news items up or down -these appear under the "Top Links" drop down. Many bloggers, left and right follow this feature religiously every morning to prep for their own blogging.The fourth great thing are the music posts - Charles Johnson is a highly accomplished Jazz guitarist with superb music taste, and he posts some really good music. In the comments for the music threads you will also find other lizard musicians posting their favorites as well.So whether you are a newshound, a blogger, a political junkie, a musician, or just interested in a great online community with it's eye on the future, Little Green Footballs is the best site for you.
Source (K): Little Green Footballs: The Best Newsjunkie Haven Right or Left

Source (H): I wish I be more positive about my review, but I can't.I had an account with LGF for some time, and had it almost instantly deleted when I disagreed - politely, eruditely and cordially - with Charles Johnson, the owner of the site about something so trivial as an analysis of the risks to Ms. Rifka Bary if she were to be returned to her parents.  There was no rancor in my attempted discussion, no rudeness, no non-topical commentary.  It would be an understatement to say that I was surprised, given the care in my attempt at a discussion with Mr. Johnson; I regret to say that I am not alone in finding myself banned for disagreeing with him.  His decision is particularly regrettable in that I was one of the few who had not taken sides in the ongoing and pointless conflict between Mr. Johnson and some other sites with parallel interests.Similarly, I can only assume that any paid membership to LGF can be deleted at the whim of Charles Johnson.  Unless you're in complete agreement with him, or sufficiently lucky to be overlooked (and some of the comments on the articles are shocking), you might well expect a rapid banning if you contradict him about anything.  I can't speak to Mr. Johnson's ethics, and I can't imagine why one would buy a subscription to LGF, but I can say - given my experience with Mr. Johnson - that your money would be poorly risked by so doing.GeoffP

I disagree heartily with T.Lawrence's review.  LGF is a great site, full of knowledgeable people whose discussion threads have helped me learn and refine my thoughts and opinions, not to mention bringing to my attention important news that is completely ignored elsewhere.
Source (K): Disagree with T.Lawrence!  LGF is a great site . . .

Source (H): If you have been going to the website Little Green Footballs for some time, you'll probably know the deal on this blog.  Either you're going to hate it, or you'll enjoy it.  If you are new to the Kindle, a conservative republican, and are signing up for this because you want something to read; you'll be highly disappointed.  And that's where my own rating comes in of one star.While still classified as a conservative web blog on many sites, LGF is far from it.  Articles routine attack popular conservative pundits such as Rush Limbaugh, Bill O'Reilly, Michael Savage, Glenn Beck, and pretty much all the other big names out there.  The author of the entries is Charles Johnson and he's waged a personal crusade against creationist theory supporting politicians such as Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal.  Anti-tax tea parties are mocked, and anything considered a traditional conservative value is dismissed as a relic of the past.  If you are an old school conservative or a religious one, do not consider this product.Now, if you were a huge John McCain supporter in 2008 and were terribly disappointed by Sarah Palin as his VP pick, LGF may be a good read for you.  Read the site for a week or two before deciding on buying into this and being subjected to many articles that I feel drone on about creationism or protecting Mr. Johnson's image.I pretty much see eye to eye with the author of these entries, but I found the material quite stale after reading about it for the 100th time.  Good luck in your own decision, but for me this is a definite no-go.

Who would pay for such thin content?  Such a pack of sycophants scrambling for Charles' approval?  The cult of LGF is not worth even a lousy 1.99 p/month.  He has banned thousands of people - many of whom politely disagreed with him. He frequently becomes obsessed with an issue and then posts dozens of articles about that issue.  If it's not his hatred of Pam Gellar and Robert Spencer, it's his conspiracy theories on some sort of 'flemish menace'.  He hates Catholics, Christians, and anyone who slightly disagrees with Obama. He has tried dictating to his commentors what websites they are or are not 'allowed' to visit. He loves AGW, plotting the 6 degrees of separation in many connections - most notably (IMHO) to various NAZI groups.  He hates conservatives and labels persons who disagree with his hard left politics as 'wingnuts'.  If you disagree in any way, shape or form with the tenets of islam - you are a racist.  His website is full of pop up ads and loads extremely slowly.  In short - not worth the bandwidth it's utilizing.
Source (K): Don't waste your time or money

Source (H): Prior to 9-11, Little Green Footballs was little more than a blog for Charles Johnson's photography and hobbyist bicycling. Searching the internet, bebopping from one web locale to the next, there wasn't much chance LGF would've offered a return incentive for most casual surfers.With the attacks on the World Trade Center, the Pentagon, and the downed United Airlines Flight 93, along with the noise of continued bombardment in Israel, Johnson patriotically realigned his blog posts. He began to cover the War on Terror, the invasion in Iraq and Afghanistan, and the left bent bias of the'mainstream' media.As the post 9-11 period began to heat up, as President Bush began his slow ratcheting up to war in Iraq, after invading Afghanistan with little controversy, a serious and often angry discussion, fueled naturally by the events in September 2001, simmered within the more conservative ranks.Leftists and many liberals blamed America, and conservatives blamed either Islam or radical Islamists. LGF provided an oasis, a watering hole where likeminded patriots could vent their frustration, share their concerns and read pertinent news stories the major outlets either ignore or relegated into the deep back pages.During the 2004 election, as smoldering media bias lent a hand to democratic candidate John Kerry, LGF made headlines by exposing Dan Rather's blatant gaffe regarding the fake Bush TANG memos. By simple, clear observation untainted by a deeply etched agenda to discredit George Bush, someone at LGF, probably after noticing the lack of a fixed-width font, typed up the memo in Word. Using the New Roman Times font or similar, and following the convention found in the Killian TANG document, grave doubt was cast on the paper's authenticity.This, I believe was LGF's peak in relevancy or, at the very least, its local maximum. Once a useful tool, the blog has eroded into a worn and monotonous rubber belt of boredom.With the reelection of George Bush, many conservatives like me hopefully expected four more years of fighting jihadists, a confrontation with Iran, the shuttering of more hate-spewing Muslim 'charity' organizations, and a large decline or pro-jihad America-based media.Sadly, little, if any, of these expectations came to pass and the War on Terror went from cradle to grave without much growth in between. Bush spent nearly four years self-portrayed as a lame duck president, squandering the chance to greatly enhance his legacy as defender of American values and as a reformer in the Muslim world. As such, currently the War on Terror is dead, an anachronism from a time in America when 9-11 mattered.And that's where LGF began to decline, as the blog had increasingly less to offer. Today, when it isn't covering Israel's endless war with suicide bombers, LGF focuses on creationism, a topic far better covered in a myriad of other locations. In short, LGF no longer offers a unique perspective on a situation that hardly exists: the war on terror has concluded, and LGF wastes post-space on an issue most educated people consider dead.furthermore, when Johnson isn't posting on creationism, or entertaining his narcissism to an audience of chirping crickets with technical posts that boast how he's improved LGF, he's offering various open threads.An open thread at LGF is little more than a multitude of knowledgeable but otherwise apparently vain and pretentious posters playing for hit points. Hit points are either negative or positive, and most posts that garner negative points are simply unpopular by not conforming to the lockstep mentality of the various cliques that serve as basis for conversation.Within the LGF nomenclature are a number of terms used to label dissenters. One of those terms is a 'Moby'. Often, especially in the past, dissenting posters were labeled a Moby for merely offering an opposing opinion and sticking to that opinion throughout what many of the other posters gleefully call a 'roast'. A roast is essentially the group slamming of a 'Moby' or 'troll', and again these labels are applied to anyone that disagrees, along with the associated down dings in hit points.To exacerbate the situation, Johnson bans anyone he or the group deems a 'troll'. If you're a KOS kiddy, you get kicked eventually, regardless of how well or polite you played the LGF game.Essentially, posting at LGF, like most places on the internet, is very similar to high school. There are popularity contests, cliques, insults, and audacious but otherwise empty verbal threats. The exception is that most of the posters are supposedly adults, and many of them are otherwise highly educated. Much of this activity is included by the conversation category of the aforementioned 'troll roast'. If you're expecting enlightened and mature discussion, you're better off watching 'All in the Family', if only to avoid the undercurrent of anti-Muslim bigotry.When you consider all the interpersonal unpleasantness and the undercurrent of dislike for Islam, which has waned considerably with the decline of the WoT, and the apparent and inescapable irrelevancy of LGF's dwindling contribution to anti-jihad discussion, LGF draws a near zero in usability.Charles Johnson's never-ending self-love and self-promotion doesn't assist the situation either. When he isn't sputtering to life about his mundane photos, or his uninteresting musical choices, he's drawing tears of boredom with tedious extolling of his AJAX and refactoring skills. I'm immediately reminded of Ayn Rand's cult of personality, wherein no member dared to question her leadership. Johnson's influence and importance is much-reduced from Rand's historical consideration, but you'd never know it from the way Johnson appropriates the past via common sense moments (Killian TANG documents) and his own undeserved sense of grandiosity.To Charles: We don't care about your musical taste, your bike or your average photos. We don't care about your technical skills. We don't care to kowtow to your popularity metrics or your thuggish bootlicking fans. We don't care about your pretentious and empty post-quotes or your silly war on creationism. Everything isn't about you. It's about America. Either return to some semblance of political and ideological use, or give up the ghost.I give LGF on star, for past merit and the hope it one day can provide more than a blog-based bumper sticker on how to wander away from purpose and alienate
Source (K): Once a relevant blog on Islamists, now a mouthpiece for incestuous boredom

Source (H): LGF presents a wide range of intelligent views on politics, science and human affairs. It is a consistently good read.
best post-9/11 blog ever, but the focus has changed.  it is now boring. charles has lost his focus. sad.

I regularly read this newspaper in its paper edition here in Italy, and I've tried the Kimble subscription to it. Too bad that it delivers late, preventing me from reading daily editions while riding to work etc. A prompter delivery would be appreciated by all European readers of this newspaper.

Ho sottoscritto l'abbonamento di prova a La Stampa, che considero il quotidiano italiano più obiettivo attualmente in edicola.L'edizione per Kindle, tuttavia, è un po'approssimativa: gli articoli sono frammentati: si trovano due o tre articoli con lo stesso titolo anche in punti diversi del giornale; spesso si fa riferimento a foto non riportate nella versione elettronica, ... .Sul fronte tecnologico, come pure su altri versanti, La Stampa dimostra di essere un passo avanti agli altri quotidiani italiani. Auspico faccia uno sforzo per migliorare anche la qualità di questa presenza.

Provata la versione dimostrativa gratuita di 14 giorni. Per prima cosa, da lodare l'iniziativa, per il momento unica nel panorama delle testate italiane, di creare una versione per il Kindle. Coraggiosi. Si spera che nel futuro la scelta diventi un pochino più ampia, ma questo purtroppo dipende dal mercato kindle in Italia...Gli articoli sono ben organizzati e completi, ciascuno diviso nella sua sezione. Il menu (click centrale) permette di andare nella sezione che interessa e visualizzare i relativi articoli.Purtroppo gli errori di battitura sono piuttosto numerosi. Si ha come l'impressione che non ci sia nessun controllo finale. Le foto sono quasi del tutto assenti (una per edizione, di solito e neanche significative), anche se poi spesso compaiono riferimenti a foto che non esistono: forse non sono necessarie, ma qualche immagine in più sarebbe interessante. A volte la formattazione generale (per esempio per le notizie brevi) non è proprio perfetta.Peccato. Con un minimo sforzo in più si potrebbe realizzare un prodotto migliore, o quantomeno che valga i 19.99$ mensili.

I was very interested in trying a newspaper on my new Kindle and, sadly, La Stampa is the only italian newspaper available. I tried the 14 day free trial anyway, wishing that having the chance to read it in the early morning while still in my bed or while commuting would prevail on the fact that the contents of the printed version are usually badly written and sectarian.The experience was terrible.The contents are indeed badly written and sectarian too, but there's more.The newspaper is delivered late, sometimes even after noon, giving me the opportunity to buy a better newspaper elsewhere before my Kindle receives La Stampa.There often are several articles (as many as 10) on the same subject, each one repeating or even contradicting what was said in the others. You have to scan through every article and bring together the informations to make yourself an idea of what they're talking about.The titles don't help either, as they are usually vague or not complete.There are also several references in each issue to pictures and tables that are not included in the kindle edition.Overall I wouldn't recommend the subscription to anyone; the only reason could be that there aren't other italian newspapers, but I was so displeased I am cancelling it, waiting for something better to show up.

This is without a doubt one of the best screen cleaners I have ever used. I use it on my flat screen TV, my computer screen, my laptop display and,even my eyeglasses. It come with a soft microfiber cloth that is very durable, and doesn't scratch what you are cleaning. Early on I found that the liquid didn't absorb into the sponge at the top of the container very well. So, I stored it standing up, with the eraser sponge facing down. When you're needing something cleaned, pop off the top and it's ready to go ! It is superior at getting scuff marks and oil off. Fingerprints come right off ! I would recommend it 100% for anyone to use.

Source (K): One use and my Kindle screen just glows

Source (H): This remote is really easy to use.  It has all the buttons you need without having so many buttons that you’re always searching for the buttons that actually matter.Here is why this remote is exceptional:Voice Search – Just hold down the microphone button and say what you want to watch.  The search results will appear within just a few seconds.  Granted the voice recognition isn’t perfect…It’s 2014, not 2054 after all…but the voice recognition works far better (and faster) than trying to type the name of the show you want to watch.Bluetooth – When you mount your Fire TV, you won’t have to worry about pointing the remote sensor towards the ceiling to get good remote reception.  Bluetooth goes right through just about anything.

Have you never lost a remote control in your life? Not you, of course, but someone else in the house -- so spend the next 10 seconds considering if you should order a spare, rather than thinking whether you are going to vote down this review.But considering that the new Fire-TV has no buttons like a DVR or cable box, and is not controlled via your phone or tablet like Chromecast-type devices, just save yourself the extra cost of frantic NEXT DAY SHIPPING later, when you do misplace the remote that ships with your original Amazon streaming device.And so to not waste your time, be aware that the optional, $39 GAME CONTROLLER also will operate many of the menu features (but not voice search) without the need for this remote. Right now though (first week of the product) there is almost a one month wait for backorders on that alternative to this wand unit.I'm sure everywhere wishes this great bluetooth remote with microphone was at least five dollars cheaper, but I hope this review might have helped a few people looking into Amazon FireTV realize their options in different controllers!

This remote, unlike most you've ever used, sends its signal to the receiving device (the Fire TV) over radio waves (specifically via Bluetooth). This means that line-of-sight is completely irrelevant! I even just confirmed it will work when I'm at the other side of my house, outside. No more pointing at the TV necessary.The two drawbacks of this are battery use (the remote takes two AAA, whereas a similar device like Apple TV's takes one watch-type battery, although those are expensive to replace), and if you have a universal remote it won't be able to control the Fire TV.The remote is well built with a good finish. I'd say it is a thin notch below Apple TV's in terms of build quality (the latter being created out of a single shaped piece, without seams).Buttons are well positioned and there are enough of them to give more options than with, say, Apple's, but not so many there is any real time spent learning the remote. If you're a true master of your TV you know the importance of being able to control the main functions without looking at the remote, and this fits the bill well.Finally, the circular directional button isn't *quite* as nice in feel as Apple's, but perfectly functional.Seriously, though, the radio transmitter in this is something I absolutely love.
Source (K): Top tier remote with exceptional range

Source (H): This is a replacement for the first remote ordered. The additional remote was to use as the second remote with the Fire TV Box.The returned remote voice recognition didn't work. Thanks to Amazon's 14 day free trials, I was able to try both the Onion Newspaper and theThe Onion Blog.  The main difference is the newspaper is weekly and the blog is daily.  The newspaper and blog (website) articles are the same, however the blog contains just 63% (17/27) of the articles published within the previous four days whereas the newspaper contains 92% (34/37) of the articles published within the previous 7 days, based on the issues of each I used for this analysis.  Paying for a blog, and only getting 63% of the updates (and not even all the updates for the current day) is appaling.  Given this is fake news, I don't mind only receiving it once a week, and at least you are getting 92% of the articles published online and in the actual newspaper.  Also, the newspaper includes all the [...] articles (approximately 35), which are real entertainment news including TV, Games, Film, Music, DVD, and Books reviews, interviews -- which you don't any of these on the blog.  As far as the content, if you aren't familiar with it, just go to [...] and give it a twirl before coming here.  These are deadpan satirical articles, not meant to be taken seriously by any stretch of the imagination.  The articles sometimes miss the mark, but others are the funniest entertainment I can get anywhere, and well worth a couple bucks a month.  [...]

Source (H): What more need be said about a publication that contains breaking headlines such as, "Art World Relived As Thieves Steal Pretty Terrible Late Period Renoir Work"? You get the subtle, sneaky humor, or you don't. For those that do, the issue at hand is whether the Kindle edition is worth the price.As a new Kindle user, one of the things I look for in a magazine is not just the quality of what's inside, but how well its put together and formatted and how much I'm paying vs what  get. Is it a hastily assembled afterthought with little real effort compared to the print or web version, or am I actually paying for something that sees fit to put a professional degree of effort into the product?In my opinion, The Onion does a decent job in taking its silliness quite seriously.*Formatting*One of the major complaints among "serious" newspapers catering to the Kindle crowd is that pictures, graphics, and sometimes even whole sections are missing and formatting is often underwhelming with little attention paid to making use of the Kindle's abilities. Not only does The Onion include pics, graphics, and satirical political cartoons to enrich the experience, it is easy to navigate. One cannot help but get the impression that the other guys just aren't trying.*Value*The current price ($2.50 a month, or about $0.63 an issue rounded up) isn't too bad for what you get. You get more sections and articles than most mainstream magazines and papers in that price range, with sections devoting to skewering everything including News, Sports, Opinion, Entertainment, and others. Ten sections and in my premiere issue, 51 separate articles. That's actually a fully loaded magazine minus the ads (which if they did have they'd likely only make fun of anyway). Not bad at all for the price of a candy bar.The quirky, subtle brand of humor won't appeal to everyone (hence the less than perfect score), but those that choose to indulge in it won't be disappointed by lazy assembly or lack of content.

The general idea behind this book is that many of the waste products your body produces are acidic (true), these waste products need to be neutralized by the body (true), and ionized alkaline water greatly assists with that process (up to you to decide). It makes natural sense that an alkaline substance would be beneficial in removing acidic substances. I was in agreement with the author and was buying into the benefits of ionized water outlined by the author, but I did a little due diligence and tried to corroborate the author's claims. First and foremost I should note that my skepticism did start while reading this book - there's several sections that attempt to prove the author's claims with chemistry; these attempts came off as though they were deliberately meant to confuse the reader (I have a weak understanding of chemistry so I was able to follow along for the most part, but they lost me at times). After reading the book, I looked for the water ionizing product that is mentioned several times in this book - aquacure. When I found their website, I immediately recognized their home page copy - it was from this book! That was a big red flag for me, so I began to look to other sources of info on ionized water. I immediately found dozens of sites outlining ionized water as a hoax. One such site really spoke to me - it stated that the alkalinity of ionized water would be destroyed by your stomach acid, something the author stated as something that occurs to alkaline foods (I never put 2 and 2 together while reading)! It also stated that city water is frequently alkaline as alkaline water doesn't rust pipes. to me, this leads me to draw the conclusion that ionized water being extermely beneficial to health is bullocksMoral of the story, if you want advice on how to improve your healt, read "how and when to be your own doctor" - it holds MUCH more valid and meaningful advice than this book.

I have used this magazine for years to get the edge on upstart businesses. Before a company or franchise hits the radar screen of the major financial publications, you will find them mentioned in an article or advertising in the Home Business Magazine.Profit from that advanced knowledge by considering investing in the franchise or other publicly traded companies. You can get additional information on the company from the two penny stock markets, which is where the stock will most likely trade.Another useful way to use this magazine, is to look at new trends and old advertisers that continue to advertise. After all, who would spend money month after month if they had little to no response? Subscribe to this magazine and think outside the box. Let it be your business intelligence source. Even if you don't invest in a home business, or perhaps you have a business already, use the magazine for information on the latest, greatest, hot, new, breakout trends in the business world.James GartonAuthor of 25 Ways to Make Money Online

Looking in the Kindle section for photo blogs and resources, a blast from the past popped into view:Shutterbug.  Hadn't picked up an issue of this magazine in a few years, yet there had been a time further back that I had been a subscriber to their print editions, so curiosity got the better of me.And more curious was the note that I found when I looked closer at the page: Available only on these devices.  A click there revealed that it was available for the Kindle Fire or Kindle for iPad, yet not for my Kindle 2.  But since it came with a 14-day free trial, decided to give it a shot.Opening it on theKindle Firewith its full-color display was interesting, as the only magazines and periodicals that I had viewed this way had been on the Kindle 2 or on friends' iPads.  And it's just like picking up any better-grade photo magazine off of a news stand... and then there are the ads. But there's a way around the ads, as I've noted in my update at the bottom.The content is good, and with some excellent articles.  The current issue that I looked at has articles such as "Gimbal Heads: An Essential Long Lens Accessory," by Jay Miller.  The photos of the heads were truly state-of-the-art examples, and the author states: "I've been a dedicated gimbal head user for a long time. If you shoot with seriously long lenses, no other head comes close to offering a gimbal's stability, articulation, and flexibility. Forget ball heads and anything else designed to attach long telephotos to a tripod. If you're a big lens user and you photograph things that move, a gimbal is the only way to go."Travel photographer Maynard Switzer's graphic use of color and composition enables him to capture every nuance of the human spirit and its environment. His photo essay "Capturing Character: Beyond the Beaten Path" was a visual exploration but also a great article outlining the processes he takes to get the right image at the right time, even when one is working with limited time.The Image Tech pages reviewed theOlympus E-PL3(aka `PEN Lite') digital camera.  This has been positioned as a simplified, lower-cost alternative to the company's higher-end offerings.  It's now the entry-level model in the PEN lineup, sitting between the PEN Mini and Olympus' flagship E-P3, offering a combination of external control points and compact-camera-like handling that may appeal to those who want high image quality in a small package, and are ready to move beyond an 'auto everything' experience.  Shutterbug came up with some interesting pros and cons, as they did in the same issue with the newNikon 1 J1, with its new CSC format.There's an excellent article in the Techniques page, a book excerpt fromWes Kroninger's Lighting: Design Techniques for Digital Photographers, offering tips, lighting diagrams and descriptions accompanying the images of the models, and it's one worth reading.And of course there are the ads, the inevitable ads, and they do proliferate.  Yet in the Kindle Fire format one can just flip past them easily, or pause to read when an interesting one goes by.  At this point I'll give this a 4-star rating.  Its layout and editorial content are truly 5-star level, but without doing a page count, it appears that perhaps up to half of the content is advertising. (Note: please see my update below on this.)Had also looked at another old favorite,American Photo.  This one is also for the Kindle Fire or Kindle for iPad formats, but it's now a bi-monthly, and has a higher subscription price.  Perhaps later, but for now I'll get my issues at the news stand.The Kindle Fire edition of this magazine includes Page View, where your magazines look just like the printed edition with all the photos and formatting, and after seeing this issue, I can attest to that.  When I first found Shutterbug here, I had only been using my Kindle Fire for a few weeks, and while exploring this monthly magazine on this device I discovered what is probably apparent to many.  The heavy use of ads was a distraction, until I found the Menu icon on the bottom middle of the Kindle Fire's screen. By tapping on this icon, you'll see the choice between Page View (the default) and Text View. Tapping on Text View allowed me to read all of the articles without the proliferation of advertising... yet all of the photos are still there, and in glorious color when thy appear in the magazine that way.  It's as if an editor took scissors to the advertisements and just cut them all out, and the test is quite readable.I can easily say that this Kindle edition of Shutterbug is worth a 5-star recommendation... and I'm enjoying all of the editorials, photos and product reviews in a manner that I hadn't seen before.  A subscription to the Kindle Fire edition of Shutterbug comes with a two-week free trial, so you have a chance to review it and see.  Try it and you'll see what I mean.February 14, 2012
Source (K): Updated: Shutterbug on the Kindle Fire

Source (H): I read and loved the Hunger Games trilogy, and after I finished I felt a hole that other books just couldn't fill.  They couldn't match the thrill of being in books so immersive and vivid.  I asked around and couldn't find anything that grabbed me, and then this book was mentioned on NPR when they were talking about books like the Hunger Games.So I got it and daaaang, let me tell you---Hunger Games was just a warm up.  From the first funny words this book has humor and humanity, but spins up quickly into VERY intense situations---and then doesn't let up for three books.  I haven't had a book keep me up past my bed time trying to read just a little bit more since High School (oh, so long ago).  This book puts the characters in some situations where it doesn't seem like there is a right answer and the lines between who's doing good and who's bad shift and blur like it must be in real life in areas ranging from the wild west, to Nazi Germany to rebellion and war zones today in the Middle East and Africa.Be aware, there is some language and scenes that are disturbing so not appropriate for all kids.  But a must read for those who are able to handle it.  A MUST READ.Also, I bought the trilogy and recommend that if you start you get all three.  Even though it's split in to three books, it's really one epic adventure (like Lord of the Rings) that doesn't have neat stopping points at the end of each book.

Pros:1. Attractive, book-like cover2. Lightweight3. Excellent grip on the PaperwhiteCons:1. Unpleasant petrochemical odor that does not dissipate outside the packaging2. Cover does not have magnet to turn Paperwhite off and on.

I agonized over which cover to buy for my new Kindle PW and finally settled on this one. I chose well. It looks like real leather - although has a smell that I hope will air out and dissipate over time. I was also afraid that the hard plastic holders might make the cover wider to hold than I wanted, but it's actually very comfortable to hold. Seems quality made, and the Kindle PW just slips right into and out of the case easily - which is good because I may do that a lot for various reasons. Unless you hold it upside down in a strong earthquake, I really don't think it will fall out. I do wish it didn't have the Incipio brand on the front of the cover, but I can live with it. Beautiful color as well.

The case looks great and works fine with one exception.  The Kindle doesn't actually lock-in, so after you close the cover, if you aren't paying attention, the Kindle could slide right out if you haven't used the band to close it.  But its inexpensive, looks really nice and has the feel of a book.  Overall I would recommend it but with the warning that its not completely secure.
Source (K): Great looking Not the Perfect Fit

Source (H): I read business week both print and online editions constantly. With a$300 net book you can read it in color and by the way do your e mail, business work and do it everywhere including foreign countries. Try that with a Kindle. Kindle edition I is a great product. Version II is only marginally better and still can't do audio books with a human voice. For audio reading one is better off with dudible.com which is owned by Amazon and far better for this purpose than the Kindle. This is not a slam at the Kindle just know what its purpose is and where it works the best!

This is my 3rd magazine subscription for my Kindle 2.0 (other two are Fortune and Technology Review). The BW Kindle version has neither pictures nor advertisements. That makes reading BW on Kindle a MUCH faster, but not quite as satisfactory, reading experience.The BW Kindle version is delivered wirelessly on every Friday, which is 3 days before its weekly Monday release. If you want to get your BW as early as possible, I don't think you can get BW faster than on Kindle.As far as content, the BW magazine always had the latest business news and trends for the casual reader. It is meant for a light read that does not require a high level business knowledge. On the flip side, BW articles usually are lacking in technical depth and deep analysis. Its articles are rarely authoritative, but rather has a high quality newspaper(WSJ) type of journalism.One thing BW does very well is forecasting the future trends. It is willing to take a swipe at the future trends (and sometimes be dead wrong) so its reader can understand the business problems, needs, and solutions of the foreseeable future.

Really I like this magazine and I think that is very helpful for my job. because i'm financial manager, but the problem is that we need pictures, tables or graps thay helpt to enjoy the reading and have the support of course.
Source (K): Good magazine but we need pictures

Source (H): I dont like the fact that there is no pictures.  Take out at least 30% of enjoyment.  i will stay with print version

Just got a Kindle DX and thought BW looked like the most interesting to subscribe to.  Not disappointed at all.  Easy to clip and save articles, formatting is a little weird, but all in all easy to navigate.  5 stars.

Pros: A great magazine probably the only one that I can read all the way through. Kindle format very nicely formatted and navigating on a Kindle couldn't be easier.Cons: No pictures for customers outside the US. Why? 3G is much more available in europe and also much cheaper. Why should people in different areas pay the same price for less content. This magazine has some of the best photography of a business magazine particularly advertisements yet you don't get this from the Kindle version outside the US.
Source (K): Great magazine limited format for non-US

Source (H): Kindle format is really boring. No illustration, table, chart, picture. Reading experience is very different from printed version. I have discontinued after 2 issues.

I have just bought Kindle 2, international version, with the idea of getting books, magazines, and newspapers delivered to me in Rio/Brazil where I live. Kindle is great but... I was disappointed to learn that, outside of the US, Amazon delivers text-only versions of magazines and papers. This means I would have to read BW and other periodicals without any photos, tables, etc. I don't think I want to buy a subscription with that limitation. I'm adding this review to others like it in the hope that Amazon will hear the "voice of the customer" and do something about it.

I have been subscribing since August and I'm now hooked.  The hard copy has nice pictures, graphs & colors but what I really like about the Kindle subscription is that no matter where I am traveling - there it is every Friday.  They do still give you the statistics, it's just that they are written out and not in graphic format.  I also like that under the article title, they also give you the number of words in the article so you know if it is just a paragraph or one of their more in-depth articles.The Sections List index is exactly like the hard copy's table of contents dividing the articles under BusinessWeek's six main catagories & it lists how many articles are in each section.  So if you typically go to a certain section such as "Business Views", it's easy to go directly there.Another huge plus is it is much cheaper than the hard copy.  At $2.49/month it costs about $30 for a year's subscription.  The hard copy publication costs at least double that amount.Also there are no ads to have to flip through!  Give it a few weeks try, it really is a great Kindle subscription.

Came upon a fascinating article about how much my identity would be worth online, only to find it consisted entirely of a graph not included in the Kindle version. Really guys? A whole week to prepare this magazine and you couldn't even so a "save as" to format an image into a Kindle friendly version? How does a goofball paper like The Onion include multiple pictures per article and we can't even get an important and informative graph in this?They're charging regular price for minimal effort. Definitely not renewing my two-week trial.

This used to be my favorite magazine. I have been a subscriber for years. Unfortunately since Bloomberg bought it has gone straight down hill. It is becoming more and more of a political magazine and less and less dealing with business. The political comment is strictly liberal.When my subscription expires I will not be renewing. The bottom line is if you like liberal politics then this is the magazine for you. If you want business coverage you will need to look elsewhere.
Source (K): Not what it used to be

Source (H): I signed up for a subscription in December 2011, and the most recent issue I was sent was from JULY 2011. There's obviously a glitch here, so I cancelled the subscription. Will wait to see if they fix it.

If one buys the magazine directly from the publisher the price is the same, $35 per year. For that one not only gets the magazine delivered but can also read the latest issue on the web before the magazine arrives. You also have access to 30 years of issues from the archives. Buying the kindle edition here providesa nice reading experience on the kindle but no web access or archive access. This is according to LRB customer service. They also said that they hope to start selling a pure digital edition without delivery of the magazine some time in 2012.
The London Review is very substantive, but I never purchased a copy or a subscription -- just read copies in friend'shome.

I think that the previous reviewer should try again. I have just (19.12.2011) taken out a subscription to the London Review of Books and received the 15.12.2011 edition.I haven't been able to compare it with the printed magazine but it seems packed with interesting articles. It also comes out 24 times per year; the New York Review of Books 20 issues per year.I have been waiting for this for some time. I enjoy the New York Review of Books but I prefer to read the LRB as it is closer to my culture. The NYROB contains many articles on American politics and issues like the US health system, which are of less interest to non-Americans like me.

Everyday I enjoy Kindling to this Reuter's feature and seeing what odd, strange or funny/weird story has been uncovered. Sort of like The Onion, but all true. The price is great for having such delightfully strange and true stories on your Kindle each day.

Reuters Oddly Enough sends wacky, entertaining news stories to your Kindle each weekday (sometimes several a day!).  Most of them are short and great for when you just have a minute or two for reading.  It seems like almost every story is a "Wow, you're not gonna believe THIS one!" and I find myself reading them over to my fiancee and family.  For all that, the price is excellent and having it delivered to the Kindle is very convenient! Enjoy!

I liked this blog OK - it is not so deeply technical and doesn't focus on games and gadgets like most tech blogs.  It is from the Wall Street Journal so it has a business flavor.  However I have not received this blog for almost two weeks (as of Dec, 2009) and Amazon has not responded to my request for help.  Maybe I was the only one subscribing to this...I canceled my subscription.

Due to customer feedback, with regard to the inside lining leaving marks on the Kindle, we discontinued the item and redesigned the case with a grey inside lining that will not leave any marks on your device. Sincere apologies for any inconvenience caused in the delay in making this case availbale. Thank you for your continued support. OCTO

Source (H): I love the unique color of this case, and when I first got it I put my Kindle in and it fit super snugly. I was worried about having  a case that doesnt close or lock in, since its so that my kindle doesnt get scratched in my purse I didn't want it to fall out. Its actually the opposite, maybe since its so new, its actually kind of hard to get out of the case, but it is secure, and once you get used to it, its not that bad. The only thing I do dislike about this case is that its black fabric on the inside and its rubbing off on my kindle. So now I have 2 black lines going down my kindle that aren't washing off. Normally I'd be extremely angry about this, and thats why I wanted to let other people know, but personally I want to get a skin from [...] anyways so that will get rid of my two black lines. I suggest if you're buying this one to be prepared for the black stuff that rubs off on the inside. Besides that, cosmetically its pretty, and it does what it needs to, my kindle isnt getting scratched in my purse now. Thanks for listening.-Maggy

I'm giving the Kindle Smithsonian only two stars, but not because of the content, which is generally outstanding, nor because of the format, which is also excellent, but because of its delivery schedule.In short, Smithsonian doesn't deliver  your subscription to your Kindle until the 15th of each month. This is completely unacceptable.Their own website and their printed edition is available to readers and subscribers on the 1st of each month. So by the time you get your Kindle subscription delivered most everybody else has already read it cover to cover.In fact, if you want, just go their website and read the available articles for the new edition, and by the time it reaches your Kindle, you may have already read most of what you wanted to read in the first place.How would you like to receive Monday's newspaper on Wednesday, and Tuesday's newspaper on Thursday, and so on.Well, the current Smithsonian Kindle subscription is even worse than that. It appears that Smithsonian not doesn't care about its e-subscribers, but actually holds them in disdain and/or contempt.I'll give them another month or two to fix it. If they don't, I'm a gonner.EDIT: I've upped my rating to five stars for several reasons. First, Smithsonian actually replied to this comment in a very professional and positive manner and explained that this was a mulitple problem error that they have now discovered and fixed.Secondly, I just received my July/August issue on the 24th of June, i.e., about a week early.Thirdly, with regard to content, Smithsonian is my favorite Kindle magazine.I am thrilled that this has been acknowledged and fixed. Thanks, Smithsonian, for addressing this.

A big thumbs-down to Smithsonian Magazine's decision to automatically remove the previous month's edition as soon as the new one arrives on your Kindle. If I don't manage to get the current edition read on time, they take away the product that I paid for.  Bad marketing decision and I'll be cancelling my subscription because of this.  I'd consider buying the magazine hard-copy edition, but the whole thing leaves a bad taste in my mouth.  National Geographic is more deserving of my money and I don't feel cheated by them.
Source (K): Great Magazine, but you'd better read each edition as soon as you get it!

Source (H): I just started my 14 day free trial and I am convinced that this is a keeper! The articles are the full length ones from the print edition, and contain the original illustrations, although Kindle users get them in black and white. The photgraphs are wonderful, as they are in high definition, and not muddled as in some other Kindle publications. I received the download this morning and immediately read the cover story on the opening battle of the Civil War -- it had the usual Smithsonian scholarship, and the black and white images from contemporary art and photos of the period appeared at the end of the article. I highly recommend this publication on your Kindle, as I could not find any meaningful flaws.
Source (K): Wish I Had Subscribed Earlier, it's That Good!

Source (H): Bad enough that Kindle only has a few past issues available for redownload for most magazines. It doesn't matter that you've paid for them. The Smithsonian erases all past issues so if you don't finish an article, tough nuts. No mention of that when I got the 14 day trial. Don't tell me to save it in my kindle, the issues should be available, they were paid for. It is a great magazine, but it does me no good if I can't read them.
Source (K): I think it's disgusting that only current edition is available

Source (H): UPDATE: Per a post by a smithsonian employee, this is not currently the case.I did not get around to looking at my issue of Smithsonian Magazine for last month, and when I went to read it, it was gone. I had not removed it from the kindle. It was just past 1 month old, and it had been removed. I went to the manage your kindle page to re-send the older issue, and it wasn't available. Smithsonian decided to restrict possession of their magazine copies to only the current issue unless you explicitly mark "keep this issue". You can *never* re-download later, even if your device dies.As a result of this, and the fact that the magazine is twice as expensive in kindle than on paper, I have decided to cancel my subscription. It's a very interesting magazine, and has a lot of articles I have enjoyed, but their policies are horrid, and I don't want to waste my money on magazines that I can't even read again later.

Source (H): I have gotten the printed Smithsonian Magazine for many years now and would love to read it on my Kindle Fire.  I see I can pay another $2/month to do that.  I get National Geographic, Sunset and Readers Digest free because I subscribe to the print editions.  Why doesn't Smithsonian have this same benefit?
Source (K): Why do I have to pay for 2nd magazine?

Source (H): I am in my 2 week free trial.  However, I am quite impressed by the quality of this magazine.  I was a little concerned about the download  time of this magazine.  It took a little while compared to most books and other magazines-but then I found out why.  They have included a set of high res photos with each story.  These photos (and diagrams and maps) are very detailed and look great when they are zoomed.  The only negative, and it is slight is that them come at the end of the articles.The content is great and it is put into an easy to digest format.  Of course, there will be people who complain that it is all black and white, but it is a Kindle.  And as I recall, Ansel Adams did quite well with his black and white photos.This is a monthly, so you have plenty of time to digest the articles.  Overall, it is a great magazine for the price.

The articles in this magazine are very engaging and well written.  I was surprised as I expected to wade through a heavy academic style of writing, but instead, the the articles are easy to read and highly informative.  I would recommend this magazine to anyone interested in the world around them.In one issue, I read about everything from sunspots to the American civil war.  There is a great diversity to the topics covered and each article is addictive and very difficult to put down once you start reading it.I'm grateful for the free trial that Amazon provides (I wouldn't have tried this magazine otherwise) and I feel that this is definitely a keeper.The only reason that this review does not receive the full 5 stars is that apparently international customers do not receive all the pictures and maps that American Kindle users do.  It would be nice to receive the pictures even if it meant paying a bit more than the US customers do.Even without the illustrations and maps, this is a fantastic read and well worth subscribing to.

i don't normally use caps or exclamation marks, but thought i should, to slam dance with the "No Pictures!" review.the Kindle Time magazine is organized so you can go to sections & then articles, or just page straight through it, all the while encountering no ads.  this is wonderful.on some articles, the formatting is confusing.  the line spacing sometimes implies that a line of information is tied to that above when it is tied to that below - & vice versa.i like getting my news on a weekly basis - after they've ironed out most of the wrinkles.  was subscribing to Newsweek, but am now a confirmed Kindle person sooooo... bye bye Newsweek. i continue to subscribe to the best weekly news - The Week - tried unsuccessfully so far to persuade them to go Kindle, but can't give them up.  oh well, i have to use all those reading glasses i bought pre-Kindle for something.BTW if you want pictures, buy People magazine - like a normal person.  that's a bit harsh.  sorry, i just like the movie line "take a Valium, like a normal person".  let's face it, i love pictures imbedded in text too, but i can't help but enjoy the efficiency of straight gulping informative text.

Enough Obama already.  There are other topics in the world.  No wonder you are going broke, the electronic version of your rag is even worse, much worse, than the regular magazine.  I am so sorry that I spent one penny on this crap!

Source (H): There's nothing wrong with being a news magazine with an agenda to forward the Democratic Party as long as you 'fess up to it.  What is wrong is purporting to report the news with no bias when nothing can be farthur from the truth.For an illustration in honesty in publishing, check out National Review.  Readers may not agree but at least they understand what they are purchasing.Love Live Prada!  Oops. I meant Time Magazine.
I am giving a terrible review because this is not available for the Kindle on the iPad!!
