what a horrible rag this has become.  any pretense of journalism is long gone.  i don t even look at it any more.

I always appreciate the reviews from others that Amazon provides. I think that like most people we tend to look at the extremes in view when in fact, like most things, the quality of a given thing is usually somewhere in the middle. No, this Kindle edition is not the paper edition with colorful pictures, advertising and needless fluff. Another reviewer found fault with Time magazine in general and decided to voice those complaints against this Kindle edition. If you don't like Time magazine then by all means don't read it, but don't take it out on the Kindle edition when in fact you don't like Time magazine at all. It is what it is, and I think we all pretty much know what it is, a well established franchise like McDonalds or Burger King, it tastes the same everywhere; and if you are happy with a convenient, portable electronic edition of Time magazine which can be read on the go, then you'll be happy with this.
Source (K): Kindle Time magazine is NOT the paper version

Source (H): I was reluctant to subscribe given the previous reviews. After trying it, I am much more in favor of the Kindle version than I thought I will be.1. The graphs and a lot of pictures are not there, but for the most part I am content with the text only.2. For those of you who like the feel of paper in your hands, the Kindle version is not it. But then maybe the Kindle is not something for you either.3. I have a little bit of commute and I can choose to have some pieces read back to me - that beats the paper edition, even if the voice reader has a flat affect, I can understand all of it.4. If I travel I can still get it.5. If I have downtime I am closer to the Kindle than to the magazines, especially when not at home.6. As for pricing: there are no ads in the Kindle version. I suspect that the ads pay some of the paper version, but not the electronic one. BTW - the INTRODUCTORY subscription to the paper version is priced lower than the Kindle version, but I am not sure that the extended subscription stays at the same price.
I love reading the Time news articlesoffered on the Kindle. I don't missthe charts/pictures/ads, and the priceis perfect.
I haven't even gotten this for my Kindle but I am baffled by the price.  The paper version is $20/yr and this is $1.49/week! Why wouldn't it be cheaper to deliver it without the paper or mail?

I have been subscribing to Time magazine for 10 years now and I just recently bought my Kindle and was excited to subscribe to the Time magazine Kindle edition.  I flipped through the issues and saw no pictures at all.  I was really disappointed by the lack of effort on the part of Time magazine.  I can get the exact same content on the web for free.  Why should I spend money and get text without any pictures?  Even Reader's Digest Kindle Edition made the effort by adding pictures.  If Reader's Digest can add pictures, you can too!  I know the image quality on the  Kindle is poor, but at least add some pictures or graphics to spice up the Kindle edition.
Source (K): Deeply Disappointed, Lack of effort - Please add some photos!

Source (H): They are not going to win any design awards for the implementation, but the content is simple and quick to read. I use it as a supplement to my printed subscription of the magazine.  I commute via the subway, so for me it's really handy to have the articles available on my Kindle.The Good: Quick and simple to use.The Bad: Don't expect this version to replace your printed or online experience. Time's photos and graphs really enhance the stories... they currently are not a part of this version.

After seeing all the negative reviews I was very worried. However, I've been wanting a regular news source on my Kindle for sometime and decided to give Time a trial run anyways. I'm very glad I did! There aren't pictures (and I love photography) but the articles are excellent, well-formated, and easy to navigate. In fact, I'm only giving it 4 stars because I do miss the photographs (sometimes photos say more than any article ever could). Beyond that though, I've found Time for Kindle to be perfectly fine.

Time has always been an excellent magazine, but there is no excuse for charging more for an electronic version that doesn't require paper, ink, a printing press, or postage for delivery, especially when the pictures and graphics (many of which help explain the article) are so limited.The publisher's unwillingness to pass on their savings to the consumer, and at the same time offer a financial incentive to undertake a greener method of delivery, earns them poor marks in my humble opinion.Everybody wants to go green, but I see no reason to make us pay extra for it when the publishers aren't.

I consider myself somewhat middle of the road.  I knew this was a left leaning mag but thought they might at least attempt to be non-biased in some articles.  Wrong!  This is too far left for me.  Not crazy about the format either.
Kindle or news stand edition, it's still a rag suitable only for the aluminum foil brigade or Obamamaniacs. May be useful if have a birdcage to line.
this year lots of kids are wasting their time in the pool.th e worst thing is that their is a virus in our state.i think you know that virus:the swine flu.

Well, I mean, yes they are, if that's the sort of thing you like. What creates a problem for me with regard to the artwork is that there are numerous times where the text will refer to an illustration or chart that isn't there. That's the part that bugs me, because the effort to digitize the whole magazine for the Kindle overlooks the fact that once in awhile you may NEED the accompanying artwork. Tables, for instance, are converted to text and are basically unreadable unless you really want to study them.Time also has a quick overview of events (it's called "Pop Chart") of the week which are laid out on a scale from "Shocking" to "Shockingly Predictable". We get this scale as a list, so we don't really get the feel for the scale itself.But graphics aside, you do get the entire magazine and a good depth of coverage on some of the bigger issues that you wouldn't get in a daily newspaper.
Source (K): The missing illustrations aren't quite the problem

Source (H): I have no idea why all these people are giving this lower ratings. This is a kindle edition so you would not expect a photos or other graphics.I am looking forward to the next edition every week. The articles are entertaining, well written and informative. When you want to kill a few minutes it is great to read a few articles.Also it is incredible cheap.

I almost didn't subscribe to get Time Magazine for $1.49 per month because of the negative reviews, but then I thought, for 35 cents per issue, I would give it a try. I am extremely glad I did! It is true, there are only a few illustrations included, and I don't know if the content is edited to account for that fact, but whatever the case, I find I don't miss them while reading. In fact, I am one of those people who mostly buys magazines because I like the pictures and charts, and often don't read the articles. Obviously, with the Kindle format, that is not an option, but I am surprised by how easy and quickly I read the articles in the Kindle format, how much I enjoy them, and that I don't miss the "visuals." In fact, I am probably getting a lot more out of the magazine than when I just flipped through the pictures and captions. Also, the price is remarkably low for all you get. I have no association with "Time," I'm just a bureaucrat from upstate NY, but I wanted to balance those negative reviews with my very positive experience!
Source (K): Much Better than Reviews Led Me to Expect

Source (H): If you love your Time magazine and hate advertisements...this Kindle edition is for you. It has all the articles and no stupid advertisements. I see a lot of reviews about lack of photos...if your get a Time magazine for pictures, you are plainly missing the point of a Kindle. The Kindle is designed for "READERS"...not for pre-schoolers who like colored pictures. For $1.50 for four issues a month...I give this five stars.

I just got the latest Time on my Kindle and it now has the cover and some pictures.  I get Time for the articles and esepcially for Joe Klein's commentary so text only was OK. But having some graphics is an improvement.  However, it is annoying that some articles are left out.

Stupidly subscribing to this online magazine since January 2011. At a price 75% higher than the print edition, I might add. But it was convenient to find it on my Kindle every Friday and even though the formatting of some articles is pretty brutal, I just accepted it as something to be improved upon...eventually. However, after finding out that there was a special Bin Laden edition released dated May 20th 2011, I began to wonder "what else have I been missing?" Goodbye Time e-edition.

Source (H): I dropped my TIME subscription many years ago, around the time when every other cover picture & story of TIME became either "Where did Jesus go?", "New details about the life of Virgin Mary" or  "How to read your Bible while having sex?" or some similarly BS, fake non-story (tried some of them and all turned out to be unsubstantiated [...], pure speculations based on the combination of some half-illiterate hearsay and ill-educated claims, all usually beaten to death N times where N>10...) Source (K): Time is a Dinosaur on the verge of extinction

Source (H): It's TIME (sorry) to give the mag a 5 star rating .......I received my 22 Mar 10 Kindle issue 2 days before the paper version showed up in the mail ..... ALL the articles were present in the Kindle version ......... ALL of the major article pictures were present in the Kindle version ..... MOST of the sidebar, secondary, smaller pictures out of the print mag were included in the Kindle version ...... you get a full page shot of the cover ..... and a TOC comparable (but not exact) to the print version .......Color? .... no, but then you know that .......Fold it up and shove it in your back pocket at the airport or park? ...... no, but then you know that ...... I believe it takes a bit longer getting used to reading mags on the Kindle then paperback books ......... size, gloss, pictures, etc .......Price? ..... yes it is a bit more than the print version .... I guess it doesn't matter to me as much as it does to a number of other users ........ it is still less than you could buy it off the news stand ....... and if you are not  at the subscriber address .. i.e. flying, out-of-town ..... I consider the effortless delivery to my Kindle (where ever I am ) worth the money ......All in all a very good ebook translation folks .........
Source (K): It's TIME for a 5 star rating

Source (H): Bob, don't know where you learned  the "new math", but at 2.99 a month the Kindle version is 69 cents an issue.  I recently renewed my paper subscription and at $20 annually, that one is 38 cents an issue.  And it has all the pictures and charts, etc.  For my money, the Kindle version just isn't a good buy.

Whether Time puts in pictures or charts is their decisiion.  Other magazines and books on the Kindle have them.  For the price, it's a great deal.  Searching articles is easy.  How many of us flip through magazines and only read those articles that interest us?  Much easier on Kindle.
if you are a democrat and support obama@you will love this magazine.  i am not and do not so i will unsubscribe

This is a rather embarrassing electronic version of Time Magazine. There are NO pictures, no charts, no illustrations. Instead whenever you run into an article that has these in any decent amount, they've inserted an entry telling you to go get a PDF or print version. The salvation here is that their MOBILE web site at least has some images (even if impossibly small) and seems better formatted and organized. It looks and feels like some cheap RSS reader collected this rather than being an electronic version of the magazine. To fix it they should include all major article pictures, along with a full-screen copy of the cover. Time without pictures, is like the Braille-edition of Playboy. No wonder it is just $1.49 a month.

I don't read Time for the pictures, so I like Time's Kindle edition just fine. However, as I write this Amazon's price for Time's print edition is $20/year vs. $35.88/year($2.99/month) on the Kindle.  The Kindle price was a reasonable $17.88/year($1.49/month) when I started.  I currently have many subscriptions to magazines, newspapers and blogs on the Kindle, but since Amazon is raising the price on many of them, I will cancel when the price hikes go into effect(that means bye bye Time magazine) and keep just a few instead of 20!  Yeah, addicted I know, but the price is getting too high to keep so many.  I hope Amazon will rethink their price increases.
Source (K): As of this writing the Time Kindle edition costs a lot more than print!

Source (H): Time has had some ridiculous cover stories in the past, but really? There's no story more pressing than some whack-job parenting technique that encourages borderline incest?

With all the negative reviews I didn't have high hopes for this but it is actually not that bad.  There are pictures although not as many as the print edition.  It is pretty reasonably priced though and very convient to just have it appear on your kindle.  No worries about old issues piled up and it saves paper!  The format is pretty much like I would expect on the kindle.
Source (K): Much better than the review lead you to believe

Source (H): When the cover story of the current issue (December 21, 2009) is "The Year in Pictures - Extraordinary Images from 2009 in the Words of Those Who Took Them" and there is NOT ONE accompanying image - yes, even in the US edition, downloaded in the US - it absolutely beggars belief as to what the point of the Kindle version is.  (Each and every article even has a lead-in crediting "Words and photograph by..." each author, just to tease you.)
Source (K): Almost complete lack of images is alarming

Source (H): No, it doesn't have the beautiful Time photographs.  Yes, it is a weekly magazine.  No, the kindle version lacks shiny glossy pages you can thumb through.  It does, however, contain the great articles that Time is known for.  I have actually found that I'm more inclined to read it cover to cover than I would be if it had the photos to distract me.  At the price (roughly 38 cents an issue) it can't be beat.

As others have noted, Time version for Kindle is pretty bland and without the feel of a magazine.  Like the  Kindle for books and the Wall Street Journal.  Can't get excited about it for this magazine.

Even with low expectations I was still disappointed in this. And now a price increase??....$36 per year for the inferior Kindle version, or $20 per year for the full color physical magazine with photos and illustrations? Huh??

Time has addressed some of the concerns previous reviewers have brought up - there are no more truncated articles, and there are occasionally a few pictures with the articles. The writing remains diverse and interesting. I find that the lack of charts, ads, and huge picture spreads allows me to better focus on the writing, and the messages the authors wish to convey.However, it still lacks a table of contents. I still feel that some articles are missing on occasion, although I don't have a print edition to compare it to.So, for a $1.49 a month magazine (just under the price of a print subscription), it's decent. But at $2.99? Nearing double the price of a print subscription, with all the color pictures and charts, and knowledge that you are, in fact, getting the whole text of every article published? Just not worth it.
Source (K): Passable - but not good enough for a price hike

Source (H): I don't mind reading Time without pictures and I have enjoyed the articles, but Amazon just doubled the subscription price.  Sure, since I am already a subscriber, I can get 6 more months at the $1.49 per month, but I am afraid that this is just the beginning.  I understand that everything goes up in price, but I have only had a Kindle for 2 months and I didn't expect such large increases in book and magazine prices so soon.  I guess I am too naive.

Now that the price of the Kindle edition has been raised to $2.99, this product is no longer worth it. I could live with the absence of the pictures from the print edition. It's not as though they would have reproduced well on my Kindle 1 anyway. I was also OK with the fact that the Kindle edition does not include all of the articles from the print version. A subscription on the Kindle wasn't much cheaper than a print subscription, but that was fine. But with the raise in price, a Kindle subscription is ~$36 annually. You can get a print subscription for only $20. Why pay more for an inferior product?
Source (K): The Raise in Price Lowers the Value

Source (H): The price increases of newspapers on the Kindle (NYT, Bos Globe, Financial Times, USA Today...) has become unacceptable and the Economist, while a great news source, is also overpriced on the Kindle. Time Magazine has strengthened it's content during the past couple of years and the addition of Fareed Zakaria was a home run. The Kindle edition has enough graphics for my needs and the content is exactly that of the hard copy magazine. I enjoy the variety of topics and the in depth cover stories. Time is a very good weekly news, culture, and entertainment source and I tend to read it much more when on the Kindle...virtually cover-to-cover. The cost of $2.99/mo is fair. The New Yorker & Time are my two Kindle subscriptions and well worth the price.
The formatting is a little off, but most of the content is there. Since there are no ads in the kindle version, it is even easier to read than the paper one. Defnitely worth the price.

The straw that broke the camel's back for me was that the magazine cover highlighted 3 stories including one about Walter Cronkite. But the Kindle edition of the issue does not include the story.  I can forgive (but not love) the lack of graphics, but when the cover stories aren't even included, then I wonder what I'm paying for.

My psycho ex-girlfriend broke into my account and made many purchases including this one. THERE IS NO REFUND OPTION HERE AND I DEMAND A REFUND IMMEDIATELY. I have changed all my passwords (for the second time). I demand a refund on this title from my account immediately.
too abbreviated. also no pics or charts. looks like Time did a very minimalist job on this project and made themselves look bad in the process.

I read the Kindle version of Time in very little time. It did not seem to have anything in it that I could not have read for free searching the internet. I have to question the wisdom of any form of weekly news magazine in the age of the internet.Not worth paying for news you can get for free on the Internet.
Source (K): Did not seem to have as much content as the hard copy.

Source (H): I cancelled this subscription the moment I saw the first "issue".  It's more like a text-only download of the magazine.  I was severely disappointed at its implementation.  Initially I had hoped to transition my physical magazine subscription to the Kindle, but I like the graphics and format exponentially better than the Kindle version.

In the advertisement, we read "The Kindle Edition of Time contains most articles found in the print edition, but will not include all images."  Either TIME has shrunk dramatically (possible) since I last subscribed, or you don't get "most of the articles".  I found a lack of hard news and too much fluff.  Images should be featured.  Until the e-version becomes a lot more robust, I'm going to opt out.

Great recipes! Many are family recipes that have been used by generations. All are tested and very makeable and delicious. I have used the website for a few years but now love the magazine too. It encourages me to try new recipes because of the nice pictures that draw my attention and they are easy to read and follow.
Source (K): Perfect magazine for all types of cooking!

Source (H): My wife and I have found a lot of very tasty recipes from the allrecipes website and the Allrecipes Dinner Spinner Pro app. When I saw that Amazon was offering a special rate on a yearly subscription (6 bimonthly issues) to the digital magazine, I took the offer. The digital magazine is a fine complement to the Allrecipes app and the website. I've already perused the December 2013 - January 2014 issue, and for both content and style, I give it 5 stars.With 123 pages, including advertisements, there's a lot to see. There are plenty of recipes, of course (and be sure to check out the seven winning cookie recipes), but there are other food articles, like "With the Grain," that describes fifteen different grains and how to prepare them. As for the layout, you can choose the traditional magazine view or a more reader-friendly view by double-tapping the page. Everything is indexed and easy to find. The food photography is first rate, as good as I've seen in any magazine.Overall, the Allrecipes digital edition is a very polished, professional-looking, fun-to-read magazine that any foodie should enjoy.

I have loved allrecipes.com forever. It is my go to website when I am on a recipe prowl. When I saw this magazine available on my Kindle, I wondered how I would use it when I spent so much time on the website. They offered it free for a month, so I figured what did I have to lose.Gotta tell you. I devoured the entire magazine. Read it like a book. Great articles, tips I wouldn't have thought of and best of all, they commented on the recipes and advised you of changes they would make if they made the dish again.I liked it enough to search for a place on Amazon to review it on my own!  Thanks, allrecipes. You created a truly great magazine.

How and why the next Great Depression will engulf usWhy the US economy far more fragile and vulnerable than it was in 19291.  Our federal government, since the "Reagan Revolution" of 1981 (e.g. don't tax and spend, just borrow and spend), has borrowed during so-called good times, on a scale once reserved for a rare Keynesian stimulus to combat serious recession.  Thus we find ourselves at unprecedented levels of debt (comparable, in terms of GDP, to the entire cost of World War II), and so our current Depression has begun.2.  A corrupt-to-the-core corporate structure riddled with bogus accounting, reliance on financial trickery for profits and misdirected/worthless regulatory oversight.3.  A banking sector of such debauchery and fraud that the excesses of the 1920s are by comparison more like the pranks of slighty-naughty choirboys and girls.4.  A Federal system of entitlements (Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security) which has grown far faster than the underlying economy for decades and now threatens the very solvency of the government itself, so stupendous are the future obligations.5.  A global military hegemony which costs more than all the other military's and intelligence operations of the entire world put together -- the US military consumes more oil than the nation of Sweden (9 million residents).6.  An industrial, transportation and energy infrastructure that, rather than being rebuilt during the past 26 years of debt-based "prosperity," has crumbled in a long decline.  Rather than invest in electrical power grids and energy-efficient transport systems, the US squandered the trillions of borrowed dollars on toys, gewgaws, electronics made elsewhere, malls and commercial towers with only transient value and millions of bloated, inefficient poorly constructed homes no one needed or could afford, i.e. "assets" which were not productive at all, "assets" which are now capital traps on a scale heretofore unimaginable.7.  A paucity of US savings (and thus of domestic capital) with only one historical comparison: during the depths of the Great Depression when unemployment was 25%.8.  A huge reliance on financial leverage, debt, borrowing and trickery for corporate profits -- the US exports soybeans, increasingly worthless dollars and "financial innovations" that are now exploding in economies from Ireland to India with the destructive force of superweapons.  In exchange for this dubious paper, we have accepted actual tangible goods from the rest of the world.  And the rest of the world is now slowly waking up to the fact they've been conned on a scale few can yet grasp.9.  Globalization has reworked the global supply chain in an astonishingly brief period of time.  As a result, the arbitrage of currencies, wages, governance (less is more profitable) and environmental regulations (zero is the most profitable) have all placed advanced post-industrial economies like the US at great structural disadvantage.10.  The US claims to be competitive but much of this competitiveness is highly selective and thus illusory.  Everything in the U.S. -- labor, goods, buildings and taxes -- is high-cost, overregulated (except for finance, banking and governance) and vulnerable to unpredictable lawsuits and officially sanctioned looting.  Other than recent immigrants, non-US employers find the workforce is often surly, unappreciative, narcissistic, entitlement-obsessed, unhealthy, poorly educated, unmotivated, and more inclined to get-rich-quick schemes than actual enterprise or productivity.The middle management labors under impossible demands to enrich stockholders next quarter and heavy turnover insures few stay in any job long enough to learn it effectively.  Team cooperation is a doublespeak fraud imposed by "facilitators," creating a phony work environment where employees and managers alike pretend to care.  This bogus environment breeds a looting, game-the-system mentality in which everyone is grabbing for all they can before retirement, restructuring, reassignment, resignation or getting fired.A "quarterly-profits-are-God" mentality reduces the workforce (even the good workers) to units of input which are pared back or hired without regard to morale or loyalty.  This managerial and cultural pathology makes a mockery of worker loyalty and breeds the very qualities of distrust and "I got mine" attitude which undermines both productivity and workplace happiness.11.  Last but certainly not least, the US economy is highly dependent on cheap, abundant fossil fuels -- the very fuels that are in the global depletion phase, happy stories about unlimited natural gas and tar sands notwithstanding.For all these reasons, we can anticipate that the Depression currently beginning to unfold will be deeper, longer and more destructive than the Great Depression of the 1930s.=====================Next, let's recount the chain of events that partly parallel those of the first Great Depression but are about to synergistically take their toll in even more destructive ways:1.  The postwar income convergence (i.e the rise of the great middle class, the reduction of poverty and the relative reduction of the Plutocracy's share of national income) reverses in the early 1970s as the "true prosperity" of the postwar era ends and is replaced by income flowing increasingly to the top, as stagflation, globalization and the decline of dollar gut the purchasing power of the middle class.2.  The rising productivity of the 50s and 60s slips into flatline throughout the 70s and early 80s, only picking up again as computer software and hardware revolutionize the back office, sales, manufacturing, just-in-time shipping/production, etc.3.  Concurrent with this gradual return to productivity in the mid-80s is the gradual rise of finance as the key profit-center of corporate America.  As income skews ever more heavily to the top 1-5%, capital/productive assets become ever more heavily concentrated in the hands of the financial Plutocracy.  The top 1% now owns some 2/3 of the nation's entire productive wealth.4.  As profits rise (from rising productivity), profits flow not to wages (which remain flat-to-down from 1975 to 2009 for all but the top-10% professional class), but rather they flow to that 1% who own the lion's share of the capital / productive assets.5.  As the middle class experiences a decline in their income and purchasing power (for reasons cited above, i.e. declining dollar, rising income disparity, and wages falling due to global wage arbitrage), they (the middle class) turn more and more to borrowing and ever greater debt, to `pay' for what they have been brainwashed to believe is "the American dream" of imported luxury goods, bloated homes, vacuous cruises, etc.The only other mechanism available to the middle class to increase household income, besides longer hours of work, is for Mom/Aunt/Grandmom to enter the workforce, which she does in the tens of millions, with sociological consequences that are still unfolding (i.e. ever higher rates of juvenile delinquency, drug abuse, homicide and suicide).6.  This advert/media-driven desire to borrow to fund the "good life" is hugely profitable to the money-center banks, which expand rapidly into mortgage securization, derivatives and consumer credit, to the point that they come to dominate corporate profits.7.  The financial Plutocracy, observing that actually producing goods is no longer very profitable unless you can fix prices, as per ADM (Archer Daniels Midlands), or gain government subsidies and tax giveaways (oil lease depreciation, etc.), sinks its capital into the FIRE economy (finance, insurance and real estate), eschewing real-world investments as comparatively unprofitable.(Though rarely noted, this is a longstanding trait of capitalism stretching back to 1400-era Venice:  When trade became less profitable than mainland farming, the Venetian Elite stopped funding trading and bought farms on the mainland.  As a side effect, Venice ceased to be a military and trading power.  But the Elite remained immensely wealthy.)8.  As the tech bubble expands, middle-class investors see the Plutocracy (those with enough capital to qualify as angel investors of vulture . . oops, I mean venture, capital) reaping huge gains, and they enter the dot-com stock bubble buildup with a vengeance.9.  In a happy accident, the Soviet Empire collapses just as productivity begins its computer-fueled rise in the US.  In a so-called Unipolar World, in which US military, political and financial influence is unrivaled, non-US investors seek the relative safety and high returns (based on appreciation of the dollar) of US financial instruments.10.  The dot-com bubble implodes in a speculative meltdown (dot-bomb), and retail investors (a.k.a. middle class 401K investors) are devastated.  The ephemeral wealth they once possessed, however briefly, fuels their speculative desire to get into the next get-rich-quick game, which just so happens to be "something everyone understands:" real estate and housing.11.  Having exhausted the dot-com play, Elite capital seeks a new high-profit home.  The miracles of derivatives (CDOs, credit default swaps, etc.) and securitized debt (mortgage tranches, etc.) open up vast new opportunities for leverage (investing using lots of other peoples money), off-balance sheet shenanigans, and outright fraud/debauchery of credit.  As chip wafer plants disappear from Silicon Valley (too dirty, too costly, etc.), they're replaced with paper, i.e. mortgage-backed securities that eventually prove to be near worthless.12.  Sniffing gold in them thar exurban hills, the under-capitalized and over-indebted US working class and middle class reach for the chalice of easy-money gold: leveraged real estate.13.  With the Federal financial regulatory agencies in a Republican/Democrat-enforced somnambulance, the coast is clear for brigands, shysters, fraudsters, con artists, liars, cheats, and assorted riff-raff in the realtor, mortgage and appraisal businesses, who all feed the ravenous maw of the money-center banks' apparently limitless appetite for real estate assets to securitize and leverage in exotic and highly profitable ways.14.  For a wonderful five years circa 2001-2006, "the game" is afoot, and no-down-payment Jill and $100-million-bonus Jack get immensely enriched.  Meanwhile, the underlying real economy is becoming ever more unbalanced and ever more fragile as real production and real productivity plummet, and everyone rushes to the speculative riches of exurban McMansions and malls.15.  This last best speculative leveraged bubble pops, gutting a Wall Street that had grown utterly dependent on ever greater degrees of leverage & debt, fraudulent accounting, and bubbles, for its rising profits.16.  Doubly devastated by the implosion of housing and their stock investments (mostly in retirement funds), the middle class faces the terrible consequences of its 26-year stupor regarding the ever-rising indebtedness that surrounds them and engulfs them.  Alas, the Emperor's new clothes are revealed as remarkably transparent.17.  Just as in the Great Depression, and to its great surprise, the Elite has also suffered catastrophic losses and declines in capital and income.18.  Having borrowed and squandered trillions of dollars since 1981 on unaffordable entitlements, military misadventures and assorted worthless bridges-to-nowhere pork spending, the Federal government (the Fed and the Treasury) finds that its ability to borrow its way out of its current debt hole is limited.  The rest of the world has finally caught on to the con, and Chinese university students openly mock Treasury Secretary Geithner's Orwellian claim that "we support a strong dollar."  The miracle is that he was not pelted with tomatoes for making such an absurd statement.19.  With the global media concentrated in a scant few corporate hands, this pulling away the curtain is purposely ignored by the media, in their ruthless campaign of pure "green shoots" propaganda.20.  As the wheels fall off the US economy and bubbles cannot be re-inflated, fruitless attempts at holding back the tide with incantations (stop, tide, I am Obama/Geithner/Bernanke!) and loopy claims (the market bottom is here, buy now! -- Green shoots are sprouting everywhere) abound.  Unresponsive to such propaganda, the real economy grinds down into a global Depression without foreseeable end.[...]

Source (H): This is a translation of a 16th century Latin grammar of Japanese. (This isn't even the good 16th century Latin grammar of Japanese; this is the shorter one summarized by someone stuck in the Latin model of grammar.) If what you are expecting is a modern grammar, look again. If you want a view into the how the 16th century Jesuits described Japanese, this is just the book for you.

I tried the Reuters news on my Kindle, and it sucks.  It gives only about 8 "headline" stories at a time, no photos, and is poorly written, and has about 200-300 words (short) per story.  If you download this trial, compare it then to your Kindle web: go to the Menu from the homepage, click "Experimental Web", and amazon has preloaded sites such as Yahoo Entertainment News, News Headlines, Technology news CNET, et cetera.  Now click on any and you'll get headlines, updated faster than your Kindle blog, better written, longer, and some with B & W photos.  For free. Just scroll to whatever article you want and click to open and read.  It is really head and shoulders above what you get with the subscription blogs.Advantage of the subscription blogs?  They are right there on your Homepage, so easier.  But a couple clicks away is the best resurce for instant news. Good luck and pleasant reading.
Source (K): Better off using free Web-based news updates.

Source (H): I have been reading this blog for a while, but I did not know how fast the blog was being updated. I was actually able to subject the blog to a speed test on the day Bhutto was assasinated. I was watching CNN that morning when the breaking news of Bhutto's assasination came up. After watching the news for 5-10 minutes, I took my Kindle and checked the Reuters Top News blog. I did not see anything about the assasination. Then, I went on the home page, pressed the Select Wheel, and chose Check for New Items. Upon completion of the update, I saw that a lengthy post on Bhutto's assasination was there. A number of different articles about this shameful event appeared on my Kindle over the next couple hours.When it comes to other top news, Reuters Top News is very fast and satisfactory. If you really would like to read about what is going in the world as it happens, I suggest you subscribe to this blog. Otherwise, you might want to save your money for more books.Another advantage of this blog: The articles do not include a lot of comments like NYT's articles. I think this blog is more objective than the newspapers. I might be wrong, though.

So far Reuters is my favorite news service available for Kindle. It downloads/refreshes several times daily with the latest top news from around the world. Reporting is the most unbiased and well-written I have found yet, which is wonderful, and the Kindle version is very well laid out... easy to navigate and informative. Perfect for a quick check of the latest world news.It's a real treat opening up my Kindle and finding new Reuters articles to read every few hours. Highly recommended, and much better priced than the "newspapers" available for Kindle.Using Kindle to go online to the free news sites is OK, but nowhere near as convenient as having it download automatically through the day. Some days I just don't have the time to navigate through to the free sites, and for that reason I find it well worth the small monthly fee to have it come to my Kindle automatically. It's all about convenience.I also like the "Reuters Technology" blog (a great value, I think,  at $0.99 a month)... also highly recommended for those who are into following events in the technology world.I didn't think I'd be using the Kindle for blogs and news etc, when I first got it, but have grown to really enjoy them. I am not a big fan of paper newspapers due to the bulk, and ink rubbing off on my fingers, which I've always detested. But on the Kindle it's fun, easy, fast, paperless! And I get the latest news faster than I ever could with a paper newspaper. It's a real treat. I will be keeping the "Reuters Top News" blog when my free trial ends (and "Reuters Technology" also).

I love the Kindle format - easy to read - easy to search - easy to archive.The electronic newspaper format is somewhat condensed in the material presented, but is still informative and very useful.5-stars for the Kindle and the delivery method.However there is a reason why Salt Lake City has two newspapers. It could be argued that each has their own agenda, however after having read the Salt lake Tribune side-by-side against the Deseret News for nearly two weeks, it appears to me that the Tribune's agenda overly influences their reporting. They may state the facts of an event(sometimes not completely) then comes the "yea, but..." second half, and out comes their spin/agenda. 1-star for the Tribune.As soon as the Deseret News becomes available in Kindle format I will be a subscriber.
Source (K): 5 stars for the Kindle format, 1 star for the Salt Lake Tribune

Source (H): After purchasing a Kindle 3 earlier this week, I immediately cancelled my home delivery newspaper (Des News) and subscribed to SL Tribune Kindle edition. Sure, no ads, comics, or crosswords, but that is a good thing, isn't it? Just pure news stories. After reading almost every article from each edition this week, I must say that I am very pleased! And at only $3.99/month? What a bargain! Sure, it isn't The New York Times, but The Tribune it is a excellent regional paper. And no extraneous ads and recycling all that paper.
Source (K): Nicely formatted, easy to read and a total bargain!

Lo and behold, it is not, you have to have your wireless service turned on and the Kindle's wireless turned on everytime you want to read an article in this magazine.  This causes your Kindle's battery to be used up faster.  At the price of $4.99 for one issue, I would think it would be yours to keep. You see everything as if you had the paper copy in your hands.This review is just to give people a heads up that expects it to be saved to their device.Shutterbug does save to the Kindle Fire.  I have no idea how long it stays at this point in time.

I am so happy with my purchase. I received the Kindle Fire HD for Christmas and I wanted to get a case for it.  When I was looking at all of my options, this beautiful case is the only thing that stood out to me...well, except for it's price! I had to sleep on it for days before I talked myself into spending $100 to cover a $200 tablet. But, I did and I love it. Just still feeling a little guilty for spending so much on a case!

The case is beautiful, and protects it nicely. Does not do an "automatic shutoff" or create a stand, but I didn't buy it for any of those things. I got this for $15.00. If it were $100 as it showed previously, I would not have been sold.
Perfect fit! Like all Kate Spade products, the cover is made well and looks exactly like the picturure. I debated buying it for awhile because of the price, but it really is such a nice case.

This cover is adorable and the price was too good to pass up!! I agree with the other reviewers that I wish there was a pocket. And it's challenging to push the buttons on the Kindle Fire when you have all four corners strapped down.

Too pricey for this cowboy!  Just because it has some designer name doesn't mean squat to me.  How is it going to stand up and in what ways can you use it?  That's what's important.  It's nice looking but the cheap looking elastic straps holding the tablet?  No way.  I'm giving this 1 star because I can't give it a zero.

I had bought this before and sent it back because it did not have the auto on and off. I decided to try it again because I love the color and have had a Kate Spade leather case before for another kindle.  I love it. Glad I bought it again.
Great color and on sale. I would give it 5 stars if it could stand alone.  I still love my choice
Fits my Kindle Fire HD perfectly!  Love the color and the pebbled surface.  Well made and looks very classy.  Glad I purchased!
If you want to see nate with a girlfriend, well this is the book. I can't believe nate got a girlfriend.

The Good:Great magazine, and fun to read on my new Kindle Fire.  You can choose between page layout and text only, although I prefer the page layout as it looks just like the physical magazine.The Bad:My biggest issue with this eMagazine is that you're simply getting a digital copy without any extra content or interactive features, and yet you're paying almost double for a year's worth of the magazine (the physical magazine is roughly $19 per year and at $2.99 per month the kindle version comes out to almost $36 per year).The Bottom Line:If the price were at least close to being the same as a physical subscription I would give this 4 stars, but paying more money to simply have a digital version of a magazine doesn't seem worth while.UPDATE:  After checking out Wired Magazine's app, I have to say that this is the way Rolling Stone should approach the eMagazine version of their publication.  I agree with the other reviewers that it's annoying that you have to also have a print subscription (sort of defeating the purpose of the digital version), but the application itself and the layout of the Wired eMagazine is awesome.  Interactive content, videos, pages built for the Kindle Fire's screen size, etc.  So, if you're reading this Jann Wenner, make a Rolling Stone APP and model it after the Wired APP.
Source (K): I like it... but not enough to pay $36 a year for it.

This is my 2nd purchase of this item! I LOVE having it, just in case!This is a 'MUST BUY', MUCH NEEDED item when you purchase ANY KINDLE ITEM for those 'just in case' moments, as stated above, especially when there are kids in the house - of "ANY" age, especially teenagers! Why haven't they caught on yet 'to listening' by this age? UGH! LOL!The first time I purchased this item, I had purchased it for the Kindle 3G w/ WiFi Keyboard. I have about 3-1/2 months of this Protection Plan left on it yet. I have NOT had to use this so far, but I have the 'peace of mind', knowing if I 'do' need to use it, it IS THERE!This is how it works: You 'MUST' buy it when you purchase the Kindle item of your choice. There is NO GOING BACK TO PURCHASE IT! It is a 'now or never' product to purchase at the time of ANY Kindle product purchase.So I originally purchased this item the first time,- the 2nd Year Extended Warranty, at the time I purchased my first Kindle, as stated above, a little more than 1-1/2 years ago. So far I have NOT needed to use it. I am very careful' when I use my Kindle.This is how 'this' product works: The FIRST YEAR you own your Kindle (of ANY type) it is automatically covered by a 1 year warranty through Kindle. After that 1st year of automatic coverage, there is zero warranty left.Now is when 'this product' kicks in! This 2 Year Protection Plan covers the 2nd Year of owning your Kindle.(Not the 1st year.) This gives you an extended 1 FULL '2nd YEAR' of warranty time.You never know what 'could' happen, so by having this, even if it is only for peace-of-mind, you've got it! I look at it as a kind of insurance for the Kindle. I feel safe and secure knowing I have a second year of warranty time on my Kindle for the first 2 years of my ownership on ANY TYPE OF KINDLE ITEM in case anything happens to it along the way as I use it.I have just purchased the Kindle FIRE HD 8.9"! I can't WAIT to get it!Yes, I purchased THIS PRODUCT WHEN I PURCHASED THE FIRE! Remember - this product MUST BE PURCHASED WHEN YOU PURCHASE 'ANY' KINDLE PRODUCT 'at the same time you purchase your Kindle (of any type)!' PLEASE remember this!You should be VERY happy with it!'The prices 'do' vary, depending on the type of Kindle item you purchase. This only makes sense, as the more expensive the Kindle, the more expensive the warranty will be. Regardless, the price of this Protection Plan has far exceeded my expectations!Additional thoughts: When we purchase ANY Kindle item, the costs add up for ALL the accessories we purchase for it, and it adds up  quickly! Not only are we purchasing the Kindle item, but ALL the other accessories that go with it, so if ANYTHING happens to your Kindle, you WANT IT REPLACED! This allows you to do so! So, to have this 2nd year Protection Plan is well-worth EVERY PENNY! It's a must-NEED item to go along with your Kindle! No matter what Kindle item it is, you are protecting!Thankfully, I have NOT had to use this so far, but still have about 3 months left on it. Hopefully I won't have to use it, but I feel safe and secure just knowing I DO have it for that 'just in case'!

I began reading "Lie To Me" and absolutely could not put it away.  It was the wee hours of the morning when I finally finished.  This is very close to my heart on many levels.  I remember being 16 and the discovery of love.  I remember many traumas and difficulties of life and poor Cassie is dealing with so much at once, and at such a tender, vulnerable age.  Suzanne Brahm manages to capture all the colors and textures, subtle and in-your-face, of dealing with life in the very difficult mode of being a child and a woman at the same time.  The transition of Cassie was so spot-on, I was mesmerized.  It has been decades since I was 16, yet when I read this book it was like a time machine had transported me back to being 16 and dealing with life's miraculous, yet frightening and challenging issues.  The character count is absolutely perfect, and the casting is flawless.  I won't publish spoilers, but just know that this book is so unique, so fresh, you are going to absolutely love it.
Source (K): Fantastic Debut.  Couldn't put it down

I read almost all of the CognitiveDaily posts on my Kindle, and then I compared them to the original blog on the web. The Kindle version is pretty satisfactory, unless one decides to go through the whole archive. The reader needs to keep in mind that the Kindle version is designed to be read daily, not for lengthy research.The crucial parts of the original posts are conserved. I assume someone who decides to subscribe to this blog would like to see the graphs and data that the author uses to support his/her views, which is successfully done on the Kindle version. The graphs and pictures are not perfect, but it shows everything one needs to see.The quotes are formatted as blockquotes, which I think is great.The bibliography is also included at the end of each post.The reader is able to click on the linked text and visit the web-sites the text is linked to as well. However, it shoudl be remembered that the Kindle browser is not designed to browse webpages at full functionality.Absolutely no ads!!!Finally, reader comments for the posts are not included in the Kindle version.

This book is wonderful and stands the test of time better than most of the books published last year. So good that reading it is practically gluttony. Sarcasm at it's finest. The sexual undertones are presented in a hilarious manner. For example, the main character of the book is kicked out of the castle he lives at when the lord of the castle finds him in the act of kissing his lovely "innocent" daughter, who had just witnessed the resident philosopher and one of the girls working there in the midst of fooling around in the garden and was "flustered." Disregarding this book is denying yourself one hell of a good story, and it's not often you get told a personal life philosophy through such obvious crowd-pleasing comedy. Go on, read!
Source (K): Candide is one of the best books ever written.

Source (H): Free Kindle version?  Yes please.  Though this is a book that is usually readily available for check out at local libraries, I wanted a version that was portable and free.  Win win.  Granted, this is the identical version to that on the Project Gutenberg website, but at least Amazon will allow this on Kindles whereas they block Gutenberg eBooks.  The format of this version is nice and it doesn't have too many issues with the transition to a Kindle eBook unlike most of the Shakespeare plays and such.It is an older translation, but a good one.  If you are assigned this book for class, I would stick with whatever translation the teacher gives you.  But if you want to read this for pleasure, or just want to have it read for your core reading list (for college or whatnot), then this is a great version.  The wry sense of black humor is wonderful.  The spellings may seem odd, but Voltaire wrote this in French in the 1750s, so it's pretty old.  And yes, the British were probably spelling Buenos Ayres instead of Buenos Aires and such.The operetta Candide is based off of this novel as well, though it strays from the novel in the end (though is faithful throughout the first 2/3 to 3/4).  A recommended reading for anyone interested in classic literature.  Now you're ready for some Kafka!

Source (H): I recently bought the Windows version of Scrivener in order to complete some writing projects and decided to learn as much as possible about the program.Scrivener itself was originally designed for Mac, so the Windows version is relatively new (Nov 2011) and a little underpowered in comparison, with some nice features like customised icons, comments, scrivener links to html (important to generate more fine-tuned table of contents for Kindle) and research word pop-ups NOT currently being present in the Windows version.It has to be said however that the "main" features are all intact, and the windows version is still great.I thought I would get this guide to go through it as it said it was specifically for the Windows version, and the others are all mainly about the Mac version which is more advanced and hence often not really applicable.The actual tutorial in the program itself is great, so go through that first.Bought this to add a real users persepctive to the whole thing.First a couple of negatives:1/ This is NOT 300 pages long. It is actually 98 pages if you convert it to PDF.Don't get me wrong, its a meaty enough book and has 33,460 words (I counted them up) and so "value wise" it's just fine; but its NOT 300 pages as decribed above, which indicates a mammoth text of maybe 100,000 words.I converted it to PDF (using Calibre), because whilst Kindle is great for reading fiction it sucks for "How To" computer books with lots of screenshots, and I wanted to read it on one screen while playing around with Scrivener on the other.On the kindle itself the screenshots are simply too small to be readable, so converting it to a format like PDF is essential in my honest opinion if you actually want to follow along.2/ The screenshots in the book could do with being higher quality. I found them quite blurry to look at even on the pdf. Some of them (especially near the beginning of the book) are also screenshots from the MAC version of Scrivener, and not the Windows version which is a bit confusing.The two are mainly the same but some of the icons and the format bar at the top are quite different.It is a windows version, so the screenshots should have all been from the windows version.(Though you cannot see them properly on the kindle anyway - Most of the book is text, so its not as big a deal as it might be)3/ The book sometimes talks about cool things you can do, but then fails to actually tell you how to do them! (Especially in the first quarter of the book)This is a bit frustrating. It gets the grey matter going and makes you think about alternatives to try out in the program, but isn't explicit enough about method.For example, early on he talks about setting writing targets and it sounds like a good method he uses, but there is no detail on what he actually does to make it happen.4/ This needs much better editing. Quite a few Mac only features have sneaked in to the text.For example, under "Write in a distraction free environment" he says:"This is a simple one. You can blank out the background and you can add your own picture,maybe a view of the sea or the mountains to pretend you are sitting in a cabin in the Rockies churning out your masterwork (or a random image if you are me)."You CAN do this in the MAC version. But you cannot do it (yet) in the Windows version.He also talks about "Page View" a few times, which again is only available in the Mac version.And I got all excited when I read:"To see where a project is saved, click on the .scriv icon next to the project name at the very top of the window and choose > Path"Because that would be a great tip....But again, not in WINDOWS! Quite frustrating!He also talks about exporting and importing to Final Draft... You guessed it. Not in Windows. (Though Version 1.1 purportedly has it, and that is due very soon, so you MAY be able to do it by the time you read this)Later on he talks about importing one Scrivener project into another, which I also believe is a Mac only feature.Together with errors that don't stack up to my experience.For example, he talks about how importing .rtf files will preserve the images (which woulkd be a useful alternative to .doc and .docx for example) but in my expoerience importing .rtf files in the windows version (no idea about the mac), always seems to strip out all the images :-(In the later Kindlegen section he talks about "You need to have Kindlegen installed on your Mac in order to generate .mobi ebooks forAmazon." - Er...this is the windows version... This needs several more read-through edits to correct silly stuff like this.And there are probably others that I simply don't know.The text needs to be checked much more carefully by the author in my opinion.5/ It ends very abruptly - One minute he's explaining someinthing, then you realize that was the last page!This book needs some kind of proper conclusion.It feels a bit like a "Frankenstein" version he cobbled together from the Mac version of his book.It needs more editing, more polish, more examples and a better conclusion.And here are some things I liked:1/ Offers some thoughts on workflow - This is more than just a Scrivener manual. There is some discussion of the authors writing workflow (though not enough)That is quite useful, especially if you are reasonably familiar with the program, and can "fill in the blanks" for yourself of how to achieve what he is talking about.If you are very new to Scrivener you will find the book confusing.If you are a bit of an old hand then you may well pick up some new thoughts on how to approach your job of writing.There were certainly moments here when my brain did fire off nuances of ways of doing things because of the text.But again, most of the time you actually have to figure out the "How To" yourself.This is more of an "ideas manual".You might get shown where the screen is, but not to much on actual day to day use patterns.2/ Gets more detailed after the first third of the book (which is a bit weak)He kind of gets into the flow more. There are more screenshots and how-tos.Again, the screenshots are utterly worthless on a kindle. You simply cannot see them. But if you convert them into a pdf using Calibre, then they do definitely help to get an idea of what he is talking about.3/ Good explanation of LevelsHe DOES explain the hierarchy rules (levels) quite well (they are used mainly for compile mode), but this needs expanding and integrating with better explanations in the compile section.More compile practical examples would have been welcome.ie THIS became THIS after compile etcA few more examples would trump all the explanations.4/ The writing style is good - He writes in a nice relaxed way, and so this is an easy enough read.Overall - An easy enough read. Worth the money. But the author could do with bringing out a new edition that "tidies" this up and addresses the weaknesses that it currently has.

I bought this speech more as a curiosity than anything else...but my .99 turned into a wonderful speech that could only be topped by being present when it was delivered to this graduating class.It is a brilliant speech and worth reading more than once.

I'm a writing professor in Michigan and I have to say that Prick of the Spindle is easily my favorite literary magazine being published today. Each quarterly issue is filled with variety and a massive amount of writing. There are new and established writers. I read it cover to cover and enjoy every selection. If you are a writer, you'll want to get yourself acquainted with this one. You can read it for free on the internet, but the reading experience on the Kindle is heads and tails above sitting in front of a computer screen.

I've been getting the City Journal articles via email subscription for some time. However, with so much emai to go through, I didn't always get to follow through on reading the essays themselves.Now, with Kindle I get them delivered and can read them away from my computer screen. Not only is this convenient, but for me it's beneficial: I have fibromyalgia which makes holding books & magazines problematic. Propping a kindle is just so much simpler. Also, it's easier to read with my legs stretched out on the sofa instead of bent in a chair.If you've never read the 'real' City Journal magazine, you're missing an aesthetic pleasure. It is by far the most elegant of any magazine I know. The whole thing has to be seen to be fully appreciated. A recent issue, the one devoted to cities, was beautiful.The Kindle essays seem to be a separate feature from the print edition; thus more timely than a quarterly could be. At 99 cents a month even *I* can afford it.

"El Economista" is one of the principal newspapers in Mexico specialist in Bussines and Economic general information. And the  price is excellent, better that "El Universal" (U$16.99). I recomend widely this newspaper.

Source (H): Este libro es una maravilla. Recuerdo que siempre me ponían a leerlo en mis clases de Español cuando estaba en el colegio, y le daba largas porque no me gustaba. La primera es que es directa, no tiene gran introducción y el lector puede comenzar a leer las aventuras desde el primer momento. Source (H): I purchased several of these packet sets for family, friends and myself. In response to Kindle Geek there is a way to get back issues. Go on to the Amazon acount that your Kindle is registered on and go under whatever periodical you wish to get a back issue of and then siply select: send wirelessly to your kindle, then select whitch back issue you want sent to your kindle and amazon will send it, free of charge.

Reading the Fortune magazine on my Kindle 2.0 has made me realize both the pros and cons of reading a printed magazine. If you want the most efficient Fortune magazine reading experience, then get the Kindle version. If you want the best overall magazine reading experience, the printed version may still have the edge as of today.The Kindle version has no pictures (as of 5/7/09) and no advertisements. There are only articles and opinions. I was shocked how skimpy Fortune magazine was in content as I was able to read EVERY article in less than 15 minutes, which is less than it takes me to read the daily Wall Street Journal (Kindle version). I usually take good 30 minutes to read the printed Fortune magazine.Reading Fortune from Kindle 2.0 is a different experience than reading from a printed version. The printed Fortune has glossy advertisements and pictures. The tactfile feeling of turning each page somehow makes reading the printed Fortune magazine a slightly more rewarding experience. The analogy is similar to getting news from television versus the radio. You may get the same exact news but the television news has visuals which speak a 1000 words that the radio can never duplicate.The speed of which I was able to finish the entire Fortune magazine in Kindle has made me realize exactly how much time I spend viewing a magazine's advertisements and pictures. Also, the ability to quickly peruse an entire magazine using your thumb still can't be duplicated by Kindle.But the Kindle has some inherent advantages over the printed version. Kindle version has a search feature based on keywords. Kindle will allow you to read just about everything much faster, including the Fortune magainze. Using the Table of Contents is far more efficient. A magazine subscription is delivered to you wirelessly usually 2-4 days before the magazine hits the print market. Finally, I can't imagine anything beating the Kindle's content delivery system using 3G wireless. The magazine downloads in less than a minute.Overall, I recommend the Kindle version of Fortune magazine. For better or worse, just don't expect it to be the same experience as reading the printed version.
Source (K): What a big difference lack of pictures make

Source (H): I highly recommend Fortune as a general source of contemporary business information. [Business school professor]

Mike Allen is a huge cheerleader for Obama, in my opinion. If that's what you want, this is the blog for you. Most liberal elites read Mr. Allen's blog daily. If you want more variety in opinion, go elsewhere.Even of more concern, Mike Allen and his co-worker, Ben Smith, also of Politico, have just been discovered to be members of JournoList, which should be of concern to all Americans. This was a group of hundreds of liberal journalists, many claiming to be objective, who got together to discuss what the talking points should be in the news, according to them. So in effect they often ended up controlling the news cycle of the day. As a result, it's hard to believe anyone who was on the JournoList would now be considered credible or part of a Free Press designed to be objective, in my opinion. One of the strategies discussed on JournoList by another journalist, it recently has come to light, was to call people who criticized Obama, "racists". So if Mr. Allen tried to shut down or spin information in order to get his favorite candidate elected, that would concern me greatly when reading his blog.

As any smartphone user can attest, you can never have too many chargers: at home, at the office, in the kitchen - pretty much anywhere you have a power plug open.I purchased 2 of these chargers for my Samsung Galaxy Nexus Android phone. I needed at minimum 5V 1Amp to fully charge my phone at factory speed and this charger did the trick.NOTE: to check if a charger is fully charging your phone do the following:1. Go to SETTINGS2. Click on BATTERY3. If charging it will say in the top left corner "Charging (AC or USB)"*If it shows "AC" it is charging at full speed/power.*If it shows "USB" it is charging at a maximum of 5v .5Amp - meaning it is charging at half the speed/Power.On top of charging at full speed, this charger is compact and simple. Simply put, if you have an Android Smartphone, this charger will do the trick.The only drawback is that it did not come with a micro USB cable. At the price you pay for this charger, you would expect at least a cable. That's why a took off a star.

No reason.  This product is described as 5W, 1 amp.  The Kindle line is mainly 5V (4.8V, what's the difference) and around 1 amp, which is 5 Watts (5W).  Why the mystery, guys?  Also, this deal is for US 110V market only?  I travel.  I like that the previous simple FIRE charger was universal (i.e. 100V-240v).  I like that the first Kindle charger was also universal.  What are you people doing?  Or, is it that the copywriter in this case just doesn't understand?For those who don't understand the details of electricity, ANY device will tell you what it needs to feed.  Voltage (V) is one thing to look at and your charger needs to say something within the range of 100 and 240 volts to meet your device need.  As far as AMPS (A). If your device says it needs 1.8 A.  It's perfectly fine to buy a charger that has a rating higher than that.  Like 2 Amps.  The device will only drink as much as it needs.  A device that needs 1.8 A plugged into a 2 A charger just means the charger is taking a nap.  Just avoid situations where your device needs more Amps than a charger can provide.  It won't necessarily explode but it will extend charge times and is generally not recommended.

Source (H): Useful, productive little entertainment source for under a buck a month.  The AP Entertainment blog delivers breaking entertainment news several times a day on a wide variety of topics, ranging from which directors and actors have signed for which projects to how that new Verdi production at the Met went over with critics and audiences.  Lots of movie, TV, music, book, fine arts, internet, and video game news fuel this busy little blog, which thankfully contains a minimum of gossipy celebrity news.  The first article is always a series of quick headlines, which usually but not always immediately correspond to active articles.  Click on "Articles List" to get your list of actual articles for you to click on and read.  This AP blog keeps about fifty or sixty stories at a time sitting at the site for you to read, though older stories eventually drop off.  A generous amount of photographs round out this well-written entertainment blog.  And, by the way, if you enjoy seeing which movies were popular during the weekend, this blog religiously delivers weekend box office grosses every Sunday afternoon.  All in all, if you enjoy entertainment news, the AP Entertainment blog for your Kindle is a winner.Note: Amazon frequently updates the presentation and functionality of Kindle blogs and periodicals, so as this review gets older, it may no longer accurately describe the current version of this product.
Source (K): Let your Kindle help keep you in the entertainment loop

Jackpot!  Reuters on the Kindle is a gold mine of all the news I'm not getting on my local newspaper's Kindle version. My first edition 11/16/10 is wonderfully formatted with the "Sections List" that my local paper and many Kindle papers use.  This makes it easy to find content by section (15 of them!) or scan through the list of article titles (102 articles today).My North Carolina paper's Kindle edition has most of the local news, but rarely has national and international stories that would come from Reuters or AP.  Not only does Reuters Kindle deliver U.S. News (6 articles) and International News (10), but today has 13 other sections: Top News (8), Politics (7), Business (8), Deals in Business (4), Green Business (3), Global Markets (6), Personal Finance (4), Science (7), Technology (10), Environment (5), Health (8), Entertainment (10), Oddities (4).  What's missing?  Sports!  So I'll continue to use the web for non-local sports content.I don't need comic strips and some of the other picture-laden content that others miss on their Kindle.  I would like to have some charts and graphs, particularly for stock news, but my keen interest is to have "ALL the news that's fit to [display]" and now I'm going to get it via Reuters on the Kindle.  It's a terrific supplement to your local paper on the Kindle, moderately priced, and sure to please if you are seeking news from a well-qualified source.
Source (K): All the News I've been missing on Kindle.

Source (H): I've subscribed to the paper editions of both the WSJ and NYT in the past, and I think that Reuters is a great replacement for either one.  The daily edition is comprehensive, with strong business and international coverage.What's missing?  Just the obnoxious editorials and fluff that you find in most newspapers these days.

When I got my Kindle I tried out all sorts of newspapers. I went through so many 14-day free trials that I'm sure Amazon thought about taking back my Kindle.I wanted an affordable newspaper with weekend editions and great coverage of USA and international news. Reuters has all that, plus business, personal finance, global markets, science, technology, health, entertainment, odd news, environment, personal finance, and even green business. I get enough articles on varied subjects to keep me reading for hours. And, finally, NO articles on sports (thank goodness). I've had no problems with delivery; every morning when I wake up, I fire up my Kindle and there's my news. I'd give them 6 stars if they were available!Reuters is a daily newspaper for thinking persons. Its articles are in depth, timely, and more enjoyable than other papers I've read. I subscribed immediately and encourage others to do so. In my opinion, they're a sleeper newspaper and destined to move up the ranks at Amazon. The price is right and the coverage is great. Thank you, Reuters (and Amazon).

I was a subscriber for a very short period of time.  After going through my free edition, I thought the content read like a web page, not a newspaper.  I went to the free website and found several of the same stories.  They were word for word the same story that I received in my subscription.  Only there was MORE news on the free website than there was in the paper.  I find it very disappointing to pay for a service that I can get for free on the web.

If you are looking for straight forward news, then this is your best source for national and international news articles. There are no opinionated columnists, no baised editorals and no boring sports sections. Most of the major news stories have photographs accompaning them, but the focus is more on the written word than the graphic content. Although this is not a real life hardcopy newspaper (but rather a news service) the Kindle content is setup just like a regular newspaper which makes locating and reading the news a pleasure.Truly, fair and balanced news!

In case you're wondering, Kady Cross' "The Strange Case of Finley Jayne" is apparently a prequel to the forthcoming novel "The Girl in the Steel Corset." But this little steampunk novella stands pretty well on its own -- it has a sensible butt-kicking heroine, a dash of classic horror, and some decent writing (albeit with some anachronisms).Only a few hours after being fired from her job (for punching a governess), Finley Jayne is offered a new position: companion to Lady Morton's teenage daughter Phoebe. The job seems too good to be true -- she gets a beautiful room, Phoebe's old clothes, and even is brought to balls and parties under the pretense of being a distant relation.However, she is uneasy about Phoebe's older fiancee, Lord Vincent. Not only is Lord Vincent creepy and twice her age, but he is also still obsessed with his dead wife, Cassandra... who looked exactly like Phoebe. Finley sets out to find out what devious plans he may have for Phoebe, and her greatest ally may be her secret, superhuman dark side.There is honestly not enough steampunk in the world, and "The Strange Case of Finley Jayne" is a decent example of the genre -- we've got clockwork automatons, steam carriages, robotic horses and a bit of "Frankensteinian" mad science. There are still some unanswered questions (Finley's dark side and superhuman strength), but presumably the full-length novel will explain that.Cross' prose is fairly good -- it's not exceptional, but it's solid enough, albeit with some comments that sound a little too modern (Finley refers to Lord Vincent's plans as "icky"). And while the first couple chapters feel a little fluffy, the story tightens up and becomes much darker with the introduction of Lord Vincent, although the subplot about Phoebe's boyfriend seemed extraneous.And Finley is a very, very likable heroine -- she's strong, self-reliant, sensible and intelligent. She also has a Hyde side (see, I can reference 19th-century horror too!), which allows her incredible strength and almost gleeful aggression that she has to keep bottled up. And I can't help but hope that we'll see more of Lady Morton, a clever noblewoman who recognizes a good bodyguard for her daughter when she sees one."The Strange Case of Finley Jayne" is a solid introduction to the world of Kady Cross' Victorian steampunk/urban-fantasy series, and leaves me anticipating whatever comes next for Finley Jayne.
