I first encountered this book in researching the history of chess for some chess articles I was writing. I had heard that chess was originated in ancient India, and that it was first mentioned, and perhaps even had it's origin (although that's very odd for a book or story to start a game, so I think I must have misunderstood) in the story. So that was my particular reason for reading this. As with chess, I quickly became both fascinated and overwhelmed by the level of complexity. There are stories within stories within stories. It is difficult to keep track of who is who and what is happening, although certainly not impossible, because it is not an incoherent story, just very complicated. It is of course abridged. I cannot imagine reading the unabridged version, although many do. It is a sacred Hindu text, so many religious and historical scholars study it in depth. But it can be read from a child's point of view as well, without analyzing everything, but just accepting the stories of the brothers and cousins who fought over a piece of land and all the animals who change back and forth from one form to another, interacting with the characters. In fact, I think that might be the best way to read this. Just let go of understanding any metaphorical implications and enjoy the stories. I also recommend letting go of the goal of understanding the story if you want to enjoy it. Just relax and float down the river with the stories that in some ways remind me of the Just So stories by Rudyard Kipling. I am sure he was greatly influenced by this text.

First off this review is for the Kindle version of FineScale Modeler only.  Not the printed copy.  The magazine itself is pretty good and I really don't have any complaints.  My problem is with the publisher's restriction on their Kindle version.  First off for a publisher that focuses on hobby oriented magazines like FineScale Modeler and Model Railroader they treat Kindle readers like criminals.  You can only read this magazine on your Kindle.  You cannot read it on any other device.  No PC, No Android Phone, No iPad.  It is also only set to keep the last 7 issues of the magazine.  What modeler in their right mind throws out their reference magazines?  Plus since Klambach puts a DRM on their Kindle file you can't convert it to a PDF or another file format and archive them on your PC.  Here is the real deal killer for me.  They charge you monthly for the subscription and only put out 10 issues.  So those two months you don't get an issue you are still paying.  The yearly price ends up being almost as much as a print subscription.  How does that work?  I can see their pricing for the print issues since they print their magazine on really high quality paper and have really high quality images, but they are not printing anything for a digital version.In the end don't bother with buying Klambach Publishing Kindle magazines until they wake up and understand what the digital copy is all about.  Personally I am completely done with all Klambach magazines which is a shame because magazines like FineScale Modeler and Model Railroader are such quality magazines.  Amazon could make things better also by offering a yearly subscription instead of just monthlies for Kindle magazines.

Diitto for iPad regarding the one star opinion from the Kindle user. We have a magazine that is published only ten times a year, with some nice photographs and OK reviews and articles; however, I don't know what the editorial staff does with their time (I hope they are paid part-time and have other jobs) since the reviews, articles, and galleries are provided by others than the editors; and the photographers don't seem to be able to take interior views, while the editors seem to use photos and graphics so they don't have to provide more content. All the while, more and more modelers may be taking advantage of the many Internet websites that provide reviews, articles, new product and aftermarket exposure, galleries, tips, techniques, and forums -- all for free. I say all this because you would think the publisher and editors would attempt to engender some loyalty in the readers who pay to subscribe to the magazine with its faults, and with no discount for renewing, by making this digital edition free for them, or at least for a discounted amount. Also, on renewal, subscribers could be given a choice of format for one price, with both formats for slightly more. This may help keep subscribers, and recruit new ones, who otherwise would turn to the Internet for the same, or better, content for free. At this point, however, besides charging the subscribers an extra $39.95 for the reader version, as pointed out before, the reader version doesn't even have the same qualities of the print version. Unless you have money to burn, I believe you should forget this purchase, put the money toward a new model, and spend some time on the Internet.

I'm a satisfied long time subscriber to the print edition of FSM, and as the proud owner of a new Kindle Fire I decided to try the digital edition of FSM.  The first thing I checked was if it was available on the Fire, which of course it is.  On the Fire it sells for $3.33 per month with no indication of a discount for print subscribers.  On the FSM website it sells for $10 per year extra for print subscribers.  Guess which one I chose?After making my purchase on FSM I was directed to the Zinio website to set up my subscription.  Zinio instructs you to download their App in the Kindle App store.  Unfortunatley the Zinio App doesn't exist in the Kindle App Store.  Emails to Amazon received quick response cheerfully blaming Zinio, and emails to Zinio of course blame Amazon; Zinio's suggestion is to set the device to "Allow Installation of Appplications from unknown Sources".  Try to turn on that setting on your Kindle Fire and you are greeted by a message that reads in part "You agree that you are solely responsible for any damage to your Kindle or loss of data that may result from using these applications."  I wasn't willing to accept that condition to read a magazine.Let me be clear that my complaint is really with FSM, not Amazon.  My impression is that they don't really get what digital publishing is all about.  Compare this experience to setting up WIRED magazine on my Fire:  WIRED setup on the Kindle Fire guides you through a simple process.  If you are a current subscriber as I am, there is a page where you enter your subscription information and boom, you are able to download your digital subscription with tons of additional digital content.  All FREE.  FSM hasn't added anything to the magazine except portability- and as Patrick Griffis points out in his review, with severe limitations on usefulness.  I'm sorry to say that I'm very disappointed.FSM has yet to respond to my request for help sent three days ago.  Today I sent a request for a refund.
Source (K): Disappointing technical issues, unimaginative digital version

WAU is a great blessing in my life.The Kindle edition is wonderful on numerous counts.It is so easy and quick to navigate. You understand it all the 1st time through.  Ease and logic prevail.  Chances are familiarity with the print version encourages understanding.Basically, home base, so to speak, is the "Section List" which clearly lists everythng in the issue.- similar to "Inside this Issue.... in the print version.Each area is divided into sections and article.  For example, if you click on the Daily Mass Readings in "View Section" you are returned to where you left off - VERY NICE!  If you click on View Articles in that section you get a list of all the Daily Readings and Meditations for the month- click on the one you want - also, VERY NICE!By the way, you can pick up Joe Difato's inspirations by clicking on "Cover".Amazon and WAU missed nothing.  What an inspiration to combine two class operations!  No doubt - it was the Holy Spirit!  Amen.In the Daily Mass Readings you will find it to be exactly like print version; you can read all the prayers and readings.  An added bonus is the Meditation at the end of each days' readings - VERY NICE!
The concept of a magazine with devotional reflections on the daily readings was an attractive option, but as an Anglican (Episcopal) priest I found that the daily material wasn't relevant.

I've been a WAU subscriber for 10 years.  It has absolutely enhanced my devotion time and kept me focused and meditative on the daily readings.  The reflections on the readings are relevant and so well written! It is exciting to know I can now carry it with me on my Kindle!  I've often used the on-line option when I've traveled, but I think this is a great "other option".  Until the "powers that be" release the NAB (New American Bible) for download to a Kindle or your phone, it's great to have the readings included with this edition.  I don't subscribe to the Catholic Mass Edition with my home delivery copy, and I use the on-line access to the NAB when I use the on-line WAU option.  Bravo to Amazon and the Word Among Us. Perhaps I would have been able to overlook a world view which I don't happen to share if the publication had been loaded with really helpful information and living in a more environmentally friendly, less consumer oriented, and minimalist manner - but even that section of it was tedious.

Having lasted almost 20 years, "The Weekly Standard" has carved out a niche for being one of the premier political magazines in America. My rating for this book might be biased because it happens to be my favorite genre - a Gothic romance, and in the late 1800's in London as icing on the cake!  It has everything: a damsel in distress, a handsome adventurer, a clever villain, narrow escapes, disguises and a thrilling ending.  I enjoyed the male point of view of the story.At the beginning of the story, Noel Stanton, our young adventurer, meets up with a friend from America.  The friend invites Noel to the theater and at the show Noel sees a beautiful young lady, Karine Cunningham.  With Karine are her aunt and uncle and a gentleman that seems very interested in being Karine's fiance.  But Noel feels like he's met the potential fiance before.  And Noel doesn't like him one bit!The lock in the title of the story refers to the Mapledurham Lock on the River Thames.  In the book it is called the Purley Lock.  According to Wikipedia, "Despite its name, the lock is located in the Berkshire village and civil parish of Purley-On-Thames on the south bank of the river, rather than in the Oxfordshire village of Mapledurham on the other side of the river."There are a couple minor formatting issues.  The page numbers show up in the middle of sentences.  And for some italicized words, there are strange marking within the word; like a double dotted 'i', and upside down '?', and a '1/2'. Source (H): This is a great idea. I couldn't wait to try it when I got my renewal for my print 7-day subscription, which was going to cost me $250 per year. At $6.99/month, the Kindle edition clocks in at less than $84 for a full year. With just a few days left on my paper edition, I decided to sign up for the 14-day free trial to compare them side by side. They are not the same. I compared the 12/27/2011 edition. Several of the small articles in the City region page were skipped. Some photos were skipped. There are no classifieds, no obituaries, and no comics. Without these three, it's just the TV news in print with no video. The lack of these three items alone is enough to keep me from continuing the Kindle Edition. If I continued it, I would always be wondering if I was getting all of the news. I see no reason classifieds, obits and comics couldn't be included. Obits are just text and a few headshots. The comics are small in the print edition anyway, and they're black and white except for weekends. And to not include "Real Life Adventures", the best comic on the planet, is just a travesty. I'll check back occaisionally, but until they make these fixes, I won't be a Kindle Herald-Leader subscriber. Thanks for reading.

It's good to find such full-fledged magazines likeDigital Photobeing made available for the Kindle Fire. A short time back, they were hard to find, and the ones that were substandard in quality and annoying in their formatting, but this one, which started online here in April 2012, makes good use of the Kindle Fire technology, and it can be fully downloaded so you can read it even when you're not wirelessly connected.There are very poignant articles to be found in this bi-monthly digital publication. In the current issue that I'm looking at right now, there are articles such as "What Defines A Pro DSLR?" by Mike Stensvold, in which he outlines some of the main ways in which today's pro cameras differ from enthusiast models, covering things like sensor size, durability, batteries (and power tips), the differences between processors, metering and such. It's a well detailed article with excellent color photos and diagarms, and one that answers the question as to whether or not a pro-level DSLR is worthy of consideration.There's an excellent article about must-have optical filters for your camera, noting that even the best software can't replace them. the article is an excellent primer for those getting started, and offering a solid general suggestion to invest in quality glass, noting that your lens is only as good as its most inferior element: if you use a cheap filter, you're compromising the quality of your entire optical system.You'll find equipment sections along with product reviews, and the columns that we're used to in the printed-paper editions are here, along with the editorials. There are features and helpful how-to articles throughout.It should be noted that this digital publication is not set up for the legacy Kindle devices; as noted in the little drop-down on the product page, this one is only available for the Kindle Fire and the Kindle for iPad (Version 2.9 or later) as of this date. This one is done by the same group that publishesOutdoor Photographerfor the Kindle Fire, for those who are interested in another noteworthy photo magazine, as it's proven to be a good one.One thing worthy of note: if you find the heavy use of ads to be a distraction, look for the Menu icon on the bottom middle of the Kindle Fire's screen. By tapping on this icon, you'll see the choice between Page View (the default) and Text View. Tapping on Text View allows you to read all of the articles without the proliferation of advertising... yet all of the photos are still there, and in glorious color when they appear in the magazine that way. Just imagine if you had an editorial assistant who took scissors to the advertisements and just cut them all out, leaving you with all of the text and images.If you're into digital photography, this Kindle Fire edition ofDigital Photois easily worth a 5-star recommendation, and this is one with which you can enjoy all of the photos, editorials, how-to articles and product reviews the way you like. Granted, this magazine can be accessed online, and they even have a Facebook page, but there are the times that I'm traveling or even kicking back at night, reading, and having access to this excellent photo publication. And don't forget that a subscription to the Kindle Fire edition of Digital Photo comes with a two week free trial, so you have a chance to review it and see. Try it and you'll see what I mean.8/3/2012
Source (K): Digital Photo Magazine: the Kindle Fire Edition

Source (H): I read the first book in this series when I was about 15. Thus, when this one came out, after a very long wait, I was ecstatic. But two years has made a big difference in how I see books. It seemed to me as if the author thought that Alera was a strong heroine, but she was the biggest wimp ever. Yes, she sometimes did brave things but immediately after she would burst into tears and be consoled by the men around her. She is not a good role model, even though I think the author wanted her to be independent from her husband. But while she was independent from him, she completely relied on other men, like the of the  "hero" of this story, and her countless bodyguards. Then on top of that, her sister is the most unidimensional sad-sack in the history of ever. There is not one truly strong woman in this book, unless you count the queen of the rival country. Spoiler Alert: She ends up with the "hero" even though, he helped to take her country away from her. I mean, WHAT IS THAT? WHAT KIND OF QUEEN ARE YOU? I get that you cannot chose who you love, but as queen you better sacrifice that love for your country. She should of killed him, not melted into his arms in the end, completely satisfied that this man had taken away her country, and helped kill her subjects. Some may raise the point that he was very noble and did not want to do it, but the fact is that he still did, and that she ends up with him sickens me. I spent the first half annoyed with Alera for being so weak, I wanted her to grow some woman balls. She never really stood up to Steldor, she just found ways to make him angry with her. And although, Scarlett O'Hara is a controversial heroine, Alera should of taken a couple cues from her to do what she could have to save her country. She was completely fine with not even knowing anything about the war, and letting her husband, whom she despises for no good reason deal with it, until it is at her front door. Alera is no queen and that she lost the war and did not even really put up a fight, which Scarlett O'Hara did to save her home, really showed that she no more than steldor was ever fit to rule a country. I spent the second part of this book cussing at it for wasting my time. If I could change the ending of this book, it would be with Alera leading a rebel army against the enemy, with Steldor as her military leader. Do not get me wrong, their marriage would still have broken up, but she would be fighting for her country even if it meant that she was fighting against the man that she loved.

Among the many helpful tools that reside at Rest Ministries, my favorite is the Devotion section. People with a chronic medical condition feel set apart from the rest of the population. The chronically ill may use a cane, crutch or wheelchair - or they may not have any outward sign of their illness. Being afraid to be a burden on others, having to spend hundreds of dollars on medications, feeling too bad to attend family or religious functions, losing job or having to downsize to a much lower-paying job - all of these can make the sick person feel depressed and worthless.The Devotions at Rest Ministries are based on Scripture and intended to make chronically ill persons believe in themselves again. They tell a story of how human frailty can be used by God to become spiritual strength. Hope, encouragement, and a realization of blessings owned combine to give the ill person just what he or she needs to make it through the challenges of that day. These devotions are truly the best for the blest!
Source (K): Devotions for the Chronically Ill - The Best for the Blest

On Kindle DX, most tables, figures and photos are fine, once the zoom function is used.  Only the busiest tables/graphs are illegible.  Fortunately, such tables/graphs are relatively infrequent and I enjoyed reading the latest NEJM on the Kindle DX, and most physicians have other ways to obtain these table/graphs if they need them.  Yet, Amazon needs to find a way to overcome this problem if they are truly going to cater to the academic audience as they report that they are trying to do.  Many textbooks have busy tables/graphs, and it may be difficult for faculty and students to get the hardcopy version of those tables.One solution would be to have higher resolution versions of all Kindle purchases/subscriptions available on line to be accessed from a PC/MAC.I cancelled my trial for the same reason I cancelled my print subscription a few years ago.  I only did the trial to answer one of the earlier reviews questions regarding appearance on the DX.  I am a pediatric endocrinologist, and most NEJM articles are too irrelevant to my field for me to regularly read the entire journal.  For me, the NEJM free table of contents delivery to my e-mail that includes abstracts is sufficient for my purposes.  Being in academic medicine, it is not difficult for me to obtain any full article on line when I need it.  However, if I was in a more general specialty, or almost any internal medicine specialty, I would not have hesitated to subscribe to the Kindle version of the NEJM.  I hope Amazon makes JCEM available.One final comment.  I do not understand why the Kindle versions of most newspapers, magazines and journals are as, or almost as expensive as the print versions.  The baseline cost for the producers should be much less for electronic versions.

As a student, I would like to read the New England Journal of Medicine on my Kindle, however the online version for students is much cheaper direct from their website.  I really wish the price was more comparable as I would love to affordably read it on my Kindle.
Source (K): Kindle version too expensive for students

Source (H): As far as I can tell, the New England Journal (NEJM) is the first medical journal available for the kindle.  There are several benefits to getting the NEJM on the kindle, and these benefits will likely lead all the major medical journals to follow suit at some point in the near future.The benefits:First, getting the kindle edition eliminates a ton of waste.  Walk into any serious doctor's home or office (or even medical library), and you will likely find stacks and stacks of journals.  Most copies sit there and collect dust...and only a few are used at any one point (what a waste of trees/paper and space).  At some point, all the old journals have to be tied up and recycled (or bound up) (another waste of time and energy).  The kindle version of the NEJM eliminates all this waste.Second, it is easier to read the NEJM off the kindle screen than a computer screen.Third, reading the NEJM off the kindle screen is almost as good as reading articles printed from the online journal...except, you eliminate the ink/tonor cost.Fourth, the kindle saves the old editions on the device for you (creating a virtual library)Fifth, the kindle will read the NEJM to you...by connecting into the speakers of your car stereo via a Coby cassette adapter.  The kindle therefore allows doctors to transform commuting (driving) time into more CME time.Sixth, doctors tend to be mobile and hard pressed for time--walking (running) throughout the hospital or from office to office.  It would be a god send to have all the major journals available at one's fingertips on an easy to read platform.  The kindle version of the NEJM is the first step toward this vision.  To expand on this thought--having "Up to Date" or other medical info. review sites available on the kindle would greatly add to its appeal.Disadvantage:  Charts and graphs in the articles are difficult to read on the Kindle 2. When you zoom in on the charts and graphs by placing the cursor over them, they are much easier to read.  If charts and graphs are very important to you, consider getting the Kindle DX, which reportedly makes charts and graphs much more readable.

I am a clinician whose primary area of practice is oncology. I am constantly looking for new and innovative ways to stay current with the medical literature. When I saw that the New England Journal of Medicine (NEJM) was available on the Kindle, I was ecstatic. The ability to have the NEJM delivered to me automatically, so I could peruse it at my leisure (and even have it read to me during my commute, as one previous reviewer pointed out) was very appealing. I own a Kindle v2, so my review is based on that platform.Overall, the articles are easy to read, and suffer very little from being converted to Kindle format, with one notable exception: the graphics and tables come across horribly on the Kindle screen. Figures which show baseline demographics of comparator groups are unreadable, even when zoomed. Black and white photos may or may not come across well, depending on the size and quality of the photo. These may be solved with the Kindle DX, but for those of us who have already invested in Kindle hardware, I'm certain you will experience the same frustrations. Amazon, if you hope to continue to gain additional readership from the medical community, and gain additional medical journal offerings, I highly suggest that something be done to correct this flaw. With a normal magazine article, pictures are often a nice addition, but not absolutely necessary. With medical literature, the figures and photos often give a vast quantity of data that are not contained elsewhere in an article. In other words, if I can't see the figure clearly, I can't interpret whether the article I'm reading is a quality article, and what impact it should have on the way I practice. I plan to give my NEJM subscription a couple more weeks to see if graphic quality is consistently poor. If so, I will discontinue my Kindle subscription, as the NEJM is widely available electronically via other means.Additionally, I mentioned that I was excited to have the Kindle read articles out loud while I was commuting to work. Unfortunately, due to the complex nature of medical terminology, the Kindle often butchers pronunciations, and stumbles over genetic information, abbreviations, etc. that are common in the medical literature. This makes articles read aloud via the Kindle almost incomprehensible. I much prefer to read articles the old fashioned way rather than have them read to me.That being said, I do find that having the NEJM available on my Kindle has increased the number of articles from the Journal that I take a serious look at (as opposed to just glancing over). Also, I have started bringing my Kindle on rounds with me. It fits very nicely into my lab coat pocket, and makes a handy reference tool (not to mention the wow-factor from other clinicians when I pull it out).Overall, 4 out of 5 stars for ease of use, portability, originality of concept, and wireless delivery. Fix the graphic issues, and I'd give it a 5/5 without hesitation.

Super quick one you can devour over your lunchbreak.  Landing on the sweeter side of the erotica spectrum, this is a decent effort for the beginning of a series.  Not sure if the subsequent stories will integrate or if their only tie will be that the heroines are modern professionals, but I wouldn't mind having this particular tale developed more - maybe seeing Celeste stick it to her ex that she has landed a hot, wealthy replacement, for example.  I'll be interested to read the next Working Girls offering!

"Celeste the Real Estate Agent" lands on the short and sweet and of the scale. It has all of the stuff you would expect from a good erotica book packed into something you can read through in half an hour or so. It has got good characters and chemistry, fantastic sex scenes that go into the perfect amount of detail without being too hardcore. I will be interested to read the rest of the series.If you want a fairly quick but really exciting erotica to read when you have some time to yourself, "Celeste the Real Estate Agent" is a good choice.

This was a surprisingly funny and entertaining read. I say surprising because you don’t usually expect erotic romances to have bits that make you laugh, but this one has a few! I identified with the main character Celeste because she was a very believable modern woman.  Both of the main characters were likeable and there was certainly a lot of chemistry! It was extremely steamy and was very well written and not ‘dirty’ at all. I could see this being more than a short story but a full-length novel.  I can’t wait to read the next instalment in the ‘Working Girls’ series.

This ebook was a fast read but didn't lack quality! If you're looking for something to spice up your afternoon then a coffee some cake and this book will do it! It is a light hearted little sex romp between strangers. I can see the author is on a winning track with these types of stories. Quick to captivate and titilate I would recommend Celeste the real estate agent! And keep an eye out for others in the working girls lunch time series.

And it tastes like llama droppings.I would only read McCovey Chronicles if I hated the San Francisco Giants, America, music, Buster Posey, Tims, Gordon Beckham's hair, MS Paint, God, cod, myself, stats, splits, Jorge Cantu, trading a B-ish prospect for the left-hand side of a 1B platoon, rosterbation, pie, and oxford commas.I guess $0.99 is a pretty good deal though.
Source (K): So Bad I Can Taste It

Source (H): Seldom do I really answer those who criticize Grant's work. In fact, the entire development of my time as a moderator at McCoveyChronicles has been fueled by my ability to ignore denigrating and trivializing criticism of Grant as I realize my dreams and my goals. However there is something compelling about Amazon's willingness to publish just about anything, and the sheer outrageous stupidity of many things some have said here that actually touches my proletarian and Democratic soul. Also I use and enjoy Amazon and I do read the reviews of other people's blogs in many fields. In sum, I believe in what happens here. And so, I speak. First off, let me say that this is addressed only to some of you, who have posted outrageously negative comments here, and not to all. You are interrogating this blog from the wrong perspective. Indeed, you aren't even reading it. You are projecting your own limitations on it. And you are giving a whole new meaning to the words "wide readership." And you have strained my obsessivegiantscompulivian principles to the max. I'm justifiably proud of saying that Grant is read by intellectual Giants fans and waitresses in trailer parks. In fact, I love it, but who in the world are you? Now to the blog. Allow me to point out: nowhere in this blog are you told that these are literally McCovey's Chronicles, nowhere are you promised on-topic subthreads or a humorless pedantry, nowhere are you told there will be in-depth coverage of every last rumored Matt Cain for Prince Fielder trade. The blog tells you exactly what to expect. And it warns you specifically that if you do not enjoy obscure references to the movie Red Dawn, listening to hipster nerd indie rock, or eating eggrolls, you may not enjoy this blog. This blog is written by a hero whom those of you writing negative reviews have already rejected. And he tells you that you are likely to reject him again. And this blog is most certainly written -- every word of it -- by Grant. Unless you count the people who write the FanPosts. Or, God forbid, the FanShots. If and when Grant can't write a blog entry on my own, you know about it. It happens. Sometimes people get married, or have kids, and have to put aside the blog writing for a day or two. That's what Josh From Hollywood and jponry are around for. And no, Grant has no intention of allowing any trusted moderator ever to distort, cut, or otherwise mutilate sentences that he has edited and re-edited, and organized and polished himself. He fought a great battle to achieve a status where he did not have to put up with trusted moderators making demands on him, and he will never relinquish that status. For Grant, blog writing is a virtuoso performance. It is not a collaborative art. Back to the blog itself: the man we typically love to hate is Brian Sabean. But since the World Series win, we've been with him more closely than we have ever been in the course of this blog; his roster moves have been as sensible to our minds as we've ever felt - and Grant vocalizes that. I've experienced breakthrough after breakthrough as I've read Grant's work, moved with him, saw through his eyes. Also, his windows. What I ask of Grant, Grant unfailingly gives. For me, three articles a week, two which make me laugh -- usually the Select Your Own Scenario or the one with the funny graph -- or even the one where Russel Martin sucks it -- are all Grant needs to do to earn his hefty SBN salary. They can be read aloud without a single hitch. Every word is in perfect place. The short series of posts about how the Giants won the World Series was for me a totally realized poem. There are other such entries in this blog. You don't get all this? Fine. But I experienced an intimacy with the Grant in those entries that shattered all prior restraints, and when one is reading one does have to continuously and courageously fight a destructive tendency to inhibition and restraint. That I have been able to get really close to the subject matter is an achievement that only increases my appreciation of Grant and his blog. Now, if it doesn't appeal to you, fine. You don't enjoy it? Read somebody else. But your stupid arrogant assumptions about Grant and what the members of his blog are doing are slander. And you have used this site as if it were a public urinal to publish falsehood and lies. I'll never challenge your democratic freedom to do so, and yes, I'm answering you, but for what it's worth, be assured of the utter contempt I feel for you, especially those of you who want us to go and read YOUR blogs instead (and perhaps repeatedly?) and how sad I am that Grant's blog - the first and last one I read every day - has invited your hateful and ugly responses. Now, to touch on another narrative you'll find at this blog: In "Home Runs and Western Suns", Barry Zito's wanting to be a saint is a vision larded through and through with his characteristic vanity. It connects perfectly with his earlier ambitions to be an actor in Paris, a rock star in the modern age. If you can't see that, you aren't reading TheLetter2's work! In Zito's conversation with the Pope he makes observations on the times which are in continuity with Aubrey Huff's observations five chapters earlier, and in continuity with Aaron Rowand's observations in all the way in the Epilogue. Barry Zito's state of mind has always been an important theme in "Home Runs and Western Suns" - though it tends to get overshadowed by all the Huff/Burrell slash. Zito's comments matter. Every word he speaks is part of the achievement of TheLetter2's work. That Zito renounced this saintly ambition within a matter of pages is plain enough for you to see. That he reverts to his old self is obvious, and that he intends to complete as many games as a Giant as he can is also quite clear. There are many other themes and patterns in this work that I might mention -- the interplay between Buster Posey and Tim Lincecum, the invisible bond that doesn't "exist" in the eyes of the front office is a case in point. There is also the theme of the lack of towels available in the visitor's locker room at Petco Park, the place where human existence becomes so beguiling that hitters simply relinquish their power as if to a spell. The entire relationship between Barry Zito and Jose Guillen is carefully worked out. But I leave it to readers to discover how this complex and intricate work of art establishes itself within a unique blog experience. There are things to be said. And there is pleasure to be had. And readers will say wonderful things about both McCoveyChronicles and "Home Runs and Western Suns" if they give them a chance. There are readers out there and plenty of them who cherish the individuality of each front page story on McCoveyChronicles which you so flippantly condemn. They can and do talk circles around you. And I am warmed by their response. Their letters, the papers they write in school, our face to face exchanges on the road -- these things sustain me when I read the utter trash that you post. But I feel I have said enough. If this reaches one reader who is curious about Grant's work and shocked by the ugly reviews here, I've served my goals. And Yo, you dude, the junk police! jponry and Natto are not clowns. They never have been and never will. But, for whatever sick reason, you probably wouldn't much like being around either one of them. And you wouldn't have to. If any of you want to say anything about all this by all means Email me at mopedtime34@yahoo.com. And if you want your money back for the blog, then screw you. It was 99 freaking cents. And yes, McCoveyChronicles totally rules! Thank God!
Who needs this junk. jponry and natto are complete clowns, and grant isn't anything special.Besides, why pay money when you can visit for free?.remember, stay away.
Source (K): I hate mccovey chronicles (By Matt Rox/sign posey)

Source (H): I took McCovey Chronicles for a short spin last year and I can tell you from experience, it's complete garbage. The site is run by people who have absolutely no knowledge of baseball or the San Francisco Giants. Most of the time, the articles and subsequent commentary from the 7 or 8 "regulars" who want to be part of something bigger than their own useless lives, have nothing to do with baseball. Instead, I have noticed a lot of commentary about video games, Asian women, and eggrolls. Real childish stuff. In fact, there's a lot of Giants-bashing that goes on there from so-called Giants fans. They're pretty much just a bunch of bitter people using the Internet to get attention. I wouldn't pay a penny for this service, let alone 99 of them.p.s. Read my blog.

I love these headphones. Very good quality and so comfortable to wear. the sound quality is so very good. great purchase.

I have to admit, I didn't think much of these headphones when I was looking at them through the box. Putting them on, though, made me a believer.The first thing I noticed is that the headphone cord, which is enclosed in a little fiber sleeve to prevent fraying, is not attached to the headphones, i.e. you get to pick which side is right and left. Neat little touch. The 3.5 jack is also constructed so that the plastic behind the plug is thinner than usual. This lets it plug snugly into my Fire HD 7", which is protected by aleather casethat tends to make normal headphone plugs not go in all the way.The physical properties of the headphones alone are good, but they would mean nothing if the sound wasn's awesome - which, thankfully, it is. The Tribeca projects some serious bass for its size, but not so much that it overpowers the rest of the music unnecessarily. Whether I'm listening to hard rock, violins, Broadway or dubstep, the Tribeca performs admirably.My one, fairly minor, issue is that the Tribeca is not designed to fit large heads. I'm a fairly slender 6'1" with an average-sized head for my height, and with the headphones at their maximum size (each size only extends about an inch) they just barely fit on my head, and I can't see myself wearing these for long periods of time because after about 15 minutes the plastic on the crown of my head starts to really hurt. If I wore a hat, that would put something between my scalp and the plastic, but I doubt the headphones would fit me then.Short of the the relatively small size of the headphones, these are a good product. I would recommend them to anyone with an average-sized head or smaller.

In the package they looked like something that might match my pair of wooden shoes. However, unlike the shoes these headphones were made in China, not Holland. Putting style aside, how is the sound and comfort of these headphones?Personally I was immediately impressed by the construction. The padded earphones are very comfortable though after a while I was conscious of the pressure on the stems of my glasses against my head. For extended listening sessions by wearers of spectacles, earbuds might be a little more comfortable. The headphones are nicely adjustable to find one's personal comfort zone.I really like the look of the wood on the headphones and the cord material used for the cables. These don't easily become knotted like the vinyl cords do.The sound emanating from these earphones is very good. I sampled them on my laptop, a Marquis 10" pad, and the Kindle Fire. It may be my imagination, but I thought they sounded best on the Kindle. Also I compared the phones to an inexpensive MEE pair and a set of earbuds that are selling on Amazon at the moment for close to $180.  The Tribeca phones outperform the other two earphones easily. These Tribeca phones produce a full, rich sound, have nice separation, and good bass without distortion. Voices and instruments both are reproduced with excellent clarity.While wearing these headphones, I can barely hear Mrs. Spudman speaking, and they work especially well with sound blocking when she brings up topics I'd rather not address.The Tribeca headphones give good sound and comfort and sport a unique style.

I've been subscribed for about 3 weeks, and just cancelled.  I really like the intent of this blog, and much of the content.  BUT it has so many URL links that it just makes me hungry to find it on the web from my computer.  So, why bother with the Kindle edition?  I decided not to.

The content is okay but somewhat limited. No comics and some graphics missing. Source (H): This is a very good book for people publishing non-fiction on Kindle. It covers a lot of powerful sales methods that are PROVEN to work. Experts use these methods to hit super sales levels. Previous reviewers of this book that have complained about these sales techniques just don't understand that these things work. People respond to "power" words and hidden commands to buy. It is a built-in unconscious response that can be measured in the lab. No matter how sophisticated we THINK we are, we all have certain buttons in our brains that smart marketers know how to push.As proof of this, just consider how a vast majority of us keep on working our fingers to the bones to keep paying for stuff we really don't need. Smart marketers just keep on pushing our buttons and we keep buying in to their vision of what they think we should have. The author of this book has studied the expert marketers and the psychology behind motivation and reveals the hidden secrets right here in his simple, easy to understand book that every book author should read and use to increase their sales. If you have written a book that you think will be of use to readers, you owe it to yourself to learn and follow these techniques so you can entice your prospective audience to actually buy your book which will really help them. If you don't use proven sales methods to get readers, their attention will wander to someone who does, and they will spend their money elsewhere and miss out on your helpfull offering. Buy this book and follow it to increase your book sales!
Source (K): Proven sales techniques for book authors.

Source (H): I'm sure that there are plenty of interesting tidbits of info in here, but I stopped reading after the first couple chapters.  This book is in dire need of an editor whose first language is English.  The book is riddled with grammatical errors, mostly missing articles or wrong verb tenses.  These are basic things that could have been addressed if someone else had read the manuscript.Also, the formatting is extremely annoying with unnecessary tabs at the start of every paragraph.  The entire book is basically ad copy, trying to get the reader to purchase other books.  Personally, I will stop at one.

One look at the description told me Anbu is an expert.  There is so much information in the book, I am not going to bore you by listing it all.  It covers every important aspect of writing a description.What was the benefit to me?  There is so much information I wondered how I would remember it all.  Then I got the idea of loading it in my Cloud reader.  I highlighted important points and immediately made a note with draft sentences for my next description.  Now my next description is almost written.There are other great eBooks on selling and marketing.  I reference them often.  This is the only eBook I will read every time I upload a new book.  I will go back and update all my descriptions for my other books.This book will put $$$ in your pocket.  Stop thinking and buy a copy.  It comes with a guarantee.PS:  You will be happy you did!  I know I am!  This book is fantastic!
Source (K): Fantastic guide by a proven expert!

Source (H): This book felt like it was being read to me by Billy Mays(RIP), and now I have a headache. I hate to write bad reviews, but this book highlights the reasons that I won't normally buy self-published nonfiction.Some examples:The authors 'power tips' section includes "learn to type fast", and "read a lot".His premise states that readers are basically stupid and that certain magical words trigger some sort of 'I have to buy this' mentality, when in reality we all learned to dismiss obvious commercials a long time ago.I'm pretty forgiving of formatting or grammar mistakes, but if you took all of the empty space and repeated sentences, the book would be about fifteen pages long.Instead, use this:Tell people how their book will benefit them,Use bullet points,Include bonus content,And the P? Use a P.S. to describe extra content at the end of the description.That's it. Now, you don't have to have a headache like I do.

Source (H): I gave this a shot for a few days, but it's just not formatted well.  For some reason, their HTML->Kindle conversion leaves out spaces between words on a regular basis.  You can kind of get used to it, but it's jarring enough to block the humor.It's a cancel for me, I'm afraid, and I love the Onion.

Ok, you can go to the website for The Onion and read the articles there for free, or pay for the paper version (which I rarely find).What's neat is a new article from the Onion is sent to the Kindle every day (sometimes two or three articles, of varying length). In the evening, after reading the 'serious' news, it's nice to Kindle to the Onion and read the days feature.

The online retailer Amazon has begun to offer The Onion delivered wirelessly to the Kindle eBook reader.  What do _you_ think?Roger Beal,Marketing Consultant"Man, I love having my favorite newspaper in a barely legible format and missing half the content for the low, low price of $1.99 a month."Timothy Summers,Unemployed"I can pick up a print version or go to the website to read the full version for free but, you know, what do you want for nothing?"Shelia Wilkins,Systems Analyst"There's all those words and articles in the full versions... it's like the Kindle is doing all the work reading for me.  Thanks Amazon!"
Source (K): Online Book Seller Offers The Onion For Wireless Reader

Source (H): I was all ready to write a 4-star review until 20 minutes ago.I fired up the Kindle and saw some new content had arrived for the Onion (which happens once or twice per day). Upon opening the first story, I saw they had addressed the #1 problem I had with the service and it pushed the review up to 5 stars: they are now including pictures.I know it doesn't seem like much, but it really adds to the humor. Previously, I'd read the articles on my Kindle while away from the computer... and then I'd end up going to the website so I could see the picture that I assumed should be there.There have been a lot of complaints in these reviews about improper formatting, space between words, etc.  All of these things have been worked out for a few weeks now, so you don't need to worry about that. I've subscribed to a few blogs/magazines on my Kindle and I'd say that the Onion is now some of the best-formatted content available. I'll post a few screenshots to show what it now looks like on my Kindle 2.If you tried it before and you were unhappy with it, I urge you to try it again. If you wrote a negative review and your concerns have been addressed, please check it out again and update your review accordingly (if it changes your mind).Fans of The Onion can now subscribe on their Kindle and be happy with the content they receive.EDIT: I have uploaded a few screenshots of how the Onion content looks on the Kindle 2. You can see them under user photos at the top.AMAZON: you might need to find a different way to manage reviews of things like this... it isn't a product, it is a service. Some of the "most helpful" reviews are over a year old. The service has since adjusted and updated so those reviews are (at least partially) no longer accurate... yet those are the first (and possibly only) reviews that a new user will see.
Source (K): They've worked out the bugs and now it is excellent

Source (H): The service is getting worse. The What Do You Think? segment is not working, missing most of article. Also now shows audio and video links which obviously don't work on a Kindle. Too bad, I've always enjoyed The Onion and hope they realize that they should tailor this to the Kindle's strengths.

When asked to review a portable, alternatively-formatted version of The Onion, a popular online satirical newspaper, a local man stated "No AV Club? No sale. Meh."He continued, "I like The Onion. There was a time I'd visit it every week for updates, which are always witty, sarcastic, and sometimes confused for real news. The paper edition, which resembles a pint-size USA Today, is also a lot of fun.""Even better is the AV Club portion of the site, with music and movie reviews not found elsewhere. I'm particularly fond of Dan Savage's 'Savage Love' sex-advice column, and Wil Wheaton's reviews of old video games."This loyal fan feels that the Kindle version isn't worth the asking price. The Kindle delivery system necessitates a certain style of formatting, using plain text, and occasional, minimal black and white graphics. Unlike its online equivalent, which is updated weekly, the Kindle edition has several small updates during the week, ostensibly to make this online publication resemble a weblog (or "blog") rather than a newspaper.The reviewer began pacing around the room, gesturing manically. "What tears it is the complete absence of the AV Club!"The description for this "blog" at Amazon's sales page states "A non-satirical entertainment section covering all aspects of the industry is offered, plus information, critique, and commentary about media and the arts.""If it 'is offered,' I don't see where, because it didn't come up on my Kindle!" hissed the commentator. "This material should be treated as a weekly newspaper, and if it isn't complete, I see no reason to pay for it in this hobbled format. I'll continue to read it on my computer, as I have done for years ... and if I really need an Onion fix, I'll hit the WAP version at [...]."He stormed off in a huff, shouting, "Somebody please wake me if/when this gets fixed, and I'll sign up again. Until then, Area Man Quits Paying For Hobbled Version of Free Website."
The Onion never fails to make me laugh.  It puts just the right comic spin on the news.  I don't love all of the articles, but most of them are very amusing.
Second issue had only two new articles, all others repeats.  Is this the norm for this publication? Will try one more day and cancel if nothing new.

Well, I beg to differ. .21c (divided by 28 days) per issue for a daily newspaper is nothing. Source (H): The Politico is one of my favorite spots online for political news, and I like to pick up the free paper edition here in the DC metro area whenever I can. I was actually looking forward to supporting them with real money. Alas, it is not to be.Like with so many other Kindle newspapers, my problem is not with the content but with the formatting. They're all needlessly mangled in one way or another, but Politico manages to do a worse job than all I've seen. One problem has to do with they way they convert hyperlinks in articles--sometimes the link text is replaced with a URL, and sometimes the link text is missing entirely. The end result is something like:- This morning, President Obama signed the example.com/someurl, which, according to House Democrats, should solve the ongoing .Another fun touch, and I can't even offer a theory as to how this could happen, is that they randomly switch single and double quote marks, so you can't tell where internal quotes start and stop. Looks like this:- Asked to elaborate on the Senator's comments, the staffer replied, 'He told me he knows "nothing beyond what's been revealed to the press,' so that's all I'll say."I hope one day newspapers can get their acts together on Kindle. Here you have a captive audience who wants nothing more than to pay you real money for the digital content you're serving up free online, and you can't even hire an intern to write a decent script to convert that content to Kindle format.
Source (K): The worst-formatted Kindle paper I've seen, and that's saying something

Source (H): Considering price and convienence, well worth it.  Was a little disconcerted at first till I found the "text view" vs "page view" button.  If you're like me, one reason we enjoy print copy is because we LIKE looking at the ads.  Sure, in page view mode it's sort of a pain zooming in and out, but if it's a good article, just switch to text. The text version also has pictures from article.  Best of both worlds.

I'd definitely prefer to have the native Kindle Fire version of PC World, but it is priced $10/year higher than the magazine's standard price for the Zinio-based digital edition (and, amazingly, $15/year more than the print version).  Since Zinio works on the Fire, I can't justify that extra $10.

Source (H): I have been reading NRO online for years. This book, although relatively short, was everything I hoped it would be. It is a guide for well-bred young ladies of society in the 1800's. It explains the "how-to's" of everything from how to speak properly and how to return "visits" to how to wear your gloves correctly and how to act at social functions. In a way, it's quite silly in terms of present day etiquette, but it also is fascinating and kind of sweet. I enjoyed reading it, and if history is one of your interests, perhaps you will, too.

I got the Nat Geo for my kids, both of whom have competed at state for the geography bee contest. I just found out that Nat Geo has decided to air the Seal Team Six video 2 days before the election. A pure crass political move. Regardless of sides here, Nat Geo is not in the politics business to this level. The President of Nat Geo said he did it to be "opportunistic".My kids can get their fill of political opinion elsewhere. Nat Geo should have been a refuge. At some point, things should not be "opportunistic" but for a greater cause...like kids.Just cancelled my subscription.

I bought one digital copy, and I'll not do it again. The best feature of National Geographic is its pictures, and the digital edition doesn't include them! There was literally ONE picture for every article. To add insult to injury, the hard copy subscription (pictures and all) was cheaper.I bought a regular sent-to-my-mailbox subscription instead.

The review is for Amazon policy of its kindle magazine not magazine itself.Before I continue, I want say I have been very happy with the service of Amazon for a long time until I have issues with my national geographic subscription. Amazon's policy makes me mad. the magazine looks so great with the kindle fire especially the 8.9 but Amazon makes me want to yell at them.First of all, there are limited number of issues which can be stored in the cloud. only the most recent 7 issues can be stored. before I had time to read the issues before the last 7 they are deleted from the cloud without noticing me. I didn't get a chance to explore the possibility of downloading the old issues on my kindle or other device before they are deleted from cloud.Second, after I realized what happened I decided to cancel the subscription. This time I downloaded all the issues in the cloud to my kindle(7 of them). I know they will delete the content from the cloud after it is cancelled. I got to access these seven issues from my kindle right after I cancelled subscription.I thought at least I got some damage control. today I turned on my kindle again and they disappeared. after 20 minutes on the phone I was told that it is Amazon' s policy to delete all issues from the KINDLE after the subscription is cancelled. Really?! I never heard anything more ridiculous than this? Basically I paid $1.99 a month for more than a year and at the end I didn't even get to read most of the magazine I subscribed? $@&=&:+#$(():Stay away from Amazon e-magazine unless you want to be ripped off.

National Geographic is a wonderful magazine, but note the small print on the Kindle site. You CAN'T load the subscription on the Kindle HD Fire. So, you can only view it on other devices in black and white. I just cancelled my subscription. I hope Kindle doesn't have more "fine print" restrictions.
Source (K): Not Available for the Fire HD

Source (H): First off. This is a beautiful magazine both in print and on the Kindle Fire. However to me this is a publication you want to keep as a reference in case you are ever going to make that exotic journey you planned and unfortunately this probably is not going to happen if you buy this from Amazon. There are a couple of things going on here.1) There are a limited number (7) of back issues issues that can be kept in the cloud. You can keep more on the Kindle Fire itself, however all the Fires including the new ones do not have expandable storage. Color magazines like these are not tiny files and if you have some music plus books plus back issues of a couple of magazines (like I do) then onboard storage starts to diminish pretty rapidly.2) And this is even more important. IF YOU CANCEL YOUR SUBSCRIPTION YOU WILL LOSE ACCESS TO ANY BACK COPIES STORED IN THE CLOUD. YES YOU LOSE WHAT YOU HAVE PAID FOR. Now again you can elect to "keep" the back copies on the KF but they eat up onboard storage and if you have several subscriptions you will have problems.It is much better to use the Z i n i o app and buy publications through them. In this case they are always held in the cloud. The company also has a much wider range of offerings than Amazon and is often cheaper
Source (K): Beautiful on the KF. However One star is for Amazon policies not the magazine

Source (H): I allowed my National Geographic Society membership to lapse so I could give the Kindle subscription a shot.  I don't like magazines cluttering my house, I want to conserve paper, and I want my magazine subscriptions on-time even when I'm traveling.  So far I thoroughly enjoy reading National Geographic on my Nexus 7.  I have compared the electronic version to a print copy and I have all of the photos and all of the content.  I'm not sure what's going on with other subscribers, but it works fine for me.Why not five stars?  The electronic version is more expensive than the print (something common to all magazines) and I'm no longer a member of the NGS, just a subscriber to their electronic edition.  I have to assume I will no longer receive the maps, but for me that's not a big loss.  To others it might be.

If you want to read this magazine on more than one Kindle device you have to buy it twice!!!!!! I am  a subscriber to NG on my Kindle DX. I recently purchased a Kindle Fire HD 8.9. To get the magazine delivered to the Fire HD 8.9 you have to use the interactive app. NG can' t be delivered to the Fire HD in the normal way. The thing is, you have to buy another subscription through the app to get it on the Fire HD. I have 9 other magazine subscriptions with Amazon. None of them have such nonsense. I can read them all on either device as I choose. But, not National Geographic. I contacted Amazon CS and I was told that there is nothing they can do. If I want to read it on my Fire HD I have to buy another subscription through the app. The magazine itself is as good as ever but this policy on the part of Amazon and/or National Geographic stinks. So, I have to make a choice: continue to receive the magazine on the Kindle DX only or buy the subscription again just so I can read it on the Fire HD 8.9. I think I will cancel and get it from Zinio just on principle.

I'd really love to know why the trend for incomplete novels has become so popular lately.  Against the Odds is such a novel..novella...short story?This review will have spoilers, so be ware.  I am so ticked with getting taken in by another cliff hanger ending that I am using this open forum to spew my angst.  If that bothers you, do not read the review.In this half written tale of woe, we have Victoria/Shell who is devastated by the recent loss of her mother.  Her father, for reasons we don't know, has moved on really quickly to date, move in, and plan to marry Missy.  She comes with Nathan, her seventeen year old awesomely spectacular Dean's list super sports star son.  Now, I can forgive the Mary Sue Nathan, but the story just doesn't add up.For all intents and purposes, Victoria's mom and dad had a really great relationship until one night, her mom, who was wrapped up with work, left work late and died in an accident.  Her dad doesn't let her talk about her mom, he has HER get rid of all of her mom's things in order to make room for the new arrivals, and he is all about keeping Victoria down.  He jumps her case about everything- when he pays attention to her.  He adore Nathan and is completely oblivious to his own daughter's pain.  Makes no sense based on the inferences the author gives about their previous life.So, Nathan tells Shell/Victoria that she needs to loosen up and get smexed, because that's what all boys want.  So they come to a business agreement.... Which quickly gets revamped when Nathan gets cold feet.  He starts dating someone else, so does she, which culminates to a fight and "I really like yous and we better tell everyone about us."Then suddenly, she is literally ripped- by the hair–- from her bed one night and hauled down the stairs by medical professionals?- who are there to "get her help."  What?  Number one, no medical professional worth his or her salt is going to violently and angrily wake a potential patient from a sound sleep, by dragging them by the hair, down the stairs.  When her father, who is standing by, glaring, says that she will get the help she needs, he is ordered to not talk to the patient.  So now not only do we have an incomplete story, we have a complete cluster of half created drama that is completely UNNECESSARY.Sadly, I was enjoying the story of two messed up teens who were trying to make the best of things.  It was believable, for the most part.  The last two chapters (including the "party" at the client's house) were complete what the heck moments that detracted from the initial story line and created drama for drama's sake.  Disappointing.  Buyer, beware.

I stopped buying magazines because the price was so high and I hated having so much clutter, but I got Traditional Home on my Kindle Fire for a free month view and was so impressed. The history of "the dozens" keeps a readers attention for the first 50 pages, after that it's more of the same third grade "dirty words." "The Dozens" sounds like  male locker room babble, but it made me sad to hear the misogynistic verbiage directed at the mothers and sisters of men so disenfranchised themselves.  Don't ease into it. I think its fine to put the info out there but sometimes I felt I was reading more of a commercial than a blog. There is some good information but a lot of redundancy. Business Today is a biweekly from India and it has a cover price of Rs 10 or so, roughly about 25 cents! And Amazon is charging 3 times that! And it is not a good business publication from India. It is generally trash and sensational reporting rather than analytical and research based publication. Journalistic values are also suspect as many of the articles are based on press releases. Especially when it comes to big Indian companies! So why should some one pay much higher for something that is not selling all that well in India? These publishers have been trying to lure readers to subscribe offering four or five times the value of subscription through gifts. So, Amazon should force them to cut the costs.
Source (K): Too high a price for a 25-cent biweekly

Source (H): I am on trial of Asahi Shinbun. As an overseas Japanese, I have been struggling in accessing to Japanese papers. Although I usually do not read Asahi at home because of its left wing stance, I decided to try, expecting good coverage of domestic news, even biased. From this point, it is successful. All key articules are there! I am satisfied. However, the delivery is too late. I got Saturday edition in the lete Friday night in Geneva and no further editions on entire Saturday and up to 10 am on Sunday. I understand the new edition is coming automatically.I wished to start my relaxing weekend with home news. At first I was happy that Asahi Shinbun has released its Kindle edition of their newspaper,however I was really disappointed that it has too little articles.Most of its article is originally written in Japanese and translated so it may take time and effortbut I didn't intend to read merely a "translation digest" of its originals.Also there's too many corporate announcements, it could take up almost half of the entire newspaper.Also there's no picures - this is not unique to Asahi but to all the kindle newspapers and magazines outside of United States, still it is a great pity.

Source (H): The Asahi is one of the two biggest papers in Japan and much less conservative than its rival the Yomiuri. Although its opinion writers sometimes annoy me, it is really good at social stories and giving a more rounded view of Japanese society than you get some of the more conservative papers. It is the equivalent of the Japanese Guardian (for U.K. readers) or the New York Times (for U.S). The Kindle English edition is good and seems to be very well translated. All of which makes it quite annoying that I can't seem to get it on the iphone Kindle app, which is my preferred way of reading. This is really Amazon's decision rather than the Asahi, I think, so I have stuck with a good star rating and a plea to Amazon to get the newspapers on the iphone. (I should add that the complaints about press releases by some other commenters below are a bit facile. The press release section is a properly labeled section of the Asahi's kindle coverage and quite separate from their news and analysis. I personally am not that interested but I think the idea is to offer people first hand access to the Japanese business etc. scene.)

I have always loved reading Guideposts and even more now that it is conviently sent to my Kindle. Every inspiring story reminds me that we are not alone in this human condition; others have walked before us. Uplifting, comforting stories of overcoming lives trials.

It is more expensive to order a 2 year subscription of guideposts to come on my Kindle than it is to order it directly from Guideposts and have it come to my mail box. If I order it for only a year from Amazon and to come to my kindle than its about the same. maybe a penny less, than if I order a years subscription from Guideposts.I'm wondering why that is, since if I order guideposts from the publisher it involves paper and mailing and etc. More expense to get the actual magazine you'd think, wouldn't you? But instead it is actually cheaper to get this magazine in its paper form.Why shouldnt Amazon subscribers get the guideposts magazine for cheaper when it comes to their kindle? No tree had to die. No one delivered it to my door. We should be seeing a big savings here but instead we are paying more for a 2 year subscription. Go figure???If I order the Guideposts to be delivered by the post office to my door, I can actually pass it on to someone else when I finish reading it. Thats a much better deal I think.Until Amazon can reduce their subscription cost I'll stick to the real thing.

When you publish a novel in serial form you really should FINISH what you started! I have been a subscriber to Fallout 101 since it started and I have put up with all the author's excuses and reasons why he could not publish this serial ON TIME every week. Bookgasm is like your favorite independent neighborhood bookstore of days gone by - the kind that carries the coolest titles that you absolutely love but would never stumble upon yourself, and with knowledgeable clerks who are walking/talking encyclopedias of classic, pop and indie literature.It's not a book store, really. More like a "book club" that clues you in on the best book titles available and points you in the right direction.The reviews are crisp and concise - like short articles on USA Today, but written much, much better. And the range of book titles and authors presented is impressive. There's even a cool sort feature that lets you easily access an archive of old reviews of authors you enjoy. And the weekly contest - it's oh so easy to participate and the odds of winning are better than you'd think.In short, if you had to pick one site to help you cobble together a reading list and keep on top of the morass of "what's out there," Bookgasm would be it. It's 5-star fantastic!!
Source (K): Bookgasm - the best place to find out about the best books

Source (H): Years ago when I was learning to fly, Flying Magazine was an integral part of my lifestyle. Articles by Richard Collins and Peter Garrison were compelling and entertainingly educational. I left off my print subscription some time back and recently decided to start it up again on my Kindle. I found that it had turned into an advertisers paradise without very much to offer. Certainly it was nothing like it once was. I compare it to DISCOVER, which offers Kindle subscribers two versions in one, where we can see each page of the magazine faithfully represented, or select text view which displays like any book and contains no advertising. Flying has a tremendous opportunity with its inertia of longevity to provide pilots of all stripes the same wealth it once did, but has chosen to focus more on commercial advertising instead. I'm gravely disappointed and saddened that I have to recommend against others buying this magazine. Take the free trial if you wish, I think you will feel the same about the weight of advertising versus content, and the difficulty of reading articles. One has to zoom them and mess with positioning text. They should take a page from DISCOVER and produce a publication that's worthwhile to the reader as much as their advertising income.

I love a printed mag so I was worried about subscribing this being my first time using my kindle fire. I think it's great. Its easy to magnify pages to see what I'd like to closer.  It is my favorite magazine but just easier with which to travel. No more wrinkled or curled pages. I also get to save space & some trees in the process. Same great magazine for a woman who wants fitness info with no fluffy filler. There will unfortunately always be ads in magazines. Just part of the product.

Source (K): Why do you charge monthly and only deliver bi-monthly?

Source (H): Ich wohne in Deutschland und habe mir in der ersten Welle der europäischen Kunden Mitte Oktober den neuen Kindle bestellt, und zwar mit Blick auf dieses Abonnement; Fazit: Nach kleinen Anlaufschwierigkeiten funktioniert die ganze Geschichte prima! Das FAZ-Abo auf dem Kindle vermittelt ein Gefühl, wie ich es nur bei der ersten Verwendung eines Textverarbeitungsprogramms oder beim Einschalten des iPhones verspürt habe. Im Einzelnen:Das Gerät wurde zwei Tage nach der Auslieferung in den USA morgens 10.00 Uhr an meiner Haustür zugestellt. Weitere Zollgebühren fielen - anders als dies teilweise in der Presse verbreitet wird - nicht an. Sie werden von Amazon bei der Bestellung hier gleich zugeschlagen und abgewickelt. Nur das Öffnen der kleinen Schachtel brachte einen Dämpfer, den einzigen: Das Netzteil passt nur auf amerikanische Steckdosen. Rasch stellte sich heraus, dass es sich um einen Kombistecker aus USB- und Netzteil vglb. den Apple-Steckern handelte. Aber: Mit meinem Apple-Stecker konnte ich den Kindle merkwürdigerweise nicht aufladen; dieser entlud sich sogar. Der Ladevorgang ging zunächst nur über den Computer! Schade: Hätte Amazon vorher darüber informiert, dass ein Adapter benötigt würde, hätte sich gleich das bekannte Apple-Gefühl eingestellt: Auspacken und sich sofort wohl fühlen. Die nächste kleinere Hürde bestand darin, dass hier bei Amazon.com im Rahmen des eigenen Benutzerkontos die bereits angegebene Karte noch einmal für den Kindle freigegeben werden musste.Dann aber ging es los: Mit dem Kindle hatte ich die erste Ausgabe in ca. 5 Minuten nach Einleitung des Bestellvorgangs auf dem Bildschirm. Seit drei Tagen kommt das Blatt nach Einschalten des Geräts pünktlich morgens bei mir an (ich wohne auf dem Land und habe keine Empfangsprobleme).Die Handhabung selbst bedeutet für mich eine so eindeutige Verbesserung gegenüber der üblichen Zeitungslektüre wie oben beschrieben. Zu Hause sitzen wir mittlerweile zu Dritt am Tisch mit unseren Zeitungen; dies wird eng. Hier beginnt der erste und vielleicht entscheidende Vorteil: Die Handhabung der Zeitung ist wesentlich entspannender, wobei die Lesbarkeit in keiner Weise leidet. Ich nehme das Kindle (es ist so leicht, dass ich erst gar nicht nachgewogen habe) überall hin mit und bekomme die Zeitung damit endlich (seit mehr als 10 Jahren) auch ausgelesen. Schaltet man das Gerät aus, merkt es sich die Stelle, an der die Lektüre beendet wurde. Es hat ein überaus edles Erscheinungsbild, das hier in der Fotoabbildung m.E. nicht so ganz deutlich wird. Die Steuerung ist leicht erlernbar und der einmal geladene Akku hält jetzt bereits locker ein paar Tage. Einzelne Exemplare der Zeitung kann man schließlich archivieren, so dass sie dauerhaft auf dem Kindle bleiben.Der zweite Vorteil ergibt sich für mich daraus, dass ich meine Zeitung jetzt auch außerhalb unseres Hauses bekommen kann (ich bin sehr häufig unterwegs); ich brauche sie vor allem im Urlaub nicht mehr abzubestellen, um mich dann aus dunklen Kanälen über das Geschehen zu Hause zu infomieren (bin gespannt, ob es auf den Malediven funktioniert!).Dritter Vorteil: Der Preis. Der oben angegebene Preis bezieht sich auf ein Monatsabo. Jeder kann im Internet nachsehen, dass man gegenüber dem Hardcopy-Abo bares Geld spart.Verschwiegen sei allerdings auch nicht der einzige Nachteil: Bilder, Grafiken und Tabellen im Orginaltext werden im Kindle nicht abgedruckt. Ich kann dies verschmerzen; für viele könnte dies aber nicht akzeptabel sein. Dafür aber finden sich nach meinem Vergleich alle Texte (auch typische Bildunterschriften, wenn diese eine eigene Information beinhalten) in der elektronischen Version.Für mich hat sich der Kauf schon wegen dieses Abos gelohnt; englische Bücher werden sicher bald folgen.

Receiving my Kindle I was really looking forward to get one of the praised newspapers subscriptions.Would be just so convenient.First little surprise was the fact that there are barely European ones available.So, I took the test subscription from the FAZ since I really like the newspaper itself.But onces I was accidentally not logged  in to Amazon but just checking the US store I found that US subscription is half the prize.Are you ****** kidding ?
