I used to love this newsletter.  I would wait every morning for it to arrive, and found lots of good books to download over the last several months.  Then, the same friend who told me about this blog told me about eReaderIQ, another daily newsletter of selected new free books for the Kindle.  I subscribed, and the next day my new eReaderIQ newsletter arrived at 5 am with about 12-15 great recommendations, and 2-3 hours later the "Free Kindle Books and Tips" newsletter arrived - 5 reviews, all of them the exact same books that had been covered in the other newsletter several hours earlier.  Wow, I thought, strange coincidence, since there were over 700 new free books that day.  The next day, the same thing - 4 reviews here, 3 of them exactly the same as the other newsletter which had arrived hours earlier.  The third day was this morning.  605 new free books today in the US store - 5 books covered in this newsletter, 4 of them repeats from eReaderIQ.Too much coincidence for me - if I'm going to pay for a subscription, I expect it to be a little more original than a re-hash from another newsletter - especially when that one is free.

Pretty good. Can be counted on to provide timely info on free books as well as news and tips related to the Kindle, ebooks, etc. However, the blog definitely has a bulletin board feel - which isn't necessarily bad or uncommon really. While he provides the ability for his readers to make comments, I have yet to see any interplay between blogger and reader. Kindle Nation Daily on the other hand seems to be more interactive.

I used to get this blog on my old Kindle and I am so disappointed to see that I cannot subscribe to this blog now that I own a Kindle Fire. Good grief, with all the Kindle Fires that have sold in the last month you would think that the author of this blog would realize that this is a LOT of $$$ that he is turning his back on.

I love this blog, the only thing I am unsure of is the fact that the links that he puts on the blog for me are not working. I have missed getting an updated blog since Jan 3rd. I keep my Wireless on just in case I am missing the right time. I have been able to find several of his suggestions to my liking and consequently I have over 40 books downloaded and ready to read.

There are many sources for finding what we fondly refer to as those "Kindle freebies" that appear daily, but Michael Gallagher's dailyFree Kindle Books Plus a Few Other Tipsblog has proven to be an invaluable resource to those who peruse the titles of the free book offerings.  And don't let anyone kid you, the freebies here will often surprise you with their quality of content.There appear to be over a million titles available at the Kindle Store, and that number continues go grow.  Within these are many thousands of free titles.  There are older out-of-copyright (pre-1923 books) classics of all types mingled in with titles as new as today.  If one has time or the inclination to wade through these, then there is enough there to keep one busy for many hours.  But for those of us who have other time priorities, Michael Gallagher has done the work of compiling many these, with frequent postings.  There are days where a few of these may appear, so it's wise to turn on your Kindle daily or at least a few times a week to take advantage of these freebies... and some of them are available at no cost for a very short time.One of his more recent postings offered the following: "There are approximately 500 new free non-public domain books in the Amazon Kindle store this morning for a total of 4,122 as I type this post."  There was  a discussion about this, and he went on to say, "As usual, I do not know how long these will be offered for free so if you are interested in any or all of them, please grab them now!"  Very sage advice, indeed.This Kindle blog is not just another online link to a list of titles, as are some.  Mr. Gallagher's postings also include frequent insider tips and helpful information that help to use your Kindle, and these are designed for novices to experienced users alike.  This one has been ranked as the top Kindle blog since 2010 for good reason.  It's highly-recommended, and comes with a risk-free 14-day free trial.  For this reader, it's a 5-star resource.1/8/2012
Source (K): Is this worth the price of the subscription? Absolutely!

Source (H): I subscribe to several blogs for my Kindle. I love this one. It gives me a heads up on great deals. I do have to go online to get them (the links don't work for my Kindle in the blog itself) but that's fine with me..I'm on my laptop enough anyway. It saves me hours searching for bargains and sometimes it gives me a heads up on a limited time deal.Well worth the cost of a subscription. Enjoy!
Source (K): Agree with the kudos - love this blog!

Source (H): What a shame; it's not available for the Kindle Fire. I would subscribe instantly if it were.Unfortunately, neither of the other two - Free Books OnKindle and Free Books For Kindle - are available on the Fire, either.

Haven't heard from Michael since 5/8/10, it is now 5/13/10...Miss you Michael, your page is usually awesome...Hope you are okay!!!Just heard from Michael.  re-booted Kindle 2 like Michael suggested...Yeah, back up and running...Thanks Michael!!
Source (K): Where in the world is Michael???

Source (H): I acquired my 1st Kindle less than 2 weeks ago on a Friday.  By the end of the weekend I had subscribed to this blog.  I have already gotten way more than the monthly price in free books just in the 1st week.  Also I appreciate the authors advice and tips as a new Kindle user.

When I got the Kindle I was a little worried about spending too much money with the instant downloads and all but this blog has saved me... I have loaded up the Kindle with free books I've found out about on this blog. Best money I spent (after buying the Kindle, that is!)
Source (K): Best 99 cents you can spend on the Kindle!

Source (H): I enjoyed my free trial for one day but than (much like monopoly) it slowed my kindle (3 gen.) down a lot until i deleted it. right away my kindle sped up but I don't have any downloaded speder-uppers so I don't know if that affects anything.  the blog itself was informing but it didnt help me at all (maybe becuse I have a cover for my kindle) although I think its cool that there are like 5 diffrent kinds of chargers but thats beside the point. I say if you have downloaded speeder-uppers than try it. if not than dont

the product is useful and worth the money if you are ok with the heavily christian message agenda that appears to underly it.  i have to sift through the recommendations to sort out the christian message-themed books.  either a very significant proportion of new publications are religious bias themed, or the editor his pushing his own agenda. i suspect the latter, but would be open to a rebuttal if i'm wrong. i have no data to support my assumption. i'd like to see a forthright editorial statement from the editor so everyone is clear up front as to what they are getting. the content is well produced, clearly and consistently offered, and there are enough "finds" to be well worth it.  given explicit editorial disclosure i would provide a better rating.thanks for the offering, michael.

Because of this blog I have not only found free books to read, but I have also gotten wonderful hints on the use of my Kindle. The author also explained why I was not getting downloads of my blogs daily. Because of this one hint I now know that if I restart my Kindle I will get anything that I subscribe to that has not given me a download lately. It is an easy process and was explained for free in this blog. Because of this I went ahead and got the kindle book written by Michael Gallagher that explains how to do some of these things that make the Kindle even better to own. When I turn my Kindle on in the morning, the first thing I read is this blog. It has been worth what little I pay for it.

So many great book recommendations & tips. Only been here a little over a week and I've already learned how to get ebooks from sites other than Amazon (mobi) to my Kindle. this was a real plus for me, as I'm seriously tech-challenged! Love his PERSONABLE (!) writing style. Well worth $.99/month! Thanks, Michael!
Source (K): Ditto to I LOVE THIS BLOG!

Source (H): Why would an author distribute his or her work free of charge? If one is to go by the offerings suggested by this blog, it is because their work is thinly veiled proselytizing. I have no problem with this kind of material, but it seems that it's a bit deceiving to refer your paying subscribers repeatedly to this kind of work and not say "this free book is a great work of Christian Fiction," or perhaps call the blog "Free Christian Books for Kindle."Perhaps Christian Fiction is all that is out there for free reading?  In any event, I felt like I was getting an Amway pitch when it arrived. Not recommended for readers who are decidedly satisfied with the state of their religious or spiritual lives.Two stars, because the recommendations were, in fact, free Kindle books.
Source (K): Free books, but almost all fall into the "Chrstian Fiction" genre

Source (H): I was very interested in subscribing to this blog after reading all the great reviews but found out the hard way that it's not available for Kindle Fire. Too bad, sounds like a great source of information.

This guy is pretty reliable - I'd say on average there are about 50-60 free book recommendations each month, with a large variety of topics such as sci fi, mystery, romance, even the strange and unusual.  I don't download all of them, as I don't think I have that much time to read.One thing that seems to differntiate this blog from the others on here touting free books is the blog author is not dependent upon Amazon-only titles.  Sure, he will tell you most of the free titles offered here on Amazon as that is easay for you and me to download, but he also tells you of other interesting independent author titles from non-Amazon sites with something unique: he includes instructions on how to get those non-Amazon titles to your Kindle.There's usually a tip or two each week: some I have seen before and some are brand new to me  such as I never thought to put my phone number as part of my Kindle ID in case I lost it during my latest trip to the airport.99 cents for this blog is money well spent!
Source (K): Lots and Lots of Free Book Recommendations

Source (H): I'm trying to delete this out of my Kindle since I gave it a shot and I do not want to keep it.  I will not leave my Kindle and does not go into my archives.  I hope this does not mean I will get charged for a subscription.  I realize it's a piddly 99 cents, but it's not going anywhere when I delete it!
Source (K): Good, but I don't want to keep subscription

Source (H): Theres some great tips and lots of free books, but the religious overtones just arent for me. Does anyone out there know how to permantly delete?
Source (K): A little too religious for my taste

Source (H): This is probably one of a VERY select few blogs that I will gladly pay for.  I've previewed about a dozen blogs, reading each for a week and a half before canceling to make so I give each a good chance.  Almost all of them have proved to be not worth even .99 a month.  This blog, however, is the first thing I read when I start up my Kindle.  In the two weeks since I subscribed, I've discovered about 30 free books (some were pre-orders) via this blog and I've also discovered how to get several hundred other books delivered wirelessly to my Kindle for free from a source outside of Amazon.com in genre's that I'm interested in.  (I didn't even realize this was possible until I read this blog.)  Not all of these books he posts are ones that I will read, but quiet a few of them are.  If you subscribe to one blog, make it this one!  Thank you so much, Michael!Edit: In subscribing to a few other blogs that include info on free books, I've noticed that they sometimes post the same books Michael lists, but their updates are usually one to two days behind his.I have strong suspicions that those blogs are finding their information from Michael's blog.  That should tell you something.  As some books are only free for less than a day, you would miss out on those free books if you were relying on another blog for your free book info.
Source (K): The only blog you need for Kindle books

Source (H): I have been getting this blog daily for a couple months now and look forward to reading it every day. Lots of different categories, although they seem to come in waves (probably how Amazon makes free books avaiable), so lots of free faith based books, then lots of free business, then romance.  The one tip that he gives you that you REALLY need to listen to - if you want a book that is free download it immediately!  Well worth the small monthly cost, actually...it's worth much more than that for all the money I save each month!I like that he includes the description from Amazon along with the number of reviews (and rating).  It seems like some authors (or Amazon) list some of the books for free to generate a lot of downloads and then start charging (I am guessing so that the book will appear at the top of the paid download lists??), I love catching a good read while it's free and he does a good job of pointing those out!I also enjoy the tips.

The sound quality is very decent.  My main issue with it is that I get an occassional buffer glitch with Pandora from my Kindle when it's connected to this speaker over bluetooth - however I can't know for sure if it's my internet, kindle or speaker without more testing.  So, I won't deduct points for that without further testing.  The sound quality is fairly clear and EQ balance is set nicely within its limitations so that you get a good clear range of sound and not a muddy or tinny mess like some of these smaller speakers.  I will say the kickstand is flimsy and doesn't stay open well when trying to set it up, but once it's set it is fine and certainly isn't going to fall over.  That's not really a big deal.  The speaker did move around on the table when I was pushing the volume limits to test the sound quality.  At normal listening levels it will not move around.  My expectations were fairly low after purchasing a similar type and size of speaker from SimplyVibe which completely died after 6 weeks.  When that one did work, it didn't sound as nice as this one.  I'm not jumping through the roof about this purchase, but it's proven to be a solid, nice sounding speaker so far.

I purchased this speaker from Amazon to supplement the sound of my Kindle Fire HD while listening to music or watching movies when not using headphones.I am surprised at the amount of bass and the overall sound quality of the speaker. There is so much bass that you can feel it through the unit, any more and it would "bounce" across the table.The Bluetooth connection was easy to pair and the sound quality via Bluetooth is very good, no noticeable difference when using the supplied cable and the earphone jack.Speaking of the cable; it has a micro USB connector on one end, a 3.5mm headphone male connector along with a standard USB connector on the other end. This allows you to charge it via your PC or play via a cabled connection with only one cable, I might add the cable appears to be of good quality.Advantage of the micro USB connection; I have charged the unit with both my Kindle charger as well as the charger for my Android phone.I have only used the speaker for a week now but I believe it to be a worthy purchase.

Received item just as Amazon said I would , it was well packed and works like charm!!!  I can hear my Kindle a good 30 feet away... Charged unit for 4 or 5 hours and it has been great to be able to hear my cloud from about anywhere in the house..I would recommend this unit to any one that needs a portable speaker system that Bluetooth  can feed plus it has an USB feed also and can be charged from your USB socket on your computer, Cable is encluded... Also I would like to say you can use your Cell Phone charger with the miniture USB pllug on it , I have a LG Cell and the charger works just fine ,and charges the unit faster than the computer USB dose...Flay

Paid $69 for it.  Bluetooth connects with my phone just fine, but I wish the volume controls were more incremental...there doesn't seem to be much range in the volume.  Since it's bluetooth, that may be my phone's fault.  It's sufficient, but not a Bose or other high end speaker.  It works well for my purpose at this price though.

I have paired with Kindle Fire, ipad, ipod, android tablet, etc. All suffer the same dropouts.I have several other bluetooth wireless audio devices that all wrk well, including other wireless speakers. So I know this is a problem with the speaker, not my multimedia device.The speaker is small, portable, and easy to carry. But the dropouts make it unpleasant to listen to.As a wireless device it has turned out to be really unusable, but using the aux input it provides pretty good sound.There isn;t a lot of bass, but for its size it des put out a good useable sound. The volume and loudness are enough to entertain a room about 12x12. Not like a bookshelf speakers or anything larger, but comparable to any other speaker this size with clean sound and little distortion.
Source (K): droupouts on every device I tried

Source (H): Love the fact that it is small and can be transported in any occasion without a lot of hassle.  The bluetooth/wireless is awesome!  Good sound quality if it's not super loud.

Paul Krugman is a horrifying, liberal, hope&change Keynesian, who contradicts his own textbook if it's politically convenient.  I would not waste my money on this crap.  Why is he even charging for this content if his conscience is so pricked by income inequality?  America needs to wake up to the fact that because of these liberals, we are ever inching toward socialism and communism that we defeated during the Cold War.
Source (K): He's a Nobel Prize winner, whatdaya expect?

Source (H): The main reason for just two stars is that you get a sporadic paragraph here and there, with little in the way of detailed analysis of current economic issues.  Krugman labels anyone who disagrees with him as a Crank or Loony, while doing very little to justify his primary premise that US Fiscal Policy has only to burst the dam of spending constraints in order to pull us out of this Depression.  For a guy peddling a worn out Keynesian ideology, he certainly is full of himself.  His ignorance of other points of view is quite staggering.
Source (K): Sparse Content, but Interesting at Times

Source (H): If you need to read what our slave-masters expect of you, then this is your man.

Krug must be saving his best for someplace else.  This is an insult to anyone who throws away their money on this mean spirited fellow who offers nothing new to his bumper sticker philosophy.  Unfortunate how Nobel's are awarded to those within the "Club" nowadays, instead of for truly deserving intellect.  Krug isn't worthy of pushing 'Hammer's chair, a real thinker.

Perhaps Krug is too busy revising one of his books and writing his column for the big bucks, because the content of his blog is often thinner than a dime that's been on the railroad tracks. Half the time all you get is a link to somebody else's blog or column, and all too often the link is to a web site that requires registration for access, or that the Kindle Web browser can't handle, or the blog has a chart or graph that is unreadable on the Kindle, making this is a poor choice for Kindle delivery. So wait until Krug's book comes out (maybe the content will improve), or go read the blog on the Web if you're really interested in what other blogs Krug has been reading on a given day.
Source (K): Thin content; poor choice for Kindle delivery

Source (H): Krugman is the first read on my Kindle each evening.  However, it's true that there are lots of refs to other blogs (which are slow on the kindle). More importantly, he references charts quite a lot, as one might expect, but the charts don't come through in the Kindle ed.

This former Enron executive and now liberal writer consistently changes his views to fit current political goals. He has touted ObamaCare as "a must have" for our nation stating health care will improve and "be as good as [England's] NHS". He also agrees with the Obama administration that the health care cost curve will bend down. This has already been proven to be wrong (the CBO increased their estimate to over $1 trillion in 10 year costs with independent estimates now up to $3 trillion).He might have been good at one time. Now his writings are nothing but liberal talking points.
Source (K): Don't waste your money or time.

Source (H): Mr. Krugman always provides excellent analysis of current events. It's easy to see why he was awarded a Nobel Prize. It's refreshing to read a thoughtful, well-argued and rational opinion that is evidence based and not shot through with ad hominem attacks.

A nice collection of Beatrix Potter Stories. No illustrations in the free Kindle version. Would have been nicer to see at least one illustration per story.This collection includes the following stories:The Tale of Peter RabbitThe Tale of Benjamin BunnyThe Tale of Mrs. Tiggy-WinkleThe Tale of Mr. Jeremy FisherThe Tale of Jemima Puddle-DiclThe Tale of the Flopsy BunniesThe Tale of Two Bad MiceThe Tale of Timmy TiptoesThe Tale of Mr. TodThe Tale of Pigling BlandThe Pie and the Patty PanThe Roly Poly PuddingThe Tale of Ginger and PicklesThe Story of Miss Moppet
Source (K): a good collection, not complete however and missing illustrations

Source (H): This is the only magazine I read.  I LOVE it.  My only issue is that I get this magazine for free with my membership with Life Extension, so I have an issue with paying $1.99 per month for it.  I've contacted LEF to see if they have it available as part of my membership.I have a Kindle but I have a Fire on order so this would be perfect to add.
Source (K): Its the only magazine I read.

Source (H): This is a great  and refreshing change. This magazine actually contains a lot of references  which helps to legitimacize the articles. It also contains lots of journal reviews and resources.

The idea of subscribing to Narrative appealed to me because I got sick and tired of seeing so many novel excerpts in New Yorker. Unfortunately, each of the first two Kindle-edition of Narrative likewise had, as flagship fiction content, novel excerpts.This bothers me . . . a lot.I looked on the Narrative web site. they have tons of bona fide short stories they can provide, both from established and emerging authors. Why on earth are they wasting space on content that cannot and was never intended to stand on its own?Actually, I think I can guess the answer. Let's call these novel excerpts what they really are: advertorials (magazine advertisements disguised to look like content). What else can they possibly be? I don't know if Narrative is getting paid by the authors to run these, but if they aren't, then that's their own foolishness because the authors certainly should pay if they are going to consume so much space to promote their novels. Whatever the case, that's between Narrative and the authors; it's none of my business.Interestingly, I find I can browse Narrative's web site and download a lot of interesting stories for free. If I want to read them on Kindle, that's easy enough; I can just send them over, and even use Amazon's PDF-Kindle conversion service. I can conveniently store them in a Kindle collection called Narrative. And considering what Amazon charges to do the conversion, I can read more stories for less money than the cost of a Narrative subscription.
Source (K): Dissatisfied with publication of novel excerpts (advertorials!)

Source (H): I am absolutely in love with this publication. The articles are so well written and informative. Inspiring, absolutely wonderful to have along on my new Kindle2. Its such a pleasure to delve into the thoughts of truly great writers, and to enjoy excellent and thought provoking prose. I am absolutely in love with this literary magazine - keep up the excellent work! Thank YOU!
Narrative Magazine is one of the five most important literary magazines being published, and perhaps the most exciting.

As a long time fan of Narrative.com, I am thrilled with my Kindle subscription to Narrative.  No more trying to read wonderful stories on my overheated, eye-straining laptop; no more printing them out and wasting a lot of paper.  Now I have the latest bounty from Narrative ready and waiting on my Kindle whenever I want it.  I love it!

I've been following this magazine since its inception. I was ambivalent at first: the submission fees they charge their writers were way above industry standards, and shortly thereafter all the literary magazines followed suit, so as if writers weren't exploited enough to always work for free, now they're expected to pay, and pay solidly, to have their hard work displayed on a website.But this is not the worst of it. I could live with it if the quality of the writing is good.  But here is the other thing: Narrative publishes on average only one or two new writers.  Most of their submissions are from already top-tiered well known writers, the SAME ONES appearing issue after issue.  Women writers are limited to the biggest names: Jayne Anne Phillips, etc.  These writers, I later found out, do not pay to have their work published.  They are solicited and paid big bucks from the funds collected of lesser known (but no less talented) writers.Finally, as if this weren't enough, today's issue publishes prominently what is advertised as a "GREAT NEW GRAPHIC SHORT STORY."The story: a girl is driving home, thinking about the great sex she had with her new guy.  Is she in love? She feels like a horse and her boyfriend is the rider.Action? A girl drives homePlot? NoneConflict? NoneWhat do we know about this character? nothing. She's a girl. She likes sex.Art? MediocreArtistic Context? Seems to try to emulate Japanese graphic art and its notoriously violent and sexist themesWhat is most disturbing: COVER PICTURE, A NAKED BLINDFOLDED WOMAN IN BONDAGE WITH HER NIPPLE BANDAGED AS THOUGH IT HAD BEEN CUT OFF.It's as if Narrative magazine editors have never heard of women's rights, taste, decency, respect for women, and good narrative.Not just sad anymore, utterly repulsive.  Shame on you Narrative.

When I used to go to Europe I would seek out a copy of the International Herald Tribune every morning, and usually read it from cover to cover. It simply was a superior newspaper, covering not only USA news but world news, business, sports, etc. Coming back home I would actually feel a sense of loss at having to read our local paper.So I was thrilled when the Kindle edition of the International Herald Tribune came out and I immediately subscribed. The IHT is as good as ever. Excellent, well written articles. In-depth analysis of world events. It's all there. My advice: try the trial subscription for two weeks; I bet you end up cancelling the Times, etc., and go with the International Herald Tribune.
Source (K): No Longer Have to Go to Europe to Read this Paper!

Source (H): This paper is really good but the subscription is limited to the kindle. You can't read it on the App (could be Apples small mindedness, not amazon's), there is no way to get a link to an article to send to a friend. You can clip things to Twitter but once there it won't let you copy text to search else where -only in books, so the only way to get a link to the article is to go into search engine and write the info. Some small articles you can't find at all. As it morphs into the NYT when you do a search.There is no index to articles so you have to blindly go through the paper one kindle page at a time though you can go from one article to another, but there is no big overview of titles of articles.This is a great subscription but it needs an overhaul to really make it worthwhile. It is wonderful to have a newspaper in the kindle but they need to do some organization to overcome the small screen. If they could do this i would give it 5 stars.I'm trying to find an article i saw on an upcoming transportation strike in France to send to a friend who is going there but i can't f ind it online & i have no way to send it from the kindle. Giving us a link to articles we can paste into kindle would help.. Or just automatically add a link to the article when we post an excerpt to Twitter.Also add an index to articles would help enormously. I have an iPad and still find a Kindle great to have. It still has a lot of potential but these small features will make or break it as other competitors arrive. We have to be able to access info on the computer to share, and not just by tweets. I use twitter as a place to paste notes to myself on what i am reading. If it would hold links for later use it would be a great tool and a nice diary for myself of what I have been reading.Also for some reason you can't save your place with a bookmark.Otherwise it reads well and has some images. Kindle is easy on the eyes, it is a nice place to have a newspaper, so please kindle do an update.
Source (K): No index to articles, no bookmarks

Source (H): This is a great newspaper, particularly on the Kindle. As others have stated, it has global reach. You won't find U.S. domestic issues here, but you will find a good deal of U.S. political/financial information.Nicely laid out. Improvements that could be made have more to do with the Kindle itself than anything about the paper. There are a few photos ... just enough to be interesting. They are of medium quality but do break up the text.Because it is so easy, I find myself reading on a much wider range of global topics. So I spend a lot of time with IHT, and sometimes struggle to keep up with the issues as they roll in.I think this is a very balanced paper ... neither extreme right nor extreme left. I have not read anything in over a month of subscribing that made me go "ah hah, someone has an axe to grind here" ... something the parent company (NYT) often triggers in me. They seem to have taken a hands off approach to IHT, perhaps increasing emphasis on US content, but not (so far as I can see) injecting a lot of bias.The one paper I would very much like to see on Amazon is the Financial Times. That plus IHT would give you pretty much everything you need to know about what is going on in the world. I also read Newsweek for a bigger picture overview - that fills in some of the domestic issue gaps. And I read extensively a number of well-known news websites and blogs, on my notebook.Very worthwhile reading for the cost. It will broaden your outlook if you read articles that formerly would have been of little interest to you. The articles are well-written and brief enough for the reader to inhale a lot of information in a short period of time.No crossword though :-(
Try Reuters international for $1.99 per month and leave the liberal opinion pages to the drama seekers.  You pay $9.99 for more left wing political opnion pages than news.
Source (K): Like parent company New York Times, the main emphasis is in liberal opinion instead of real news

Source (H): Why must journalism of today impose political ideals on the readers?  Can the news not be delivered without bias?  True journalism is dead.  Since IHT, a paper I really like, has decided to be so vocal in their support of Obama, I'll be cancelling my subscription.  A Catholic can't support a pro abortion candidate.  Neither can I support this paper which has decided to assist such a candidate in his cause.

I have just bought the international version of the Kindle and was looking for an international newspaper. I have to say that I liked the Herald Tribune. The articles were informative and interesting. However....the weekend edition (this was written on 1st Nov 2009) did not appear and instead I got an apology from Amazon first saying it was delayed, then that it was not coming at all due to problems with the publisher.For me, one thing that I want to be sure of when subscribing at a not insubstantial cost, is that the paper will actually appear, and having had this experience I cannot say that with the Tribune. Unfortunately I have now canceled my subscription so won't be taking up the paid option.

well, if you already subscribe to the NY Times on your Kindle, there are only a handful of additional articles here.If you DON'T already subscribe to the NY Times then I imagine this would be great.(No comment on whether it's good or bad, that this formerly independent newspaper was bought out by the NY Times and basically just turned into an overseas edition of the NYTimes...)
Source (K): good only if you don't already subscribe to NY Times

Source (H): If you truly want to know what is going on in the world this is the paper for you.The articles are a collection of the best of the best from multiple news sources. The articles are factual and intelligent. No spin and no soft pedalling of the many missteps by our country and others. Most important the articles are succinct and actually list the word count. Within 30-45 minutes you too can know what is truly happening in our world. After all isn`t that the purpose of a newspaper?

Since being offered on the Kindle, I've purchased one or two issues of the International Herald Tribune.  It's a good paper, with a broad international perspective.  Just be aware that it's mainly a compilation newspaper that pulls its stories and features from the world's prominent newspapers and news sources, including many you may already subscribe to on your Kindle.  But if you don't already get items like the New York Times Latest News blog and some of the dollar-a-month wire service news blogs (or won't mind the slight redundancy in articles if you do), go for it.  Like the handful of other Kindle newspapers I've experienced, the Kindle edition of the International Herald Tribune is laid out well, is easy to navigate, and features a generous allotment of photographs.  I'd be tempted to buy it more often, or maybe even subscribe, if the subscription and/or single-issue price was just a bit lower.  But, of course, that won't be an issue with everyone.Note: Amazon frequently updates the presentation and functionality of Kindle blogs and periodicals, so as this review gets older, it may no longer accurately describe the current version of this product.
Source (K): A more global perspective on the news

Source (H): *Updated* News sold as pure and high quality cannot regurgitate the same canards, half-truths and revised history you can find anywhere else.  If the story is based on information from a whistle-blower exposing a crime that's one thing, otherwise the world is full of people with the authority to articulate policy, if you want to assert an official opinion quote one of them.  If I want a writer's opinion or speculation I'll read a blog.  If you're going to constantly do political vanity pieces do them on politicians across the political spectrum not just the ones who think rich people and the fantasy "market" will save the world.  All I want from news is the facts.  Enough new ones so I understand what is happening now, enough old ones so if I didn't know the context before now I do.

The IHT was at one time many years ago a fine newspaper and one that was indispensable to the Anglophone in Europe. Under the control now of the NY Times, however, it reflects all the biases of that paper: it is in the tank for the Democratic party, and in fact reflects the naive views of the far left in that party. Anyone who characterizes the paper as "objective" has never been exposed to an unbiased, full presentation of, uh, facts. In Europe, tho, it is the best one can do other than British papers. The Kindle version downplays one of the best features of the IHT print edition, which are the obituaries. Obits, as many have noted, are the best written part of the paper, and of the NY Times.
Source (K): Simply pawn of the NY Times

Source (H): Great product from the New York Times Company, with more focus on the rest of the world than the NYT (AKA best US paper). Has material from the NYT (opinion, etc.) as well as reporting and world sports that you will not see in a typical US paper. The volume is not huge so you can read the whole thing in a couple of hours (I hate missing sections from my favorite paper because of time constraints). The only disadvantage is that they do not publish on Sunday and you end up buying a single issue of NYT or WP that day. That's why it's only four stars.
Source (K): Would have been perfect with a Sunday edition

Source (H): I gave this periodical a try, but I found that it was not for me, primarily because of the lack of material, not only for USA news, but world wide as well.  This is a very small paper with just a few headline topics from various countries around the world.  The paper did arrive early ... before 5:30 AM, which is nice.  The best thing would be to try it, then decide for yourself.

I decided to try this newspaper because of the 5-star rating, and I end up canceling Time, US news and world report, and stop buying Wall Street journal by the issue (not everyday).This electronic version is well laid out, has some pictures in it, and the articles are very easy to read. I have had this over 2 weeks and have not found anything being omitted yet, which happened in the other periodicals. For example, if a table or chart is indicated to show something and is omitted, part of the story is gone.This newspaper also gives a more worldly view, but has enough articles regarding the US to keep the US readers reading. I look forward to turning on my Kindle every morning and see it delivered in the air! In fact, I was waiting for it to come this past Sunday just to realize that there is no delivery on Sundays.I decided to add this after having the paper a bit longer... this is essentially the international version of the NY Times, published by the NY Times, I also have the NY Times Latest News (Blog) and some of the articles are almost identical. I found this is a 'more for your money' paper than the NY Times since is includes more international stories.I absolutely recommend this to anyone looking for a Kindle periodical.

I was happy to have the New York Times, but I couldn't keep up with the amount of information delivered daily. The International Herald Tribune captures the information I need. I haven't canceled my New York Times yet, but I getting ready to before the next billing cycle.

I absolutely love getting this paper on my kindle every morning (except Sundays of course, as there is no edition). Very in depth articles that leave you understanding the story, and not asking yourself more questions. I don't necessarily agree with all of the opinion articles (somewhat liberal), however, these are very thought out leaving the reader with an appreciation of the issue at hand.I definitely recommend this paper, as it brings things into a "worldly" perspective compared to other papers you can get on the kindle.

I took the IHT home delivery for 20 years. Then I opted for the Kindle version- same content, less money.When the NYT went to a pay-portal, they promised us full access to nyt.com:March of this year email response:"Subscribers to The International Herald Tribune on Kindle will receive full access to NYTimes.com. We are currently working through the technical requirements to verify Kindle subscriber accounts and offer access. More information will be available soon.We plan to enhance our e-reader subscription options in the near future. Please make sure your e-mail address is up-to-date so you can receive the latest site news and announcements from NYTimes.com."NEVER HAPPENED.Now, less than a year later, a 50% increase for Kindle subscribers. Amazing.What a depressing legacy for once great paper.

I have just downloaded my first Fountain magazine and so far I find it fascinating. The variety in subject matter keeps me interested and the lack of advertisement keeps me reading. The only downfall I see is that the sections list is not separated in any manner. I need to go through every article chronologically to navigate between subjects.All-in-all its quite the read.

I read 1 issue of this magazine on my Kindle.  It renders fine on the Kindle.However, the magazine itself is extremely low quality.  The description of the magazine says its topics are "scientific thinking and religious-spiritual life."  The religious-spiritual articles were so full of fluffy language I couldn't even guess what they were talking about.  The one scientific article was written at 5th grade level.Maybe I just got a bad issue, but if that issue was representative, this is a terrible magazine.

The Fountain is a magazine published bimonthly that has articles written about everything from scientific to literature to spiritual thought. After I suscribed to this magazine I was surprised when I first received it to find that it was a magazine that encourages its readers to submit articles and actually prints them.There are no advertisements in the magazine at all and it is just straight information. very refreshing after being used to getting mags for years that are page after page of ads sprinkled with articles.The Fountain is concerned with the global problems of the modern world and highlights social topics such as maintaining peace in the world, cultural diversity, enhancing the overall welfare of society, education, health care, preserving the ecological balance, divorce, the problems of young people, alcoholism and all kinds of addiction and preventing young people from turning to crime. It also promotes universal ethical values such as respect and care for parents, honoring the elderly, safeguarding the family as the heart of a sound society, love and compassion for all, neighborliness, hospitality, charity and the like.

The blogger is not putting much effort into this blog- during the trial I got only 1 or 2 articles per week. There are many websites that carry news of people doing stupid things from which the bloggger could get material for his blog, but he obviously isn't bothering to check them. Plus, there's no reason for him to be charging twice as much money as blogs that have much more information.
I've tried three times over the years to be able to get though one issue of this magazine without wanting to toss it in the wood stove. All I want is good book reviews not a liberal diatribe.

As noted by a previous reviewer, the cover and one page with three lines identifying a single letter to the editor is all I can see of this issue on my Kindle Fire. This would be my third issue. The first two were fantastic on the Kindle Fire. However, I also cannot find any way to go back and look at previous issues. Since many of the articles in NYRB are timeless, e-subscribers should be able to archive issues.
Source (K): Only One Page Visible in Jan 12, 2012 Issue

Source (H): I subscribed to this magazine Dec 9 2011. I immediately received a perfectly enjoyable issue. A couple weeks later, I saw that a new issue had shown up on my Kindle. However, it was a lie: the Dec 22 issue was nothing but the cover and a correction for an article published Dec. 9. I repeatedly tried to download the new issue and never succeeded. I waited a couple more weeks, hoping a new issue would one day arrive. It never did.I wrote the NY Review of Books to complain about the problem and they never wrote back or called back. So I am canceling my subscription and will request a refund. It's a shame because NYRB could be a good Kindle magazine. But not if it doesn't work.

This is my favorite periodical and I have to say it is easier to read on the Kindle than in print. It is with me at all times and is great to read when I have a few minutes free or am riding on the train. The Kindle format is very good for text-based periodicals. The only thing missing are the ads, which are sometimes interesting for book ideas, but that is a small deficiency. I love reading on my Kindle and I would keep it even if NYRB was the only thing available on it.UPDATE Nov. 20: I'm now using a Kindle Fire for this subscription and it provides a wonderful rendering of the print edition, including photographs but not including ads.Update Dec. 27: Now includes the full print edition (including ads). You can still read in text view or view the actual print edition. Excellent value. (BTW, Amazon mistakenly sent the January 12 issue early and incomplete and gave subscribers a free month for the inconvenience. The full issue came on the scheduled date. Can't beat Amazon for great customer service.)
Source (K): Might be better than in print.

Source (H): Some publications work better on the kindle than others - for example, I'd rather have the Atlantic Monthly in printed form, because they have a lot of nifty maps and charts that graphicaly can't be reproduced on the Kindle (no color, for starters)! But I just got the NYROB on the Kindle and I'm enjoying it now - like the New Yorker, it's text-heavy, so it loses (almost) nothing on the Kindle. Plus it's nice not having to throw away all that paper into the trash 26 times a year after reading it! The only question is - what took so long?
Source (K): Happy to get the NYROB on the KIndle

Source (H): Latest issue a disappointment as most of it is missing. I d/l it to three devices I have and it's the same on all three.

Finally, my absolute favorite magazine comes to the Kindle!If you are not familiar with it, the NYRB (not to be confused with the New York TIMES Book Review) allows its writers to use recently published books as a jumping off point to discuss and explain topics in current affairs, politics, science, the arts, technology, philosophy, popular culture and other areas. The viewpoint is often somewhat liberal, but everything is carefully argued and supported. No mindless doctrine or slogans here. The authors are some of the world's most respected scholars and writers. Recent contributors include Zaidie Smith, Freeman Dyson, Michael Rosen and Tony Judt. It produced the most carefully crafted, informed, and passionate argument against the 2003 invasion of Iraq I ever read. A truly marvelous magazine.

If you enjoyed "Twilight" and are looking for books that are a lot like it, this may be something that you will enjoy.  However, I did not enjoy this book.The plot was drawn out unnecessarily due to characters not sharing necessary information with the main character.  Her mother leaves her alone for weeks in situations that she has to know will be dangerous (she knows others are watching over her, but she still doesn't seem to care about what is going on in her daughter's mind).  She asks questions and characters who are supposed to be on her side respond with things like "If you don't know, I'm not going to tell you."  The main character doesn't ask questions about things that are clearly out of the ordinary.  At one point, she reveals that she doesn't go to the bathroom normally.  Not only does that not make sense (I mean, not that I want to know, but what is she talking about?), but why is she not concerned about it?  How is she going through life with superhuman strength, speed, and unspecified bathroom issues and not in the least bit worried or concerned about it?The story was full of the wish fulfillment that is too typical of the genre.  Zillael is much more beautiful than her classmates (something you hear about in great detail throughout the book), but she hates all of them.  Why?  Absolutely no reason.  But then she gets involved in a hot love triangle just out of the blue.  She hates the town she lives in, so she never makes an effort to do anything more than sit around, eat salad, and mope.  I got so sick of her within the first few chapters.The writing is in desperate need of some good editing.  Punctuation was slipshod.  "McDonald's," the most widespread and successful restaurant on earth, was misspelled ("Mac Donalds").  How does that even happen?The style was confusing.  The item description clearly states that this is adult, not YA.  Unfortunately, the only remotely adult content is the book is a brief and not terribly explicit scene towards the end of the book.  The tone and style of the book was clearly YA.  I can't imagine too many adults being interested in Zillael and her silly problems or being able to maintain interest in the unnecessarily drawn out and sketchy plot (just making up different names for vampires is not the same thing as coming up with a story).  Adding an adult scene to a YA book doesn't make it an adult book.  It just makes it a confused YA book.
Source (K): Cliched, sloppy, and kind of boring

Source (H): I got this for free for my Kindle. I read through it yesterday. It was a quick read, full of action, angst, lore and lust.The author has created a new vampire-esque mythos. The voice is young and fresh, but the story is not. Part Buffy, part Twilight, part Charmed. As a YA, it is more sexually explicit than I would recommend for my students or daughters, but it is too YA to bridge between YA and general market romance. My impression is that the author was not satisfied with the sexual content in Twilight, but liked the love triangle dynamic and decided to write it her way.The title might make sense for those familiar with the whole series plot line, but I found it misleading - though I may have skimmed the part where that was explained. I will not be reading the rest of the series.Generally I am not moved to leave a review if my impression was dominantly negative, but I downloaded this based on it's high reviews and thought I owed it to other readers to be honest.
Source (K): Cliche, but a fun, fast read

Source (H): This is written in a fresh bouncy YA way and I enjoyed it. Zillael (prob. spelt that wrong)is the type of older teen that always seems to be in detention, due to her attitude. She hates the small town she lives in, the people around her, the fact her mom is never around and of course the way everyone stares at her because she is a beauty. During a detention stint in which she has to serve punch to fellow classmates, she is attacked by vampire like beings and that is when she finds out that not only are some people around her not entirely human, but neither is she. The only thing that bothered me about the storyline is that it took me a while to figure out her age, because in the beginning she appears to be much younger (based on reactions in class and classmates) and it wasn't until the author mentioned a car she drove on occasion, that I realised she must be over 16. The scenes with the young male vamp in her bedroom are a bit racy (only a tidge, so I would recommend that the reader be over a certain age). THe book ends in a way that interestingly enough you have to read the first book to understand where and who Zill actually is. I recommend that readers of supernatural/para fantasy give this author a go.
Source (K): Supernatural Fantasy with teenage attitude to boot

Source (H): I would be subscribed to this right now if not for the fact it would cost me more than having it delivered to my door in a print magazine format. I thought part of the appeal of the Kindle was to have books and magazines that cost less than the printed versions. How could it possibly cost more in this format? Oh well, they tried to be greedy but they won't get my money.
Source (K): Why is digital format more expensive than print?

Source (H): I don't understand why Dell is charging as much or more for the Kindle magazine as the price of a printed and mailed version. Kindle books are cheaper than the printed versions, this magazine should be priced like Reader's Digest. I would be interested in subscribing if it was.

I have enjoyed Hitchcock and Ellery Queen for many years. The Kindle editions are crude renditions of these high quality publications. The transcriptions are filled with errors, especially replicated lines of text or odd insertions of text as a result of typesetting or scanning artifacts. The magazines include some illustrations, and since the originals are newsprint the monochrome pictures should be beautifully rendered on Kindle. Instead, they are often poorly scaled and blurry or blotchy. Sometimes, a JPEG filename appears instead of the picture.A little proofreading would go a long way. I have canceled my subscriptions.

I was given some old copies of this magazine and really enjoyed reading it.  I have been considering buying a Kindle and wanted to see what was offered, besides the books.  I checked out the subscription price of the print version and was surprised to find that the electronic was more expensive by $.50 an issue.  Shouldn't electronic delivery be cheaper than print?
Source (K): Why is electronic more expensive than print?

Source (H): I had never read this magazine before subscribing to it on my Kindle; I am a big fan now! The diversity and quality of the writing  has never disappointed, and I thoroughly enjoy the different mystery genres featured. Good writing should always be rewarded and I think the electronic subscription price is very fair; the magazine is definitely worth it. I expect to be a subscriber for a long time.
Source (K): This is a superbly put together fiction magazine!

Source (H): At least part of the cost of a magazine subscription is determined by the cost of the materials used in its publication. The cost of paper will do more to influence the price of a newspaper or magazine than anything else. The printing press, the ink, warehouse storage, and finally the cost of actually mailing it out.So why is a digital version, which eliminates all of the materials cost, and most of the delivery cost (pennies for bandwidth) priced the same as or more than the print version?Consumers aren't stupid, and I have no intention of paying for this product until the publishers pass off some of the savings on to the consumers, giving us a financial incentive to go green, instead of trying to take advantage of our desire for convenience.
Source (K): Pass the Savings on to the Consumer!

Source (H): I've been a reader of AHMM (& it's sister, EQMM) for well over a decade (probably two).  I'm thrilled it's available in this format.  Just purchased my first copies for the Kindle this AM, have not yet read them.  My only disappointment is that the AHMM does not seem to have the "Mysterious Photograph" feature & story.....hands down one of my favorite things about the magazine.  They do have pictures, so I'm not sure why this has been left out.Otherwise, very excited I will not have to worry about what to do with all of those magazines I've seemed to have accumulated over the years!UPDATE:  Upped my vote to 5 stars, and YES, they are now including the Mysterious Photograph.....

This is a great magazine, I've read it for years! that's why I was able to immediately recognize the incredible ripoff being perpetrated here by Dell Magazines. A 12 month sub to the paper version of the magazine which gets mailed to your door costs only $29.97, that's right a mere $2.4975 per issue! These creeps are trying to fleece us @ 50 cents per digital paperless issue.I'd be subscribed to both this and EQMM if the prices weren't INSANEI am very disappointing by this lunacy.See for yourself:Alfred Hitchcock Mystery Magazine
Source (K): RIP-OFF! paper issues cost 50 cents less per month

Source (H): Alfred Hitchcock's Mystery Magazine is, without a doubt, one of the best venues of fiction there is.  Great writing by terrific authors.  And I really cannot believe that anyone would complain about the cost.  This is a literary bargain!

As a potential Kindle DX customer, set on purchasing a reader shortly, I stumbled across AHMM while looking to see which magazines would be available to us poor Europeans. In a world of global communications, the Global Whispernet and 60-second delivery of books, I have to admit that not only am I perplexed by the erratic pricing policies for customers outside of the US, but also feel that I have suddenly become the victim of discrimination. While Dell's very clearly worded explanation of their pricing seems to have cleared up any problems on US pricing, I was dumbfounded to see that as a European customer, the $2.99/month subscription rate suddenly jumps to $5.99 (including International delivery rates). Eeeerrr.... Am I right in understanding that it costs $3 for me to download a magazine that only costs $2.99? Is that what you're saying? Absolutely ludicrous!! I'd love to sign up for this magazine, but feel that to do so would be signing a piece of paper saying that I don't mind being taken for a fool. I've tried to find some kind of explanation for this pricing system in the Help section, but to no avail. I really would appreciate some kind of explanation as to these charges.
I have loved AHMM for over 2 decades.  I will continue to subscribe via Kindle, but fail to understand why it costs more this way.  However, it will continue to be worth reading.

This has been my favorite Kindle blog until the last week or two.  It went from a solid blog to a waste of $[...]month.  I was getting 20-30 headlines (about 4-6 Kindle "pages" worth).  The past week or two I've been getting about 5 or 6 headlines- less than one Kindle page worth.  This morning, ONE headline.  Are you kidding me? Not even worth turning on the wireless to check it if that's how it's going to be.  I'll give them until the date my monthly subscription expires (which happens to be next week) to go back to their old format before I pull the plug & start looking elsewhere.I loved that it updated throughout the day with the latest news & events from around the country (unlike the Kindle newspapers which were delivered in the morning & that was it).  It was the perfect fit for a news junkie like me.  But with the lack of information in the last week, I find myself going to [...] on my phone, or [...]  or any other news site just to get the headlines since the AP isn't handling it anymore.If they fix it, I'll update my review, but right now- DISAPPOINTED!Update: 12/20- There was ONE headline again this morning. By dinner time there were FIVE. I am fairly confident there were more than 6 stories around the US today. They have one week to straighten this out before I punch out & find a new news blog.Update: 12/31- Well, I've given up.  My subscription runs out today & I'm done.  The average headline count has been between 5-10 & most of the time those were simply repeat headlines from day to day instead of new stories.  What was once my favorite blog has become useless & utterly NON-newsworthy.  Sorry but I can't recommend this to anyone.  Maybe in a few months I'll try again, but for now- good-bye AP, it's been great for 2 years, but the last month you went WAY downhill.  Consider yourself warned.

I was skeptical of this "blog" but found it to be the best news subscription for the Kindle.  The other newspapers like the New York Times and USA Today are way overpriced for what you get.  This AP news blog is only $1.99 a month and you get multiple updates every day.  The articles are very well written and informative.  Just long enough to really get the feel for the topic without being long winded.  If you pair this with the New York Times daily update blog you will get the best news options for your Kindle and the combined cost would only be $3.98 a month compared to $10 to $15 a month for one of the newspaper subscriptions that doesn't update multiple times daily.  The true test for me is if I feel the item is worth the price.  The AP daily update blog is money well spent.
Source (K): Better than the Kindle newspaper options, concise and informative.

Source (H): One of the most useful things I've discovered so far with my Kindle is the AP News updates.  The news is constantly updated and moved to the top of the list and listed as "new" every time a new story is added.  The "skip story" feature is very handy for the junk news stuff.It's pretty straight forward, if you want the major news headlines at your fingertips via your Kindle, then AP is the way to go.
Source (K): A great way to keep up with the news

Source (H): I have been pleasantly surprised by the layout and content of the Kindle version of this paper. I travel so it is very nice to have the paper delivered electronically wherever I am. I will continue to subscribe. There are two key missing features, both in the Sports section. First, it would be nice to have the home teams' upcoming game dates/times as is present in the print version. And second, it would be nice to have the league records/standings for each sport as is available in the print version.

1 December 2009I have been waiting for a kindle version of the Post Dispatch for over a year.  So when I updated my kindle last week, I discovered that there is now a kindle version of my hometown paper.  So I subscribed immediately.I was quickly disappointed.The point of an electronic version of a newspaper is to replace the "meat" of the paper version.  Due to limitations of the technology, there are currently limits to what can be placed in the electronic version but at a minimum, all of the non-graphical content should be included and if possible the photos associated with an article, like the front page, editorial, regional news, etc.  The current version of the kindle version has a selection of the frontpage, everyday, and Sports sections.  I am still finding it necessary to go to [...] in order to get St. Louis news.A good example of kindle versions of a paper is the San Jose Mercury News, and the The Oklahoman.  Both of these papers include all of their print content, including regional news, but also includes some articles only found on their web pages.  They also have their papers priced at a lower price.I really want the Post Dispatch on my Kindle, but this is not worth $6.99 a month.  Unlike most internet users, kindle users typically do not mind paying for their news, but you have to provide value for the content.  If a user still has to go to the web page to catch what they miss in the Kindle version, then at some point they are going to question why they are paying a premium for something they get for free online.-dhickman
Source (K): You can do better than this.

Source (H): I enjoy books of poetry and quotations. Although I find quite a few of these quotations to be on the short side (4 of 5 stars), over all it is well worth the download. I have enjoyed paging through it.A note on the "Bible" comment: the first 9% of the book includes the title page, the long author list and quotes form both the old and new testaments of the Bible. There are more Shakespeare quotes (which follow the Bible) than those of the biblical variety. This is a nice selection.
Source (K): Indeed a book of familiar quotations

Source (H): Wasn't expecting a bible book. It would have been helpful to mention it on the book cover or item description.

This is a wonderful collection of quotes from 166 different sources.  If you begin with [Go to..]Cover, or page backwards from the preface you will find two working alphabetical indices.  One index finds quotes by the author (Wordsworth, Shakespeare, Lord Byron, etc., etc.--166 of them).  You can click on the name of the author and see all the quotes by him.  The other alphabetical index is by the quote.  It gives you the number of the quote where you can click to read the whole quote.  All very entertaining and easy to navigate.

The book title and the posting do not describe this as a book of bible references. If that's what you are looking for this is one is for you & give it 5 stars....alternately if you're not into bible quotes this is one star.

I feel really bad for the people that do not know that the truth is the truth. It does not change for anyone wheather they like the bible or not. You could live your life in total rebellion against the bible. See how that turns out!

Apparently a few reviewers only read the first few pages of a book before writing a review. The Biblical quotes in this book make up about 7% of the total content which, if anything, is a bit low on biblical quotes considering how commonly Biblical references are used in modern society. Overall this book has a nice set of classic quotes that are focused on older popular literature such as Shakespeare. Certainly worth the price...and correctly named!

*Reviewed on Mundie Moms on 1/23/2013*I have been waiting for this e-novella since oh, I don't know it seems like months and months.  Why? Okay, I adore Ally's writing, her characters and both the Heist Society and the Gallagher Girl series have me on the very edge of my seat waiting for the next (and final) installments. So this morning when I poured my cup of coffee and checked my kindle for the download, I may have breathed a sigh of relief that it was yes indeed, there.Macey McHenry, the senator's daughter, cosmetic heiress and Gallagher Girl waited for me to read her words as she described her first impression of the always dreamy W. W. Hale, V. And Macey must never be kept waiting. It was so logical for them to meet up because, after all, they do run in the same social circles. The tension, flirtation and most of all their cooperation in working together made for some tense page turning moments.The story is short but satisfying and yes, it does feature two of my other favorite people from both of the series. I won't spoil it for you; you have to read it yourself. And hey, it's FREE. Many thanks to Disney-Hyperion for giving us this satisfying treat while we wait for Perfect Scoundrels release on February 5th.Oh and if you download Double Crossed now, you will also get the first chapter of Heist Society and the first two chapters of Gallagher Girls #1 (I'd Tell You That I Love You, But Then I'd Have to Kill You). If you haven't read these series, yet, what better way to get introduced to them than through this free e-novella? In the mean time, I may be re-reading Double Crossed again in the school pick-up lane. If you see me, shhhhhh, do not disturb the reading mom.
Source (K): A Perfect Tense Page Turning Moment

Source (H): I have been reading Ally Carters novels since the Gallagher Series came out in 2006. I always buy her books and read them the day they come out, so I am a BIG fan. I was so excited that she mixed her worlds in this novella. I thought it was really well done and was not disappointed. I think she should (at least) have run-ins between the characters in both the Heist Society books and the Gallagher Girls series because it always makes the books more fun when an author included character from different series, even for just a `cameo' appearance. Ally Carter was kind enough to make this free so you should definitely buy it. If you have never read any of her books, this is a good starting point. It gives enough about each series that you get a taste of what the books are like. This novella also included excerpts from both the Gallagher Series and Heist Society so you can read samples so you can get a closer look into each series. This was a really good novella and I had a great time reading it this morning. Thank you Ally Carter!
Source (K): Fans of both series will not be disappointed! I have been reading Ally Carters novels since the Gallagher Series came out in 200

Source (H): Wow! Are you trying to see through the virtual "Clouds"? O'Reilly's RADAR may be for you. This blog is not for the faint of heart nor faint of technical knowledge. I must admit that I blundered onto this site, confusing the name with the top-rated cable news broadcaster. Imagine my surprise. Instead of entering the "No Spin Zone" of Bill O'Reilly, I got so spun around in this techie world that I felt like Judy Garland when she said, "Toto, we're not in Kansas anymore."Having stumbled into another intellectual dimension, I found RADAR intriguing. It is impressive to eavesdrop on the makers of software as they cryptically exchange qwerty communications. I'm opting out of this ongoing conversation. It's way over my head. But for those of you up there in the Cyber Clouds, you may well enjoy the upwelling of this informational cumulus.
Source (K): Deep in the Heart of TECHses

Source (H): I have to agree, the pics do not do this cover justice!  I wanted something classy and I was blown away with this cover.  I got the black/brown version and love it.  It's thin but feels slightly padded by the woven leather.  I think this will help protect the screen.  The smell of the leather is divine.  Love the hinge attachment and the clever loop at the bottom to keep the kindle attached to the back cover.  I would definitely buy this cover again if I needed another.  No regrets!

Like the other reviewer says, the pictures do not do this cover justice.  I am so pleased and surprised at how much I like this cover.  This is not a bunch of leather strings woven together and stitched into shape.  The black portion of the cover is one piece of leather!  It is then die cut and the contrasting brown pieces are woven through the cuts!  This takes time and makes the finish quality superb.It is lighter than I thought it would be and I get many compliments on the design.  The cover folds back for easy reading and returns back to a protective cover with ease.  It uses the Kindle 2 mounting system which is simple, clean and effective.  I love the simple design with no snaps, flaps, zippers or tabs in the way when you are trying to hold it to read.  I'm very pleased.
Source (K): What an exquisite design, materials and quality.

Source (H): Great value for the price. A perfect fit for my Kindle! It's a great supple leather and protects my Kindle well. The picture doesn't do any justice. I was pleasantly surprised to see how nice it looked and the contrast of black and brown. The weave style also makes it more forgiving especially with wear and tear. I just got back from travelling and I really USED this. And it still looks great!
Source (K): Great value! Perfect Fit! Looks great!

Source (H): Have subscribed to this magazine for about 2 months now on my Kindle fire. Photos are crystal clear. Once you know how to use your kindle for reading magazines it is simple. Most people can't just read the little print on the screen so you have two options. You can use your fingers to zoom in on the writing and read it that way, or you can double tap the screen and choose text mode and then you can read everything VERY clearly without zooming in and out on each page and see each photo as well. I love that I am not waisting all this paper, saving money on magazines and have them all on my Kindle Fire.

I'm viewing the magazine on an iPad 3 using the Kindle app. Images and text looks great. Can zoom too. I only have one issue that I downloaded so far and reading the reviews for Star and US, I'm hoping my issues come on time. The only thing I was hoping for, is that have the websites in the magazine can be actual links that I can go directly to the ads website. Do that and it will be a 5 star review!

I write blog reviews forThe Kindle Blog Report.By its very name you can tell this blog isn't suitable for Kindle - there's no way to listen to the podcasts, except to go to the website. And if you're going to the website, you may as well read the other articles - published infrequently as the are, there.
Source (K): Great blog, not suitable for Kindle

Source (H): This was my first time reading this play and i found it very entertaining. Several passages were so well written as stir my heart, and I recognized many often quoted lines throughout the text. I would give five stars for the play itself and would recommend it to anyone.My problem lies with the kindle edition. there is no table of contents. There are no page numbers. There are several short sections of text where the letter b is replaced with the letter p. This is slightly distracting.
Source (K): great play, the kindle edition is slightly lacking

Source (H): Even for a dollar I felt ripped off.  The writing Is completely inept, artwork was all stolen From the web. Total garbage.  Wish I could give this less than one star.

Just google free owl clipart, and you will see one of the reasons I gave this one star. I do not agree with someone taking free images off the internet and making their entire book from them. Cover images for a novle, that is fine, but the entire substance of a kids picture book? Another review mentioned that the dialogue seemed rude, I also agree with that statement. I just don't think it is fair to make authors with creative and original ideas compete with this sort of thing.
great way to get yourself an app every day for months and its only one dollar every month awesome thing to try or subscribe
A dollar a month is not "free". This is the most blatant case of false advertising since 'The Never Ending Story'.
Why isn't this available for Kindle FIre??? I just spent two hundred bucks and I can't even use this app??

Check to see if your device is supported.  Kindle Fire was not on the list of supported devices at the time of this review.And you will see the free app of the day on your Kindle upon start up, so don't bother paying for this app for your Kindle.
