Source (K): Ever feel you are paying for something that should be free?

Source (H): There are a lot of good tips in this blog - how to do something, free book alerts, etc.  The author puts in a lot of time with this blog and there are usually 2-3 posts per weekday, although the weekend seems a little thin.  The how to's, etc. are invaluable to me and I hoep he keeps pumping them out.However, I get turned off at times with this blog with the endless self-promotion of his own book titles and what comes across as arrogance on prognostications and how evil the book publishers are: many times, I have read the same thing on someone else's blog which makes me wonder if I am getting a regurgitation / paraphrase with a self-congratulatory pat on the back.  If he toned this part down, he would probably have 2x however many subscribers there are now.Overall, this is certainly worth a buck per month!
Source (K): A Lot of Pomp and Self-Promotion

Source (H): I subscribed to the Kindle Nation Daily for over a week, taking advantage of the two week free trial.  I'm not going to continue my subscription to the blog.Kindle Nation Daily focuses almost completely on the Kindle, and not on eReaders in general.  It announces free books for the Kindle, and provides a good set of hints for using your Kindle well.  So, why won't I renew my subscription?First, the author of the blog has also created a good user guide for the Kindle.  If you want good hints for using the Kindle, why not just buy his book?  Most of his hints I already knew; I suspect the rest are already in his book.Second, I already have over 300 books to read on the Kindle (most of which were free), and won't have them all read in the near future.  Most of the free books listed for the Kindle are not books I would normally read; none were during the week or so that I read the Kindle Nation Daily.  I get my free Science Fiction from Project Gutenberg and the Baen Free Library (as well as the Baen CDs that I burn).  It'll be a long time before I catch up on my library of available books.I'm also more interested in the interactions between the Kindle and the rest of the industry, both narrowly defined as the eReader industry, and more broadly defined as the publishing industry.  There are other blogs out there with a broader focus.  I'm sure I'll end up subscribing to one of them.  But this blog's focus is just too narrow for me.Another blog you may wish to look at isI Love My Kindle.  It also covers the Kindle, but also goes beyond looking just at the Kindle to look at ePublishing, too.  However, it doesn't give in-depth Kindle hints or freebies that you'll find in Kindle Nation Daily.

Entertaining writing style, consistently updated blog.  Will save you money by letting you know when there are new free books available. Actually cancelled my subscription & renewed it the next day. missed the updates.
The bible for Kindle owners: great tips, great deals, and everything we need to know about the changing ebook world.

I've had my Kindle 1 since October of 2008, shortly after it appeared on Oprah, touting it as her favorite new device. I discovered Kindle Nation Daily in October of this year, and now it is the first thing I read each day because it is so full of helpful information... things I would never have discovered on my own. He has so many links of helpful information on his site that I still haven't examined most of therm. After Amazon introduced the free Kindle for PC program, Stephen found a couple of essential free programs to go with it, that most of us would never know about, such as Calibre and InkMesh.I think it is almost a freebie to get all this useful information in one place for just 99 cents per month...and there is new stuff every day, that's why it's the first thing I read each day. One unexpected bonus: Last October, Stephen told us that the Kindle was soon going to go international, after spending a couple of years as a US only product. I knew how much I loved my Kindle, I though to myself that there would soon be a world-wide market of millions of potential Kindle lovers just like me, so I immediately went online and bought $10,000 worth of Amazon [AMZN] from my IRA money market retirement account at $92 per share. The next day it opened at $125 per share and is $135 per share as I write this. There's a reason for this: Amazon is one of the best companies in the world, they have great, reasonably priced products...and great customer service if you have a problem.Thanks Steve, for another great Amazon product - your blog - The Kindle Nation Daily![Disclaimer: I don't know Stephen Windwalker - except from reading his blog - and I have never met him.]
Source (K): Kindle Nation Daily - a must read for all Kindle owners...

Source (H): Hacking one's way through pages upon pages of sponsor-bloat was becoming more and more of a chore, so I suppose it should come as a relief that the blog now contains only the beginning of each article.  After a few paragraphs, the text ends with a neat [...]; there isn't even a link to the online edition.  Disappointing and possibly not worth even .99 a month.

Stephen Windwalker provides his Kindle Nation either via PC or Kindle and the PC version is free.  I subscribed to the on line version because I use the links a lot and would rather link from the PC than from the Kindle.  His information is good for newbies as well as more seasoned users.  It is also not restricted to just the Kindle.  The blog is well laid out, well designed, and I rate it as 5 stars.  His is not the only blog out there in Kindle Land, but I look forward to reading his the most of the ones I do get.

The author was annoying. True, it's only $.99 but having to page through 5-6 pages of their sponsors to read three lines the author has to say isn't worth it. There are other blogs with no ads that point out free books and on sites OTHER than just Amazon!Just no "meat" and all fluff. Canceled.
Source (K): Disappointing. Lack of any substance. No meat.

Source (H): This is one man's evaluation ... perhaps yours will differ:  I found the layout unattractive and the content unappealing.  The author's preoccupation with "sponsors" signals less importance is placed on meeting the expectations/needs of the reader.It's sad but even a $1 a month seemed too expensive for the value of the content -- I deactivated the subscription after just a couple of days.

I don't write reviews all that often considering everything I buy on Amazon.com but I wanted to warn those who are not of a liberal mindset and who don't care for endless listings of Erotica Kindle selections.I found the blog to be a good resource until I had to plow through the seemingly endless pages of Erotica book selections. I thought perhaps it was simply a one time blog that had this pattern, but after three days, I realized, that was not the case. One book for "Religious" reading was suggested and pages or Erotica for three days. I'm just thankful that the trial period was free.The final straw that broke the proverbial camel's back was when Steve - apparently the blog owner, recommended an "historical" book that was so left-wing, so completely biased with regard to the war in Iraq and the history of Iraq, the very first line of the book said it all. I can't quote it here but it went something like the "occupation" by the U.S. of Iraq and all the destruction the U.S. has caused in that country...well, I didn't need to read on to get the gist of the book's theme. If I wanted revisionist history, I could read other far more intellectual blogs with left leaning views.While Steve attempted to make it sound as if he wasn't promoting the book personally, he was by saying the author "nailed" the history of Iraq and it was a book everyone of any political persuasion should read. I had had enough at that point.If I wanted to raise my blood pressure I could find many far more interesting ways of doing so.  Reading erotica along with biased political rants aren't among the list of things I'd prefer doing to achieve this goal. Subscriber, beware.
Source (K): If you are Interested in Erotica and Left Wing books this one's for you

Source (H): I live in Europe and have to say that reading international newspaper is something everyone tells you to do, but as a teenager like myself I never was motivated to try it out. Got my Kindle as a birthday present and scammed through all the newspapers available. At first I tried "The Times", which is the most popular and best newspaper I thought. But after seeing the high monthly subscription price I rejected the thought of subscribing "The Times" in order to improve my english skills. Later I took a glimpse at the "Asian Newspaper" section. "Very interesting", I thought, "to get information directly from countries' local newspapers you nearly have no contact with." And there I found "China Daily US Edition", which was perfect for me: news from China, the largest country in the world, in english and with an affordable price! I took the 14 days trial and was surprised that even with a low price of 4.99$ the articles had a quality compareable to "The Times" and "The Independent". Now I read the China Daily on a daily basis, getting inside-news from China and improving my english skills bit by bit. Try it out yourself! 14 days are for free.PRO:- cheap price- high quality articles- interesting view from a distant country's newspaper- articles about china, which are not in the global newsCONTRA:- censored(this can also be interesting as you can compare global news from China Daily to non-censored newspapers to get an idea of what the chinese government want their population to not be informed about)

Reading China Daily is a very different experience from that of reading other English-language newspapers' reports on China.The issue of political bias always arises with the media. China Daily takes a different stand on many issues (than that of other western medias), but it is at the same time scrupulously fair and balanced. It's intriguing to read another side of a story without knowing the native language.I strongly recommend it.
Source (K): A very different daily newspaper on China

Source (H): I'm pleased with this kindle version. I used to read this newspaper in China, but I can not buy it in US. The kindle version is text rich and give all materials I want. Five bulks per month is reasonable, which is equal to the price they sell in China.

I subscribed to Shanghai Daily and China Daily at the same time. After several days of reading both of them, definitely I prefer China Daily. The quality of articles is much better than that in Shanghai Daily although in which there are more global news. The second good thing of China Daily is that it's much cheaper than Shanghai Daily. I really don't understand why Shanghai Daily sells better than China Daily because, to me, China Daily is obviously a better choice. If you want to get news about China, then try China Daily, you'll love it!
Source (K): perfect newspaper to get news from China

Source (H): Jestem wiernym czytelnikiem Polityki i chociaz w "kindlowym" wydaniu ilustracji jest niewiele i sa czarno biale, to przeciez nie dla obrazków czytam ten tygodnik. A czyta sie wysmienicie. Brawo dla Polityki, ze weszla na terra incognita i jako pierwsza dala nam polska prase na nasze "kundelki"!

Pierwszy polski magazyn przeznaczony na Amazon Kindle. wysokiej jakosci artykuly (i co wazne, nie tylko o polityce), humorystyczne obrazki oraz felietony. To wszystko dostepne na czytnik Kindle, ktorych coraz wiecej w Polsce.Cena miesiecznej subskrypcji jest bardzo atrakcyjna. 12 zl. to polowa tego co zaplacimy za wydania papierowe. Oby wiecej polskich wydawnictw wzielo przyklad z Polityki. Brawo!

O poziomie "Polityki" pisac nie trzeba, mysle, ze kazdy, kto siega -- czy to w postaci pliku na Kindla, czy kupujac papierowy magazyn -- wie czego mozna po tygodniku oczekiwac, wiec albo mu sie podoba i nie ma problemu, albo... sie nie podoba i takze nie ma problemu ;-)To co warto odnotowac na duzy plus dla wydawcy, to ODWAGA -- mysle, ze decyzja o wejsciu w e-rynek nie bylo latwa, zwazywszy na ilosc czytnikow w Polsce (z drugiej strony podziwiam wydawcow, ktorzy decyduja sie na przygotowanie aplikacji na iPada).Mimo tego cena miesiecznej prenumeraty (4 dolary) to jakby na to nie patrzec polowa tego, co musialbym przez taki miesiac zostawic w kiosku. A wiec znow plus ;-)Dalbym 5 gwiazdek, gdyby az tak bardzo nie skapiono nam grafik. Rysunki Mleczki, Sawki, etc. sa po prostu nieczytelne -- aczkolwiek nie za sprawa braku koloru (ktory do odbioru nie jest niezbedny!), lecz jak sadze dlatego, ze wydawca traktuje te sekcje nieco po macoszemu.To samo tyczy sie innych elementow kazdego wydania, ktorych po prostu brakuje (tabele, infografiki).Licze na to, ze w przetarte przez "Polityke" szlaki rusza inni wydawcy.PS prawie pol roku po napisaniu recenzji dokladam piata gwiazdke. Za to, ze w wydaniu na kindelka (i na iPada, podobno) pojawil sie bonusowy tekst, ktorego nie znajdziecie w wydaniu papierowym. Grafik nadal brakuje -- boli zwlaszcza wowczas, kiedy w tekscie sa odniesienia do tabel czy wykresow (co nie nastepuje jakos strasznie czesto) -- ale dodatkowy material chyba jakos tam rekompensuje ten deficyt.
Source (K): 4 gwiazdki za odwage, dam piata za popracowanie nad niedociagnieciami (zmiana: piata gwiazdka za zmiany w kindelkowej Polityce)

Source (H): Nie ma sie czym tak podniecac. Rzucili Polakom jeden tytul i juz leca 5 gwiazdek. Nie chce dawac ocen na zachete. Co do Polityki to bardzo sredni tygodnik nieopiniotworczy prezentujacy jedna linie myslenia o Polsce co mozna zobaczyc od razu w pierwszym wydaniu na Kindle. Czekam przynajmniej na polskiego Newsweeka. Plus za cene(mimo okrojenia wydania elektronicznego) poza tym dlugo trzeba czekac na kolejne wydania.

Wielki plus za obecnosc tygodnika na platformie kindle. Cena wydaje sie rozsadna, jednak skasowalem dzis moja subskrpcje. Powodem tej decyzji jest irytujaco niski poziom zawartosci tygodnika. Artykuly maja charakter publikacji PR, a prezentowane tresci sa odbiciem prywatnych pogladów autorow lub ich poboznych zyczen. Ogolnie oceniam nisko poziom dziennikarstwa, co niestety jest charakterystyczne dla polskiej prasy o dowolnej orientacji. Zapoznawanie sie z tego typu wywodami to strata czasu.Polityka

This book contains some useful information, but it gets lost in amateur writing where wordiness, cliches, and punctuation and usage problems abound. As a writer, I quickly became impatient wading through it to find the information I needed. When I finally did reach it, I was disappointed to find the couple of practical how-to points, complete with pictures, shifted to general overviews of what you can do but which provided no "click this, write there" instruction as I expected and wanted. I'm relieved I didn't spend money on this book. It needs an editor. If you're writing for writers, it's important to be polished. That said, there IS some useful information herein, so it deserves a few stars. I understand a little better what Projects are (though not how to implement them) and Binders. I'm not sure I want to keep wrestling with this book to learn what I need, though, so I think I'm going to purchase an alternate guide.
Source (K): Some useful info, but hard to read

Source (H): Scrivener for Writers (Apple Mac) is a very helpful, well-written manual on setting up a proper workflow with the Scrivener application. It can be read in linear form, or as a specific-topic reference guide for those, for example, who just want instruction on use of the Binder.I would give it five stars but for a failing common to how-to manuals: It spends too much of the opening pages of the book extolling the virtues of the subject product. This, I've always felt, is wasted text. I already know about the product for which I'm purchasing a help manual; I know how it's going to affect my life. Usually when a person purchases a help manual, they've already made the decision to purchase and use it; they do not need a sales pitch.
Source (K): A fine how-to, especially for novice users of Scrivener

Source (H): Phew. I love Srivener but sometimes feel that I'm missing out as there are so many features that look useful but ... I have no idea what to do with them. The online video tutorials are hopeless. However this book is really easy to read and cleared up all up all the mystery. I thoroughly recommend it.

As a resident of Las Vegas for over 20 years and as an early adopter of the Kindle I was thrilled to see that our local newspaper was finally coming out in a Kindle edition.Layout/presentation (4 stars):  The Kindle edition contains a "Sections List" which includes the major sections of that issue, i.e., news, business, Nevada, sports, etc. and shows how many articles are in that particular section.  However, it does not list the headlines, etc. for each section so you are forced to click between articles in a section rather than selecting an article directly from the sections list.  The articles themselves are laid out nicely and include clear and crisp photographs, charts, etc.Delivery (2 stars):  I have been a subscriber to the Kindle edition for 8 days now.  Of those 8 days, the paper was on my Kindle by 7 A.M. on 6 days, yesterday it did not arrive until mid-morning, and today as of the time of this posting (approx 9 AM) it had still not arrived.Review-Journal content (2 stars):  I am shocked to see a couple of reviewers here who believe the Review-Journal is a liberal newspaper.  That has not been my expierence at all.  In my opinion, the editors of the RJ are as far right as you can get. As far as reporting general news is concerned, the newspaper is okay (it is basically the only game in town). However, forget about it if you want a well-balanced and insightful editorial.  Almost daily the RJ editorials bash the democratic party no matter the issue.  They consistantly tow the Republican party line in support of big business and big oil.  If you are a conservative Republican, this is your newspaper.
Source (K): Kindle Edition of the Las Vegas Review-Journal

Source (H): I agree with Mac Man 3/28/09:  What do you expect, a paper in a town built and operated by labor unions. It does a fair job of reporting the general news, but if it involves the police or politics, prepare yourself for the extremely liberal point of view.AND I would ADD that it does not offer much to anyone licving ourtside of Nevada EXCEPT that it has a good Sports Section.

I've lived in the Las Vegas Valley for 20 years and do enjoy the local paper, for reasons different than those already listed here.  I like to know what is going on in our fair city and seldom watch the news on TV.  When the paper called me recently, I suggested that they look into having it available to Kindle readers.  I'm very pleased to find that they did just that.  My biggest beef with the local paper is that I don't want to have newsprint delivered to my door because of my working hours, it would appear that no one is home to get the paper which is not true.  I believe in conservation of our natural resources and this seems to be a great way to have the best of all worlds-be able to read the paper AND leave the trees alone!  Many thanks to the staff of the RJ for taking my request seriously!
Source (K): Great read for locals that saves trees!

Source (H): What do you expect, a paper in a town built and operated by labor unions.  It does a fair job of reporting the general news, but if it involves the police or politics, prepare yourself for the extremely liberal point of view.
Source (K): Great paper.....if you subscribe to the liberal point of view.

Source (H): Foodista offers a great foodie blog.  Foodista will tempt you with delicious recipes and amuse you with random food facts.  Did you know for example that November 4th is National Candy Day?  Foodista does.Another reason I like Foodista is that they license their content under a Creative Commons license, which enables others to legally share and remix. You can support open content providers by reading their blog.

I write blog reviews forThe Kindle Blog Report.I enjoyed this blog. Lots of interesting and a wide variety of topics covered. The articles are well written.The only drawback is that some of the posts are no good for the Kindle. A post whose single entry is a video, which of course the Kindle can't see. Weekend posts that are nothing but links to stories, which are so unweildy for Kindle readers to get to... but overall, if you're in to expanding your knowledge on a wide variety of subjects, from members of the Baseball Hall of Fame to biographies of people such as Katherine Graham, you'll find this blog of interest.
Source (K): Fun blog, with a few issues

Source (H): This is an excellent blog, loaded with things to keep you entertained and informed. I got between 7 and 10 articles on each day of the trial. A lot of the articles are about pop culture- famous people, movie stars, rock stars, TV shows, etc. It has humorous articles about funny things that have happened around the world recently. It has quizzes and word games to make you think a little. It has videos which of course you can't watch on your Kindle, so to see them you have to get on a computer and go to Mental Floss's website and search for the article. The only thing I don't like is that only a few of the articles are full, many of the articles give you a paragraph and then you have to click a link and wait for the rest to download over Whispernet.Despite all of this praise I won't be subscribing because I'm just not into pop culture. I prefer jazz and classical to rock and pop, I like the sciences better than movies, and I definitely do not care about celebrities. Take the free trial and don't hesitate to subscribe if you like it, but if you're like me there are other blogs that you'll like better.
Source (K): Very nice, but not for me

Source (H): The recurrent problem:  You cannot read it on your iPad if you network your reading materials amongst your Kindles and that device.  When are we going to be set free by Apple?

I was hoping for a more historical treatise than a collection of proverbs and quotes.  If that's what you're looking for then you may find it to be a great book.  It wasn't what I was looking for and I felt that the title is a bit misleading.  Maybe a better subtitle would have clarified that.

Paper is ready for me in the morning. I like the way it's boiled down to the articles and I don't have to cart papers to the trash.Articles are well organized and the Kindle is great as a reader.Simply amazing. As for the weather it's on the TV, my computer, and out my window.

I got my Kindle 2 the day it came out, and subscribed to the Seattle Times the first day. It has been a little over 2 weeks now of me getting the newspaper digitally. I should note that I do not receive the printed version.I read many of the other reviews that spoke of the paper not being delivered until late in the day. I have not experienced this. I wake up 3 days a week at 5AM, and the remainder of the days at around 6:30 and the paper has been available when I wake up every day so far. Perhaps they have improved since those reviews.As for the content, I do enjoy being able to skip around and enjoy the subscription so far. I feel like I am missing a lot of content though. I knew ahead of time that I wouldn't be getting the entire paper and sections such as classifieds etc. would be omitted. I do wish the comics section was available along with the weather.  For me I am busy enough that reading the paper every day is difficult, so I enjoy the table of contents and being able to read the headlines and read the articles I am interested in. I feel like if I bought the actual printed version that there would be many articles in the printed version that were not available in the digital one, though I have not tried this.Overall I enjoy my subscription and will continue to get it. As I said before, it would be even better with more content but overall I am pleased.

I find it more than appalling that the Kindle charge for a Seattle Times subscription is rising to $9.99 per month and the home delivery is only $5.35/month. What gall! The electronic version saves the paper so much money in printing and truck/car delivery. Not to mention the fact that the electronic paper comes with less e.g. no coupons and less content. Who is making these ridiculous, bassackwards decisions????

UPDATE #2: The weekday Kindle editions of the Seattle Times have been arriving between 5:15-5:30 am (better, but still not as good as the San Franciso Chronicle which is already delivered when I check at 4 am). The Sunday Kindle edition of the Seattle Times is still not being delivered before 7:20 am.UPDATE: Today, for the first time (during the 9 days of my free trial), my Seattle Times Kindle edition had already been delivered when I checked at 5:20 am. I will update again after a few days when I have determined if the new, earlier delivery will be consistent, or not.So far, I am not real pleased with the Kindle edition of the Seattle Times. As with all of the Kindle newspapers, the content is limited and no pictures (although I noticed the San Franciso Chronicle does include a few pictures) The "deal killer" will be if it continues to be delivered late. The print edition of the Seattle Times is required to be delivered to my home by 5:30 am. Mine usually arrives earlier. The online edition is available much earlier. It's 6:00 am and I still haven't received today's Kindle Seattle Times. In contrast, the San Francisco Chronicle and the Wall Street Journal Kindle newspapers were delivered before 5 am.

The Seattle Times Kindle edition needs to show a "weather" page link that is easily found.  Evidently the "Kindle Edition" has no weather details. It was 7:20am plus before the edition arrived on my Kindle, this a problem when drinking coffee before work in the morning.

If the paper is STILL not here by the time I get to work at 11am, there's something wrong with that service.  If Amazon wants to make this a viable option to the hard copy, they need to bring up the delivery speed.
Wish it did have some picture content, but an even bigger problem is that you subscribe to a regional paper and it has no regional information, such as weather and local issue columns.
Usually comes between 7-8am PT.  Too late for a newspaper.  This is a fatal flaw in the Kindle's newspaper service.  Fortunately the NY times is always there before 5am.

Seattle has two major daily papers. The Times is the lesser one. It seems determined to convince liberal Seattleites to be more conservative. That's fine. But they went so far as to endorse George Bush for the presidency. Forget ideology, that's the kind of editorial misjudgment that makes me wonder about their whole enterprise. Hopefully, Kindle will offer the Seattle P-I soon to those wanting news of the NW.

I was looking forward to replacing my print subscription with something that was more convenient to read and didn't generate so much waste paper. In that sense, the Kindle edition of the Seattle Times succeeds. I found the delivery very prompt and you can't beat the convenience of getting the paper in bed on Sunday morning. I found the display on the Kindle sharper than the newsprint and easier on my eyes. It is nice not to have to wrestle with the big floppy sheets of a newspaper. Reading it on the bus would be a pleasure. I like not having to hunt for the continuation of the stories on inside pages.BUT...just too much useful content is missing. Here is a list of content I found in my print edition but not in the Kindle edition:- Maps, charts, statistics boxes. A story on home sales/prices was crippled by not having the charts to illustrate it. A map can be critical to understanding where a news event occurred.- Most of the photos and their captions.- The "Newsline" and "Biz line" columns of shorter articles. As the print edition has shrunk, sometimes important stories can only be found there.- Pacific and Parade magazines.- Sidebars showing where to find follow-up information, ticket information, addresses, etc.- Comics, puzzles.- All sorts of useful sports information, anything that is not an "article": league standings, box scores, batting averages, line scores, the entire page of statistics from various sports.- Sub-headlines and drop-quotes that give you a hint about whether you want to read an article.- Weekly review.- Weather.- Letters to the editor.- Movie show times.- Stock listings, charts, other economic indicators.- List of things open/closed during holiday.- A handful of miscellaneous missing local news stories.- Advertisements. In a local paper, ads can be an important source of information about new businesses and products, sales, movies and other arts performances, new property developments, etc.All-in-all, I can't imagine subscribing to the current Kindle edition if I have the option of the printed edition.
Source (K): Too much missing to replace print edition

Source (H): Shakespeare was a real cool person for his time. Unfortunately, his plays are not a real cool thing to read for my time. It is  English and I speak English. I just don't happen to speak Old English. Which is really ironic because I am old and speaking English. If you read slowly and put your thinking cap on, you will get the gist of what the story is about. Or! You can just purchase Cliff notes, etc. This story is exciting and full of action...........I Think?
Source (K): Me doth not thinkift I understandifth this tale

Source (H): I'm a long-time knitter and have subscribed to Interweave Knits for years but thought I would try this. I've tried other magazine apps and was disappointed but this one works beautifully.PROS* It is the complete magazine and includes the ads (very important in a specialty magazine)* Price - it is actually less than a print copy and takes less shelf space too!* Color and graphics - excellent. The yarn colors are just as tempting.* View options ---- PAGE view which is just like looking at the magazine. You see 2 pages when in landscape mode. You can pinch to zoom or double tap to go up/down a magnification level. Tap the middle of the screen to see thumbnails and a scroll bar at the bottom with the magazine pages numbered. You can even see which pages face each other. Long press to select a URL and then you can choose Search, Wikipedia or Web and then choose between Browser or Google (but it defaults to Google even when you use the Browser option).--- TEXT view makes the print look more like a book and you lose the ads. Pinch to zoom is not available unless you look at it as a photo graphic. However you can change the text size using the standard Aa Kindle option.CONS* The PAGE view does have some limitation on how much or little you can magnify.* The TEXT view has a scrolling table of contents without page indicators. It also moves more slowly between pages.* May take a little practice to control the scrolling speed (it is VERY responsive)* Only available on Kindle Fire and Kindle for iPad  (please offer an Android option)SUGGESTIONS* I would love to see a bookmark feature* Kindle viewing options for Android and Kindle PC please!* While I am wishing it would be wonderful if one could Send to Kindle a pattern page(s) so one could focus on a single knit projectNOTE: I am still looking for the file size and wonder how it will save/update future magazine issues.
Very useful to have these rapid and car charger. My kindle seems to drain battery very quickly even when not in use. I am glad to have these chargers that I could take with me.
Why can't a Kindle be made with a built in light so people can read in bed when their significant others are sleeping.ThanksKelly

I bought this for the car charger. Nice that there is also a wall charger. Somewhat redundant that there are 2 cords since they are detachable from the charger itself. One cord would suffice since it could easily be plugged into either. The wall charger does the job but it is considerably more bulky than the Amazon charger.

I purchased the Kindle 2 within a week of its release.  I carry it everywhere.  The first thing I am concerned with when purchasing any portable electronic tool is having a back up charger - preferably for both home and vehicle.  Initially, I went for theiGo Everywhere PS00252-0003 Universal Wall (AC) and Auto (DC) Charger with Retractable Cable (Charger Only, Tips Not Included)which was recommended when I purchased my Kindle 2.  However, when it arrived, I tried to purchase a tip for the Kindle 2 and there was none to be found (Kindle 1 yes!) - even the vendor didn't have one available.  One of the things that drew me to it was the shared cable.  I would only have to carry one tip (wall or car) and share a cable.  I returned the iGo - didn't satisfy my needs.  Then I purchased the Gomadic Corp. Essential Kit.When it arrived, I was PLEASANTLY surprised to see that it used detachable USB cables for each charger - vehicle and wall.  WOW! I can carry either tip (vehicle/wall) and one detachable USB cable to plug into each.  These detachable cables also let me connect my Kindle 2 to my PC for file transfers (like the original USB cable/charger that came with my Kindle 2).I now have two extra USB cables, so I can keep one at home as a back-up.  I am already using the plugs (vehicle/wall) and USB cable (separately) instead of the cable that came with my Kindle 2.  Talk about multi-use ... this product is great.  Best of all, I do a lot of traveling overseas and this lets me use one product for all my traveling.The fact that it auto-switches for foreign voltage (240) and the built in circuitry for surge protection and over charging ... makes this product a must have for anyone who does a lot of travel.One final point - since I needed both a wall and vehicle charger, this product offers both for twice the price of theAmazon Kindle 2 Replacement Power Adapter.  But it gives me - TWO detachable USB cables and a way to charge my Kindle 2 in the car.
Source (K): Essential - YES - a pleasure to use and has a surprise.

Source (H): Comes with two black USB to mini USB cables, a USB to 12vDC (cigarette lighter) adapter, and a USB to 120vAC (US house) adapter. Works as advertised, with one big and important exception. If you're tempted to buy this because it advertises that it has "Rapid Charge Technology," skip it. How fast the Kindle charges is limited by the power control chip inside, not by what comes through the cable. Having tried it on two consecutive days, this charger takes the same amount of time to charge my Kindle DX from empty that Amazon's included charger does. Buy this if you want both a spare charger and a car charger at a discount price. Buy the stand-alone car charger without this if you just need the car charger. Don't buy this if what you wanted was a faster way to recharge your Kindle.

This is my first foray into this new serial venue and if this is the level of storytelling I can expect, I am all in. The Betrayer starts with an engaging cast of characters - damaged and haunted and determined, each in their own fashion. The characters are distinct and believable. My worry when I began was that I wouldn't be able to follow a series (I have the attention span of a fruit fly) but I can't imagine losing this thread. The writing is first-rate and I'm excited about this new form (or resurgence of a classic form) of storytelling.Now I'm going to check out other serials.

I definitiely would recommend you to subscribe to this blog for the trial period. This way, you can see for yourself what I really mean. It is more like a political/heavily religious platform for its authors. I have included some of the entry titles below. You decide. (By the way, if you decide to vote for this review as "Unhelpful", please explain your reasoning as a comment attached to my review, or as another review, otherwise, everyone will assume you are one of the authors of the blog!)Holocaust ChildrenAn Interview with Brian Switek (He is a college student, and a "serious blogger"!)Santa Nailed to a CrossKitchen Science: Magic MilkCounseling a racist before letting him in the country?Birds in the News (I think this is one of the few posts that can claim to have any scientific content)

The other reviews of the Miami Herald Kindle edition have been too generous.  I agree that the multiple, duplicated stories from various Herald editions are annoying.  The only good feature is that the Kindle edition actually has more local news than the print edition, by combining Broward and Miami-Dade editions along with Neighbors.  Skimming articles is easier than with print editions.  The biggest downside is that the articles are not well organized.  There is no rhyme or reason of why an article pops up in the lead spot in each Kindle section, clearly not the most important article or one that would even warrant coverage on the print edition's front pages.  The articles appear to be randomly loaded.  The Kindle edition should have a list of headlines for each section (sort of like a front page# so the reader can pick and chose the articles he/she wants, and the ability to skim the others.  Use of graphics used in the print edition articles would be helpful, along with more photos.  The Miami Herald Kindle edition has set newspapers back several decades.  Herald editors should take a look at their own electronic edition, website, and most importantly some of the other Kindle editions #such as the NY Times) to get some pointers.  The price is way too high for such a low-quality product, and existing Herald print subscribers should be given a price break.  My print subscription actually costs less than the Kindle edition's cost.  I will be cancelling my Kindle subscription and will not return until it is markedly better.

i am disappointed with the layout and the choices of articles chosen.  todays addition has 29 sports articles one national article.  i also agree that people should be included.  i was excited to have the herald on the kindle but i do not plan on keeping the subscription.  i stick with the paper.

I really wanted to like the Kindle version of the Miami Herald, but I just cancelled my subscription and do not wish to pay for this Kindle newspaper.My biggest gripe would have to be the duplication of articles. In any given Kindle edition, there are 2 or 3 duplicated articles, sometimes all under one section, sometimes spread out over several sections. I get done reading an article, hit next page, and am confronted with the same article under a different title causing me to question whether or not I actually hit next page.  Ex: In today's newspaper, January 11, 2010, there is two articles in the Local section: "Miami-Dade plans to fight state's rejection of slots at MIA" and "Slot machines at Miami airport aren't dead yet." While reading the headline gives you a false sense of different articles, they are the same.  I am not sure how the paper edition of the Miami Herald compares, but I find it to be a big waste of my time as the reader to read the same article over and over again.The Miami Herald is the biggest newspaper available for the Florida keys, and the city of Miami itself is a decent size, yet the Kindle edition newspaper gives on average just 30 articles to cover local, state, and world. The sports section is the biggest section on the kindle boasting an average of 50 articles between Sports Wire and Sports.  I want my newspaper to tell me news, not sports; that is what ESPN is for! A quick highlight of the sports coverage is more than sufficient.The weekend addition of the newspaper is better with special sections like Travel, Neighbors, Editorial, and Home an Design, but still lacking in content. I really wish they would incorporate at least some classified ads (on the weekends only) or some comics. I agree with the other reviewer that the local legend Dave Barry is missing, which is a real shame.The business section, when it is available, is sorely lacking with usually less than 5 articles. The Tropical Life section should really be called Arts and Entertainment.Overall, this kindle paper is sorely underused. After reading it daily for over a week, I became bored with the articles, nothing newsworthy in them. I won't be wasting my money on this subscription unless they come out with a weekend only subscription to catch me up on the weekly happenings.
Getting it on the Kindle is an outstanding way to keep up with what is in it.
Source (K): American Scholar is a terrific journal

Source (H): I've been hoping this wonderful journal would be offered on Kindle--at last it's here.  Wonderful writing on a myriad of subjects, almost all of which you will find interesting.  I have held onto many of my hard-copies because they are worth keepimg.

This is one of the most aptly titled magazines I have ever seen - its target audience, quite simply, is those who want to become more educated, in a broad sense. I have had my subscription for about a year now, and have been recommending it to many people I know.Not every article catches my interest, and not every article blows me away, but in each issue have been two or three things that, between them, are worth the entire subscription price, plus plenty of others I enjoy. The articles and stories are written by experts, and target an audience of individuals who are well-educated, but not necessarily in the field of the author. The end result is a set of articles which are erudite and informative informative while also being thoroughly engaging, all without being condescending to the reader.This is not a magazine to be flipped through quickly, nor is it a magazine to be read from cover to cover in a single sitting, unless your tolerance for brain-stretching study is truly spectacular. It's not a short publication; every issue has a large amount of material in it. I find I enjoy the magazine best one article at a time, reading each issue slowly over about a month. I then eagerly wait two more months for the next issue.

I had never heard of The American Scholar before it landed in the Kindle store, but I'm glad it did. For fans of long-form journalism, this is an absolute must. While not always straight-up news or analysis of current events, it proves to be relevant to current issues. Far from being boring are dry, most of the articles and stories are quite interesting, so you walk away feeling enlightened and like you actually learned something. Because it comes out quarterly, it gives you plenty of time to read and absorb the articles. I recommend it for fans of the Kindle versions of the Economist and Foreign Affairs.
As soon as I downloaded this magazine my kindle went slowerer and slowerer. Not to mention,it has a horrible topic. Also I think they read this book in hell

I tried an issue of this magazine. An excellent quarterly journal if one is interested in the subject matter. The title is "MHQ; The Military History Quarterly, regarding the issue I am reviewing the title should be "AMHQ: The American Military History Quarterly." Overwhelmingly American. Nothing wrong with that if you are purely interested in American military history, I was expecting a journal much more world wide.The four star rating is for the American content and the fact that on occasion it does include a small article containing content outside the United States.

Source (H): Am I locked into this subscription forever? I have been trying to figure out how to cancel for 2 months. every time I think it is canceled it shows up again the next month! You better be sure you want it before you sign up.
Source (K): How do I cancel my subscription?

Source (H): I just received my first issue dated April 1st, 2009. I was very interested in the cover article on "The 10 Emerging Technologies of 2009". But where is it? There is only the opening introduction and then nothing - not one of those top 10 technologies. After a couple days of searching the mag on the Kindle thinking "it must be here", I gave up. Upon going to the website for Technology Review, there it is again, but fully available. All 10 technologies with individual articles on each. I am not paying for a subscription to get a teaser to bring me to their website. I saw other articles in this months issue that were not available also, such "Electric Avenue" and "How Lasers Can Heal Surgeons' Incisions". I did see references to these articles in the "From the Editor" and "Contributors" sections.This is not acceptable to me. I am paying for a product, the full magazine in this case and not teasers to get me to come to their website.
ive read tech rev via paper a long timethis kindle version is better for travelthe content isalways top notch...especially the articles on the impications of technology
I enjoy the discussions on new technologies, but not the baseless politicized misrepresentations of science.
I liked reading the articles, but found it difficult to follow the red, blue, and purple lines in the monochrome diagrams.  This would be excellent in a color system.
Source (K): Good, but needs an improved display

Source (H): I drive quite a bit and so I use the text to voice option in order to keep up on my "reading". Granted, when the rare occasion presents itself, I prefer to actually read. But, like most, I'm very busy. This is one of the main reasons I purchased the Kindle and I'm so glad I did. While it isn't perfect, it is good enough that I get what I need.That having been said; I know this isn't a review of text to voice, but it plays into my review of the Kindle version of Technology Review. The magazine itself is very good, but not great. The articles are well written and informative. Often I find them to be a little to light on detail, however. I prefer for them to delve into a subject more, rather than provide what feels more like a briefing or synopsis. The editing does leave a little to be desired due to the random hyphen that causes the speech to mispronounce words in the most peculiar ways. It would seem that using a simple spell-check program when authoring the thing would only add a couple minutes to the editing process. If I were reading most anything else this might be easier to overlook. But, this is called Technology Review and is from MIT. Maybe not the best foot forward.That having been said, I'll definetly be keeping my subscription. I'll just hope they put a little more review in future issues.

Overall, despite my gripes, I think this is an enjoyable magazine IF you are not looking for a magazine that provides deep technical overview of the future technologies.Most technology articles are 300 words or less and they seem to be geared towards the non-techies. At best, each technology article provide a very shallow overview of the foreseeable technology changes. Moreover, each issue is very short in content. I have counted 30 short articles (most of them fewer than 300 words) on each issue.The magazine is published once every two months. Effectively, you are paying $2.50 per issue (as of 5/27/09) when you purchase the Kindle version.I have, however, enjoyed reading this magazine as I usually do reading Popular Mechanics and[...] I think this magazine is worthwhile for its target (non-techie) audience.

I live very close to MIT, so I've had a good deal of exposure to the print version of this magazine, and I enjoy it. That said, I was hoping to like the kindle version, since I commute to work on public transit and would prefer to be able to read this on my kindle. The words were all there, and that worked fine for some articles, but others kind of lacked a soul without being in a magazine surrounded by graphics, pictures, and richer formatting. For example, the "from the labs" section felt like a chore to read on Kindle, due to the bland, often hard to follow, formatting.Despite all that, it's still got a good amount of very interesting material and it isn't too long-winded or full of jargon. The price is small enough to barely be noticed too - though that kind of thinking can lead to a lot of small things adding up very quickly. If you want to read this magazine and can live without the convenience of kindle for it, I suggest the print version.
Can somebody please explain by this costs $1.25 for a bi-weekly subscription and $2.99 for one issue?

I've received two issues of this magazine so far and it's been good for the price.  The content is varied and significantly more detailed when compared to similar magazines along the lines of Popular Science and Popular Mechanics.  The formatting, however, needs serious work as some articles can be difficult to read.Examples of this are:- Stray hyphens from the original magazine formatting (i.e., "tech-nology" on a single line and -significant -amounts -of -words -with -hyphens -in -front -of -them, even if they're in the middle of a line)- Lines of text that reference non-existent pictures or graphics (should either be removed or reworded in proofreading if it's not possible to include the graphic)- And finally, the strangest out of all of them, there's one word per issue that will always have an umlaut over one of it's vowels.  This occurs on every incidence of that single word throughout the magazine.Additionally, when graphics are included (usually graphs and charts) they're useless.  Not because they're monochrome interpretations of a color image---no, there's a bigger problem that comes before that.  The issue is that the images are merely thumbnails...even if you click on them to make the image full screen.  Either way you have a useless image.  The thumbnails are too small, and the expanded image is a mass of indistinct pixels through which you can scry only a blurry line (or bar) graph, or pie chart.Back on the positive side, unlike the other magazines available for the Kindle, this magazine is more dependent on text than pictures. Therefore, any pictures typically are not an integral part of the article.  Plus, it's cheap.  (although, if I was picky, I'd say it should be cheaper since it's bi-monthly---Newsweek is only 24 cents more per month, and that's a weekly magazine)I'll be keeping the subscription.  The content is still very readable despite its flaws, and it makes for great reading when you've finished the daily newspaper but don't have enough time to read a chapter of a novel.

Political Wire has quick updates of political news during weekdays; however, this liberal site is basically a group therapy session for "progressives".  News posted often comes with flaws and biases in order to serve the site's liberal readers.
Source (K): Political News with Many Flaws and Biases

Source (H): I have always been intrigued by the whole hierarchy of angels, and what each choir does. Since the Seraphim is the highest order of angels, this book caught my eye. It was a great read, and even as old as I am, I got caught up in the story and kept referring to the map that was provided. Am I a geek cause I would like to know what a Ulrog looks like? I'm ok with that cause the author worked hard to bring all the characters to life, where you actually wonder how they look when they move around the forests and villages. I really got caught up in the journey, and I enjoyed this book very much. My three dollars bought a nice diversion. I will look out for part 2!

I don't know how this book received so many five star ratings!!  The flow of the story is very choppy and slow - almost painful reading.  The story has so much potential but it is continually thwarted by the poor writing style.  It is hard to describe why I didn't like reading the book but I will try:1. It goes way overboard on the theology of the world in question.2. The author continues to draw out certain traits in the characters that don't make sense or ring true (I just shot blue magic energy out of my hands but I still think I'm just a normal kid).  Any normal kid would have been asking all kinds of questions of the only other guy who could do the same thing.  There are multiple other character problems . . . .3. The scope of the geography is almost infantile.  It takes a HALF a DAY for the main character to WALK to an isolated and supposedly distant elven empire.  To make the journey seem more like an adventure than walking 7 miles normally would, they have to go through a "big" forest (which, incidentally, you can't see from the village).4. The forces of evil are searching for the new seraphim but the main group travels for days (3?) before encountering any real resistance.  There is only one real battle scene in the whole book!  (there is one other "fight" scene where mostly magic is used.)I don't think I've done justice to the reasons this book is such a poor read.  I can't recommend this book except to say, "This is really bad - here, try it."

If you like David Eddings and Terry Brooks, then this is the book for you.  Like Eddings, McHugh loves to play around with old philosophical and religious ideas, dressing them up in new clothes for a night on the town in the 21st century. Like Brooks, McHugh is enchanted by the same tropes all fantasy lovers are enchanted by: elves, a young hero shepherded by a mysterious but wizard-like guide, and big battles with swords and magic. But McHugh is no Tolkien-lite. He has provided his readers with some fresh creations that fill the imagination with vivid pictures and scenes, reminding the reader why fantasy is such a beloved genre. Well worth the $3.
Source (K): The Old and the New in the Next Great Fantasy Series

I loved this book. The main characters are relateable, intriguing and complex, many layers to them and their personalities. I loved the story line, the romance, and the pace of the book. Katie Klein does a great job of not giving useless fillers to the book. Nothing is more annoying to me then authors describing the green grass for two paragraphs just trying to fill the book. The information you need is there and she delivers it in way that leaves you not wanting the book to end! Yet, I couldn't put it down and successfully read the book in a day and immediately came back here to Amazon to download the second book in this trilogy, Vendetta. After successfully reading that book in a day I am eager for book 3 in the series. I wish Katie Klein had more books for us to read!

I get both Running times and Running world and I enjoy both, but I do think Running times is a bit more "serious" about running with articles about running personalities, stats, history of running, articles on how to avoid Lyme disease in trails, sports tape, things like that. I feel part of the group when I read this magazine, and it unintentionally makes me laugh really loud with endearing quotes like the one by Pat Rizzo on this last issue: "If you want to run 6:30 mile pace at the Boston marathon, don't let the first downhill miles- or worse yet, the screaming, kissing women of Wellesley college- propel you to all of a sudden start running 5:30 pace."Get it if you love running, you don't need to be a great runner, not even a good runner... you just need to care :)

I've been checking periodically to see if the Freep was available on the Kindle and noticed yesterday that it is.  If there was a big announcement about it being available, I missed it.  Anyway, I read today's paper entirely on the Kindle and find I prefer it to the e-edition.  There was something about having to click on the article and then only seeing that article in the e-edition that caused me to skip over a lot of things I would have at least skimmed in the paper edition.  And I was going days without reading it because I simply forgot about it.  It was disconcerting to so quickly lose the 30+ year habit of reading the paper each morning.  This morning I just grabbed the Kindle from my bedside table, clicked it on and read the paper without leaving my bed.  There were no pictures or graphs but I didn't really miss them.  In other papers I've read on the Kindle there have been pictures so perhaps that's still coming.The only problem - no comics.  I hope that's remedied because it was one of my favorite parts of the paper.

I have a difficult time understanding what people expect from a Kindle newspaper. Do you get the graphics and photos? No, because you're viewing it on a e-book reader. Do you always get EVERY story in the online paper? Probably not, but really, who cares? What I'm looking for is a quick and convenient way to read the newspaper on my Kindle. With the Detroit Free Press edition, I get that. I can read it in probably 30-45 minutes. Perfect.

As a new Kindle DX owner and a former Michigan resident, I looked forward to subscribing to the Free Press on the Kindle.  I cancelled my subscription yesterday.  Why?  Too many reasons, but basically (1) paid Kindle edition is not as good as free web site version, (2) no pictures, (3) no comics, (4) no classifieds, (5) no sports scores, (6) believe it or not, no ads - I want to know what's on sale in the Detroit area when I am up there, (6) poor indexing of articles, (7) related groups of articles are often placed out of order, making it confusing to follow, (8) when there is a multi-item article, like news briefs from Oakland County, the items are all run together without spacing or font changes, so they are very hard to separate, and there is no indexing of such items either, (9) no weather reports, no local road construction or other local info, (10) no reader article feedback like on the web site, (11) no columnist sections, and (12) the Kindle edition is issued only once a day, instead of being re-sent more frequently during the day with updates and breaking news like the web site has.So, what does the Kindle edition offer that the web doesn't?  Outside of being downloaded on my Kindle each morning, which starts up faster than a PC, the Kindle version has no advantage at all.  And since I have to pay for it, the disadvantages totally outweigh the free web version, which of course not only has pictures, but has them in color, and even occasionally has animated editorial cartoons.  What makes it worse is that there is no mechanism whatsoever to relay feedback or problems in the Kindle edition to the Free Press editorial staff, and if you go to the Free Press web site, you can't find any evidence that they support (or even know about!) the Kindle edition of their paper.Unless you are a total diehard Freep fan, I wouldn't recommend getting this.  Kindle is good for books.  Newspapers?  Not so much.
Source (K): Disappointing Kindle Free Press not as good as web version

Source (H): I have been reading this blog for quite some time and have found lots of great links to FREE e-books!  It is a wonderful sight for info on books that might interest you -  lots of free, some low cost!Great blog - now I will get it straight to my Kindle!

Updated promptly, this blog offers e-bargains for Kindle, Nook, Sony--wherever the bargains are on any given day.  There are occasional reviews, opinions and commentary, but the main thing is bargains.  Weekends there is often a post about game deals, audio and music.  Good, reliable blog.

First Things is great. Most of the articles each month begin with a view of the world founded on truth as a reality accessible by the human mind, something that no other popular magazine provides.Kindle First Things is wonderful, when it arrives. I love using Text-to-Speech while eating breakfast - much easier than flipping through a magazine.The problem is that the delivery is later than the paper edition, something strange in the internet age. I do not expect an email to take longer than the U.S. Post, but the Kindle edition arrives well after the print edition. Even the free articles are on the website now, and I still do not have the new edition.Also, I am glad to support First Things, but the price inconsistencies are strange. First Things paper edition is $39 a year directly from the publisher, $20 from Amazon, and the Kindle edition is $24. How the paper edition can be less than the Kindle edition between postage and printing, I do not know. That it is half the price when Amazon sells it than getting it directly is also odd.Also, while paying more, I do not get the benefit of the website subscription that print subscribers get for free.When the Kindle edition is finally delivered, I will probably read it cover to cover in a couple days, and I would be loathe to give up text-to-speech, but I am tempted to pay less, have a website subscription, and get earlier delivery by subscribing to the paper edition.
Source (K): Glad to Have it on the Kindle, but late delivery is bad

Source (H): Religion, to me, is not a word that is synonmous with Christianity. It seems with this work that is the case. The articles seem well researched and are undoubtedbly well written and range widely in topics. An enjoyable read but everyone is based in Christianity and Christian views.Which, again, is fine except that the magazine is billed as, 'America's premier journal of religion and public life. It begins with the premise that to understand American society--and where it is headed--it is necessary to understand its religious life and values. FIRST THINGS' broad coverage of religious and cultural issues encompasses politics, economics, ethics, education, science, and literature and the arts. Though concerned with issues of great seriousness, FIRST THINGS is lively, readable, and entertaining."Replace religion with Christianity (to be fair it seems to embrace both protestantism and catholicism) and you'd be closer to reality.
Source (K): Well written but not a religious periodical, rather a Christian one

Source (H): **** About First Things Kindle Edition ****The arrival of the Kindle edition of "First Things" is a bit of a dream come true for me. I am a longtime "First Things" reader and one of the early Kindle enthusiasts. Ever since I got my first Kindle I thought that "First Things" would make an excellent candidate for a periodical that is formatted for this device. "First Things" is foremost a journal of ideas, and the vast majority of its content is textual, thus being ideally suited for a small format of e-ink reading devices. Now that I've had the chance to read First Things on my Kindle I can safely say that my expectations have been largely met.The content of the Kindle edition more or less follows that of the print edition. One big exception is the poems: in Kindle version they are all collected in one single section instead of being placed throughout the magazine. Due to their often unorthodox meters or break structure, many of the poems don't look too good on Kindle.Reading of the articles on Kindle is a pleasure. Having the text presented on a six inch screen makes it seem much more manageable and legible in my opinion. Kindle also allows you to share your notes and highlights with others, including posting them on Facebook and Twitter. This is one of my favorite Kindle features in general, and I expect to post a generous amount of "First Things" content in the future.One of the best things about the Kindle edition, and one of its strongest selling points, is the price. The subscription comes to just $2 a month, which translates into $2.40 per issue over the course of the year. Single issues can be purchased for $4. All of these prices compare very favorably with the regular subscription of $40 a year. On the other hand, the print subscription to First Things on Amazon is just $20.Unfortunately, there are a few shortcomings of the Kindle edition. If you are subscribed to the print edition there is no way of either accessing the Kindle issues or converting to the Kindle-only subscription. You will have to cancel your print subscription and re-sign with the Kindle subscription again. Another big drawback of the Kindle subscription is that it doesn't let you access the exclusive First Things online content, including the past issues. This is not exclusively a problem with "First Things", but affects all Kindle periodicals. If you only access online content and past issues occasionally, then this may not be a major hindrance. Overall however, I am very happy with the Kindle version of "First Things" and will stick with it despite the few deficiencies.**** About First Things in General ****The journal "First Things" fills an important niche in the intellectual landscape of the ever-changing marketplace of ideas. It is, as its description states "the journal of religion, culture, and public life." In my humble opinion the definite article in the description is well deserved since "First Things" has positioned itself as the definitive journal on those three subjects and especially on their intersection and interplay. The ordering of the importance of those three subjects in the journal's description also reflects more or less accurately how prominently they are covered in the pages of the "First Things." The journal has gained considerable reputation for its unapologetic stance on the role of religion in public life, especially when it comes to politics. This is one of the thorniest issues that are often misunderstood: religion, just like any other ethical system, can and should inform those decisions that are relevant for the common good.The longtime editor-in-chief and the founder of the magazine was late great Father Richard John Neuhaus. He was a public intellectual par excellence and someone whose opinion and knowledge I admire a great deal. Each issue of "First Things" has several lengthy in-depth articles, a few shorter opinion pieces, book reviews, correspondence and poems. Over the years contributors to the "First Things" have included Joseph Ratzinger (now Pope Benedict XVI), Avery Cardinal Dulles, Christoph Schönborn, George Weigel, Stephen Webb, R. R. Reno, Timothy George, Stephen Barr, Joseph Bottum, Michael Novak, and many, many others.All past issues of "First Things" (older than two months) can be found on the journal's website and I would strongly urge anyone who is interested in finding out more about this wonderful publication to visit the website. In addition, the website features a daily blog article that cannot be found in the journal itself.
Source (K): Great Version of a Great Magazine, but not Without Few Flaws

Source (H): I have not gone to the end of this magazine  because I am saving it for when I am out-- waiting in the car, at an airport, or even lazing in the backyard hammock.The magazine has colorful, bright, inspiring images of cozy homes and yards.  The homes reflect how only usually builds their home...not buying things that match all at once, but furnishings that show a lifetime of collecting, inheriting, saving, etc.In addition to homes, there are also features on gardening, cooking, artists, and crafting!I can hardly wait to be stuck waiting for a kid to come out from school/practice/etc so I can further peruse this beautiful magazine!
Mr.  Will has a great writing still that really sucks you into the article.  I also learn so many new words from Mr. Will's articles which has help expand my own vocabulary.

I tried, I really tried to keep going to MM's site but after a few month's I can't take it anymore. At first, I really loved it because she was spunky, to the point, didn't mix words and was funny. After a while, though, it seems your eyes are opened to some painful facts. While I understand her trying to make money off her site and having sponsors but I find the line upon line upon line of ads distracting and annoying. Especially when you can't even FIND the articles or relevant information unless you keep scrolling and scrolling thru tons of ads to get to them way on the right border of her site, toward the bottom of the page. And 9 times out of ten, they are AD links not articles! Who wants to keep worrying every time they click what they think is an article is another flipping ad!The attitude I took for no nonsense and spunk, I soon realized seemed to be just plain bitterness. During one of her many web page changes, she lamented about gaining weight and that if she had the choice, she wouldn't have had the surgery and she regretted it. What?? That is what the site is supposed to be about, right? How did she think that other people who came to look at her site for support took that? She described the food she was eating and I was appalled that she was surprised as to why she gained weight! How many of us after bypass eat Godiva chocolates and doughnuts from the local bakery or can eat it? Most of us would be puking our guts out from all the sugar! At first, I thought maybe she was joking but it was for real! My friend actually phoned me to go look at the site because she was just as disappointed that this was the kind of stuff that was posted. She hadn't had the surgery yet and went there on the advice of someone else and after she saw it, she wondered if this was gonna be how she would be a few years after surgery or maybe it doesn't really work. Her husband's blog (who also had a bypass) was linked to her page and when you clicked over to his page he complained about the same thing of gaining weight and that at least he cut down from a dozen doughnuts to 4 but didn't understand why his weight loss was not budging! What is wrong with these people???I really, really don't know why anyone would subscribe to this on Kindle when you can go online to it for free or to go there at ALL; but to each his/her own. If you expect support, a forum, or any articles that are to help you with Gastric bypass/weight loss surgery, this is NOT IT. What's realistic about a sarcastic, bitter woman, who STILL can't/won't control her eating and blames it on her bypass being a failure? I would never recommend this site to ANYONE (unless you are an advertiser)and will never go there again.
Source (K): If you want support, you won't get it here

Source (H): Tal Brooke has an astounding capacity for social and cultural analysis. His brilliant weaving of the progress of thought through history and their resultant effects on society are worth the price of the book. From philosophy through psychology and into politics, education and spiritualism, his insights are well researched and told with narrative vivacity. Very helpful for anyone who wants a big picture understanding of why we are the way we are now as a society. I love his colorful analogies throughout like when he debunks modern man's attempt at removing God from his seat of dominion in philosophy and replacing him with ourselves as the center. He likens this to standing next to a life-sized cardboard cutout photo of a celebrity and taking a picture and presto! We think we are now in the picture with that celebrity, while really we are fools to think so. Anyway, while I don't share Tal's end time millenialism with a future "Antichrist," I still consider his warnings very pertinent to the danger of worldwide tyranny and despotism. Future Antichrist or not, man has a drive toward tyranny in all his culture and beliefs.
Source (K): The Tyranny of Man's Philosophy unveiled

Source (H): Aside from its infrequent sardonic passages, this book is a masterpiece.Today's gospel of multiculturalism contains a moral calculus that denies not only the difference between good and evil, but goes even further by denying good and evil outright. Instead, an elitist professorate allied with a cadre of new age prophets proclaim there are no facts beyond political perspective and no reality beyond the constructs of language.  We are told that tolerance, not truth, must reign supreme. Yet it is precisely the purveyors of the religion of tolerance that are incapable of tolerating anything other than their utopian vision.  And on that utopian vision all possessing sanity must be horrified. A common theme of all utopian thinking is to view at least one segment of humanity possessing derivative value (Pol Pot, Adolf Hitler, Joseph Stalin, and Barbara Marx Hubbard, to name just a few). We must embrace the simple fact of history that Hitler and Stalin killed more people off the battlefield than all of the battles of World War II combined. With enough faith, however maligned, people can be led to believe, and perpetrate, anything. Thus enter new age prophet and self-appointed sage Brian Swimme, who perhaps best exemplifies new age doctrine when he wrote: "The well-being of the Earth is primary. Human well-being is derivative." Chilling words indeed.  In this case, the phrase Thousand Year Reich is replaced with the phrase Well Being of The Earth. So the stage is set: environmentalism becomes a handy epistemology for eliminating from the planet all who continue to prevent the Great Harmonic Convergence. All that the Hubbard's and the Swimme's of the world require now is power. And make no mistake, as Tal Brooke convincingly argues, how their ilk would proceed with power in hand.

After reading several reviews of Tal Brooke's classic One World, I concluded that those who gave Mr. Brooke a one or two-star rating undoubtedly don't possess the mental capacities to comprehend what he wrote.It appears that a high degree of spirituality, plus a higher than normal I. Q. are prerequisites for understanding Tal Brooke's several publications. I would that our failing culture could recover some of its qualities of yesteryear.Dr. Gordon

Source (H): Although Tal Brooke is doubtless a good writer, there is in his updated book more of the same John Birch Society, extreme Right Wing rants about the Illuminati, Council on Foreign Relations, and so on.  In the 1990's, there was an outpouring of Christian prophecy books that gleefully used antisemtic and conspiratorial writings as authoritative works.  Some of these same works were even used by Nazis decades ago to justify their policies.  Does the author believe, for instance, that there is a Jewish world banking conspiracy?While the author may not have intended to do so, his writings also provide ammunition for the Christian Reconstructionists and/or the Dominionists who claim that only Christians should have a say in American government.  These are the people who would claim that there is no such thing as separation of church and state, that America was founded as a "Christian Nation" and that because the majority of early Americans were Christian, that the nation itself was founded to reflect that.  This, despite the fact that God, Jesus Christ, the Holy Spirit are not even mentioned in the Constitution.  These folks want to take America back to the time of the New England Puritans or John Calvin's Geneva debacle.  Is this, then, what the author wants to bring to America?  Is the struggle against the "Invisable Hand" and evil spiritual forces meant to bring about a "Christian America"?Brooke's best work--and it is noteworthy--has been in opposition to the various and sundry cults that have afflicted America and the world.  Sadly, he seems now to have (re)entered a cult himself, one that has him looking over his shoulder for the dread Illuminati, gazing at the sky for Black Helicoopters, and wondering which spirits inhabit the space under the world's collective beds.Conspiracy theory has done little other than encourage antisemitism, fear, bigotry, and hate for groups outside of the conspiracy believer's circle.  It is exclusivistic, narrow-minded, and not at all helpful in the effort to find common ground with the rest of the world.  In that sense, it is like Christian Reconstructionism.  Gary North and Rushdooney would understand Brooke's approach, even if they would have opposed his end-times views.
